title: Monster Train
review: Excellent game, the best deck builder I'v played personally. Great art, fun and vibrant, with a massive amount of replay value. Totally worth it's price. However... Balance is a bit of a joke right now. Some clans are just objectively better than others. Umbra especially are kind of mediocre right now. Sometimes you'll get a boss variant that hard counters your build and all you can do is throw your hands up because your run is over before the fight even starts. The final boss in particular can just get really silly unfair variants, but a couple others have variants custom designed to ruin certain builds. So most of your runs once you get above covenant 0 will end because the starts didn't quite align for you to get a god tier build... so be prepared to restart A LOT by no fault of your own. But at the same time, lots of times you'll get a disgustingly overpowered, unstoppable set up. As I said, balance is a joke, very swingy and silly. That said, amazing game on a whole, still an absolute blast, and despite the frustrations of the balance you likely will find yourself wanting to try again and again. If you can accept that RNG is king here, you will get loads of playtime out of this game!

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is an addictive roguelite deckbuilder at it's best. It's easily my favourite in the genre.

You can chose one of five Champions. Then you get to decide a second race. Each combination plays different. In the latest update they even added variations to champions. A run can take up to an hour. 
Whats different in Monster Train compared to other games in the genre?
The battles are within a train. Each train has 4 floors whereas the fourth is your hearth. This means, if enemies reach the fourth floor they will directly attack you and you lose HP. If you reach zero, the game is over. Your hearth has an attack each turn. So there is still a chance to win, even if an enemie reaches your final floor. 
But lets start at the beginning. Each turn you can play cards. You can place monsters on each floor. Enemies start out at the first floor. If you end the turn the battle starts. If your monsters die, they are gone for that battle (but not removed from your deck). Spells and other cards are not removed from the battle (Except when the discription says so). After a turn all enemies move one floor up if they have HP left. 

That's basically the game. Each Champion has lots of different cards, artifacts and more. You can upgrade cards throughout a run and each combination of races plays differently. 

I played over 90 hours and had fun in every one of it. If you beat the game you'll unlock a higher difficulty. In total there are 25. Each difficulty adds something new (e.g. stronger monsters, different starting cards and more). 
There are daily challenges and an online mode (even through i don't really like it. It basically adds nothing new to the game IMO). 

If you liked Slay the Spire or similiar games you'll love Monster train and should immediately get it. The only thing i dislike is that there are no DLC's yet. They updated the game and added new content, but i need much more of it. It's definitely worth 20€  through. 

If you like my review and are into strategy games please consider following my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38553778-All-about-Strategy-Games/

However, completionists will very likely feel frustration. For example, there is an achievement to earn 50,000 points in a daily challenge. As of writing this, today's challenge was attempted by 715 players, with the highest reaching 46,140 points. If you want to 100% this game, expect to put in a lot of time.

The game has a lot of tools to customize your run and create the deckbuilding experience that best fits your preferences. If you think this game might be your type, you won't be disappointed.

title: Monster Train
review:
Cannot recommend this game enough to people who love deck builders especially for beginners. This game has something for everyone, beginners and pros alike. It has a relatively easy beginning with ramping difficulty and plenty of challenges for pros of the genre. This game is amazing and is worth any amount of time you want to commit to it. A lot easier to pick up than games like slay the spire and I actually recommend this game before STS if you are new to the genre given how relatively easy it is and how it can teach you so many things such as synergy and the fundamentals of deck building such as what cards you want to draft, what cards you want to remove, and when to and when not to spend your gold. I cannot recommend this game enough. 

Rating- 8.5/10

title: Monster Train
review: It's a great game overall; The graphics are great, no bugs. The gameplay is pretty fun, but it gets stale. You traverse the levels of hell, and it's the same exact path, every time, with a left and right option that determine what you receive for your run. It's got several races to unlock, but after a few runs, you get them all. Replayablity is in the randomization; different starting cards, artifacts, and different events on your journey. The biggest issue is that the enemies are limited. Every run is the same set of enemies with a slightly randomized ability. I'd say buy it on sale, so you can enjoy it when you've got nothing much better to do.

title: Monster Train
review: This is currently my favorite game of 2020 so far.  Hell has frozen over and it's your job as "bad guys" to protect your pyre long enough to reignite the frozen heart at the end of the rails.  With only your units, spells, and a train you must fend off the various creatures and angels attempting to make sure your pyre never reaches the end.  Friends will join you, your train will upgrade, imps will die.  This is he nature of Monster Train.  With a full length soundtrack to play behind each three-leveled fight this game provides an enjoyable experience that really makes you consider if "bigger" minions necessarily means "better" minions.  The Friends and Foes update adds a wide range of play styles and card builds that help to add an extra dimension to this game that on release, I thought it was missing.  Now I have found this game to be one I love dearly and find myself playing at least a run a day.  Sometimes it's difficult and frustrating knowing you're just one turn away from being able to save your pyre, but it's the growth and overcoming the odds that makes this game worth it.

title: Monster Train
review: I've never been a fan of card/deckbuilder games (you can check my library if you don't believe me) and I always thought I wasn't really smart enough to play those types of games, until I started watching the great Eggfather play and somewhere down the line of watching him fail over and over and critiquing those fails made me want to see if I could do any better.. As you can see by the playtime, I freaking love this game, I am now in love with deckbuilders, and even after beating Covenant 25 I'm still playing daily (normal runs to complete every clan combo at covenant 25 and completing the Expert Challenges which are insanely challenging but so fun seeing the weird and wacky things this game can do outside of base runs, I HIGHLY recommend checking out the Dangerous Minds challenge).. This newest update literally made this game feel brand new again and the new variations in the new champions are awesome. I've 100% gotten my money's worth out of this game and more.. Can't wait to see what else will come in the future from MT and from the creators of MT in the future.. Thanks for ushering me into a new genre after 20+ years of ignoring it!!

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like Slay the Spire, you'll like Monster Train. 

Optimism
[list]
[*]Fewer, more meaningful fights, with more rewards in-between.
[*]Fun music, theming and aesthetic. You'll probably hum along with some before you're done, but they honestly spent a lot of dev energy on this and it works out. There's even a Bastion-esque credits track that I didn't expect.
[*]You can be an imp mum and all your children say "mama!"as you send them off to die. <3
[*]Covenant (prestige/difficulty scaling) system for learning the ropes and development of playstyle! It's an accomplishment to beat it!
[*]Social interactions: friends' leaderboards, factoids on performance, etc. I had some nice social interactions with friends around release as per these features.
[*]Some of the characters make weird groans.
[/list]

Pessimism
[list]
[*]Reused art assets means telling cards apart can be bothersome, especially at first. 
[*]UI can be cluttered (playing on 1080p) in both a full hand and board. You kind of have to play it to see what I mean, and this can compound the previous point. 
[*]Some of the characters make weird groans.
[*]Game dissolves into "upgrade a creature to be a beater" and "protect the beater" pretty quickly. You can win with spells decks, especially at earlier covenants, but it usually devolves back to this even in such decks.
[/list]

They have, since launch, patched in a plenitude of content in their Friends & Foes update. This is a very considerable drop and I think it's worth trying it again if you haven't; it gave me the juice to push to Covenant 25.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is game combining deck building and roguelike mechanisms, and in this regard is often compared to the highly successful "Slay the spire".

Having played both, I can confirm that they indeed sit in the same niche, but on different ends. 
Slay the spire will have you slowly climb 55 procedurally generated levels to destroy the big guy sitting at the top, with little back story and very little room for error, as the tiniest mistake will snowball on the many following battles and slowly but inevitably make you fail. 
With Monster train, not so much. Monster train's story grabs your attention from the get go and rushes you on a deadly descent to the heart of Hell, with one fight in each of the 8 rings against the legions of Heaven. Their armies will do everything they can to stop you from rekindling the fires of Hell, as the last burning Pyre powers your train.
(For some reason, the Angels are too stupid to just demolish the rail tracks but hey who am I to judge them :p )
Gameplay wise, Monster Train is quicker (only 8 battles!) and more forgiving than Slay the spire, since before each battle there are 2 to 3 events that will allow the player to tailor his/her deck. No so in Slay the spire... In my experience, it makes for a lot easier and more enjoyable runs, as the deck combos will work much sooner.

title: Monster Train
review: If you liked roguelike card games like Slay the spire, you will like this game. Free updates are constantly flowing in too.

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1]A better deckbuilder than Slay the Spire[/h1]

Talking about Monster Train immediately conjures the large shadow of Slay The Spire. And at first glance, it could seem like Monster Train is just riding StS's coattail. A deckbuilder game with a large variety of cards and artefacts that allow for complex interactions, that are made possible thanks to the game telling you the damage calculation ahead of time.

However, as soon as you play, you will find the feelings of both games are very different. Slay The Spire has a lot of random events, artefacts that always have a drawback, bosses that end up being exact counters to your deck, and so the overall experience is often one of misery, where you're never fully in control, and you're just trying to survive what the game throws at you. With Monster Train, this is all gone. Artefacts are all positive, bosses are announced ahead of time, and the random events are limited in scope. It's time to make the cards deck of your dream!

[h1]Enjoy building and using the deck of your dream[/h1]

Monster Train focuses on building the best deck you can. You can see the whole map from the very beginning, and you're also warned about which bosses you will have to face, so the whole game is about preparing for that final confrontation. You have all the information, success or failure isn't random, it is all dependant on how you build and use your deck.

The game offers you many ways to customize your deck as you see fits. You have various merchants allowing you to upgrades your spells and your units as you see fit, and you're also able to duplicate upgraded cards that you like so you can have even more of that goodness. In the end, you end up with the deck of your dream with often ridiculously good units and combos, which make for long combo, big damages and a very satisfying experience.

Obviously, in turn, the enemies need to be balanced to be a good challenge to your strong deck. Monster Train starts somewhat easy. It should not take you many games to get your first victory. But do not be fooled by those easy beginnings, they are mostly here to ease you into the game. After your first win, you will be able to increase the "Covenant Ranks", that makes the future runs harder, so you can truly test your deckbuilding skills.

[h1]Lots of content and variations[/h1]

But just having higher difficulty levels would make for a boring game, if you were constantly using the game cards. Luckily, once again, Monster Train was well designed, and offer a ton of replayability.

The game features 5 clans, and each run starts by selecting a primary and a secondary clans, which means your deck will be a mix of the cards from both clans, and you will have a special champion unit that comes from the primary clan and helps you decide on the overall direction of your deck.

Thanks to that, climbing the ranks is a really fun and diverse experience. If you like a specific combination a lot, you can just use it over and over, but if you prefer to try new things, you can constantly change your clan selections and create new decks that work completely differently.

Moreover, if you still want more things to do, the game is happy to provide, in the form of "Hell Rush", a multiplayer time attack mode, and the "Daily challenge", which feature runs with modifiers. Monster Train is therefore shock full of content, and should keep you busy for a looong time.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Monster Train is a lot of fun. Easy to get into, Fun to play, and will keep you entertained for a long time. A more positive experience than Slay The Spire, it will appeal to both beginners and experienced deckbuilder players.

title: Monster Train
review:
The game is fun and I've spent a lot of hours with it. With a slight discount it's probably worth the price. But it has one glaring problem compared to slay the spire that hampers it's replayability - boss battles.

Boss battles in Monster Train are entirely passive. The idea in the game is to use the waves of non boss enemies to build an engine for the last boss battle, which in most cases is exponentially more powerful the the non-boss ones.
Once you get to the boss battle either your engine worked and you win or it didn't and you lose.
The problem is that the nature of boss battles means that you must build an engine that is passive - I.E. the engine must work without you actually playing cards. Which leaves basically only a few possible strategies to win - involving your creatures building up their power as they fight.

Besides removing tons of what might be fun strategies otherwise, having the main battle be entirely passive isn't as fun. The boss battles, rather than being what you anticipate to and have the most fun in are instead an unwanted distraction you must dredge through.

Progression is also very weird, basically everytime you beat it you have the option to just do it again but slightly harder. Overall just felt very fun but then got stale very quickly. Pick up at like -50% I guess.

title: Monster Train
review:
Similar to the Slay the Spire, Monster Train is a deck building card game. You pilot a train from Hell trying to escape in a rogue-like environment, facing regular battles as well as intermittent boss battles. Deck building-vice there is more variance in that you choose between two different clans to make your starter deck. The chosen clans also determine what kind of cards you can get as drops. On your journey you can also gain artifacts that provide passive bonuses to your cards as well as remove unwanted cards from your deck to make it more focused - same feature as in the Slay the Spire.

The actual game play is focused on the attacks against your trains, which is basically a card duel, except opponent most often sends creatures on the bottom floor of your train - the train comprises of three floors and the attic where your shard (ie. life total) is). Your goal is to destroy those creatures with creatures of your own or with spells before they reach the top and damage your shard eventually destroying it. Boss battles differ from the regulars in that the bosses are relentless, unlike normal creatures they do not ascend to upper floors at the end of the round, but keep on fighting until they or all the creatures defending the current floor are destroyed.

Thus far, I've enjoyed the deck building aspect the most, it having more options than Slay the Spire for a starter deck. However, the candy-like graphics and made-up funny themes haven't really appealed to me.

review:
You've played and loved Slay the Spire. Have you ever thought to yourself "But what if this was bolder, more beautiful, and all on a train rattling through the depths of hell?." You should probably play Monster Train.

This game spreads out before you a bountiful selection of cards. Will you take the truly gargantuan demon that can one-shot the boss? How about the invisible sniper that only grows more powerful when it dies? Maybe you'd prefer to grow a garden of soot morsels to feast on, gaining strength with each devouring?

Each of the five factions has a distinct personality and specialty mechanics that fit seamlessly with the theme. The spells feel powerful. The units feel monstrous. The enemies feel unbeatable. The choices feel meaningful. When you manage to build a deck that works you feel invincible.

title: Monster Train
review:
Honestly as someone who loved Slay The Spire but wanted something new, I really wanted to like this game and I did for a little while.

The problems in this game turn up as time goes on. There's nothing so massively in your face "woah that doesn't work and is terrible", but I found a number of disappointing/irritating things that incrementally took the fun out of Monster Train.

1. Artifact variance
2. Points of no return
3. Combat trials options
4. Certain enemy types
5. Lack of information available

The artifacts in this game are a mixed bunch. Some of them are amazing but situational (cheaper units, additional upgrades), some are weaker and consistent (your starting units are better, each unit starts with extra health/armor). Each class has some artifacts exclusive to them.

The problem is that there's way too much variance in these, up to the point where some artifacts feel like net negatives (units with the sole purpose of dying gain a ton of extra hp, at the start of each turn add a persistent spell to your deck, at the start of battle summon 4 of your units at random in a random order on the middle floor).

It's never a good feeling to make a routing decision based on gaining an artifact to be given a choice of two terrible options.

I think that these artifacts should be tagged with certain keywords ("Ember", "Pyre", "Spell", "On Summon", "On Entry", etc) which could be shown to you when you hover over Herzal's Hoard before choosing a route, so you could see that "Buff" and "Spell" artifacts are available and work that into your choice.

Alternatively group the artefacts into "small consistent effect" and "huge situational effect" and make it so you're always given a choice from each. It's a big deal as artifacts are rare in this game (A StS run might end with 20 relics, a MT run can end with 5 if you don't route for them) and getting one that synergises with your deck can immediately drop you into "broken deck" territory.

Something that could be done is give each clan a "Starter Artifact" which can be taken or replaced at the Hoard you find before the first fight. Each clan has one or two artifacts that would be ideal for this as they don't push a particular archetype.

Annoyingly enough, we have a bit of this already. Your Champion is given a choice of 2 (out of 3 total) upgrades right at the start, which is good. More of this approach would be great.

What especially sucks is any combat trial with a "Random Artifact" reward. Having the option to take a harder fight in exchange for a reward is great, but committing yourself to a tougher fight (and probably losing some HP for it) is a tall ask when the reward might be something you decide to not include in your deck afterwards.

This should be reformed to "Draft Artifact" (maybe with the above suggestions included, ay?). Seeing Draft Unit as a reward is something you pretty much always want to go for - a shot at a useful artifact feels meh in comparison.

Some of the options for these Combat Trials definitely feel ill-thought out. 
The choices tend to "Enemies have extra armor/damage/spikes/spell shield) and are seemingly picked at random.
Fairly quickly the first question in the early game becomes "does the trial counter my deck entirely" and the answer is yes surprisingly often. I feel that certain clan combinations should be exempt from certain trial types, especially early on when you haven't had chance to work around it yet (Hellhorned/Remnant vs Spikes, Stygian vs Spell Shield).

In fairness this is a theme that persists throughout the game. Each fight *seems* to be against a random selection of enemy types with a boss at the end - some of these types have certain mechanics that you just can't play around as certain clans/combinations. 

If you're Remnant/Stygian/Umbra, you're going to really struggle to defeat Conduits (enemies who sit at the back and buff their friends) because you won't have targeted spells to take them down.

If you're playing any strategy that revolves around many small units (Umbra morsels, Remnant burnout, Hellhorned imps), you're going to lose if the Warrior of Light enemy turns up (high HP, hits everyone on a floor, gains attack when he kills something).

This is compounded by the lack of information about upcoming fights. For example, the final boss has multiple forms and you're told which one you're fighting at the start of the run, explicitly to stop you from building a sick buff deck only to find the Big Bad removes your buffs - this is the only time the game will tell you what's about to happen.

It's only when you start each fight you're told what you'll be facing (this is the stage that you can opt into the combat trial). Once you're here, it's a point of no return, which means that you've just had a bunch of upgrades to pick from but with no idea what you're fighting next.

Just lost against the Warrior of Light? It'd be less frustrating if you hadn't just passed on an artefact or unit upgrade that would have saved you, but you went for something else that improves your deck against everything else.

Even the other two bosses (Daedalus on Floor 3, Fel on Floor 6) have multiple forms. You are not told which form you'll be fighting until it's too late.

In Slay the Spire, you know that Gremlin Nob exists so you know you need early damage in Act 1. 
You also know that you're fighting Slime Boss at the end of the Act, so you keep an eye out for ways to set up a powerful split or AOE to cope afterwards.

Not forgetting that if you don't find the tools to beat Gremlin Nob, you can just... not fight him and avoid elite fights (forfeiting the rewards). Hell, if you're struggling with any fight you can route for campfires, shops and events until you get back on your feet (or inevitably die against the Boss of that Act).

It actually shows there's a lot of ways Combat Trails could be further developed. Why not allow the players to pick and choose enemy types, granting extra bonuses for each one? At least that way if the game throws you a run-ending curveball, you have the option to route around it, sacrificing late-game resources to do so.

Maybe the game would benefit from a comprehensive Wiki that explains which enemies can appear on which floors, but this information just isn't available. 

Either way, the game should flat out tell you "HEY YOU'RE FIGHTING SWEEPERS NEXT, AND YOU CAN OPT INTO GIVING THEM BONUS DAMAGE, PREPARE ACCORDINGLY". At the moment it's "Oh you didn't plan for this one exact enemy type? too bad, he's here, you lose".

All of this compounds into a game with limited archetypes. Synergies within a clan's cards are fairly obvious and the game does give you an interesting number of building blocks to work with, but a lot of these combinations are either gated by gaining a certain type of artifact (Awoken Sting decks) or by certain enemy types (as above).

Exception would be Umbra - This clan has no units that don't have a Gorge mechanic or create things for you to Gorge on. It's a bit of a sad single-tracked time really.

The end result is a game where you're punished for trying to do something new. You can either play through the game doing the same proven combination over and over, but fail repeatedly as the game hard-counters an experiment without giving you a chance to prepare.

I'll probably keep an eye out for balance patches in the future and I hope this game improves. Until then though, I'll stick to Slay the Spire.

Edit - "But andy, you have a hundred hours in this game!" - I do, but I would recommend Slay The Spire to anyone regardless of if they had played anything similar to it before. Monster Train really makes me think about the recommendation before I give it.

While I'd put StS in front of my nan, I'd never give her Monster Train.

title: Monster Train
review: Monster Train is an extremely addictive deck building roguelike. Pick one of 10 unique heroes, choose one of 5 allied clans, and off you go. You play as the bad guys and your objective is to defend the last train to hell from waves of invading heroes. Each wave becomes more difficult, but rewards you with extra cards, credits and possibly some magic artifact. In between waves you get ample opportunities to add or remove cards, repair your train, boost cards or buy artifacts. Each run feels different, there is a daily challenge with run modifiers, you can setup your own custom challenge, and there are end-game objectives aplenty. I like everything about this game, both art and gameplay are very much my cup of tea. If you love(d) Slay the Spire, I think this game can scratch that same itch while at the same time being very different. 10/10 for me, easy recommendation.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is like a mix of Hearthstone and Tower Defense, in which you place units and make magic using cards in order to protect the pyre.

I bought the game expecting some time with it, but now I'm already with 100+ hours...

However, I must say, it definetely made a better deal with the last update, Friends and Foes, that is free.
Biggest pro of the game is how well designed it is to you have FUN. Mechanics synergize easily, it's fun to explore possibilities and combos. Even the challenges are well designed, makes you think about mechanics that usually would go unoticed.

My con with the game was the price x content, but as said, with the Friends and Foes update, I think it's well worth it. Other than that, nothing really worth mentioning. It's a solid deal all around.

I recommend Monster Train for card-game, rogue-like and tower defense fans, casually or hardcore. I also recommend it for game design students, THIS is how it's done. It definetely earned my appreciation within "superb-designed games" tag, alongside FTL and Slay the Spire. Every bit of content is well used and appreciated.

title: Monster Train
review:
Linux! 

Okay, now that I have your attention: first off, I really, really wanted to buy this but then saw the Windows only logo. So I put it off for months. 

I finally got my gaming rig fixed from Microsoft's latest incompetency and made the leap. You can read comments way more articulate than mine about how awesome and balanced this game is. I'm hardly a veteran of deck builders but this one has devoured at least 2 hours of my life, maybe even 176 at last count.

While killing time waiting for the week or so it takes QT to recompile on a system update, I popped into Steam and saw a little green Play button for Monster Train. [i]Well[/i], I thought to myself, [i]It's not like I can do much else[/i] as my ultra portable Arch Linux laptop was trying its hardest at heating the neighborhood. But the cats huddled close to it so somebody was enjoying the electrons.

Back to Linux.

Flawless. Absolutely and completely flawless. Vulkan with Proton 5.1. System utilization never got above 2% on my 4 core i7-8550U, the RAM utilization didn't even show up on my top 10 offenders Top chart. And the Intel UHD 620 was able to rock at 1920x1080 at 60FPS. Admittedly my Windows box rocks a whole lot harder, but the GPUs in that monstrosity dim the neighborhood when I'm training a neural network.

There were a few hiccups on the larger, zoomed out screens; but that went away as soon as my QT compilation was complete so I'm going to chalk it up to either disk IO or forcing gcc to work threaded.

title: Monster Train
review:
At first, I loved this. I'm a fan of TCG and other deck-building games, and this had almost nothing but rave reviews.

Almost. The one negative review I saw suggested that it was a pretty deceptively simple/boring luckfest, where you either became extremely overpowered or got crushed, all just based on luck. This reviewer suggested there was a lot less ingenuity involved than others seemed to think. At first, I joined the throngs of people who disagreed, and thought like many people do "Oh, this person just doesn't know what they're talking about."

Then, after I maxed a race out and started to get on a win streak which ended, I noticed the exact same thing. Those runs I won, 3 in a row, I got things that I was able to work into something good enough to win. Afterwards, I had far more dud runs, and I've outlined some of the issues I see below. There will always be luck involved with games like this. That's part of what makes it fun. However, the sum total of the points below makes this a game I don't see myself playing for hundreds of hours:

*Bad starting cards which gimped me the entire game
*Bad luck with units or spell draws at every point in the game -- there isn't much of a chance to win when you can only pick from units that don't work all that well together. There are not a lot of possibilities at times, and you can end up getting junk card after junk card until some minor fight overtakes you
*Bad luck with relics; some relics are game-breakingly good, and some are less than useless. *Gold awarded for skipping doesn't even come close to allowing you to gain much from relics you're not going to benefit from, whereas if something else pops up there, it practically means you win the run
*Many runs where you just don't get a workable strategy -- what do you do when getting or not getting certain cards breaks the game in a good or bad way, and there isn't much in between?

Everything is just a *bit* too random, and it ends up putting you into situations where you can't really see a way to win, over and over and over again, or on crazy win streaks that end as mysteriously as they start.
The game practically admits some of these things by allowing for easy restarts -- that is, if you're prepared to sacrifice your win streak. The problem is that the immense luck factor in this game makes win streaks themselves feel hollow, and it leaves me feeling like "Why am I playing this again? I could just like download a slot machine simulator instead and stare at that."

I want to be wrong about this game, and I'm going to play it more to see if I feel differently about it, but as I gained a real level of familiarity with this game, I don't think I'll be playing it for nearly as long as I thought. It needs a lot of work to make it feel more interactive and less like a slot machine where you get game-breaking combos or nothing and get crushed. If player choice and skill were tweaked in a bit more, I think I'd enjoy the game for much longer. I will update this review if my opinion changes as I play more, but since I started thinking this way *because* I played more, I kinda doubt it. I'd say if the points above don't turn you off like they turn me off, go ahead, but otherwise maybe wait and see if they balance it a bit better. This has the potential to be better than any of them, but I feel it definitely falls short in its current state.

If somebody sees this and disagrees, and has played the time/gotten things done to back it up, I'd love to hear why I'm wrong, how it can somehow be played more elegantly, but I'm just not seeing a lot of interactivity anymore. It's either get good stuff and win, or get bad stuff and lose. It feels like my only contribution is noticing combos. I'd love to be told to "git gud" by anybody who wants to tell me that, just please let me know how to do it, how you work with the extreme luck factor when it isn't working out, which is plenty.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you enjoy deckbuilders and/or roguelikes, you'll probably find a lot to love in Monster Train. It's not just another Slay the Spire clone - you summon a lot of minions along with your "hero" across multiple floors, and you can upgrade and custom tailor both minions and spells as you play to make them much more powerful and set up new synergies and strategies. 25 levels of challenge modes (each one stacking another modifier to make the game harder) and competitive multiplayer ensure that the game continues feeling challenging for quite some time even as your skill and game knowledge improve. 

One thing I really love about the game is just how powerful the synergies, upgrades, and artifacts can be. It's rare to go through a run without at least a few really satisfying power spikes. It feels great to put a couple upgrades on a key payoff card for the synergy you're building around that make it an absolute powerhouse and then having it carry you through the run. There are a lot of different synergies and strategies to try out, too. No two runs have felt the same so far after 15 hours.

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1] Summary [/h1]
[b]The game is fun and I enjoyed finishing all the classes.[/b] However, the Overwhelmingly Positive is not quite deserved, the game is overrated. At first, the game is way too easy (and that might not a bad thing for some casual players) but at the current price of 20€ I cannot recommend this game.

After finishing the game with a class, you can play on a new difficulty mode called "Covenant Rank" which goes from 1 to 25; so that you have an idea covenant 1 starts to be challenging (compared to the base difficulty which is non-existing) and RNG plays a big role. The more you play the more repetitive the run feels, the added difficulty is very artificial.

In short, [b]Slay the Spire is still superior in most aspects[/b].
[hr][/hr]
[h1] How this game compares to Slay the Spire [/h1]
If you don´t have Slay The Spire and you are trying to decide which one to buy: go for Sly the Spire without a doubt; If you already have it and you want a similar game it´s probably the best next alternative out there.

Monster Train is much easier than Sly The Spire generally speaking. Graphically, both have their charm. Both feel slick while playing. 

The core mechanics in both games vary just a bit and in my opinion Sly The Spire does a much better job overall, however, they share several things like the stops between fights, artifacts, etc. I would only recommend Monster Train if you own and finished Sly The Spire - at least with the basic characters - on the default difficulty.

[h1]Slay the Spire or Monster Train if I have none of them?[/h1]
Slay the Spire, without a doubt. Unless you are looking to play in "zen" mode, totally casual, in which case you might find Monster Train more appealing.

Ultimately, both Spire The Sly and Monster train can get a bit repetitive, is just that the mechanics of Monster Train makes it a bit more annoying.

[h1]How is the game, though?[/h1]
Graphics are good, music is decent, the game runs smooth. At first, the game is very interesting and definitively fun, but it gets repetitive very fast once you win with all the classes.

The "covenant" difficulty is not very well calibrated, covenant 1 is orders of magnitude more difficult than the default and you depend on the RNG a lot more.

In my case I already played Slay the Spire which I got from some bundle and I enjoyed Monster Train, which is essentially a copy of it. And so, I found Monster Train refreshing, but I cannot advise anyone to play this game first and then Slay The Spire to be honest.

You can beat the game with all classes in a few hours, your first run win can be in less than an hour, so it´s that easy. IMHO, there should be more tracks per run, at least one more should be added.

The game at the full price is arguably expensive, I got it on 20% discount which is not that much after you see its content.

[b]What about replayability?[/b]
It has pvp, daily run and challenges. Since it has many classes and combinations together with covenant modes I can say there is a ton of replayability in Monster Train. Unfortunately, it gets boring rather fast and the difficulty added by the 25 Covenant Ranks is just tedious rather than fun.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
The game is fun (even if not for too long). You should play Sly the Spire first except if you want to play on "easy mode" only.

You can easily get up to ~30h of gameplay having fun before you enter Covenant Ranks, then it gets a bit tedious and more repetitive but if you are looking for a challenge you should play Slay the Spire.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster train is the best rogue lite I've played in a while, and it is definitely worth trying if you are into deckbuilders.
It's unique train car system creates interesting situations, and the available factions explore tons of different design spaces, which all feel unique. I'm not even close to covenant rank 25, but hopefully someday I will be. The recent free Friends & Foes update added a ton of new content that most games would charge for, but it was added for free, and just sweetens the pot in what I already consider to be an incredible deal.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game concentrates so well that feeling of being conniving mastermind edging towards some ridiculous build that is just ready to pop off with a few more key items.

The acceleration of popping off will give you whiplash, it is just so much more potent and higher than most deckbuilders of its kind. But, with this in mind don't try and think that the escalation is the same through several runs. In many ways, ways that you might not even think of will ascend your deck to the skies thanks to the fact that the devs have thoughtfully implemented plenty of ways to combine attributes.

Extremely well made that is still getting updates. Just buy it.

review: Watched many YouTubers play it (Northernlion, Rhapsody and MichaelALFox mostly) while playing or even in free time. It's an extremely entertaining and fun game, with excellent replayability from a quick run every day or just to slam failed run after failed run trying to make the cards you're given work. The difficulty ranges well as it is easy to pick up but incredibly hard to master and perfect each run. With devs working super hard and pumping out consistently great updates the game is positively going to improve even further.Highly recommend the game for those that enjoy roguelikes, deckbuilders or those that love a good time sink; reviewers hours speak for themselves in many cases but here the case is especially true. 10/10 A true gem from this year.

title: Monster Train
review: I've heard other people rave about other card-based games.  I've tried them and none of them sparked until this one.  I get it now!  You can enjoy a couple of levels in a few minutes and go on to life's errands or very often, look up and see an hour has gone by unnoticed.  I like the short "chunks" of strategic and tactical thinking:  it breaks up your decisions in manageable, unintimidating pieces.  It ramps up your learning appropriately, you are not trying to grasp a gigantic, complete cardset, buffs, warriors, spells all at once.  The "cartoony" aspect lightens its tone to stress-relieving entertainment. -- I love this game.  It's fun, diverting, good for a short or long play session.  Still lots to discover (e.g., daily challenges!)  It is my first card game and hopefully will lead me to others.

Plus, with each major patch the devs add new content that is fun to explore, so you're getting a lot of bang for your buck.

title: Monster Train
review: I've always loved the idea of games like this, but almost 100% of the time, I bounce off similar games as there are one or two aspects of them that don't thrill me and that I consider "deal breakers". In a world with fewer games, I could probably move past those quibbles, but as it happens, I have plenty of un-played games that I quickly move onto in these cases.I'm really happy to say that I have no such hang-ups when it comes to Monster Train. It's just a great and satisfying game all-around, from what I have experienced so far. It feels fair, it's simple and easy to learn on the surface but has a load of depth and variance and it's extremely easy on the eyes and ears. It's just a bunch of fun to play.As of this writing, the attitude toward this game on Steam is "Overwhelmingly Positive" and as far as I'm concerned, it's well deserved. I'm looking forward to future updates and DLC, and will definitely be keeping my eye on Shiny Shoe and their future titles.

title: Monster Train
review: Excellent game. There are TONS of synergies between each clan and allows for a ton of different play styles. While some play styles are better than others, the devs are trying their best try and put them all onto the same playing field, which gets them points in my book. The underlying lore of each faction and hell/heaven itself is also very interesting, and I for one can't wait to see what they do with it next. Though, I wish there were more levels of hell to traverse, or more levels of anything in general. Regardless, here's to (hopefully) many more updates to come!

title: Monster Train
review: TL;DR: This is an amazing deck building game that definitely did a wonderful job in balancing a good challenge and having fun.There's no way that I can talk about Monster Train without talking about Slay the Spire, which is another great game but definitely requires time to learn the cards and right combinations to come up with a deck that can help you climb the Ascention levels. Here at Monster Train I find it way easier to understand the game mechanics and make multiple combinations to have a deck that can actually win. If you're more of a casual gamer (which is my case) this game definitely works and you can progress without having to invest a crazy amount of time learning all the meta.

title: Monster Train
review:
As much as I wanted to like this game, I can't properly say that I recommend it. I believe there are definitely some interesting qualities to it and it has some form of redemption hidden away somewhere inside it, but I feel like the game balance and numbers are too off. Even with the new update, almost doubling the unique content in the game wasn't what was missing or what was needed, it just needs a second look at balancing the game.

The game has some fun elements, the mixing of clans to get specific cards, the variety of builds... But unfortunately, sometimes there are certain boss modifiers that will lead to a lost run. Of course, they warn you what bosses are coming up so you can adjust your strategy to deal with them, but sometimes you get the feeling of "this run is DOA" because you picked Stygian v a boss that counters spells.

As for the gameplay, the runs feel a little bit too short and the numbers feel so wild and uncontrollable or unpredictable. Even after 24 hours of play, I'm still not comfortable with energy costs, since I can do 5 damage with a 3 energy cost spell and 60 damage with a three energy cost spell and even fully upgraded,  both spells can do the same amount of damage. 

I compare this game to Slay the Spire, a game whose balancing act has been so perfectly set up in a way to make a toxic grown man cry. When I look at a card in that game, I understand it and every use for it immediately, but when I look at Monster Train, every card has 6 different unique uses for every single clan depending on what deck its in and how it's upgraded, but as exciting as that might be, it's immediately overwhelming and difficult to fully grasp. I've seen a unit that I think can be potentially incredibly useful and have had great success with that someone that has more in-game time will immediately dismiss and consider garbage.

In conclusion
While I don't think this game is bad, I can't say that I recommend it. It's lack of a comparative baseline for cards and effects can be really frustrating or confusing at times, its lackluster take on balance and surprising balancing act of "We'll create a boss to counter one specific playstyle and be a total pushover to all others" is not the way to go about creating an enjoyable experience,

title: Monster Train
review:

So far, there's already been 1 update introducing new champions and styles of play and it's an excellent addition for free, especially so soon after release.

If you've played deckbuilders before and enjoyed them, I would wholeheartedly recommend this. Great fun, great replayability and beautifully designed.

title: Monster Train
review:
Some games need an introduction, not because they aren't able to stand on their own, but because the developer knew their gaming audience so well, because they are an underdog that is upsetting the standard. This is one of them. I went ham on this game, when I first played the game I thought, oh it's another slay the spire, but that was doing it a disservice. This game has a lot more than just being competition going for it. Roguelite elements are handled very well and even if you suck at card battle type games it has so many difficulty adjustments and modifiers that it will welcome you, if you need more of a challenge they have modifiers for that too. The variety of play styles in this game are truly indulgent, if you are familiar with RPGs or card games in general you will love recognizing and using different playstyles such as damage over time, aggro, burn, etc. I almost wanted to give it a 10/10 but realized I was being just a hair biased. Get it and you won't regret it. If you want to see more here is my video on it.

https://youtu.be/DiTCSFq1aqI

title: Monster Train
review:
Slay the Spire-esque deck drafting with a unique take on strategy. I would say this can be a bit tamer compared to Spire, at least until the later Covenant levels. There is tons of variety, but once you start building your deck the upgrades and decisions usually seem pretty obvious. Although I think Slay the Spire is a more polished, enticing game, I have put more hours in Monster Train and it hasn't been a regrettable experience. Working up the covenant ranks will take a while and it adds just enough extra difficulty to make things interesting. Also while I don't play it much myself, the online mode offers some enticing modes if you get bored with standard runs (not to mention mutations to change your game up)

With the free updates, the devs seem dedicated and if you are at all into this type of deck building/strategy game, you will love this game too.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is the best of its kind.  It takes the best pieces of Slay the Spire but leaves you more in control of your fate, less to RNG.  It also masterfully makes for many viable play styles and approaches without restricting you to a set standard pattern and cardset in order to win.  The difficulty curve progresses at a steady rate.

I have beaten the final boss with 5 entirely different styles so far, and I find myself liking all five of the clans and all of the champions.  Each champion has three progression trees that further strengthen its style.
Each of the 5 clans is strongly themed and the synergies between the different clans plays out well in all cases - as long as you play intelligently.

There are some cards in each clan that seem to be "junk" - but even the junk cards in this game are useful in the right setting, or when upgraded with an appropriate rune - certain cards I felt worthless at first turn amazing with proper upgrades and use in play.  And I like this - you can find ways to make almost any card work - but you need to put some thought into how you upgrade, which new cards you pick or if you pass (and avoid deck bloat), and how you spend your coins that run.

The ability to duplicate and purge cards also helps tremendously, and is among the top choices when I pick my path through the game and build my deck.

Overall the balance, user control over their fate, and overall fun levels are great.  RNG is still there, but you can mitigate it well enough to advance - and 3/4 times when you fail it's because of choices you made and not overwhelming bad RNG.  And when you win - it's almost entirely because of choices you made and not because of good RNG.

I highly recommend this game to anyone interested in rogue-like ccg style games.

title: Monster Train
review:
Superb.  

If you came here from Slay The Spire like many of us: Slay The Spire was good. Monster Train is better at everything, 100 times. It is like Doom 2016 and Doom 1993. More of what we liked, less of what we didn't like, a lot more variety, and the developers are on board fueling this crazy ride to hell with updates and content.

title: Monster Train
review:
Just can't recommend this at the price it's listed at. The quality/polish just isn't there. Many visual bugs & selection errors. There are loading times for still images. There is no controller support for no discernible reason.

There's a lot of potential but if you're a controller user or allergic to lack of polish this title will frustrate you. 

Recommended heartily under $20AUD, but the $30+AUD RRP is just silly. This is a card game, essentially a glorified minigame. You do not deserve full price for this and you know it. There are games with fully detailed 3d worlds with under half the price tag of this game.

Sadly since the initial writing of this review, I have noticed MANY instances of the game cheating. Examples:
*play a card that allows you to draw morsels - morsels are not drawn when the game feels like it (usually later in a run)
*play a spell to heal your units and they are not healed
*buy an upgrade and have it not applied

title: Monster Train
review:
Spire-likes are becoming a thing now, and this one feels the most like playing a card game while also tying in the turn-based RPG elements to an impressive degree, thanks to faction pairing, unit and spell card designations, and a focus on unit combat. The basic elements of Slay the Spire are here (health, armor, trinkets, deckbuilding, etc.), but taken a few steps farther. Playing units on each level of the Train, with limited space, adds a degree of planning and decision-making that other Spire-likes simply don't demand from the player.

Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys card games, turn-based-RPGs, or deckbuilders like Dominion or Slay the Spire.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
I am an avid roguelike player, having played numerous similar titles for countless hours. The UI/UX design and the amount of content are both quite impressive and overall, I am really, really impressed with the game.

With that being said, I feel like the game could benefit from more agency at times. I am sure some of those things were considered and perhaps removed after the prototyping stage but at times it can truly feel like your choices IN-GAME are limited (in comparison to something like Slay the Spire, choices made in the progression/upgrade state of the game loop are actually more substantial at times, as far as the actual gameplay is concerned though, not so much, even though the tower defense inspired systems should enforce that).

- Switching the position of friendly units: this seems like a no brainer to me, I understand that this, like most of my potential suggested mechanisms, are a double-sided coin and might strip away from the game's difficulty etc. At the very least, allow players to switch the position of ONE unit on ONE lane (not switch lane mind you), prior to the attack stage. Having such a limited choice also enforces agency and makes the decision that much more crucial.

- Add a mulligan-like mechanism to the initial cards received system: give players a choice of X set of cards (not sure about the range here, 3 feels like a good number) and allow them to choose one. Currently, you might as well restart a run if you don't like your choices, seems like a UX related issue. Just to clarify, I do not mean the actual mulligan during the combat, that would simplify the game.

- More pathing and variety in geometry: change up the order in which the bosses appear, this would also require some balancing alterations, obviously but I feel like the game could greatly benefit from it. This is more of a player perception thing since like I have already stated, I feel like the amount of agency in terms of progression is fine.

- Since the enemies are always attacking first, the game can feel very binary at times: I understand the reasoning behind this but the current combat system limits the design space significantly - rather than have one keyword I feel like this should have been tweaked more. For example. an initiative parameter could have been added to unit cards to determine the attack order of units (which would obviously also help with balancing and again, the player agency would be further enforced).

These are just some thoughts off top of my head (if they were to be considered, would obviously have to be iterated upon). Feel free to share your opinions, I would love to hear whether you agree or disagree.

title: Monster Train
review:
An outstandingly good and addictive Player vs Environment Card Game in the vein of Slay the Spire, Monster Train is proof that there's plenty of room at the top. Draft cards in a soft Roguelike experience where you try to put together the most pleasing wombo combos to survive your relentless enemies, cursing the runs that fall short and exalting in those that defeat the dastardly Seraph. You set up lines of units in three lanes as enemy waves try to advance to the fourth at the top. It is all easy to learn yet very compelling, a fine mix of tower defense and puzzle solving. This game is immensely satisfying for the feelings of great wit it feeds you.

Monster Train is simple to pick up and a long time to master. It is a perfect pick up and play where a full run can be executed in under an hour, yet there are so many variables and tough but fair RNG components that the "just one more run" is more infectious than bobbing for needles in a barrel of medical waste. There are plenty of options here for decks of many varieties, as you pick one of five clans, pick an allied clan from the other four, pick one of two champions from there, each champion has three upgrade paths and you can mix them, you get some semi-random cards available, artifact drops, card recruits, merchant luck, so on and so on. It's a great rogue-like spirit in that in most cases you are afforded a more than fair chance to clear the game, you just need to make the best use of the tools you do get and the synergies you can make. I will note as a fan of both that I found Monster Train to be more appealing than Slay the Spire just because the difficulty spikes felt more cushioned. Enemy units reaching your core aren't an instant death and unit strength recovers between every battle. Of course with the rising Covenant(New Game+/Ascensions) difficulty and so many options to experiment with as well as Daily, Crafted and suggested Achievement challenge runs there is a lot of room to make the game as hard as you'd like.

It is hard to quantify everything that makes this game so good. The highest praise I can give it is that it captures that feeling of slumming around Warcraft 3 custom games and finding a highly addictive tower defense with multiple interesting unit paths. A certain je ne sais one more round. The charming art oozing with character, the rapid loop of a campaign run that doesn't leave you sick of the task at any point and leaves you feeling at any moment that you've got a good idea for a new run, the air-tight soundtrack and the smooth 2D graphics. There's just a point where you love a game because of the sheer polish and effort the developers have clearly put into it, leaving you with a much beloved title. Monster Train is so good I'd pay more than asking price now that I've tried it.

title: Monster Train
review:
This joins Slay the Spire as a card game of such a high caliber that it should basically be used as the measuring stick other card games are judged against.  I would argue though that it might even be MORE impressive than StS in terms of its ability to balance mechanical complexity with strategic diversity with ease of entry...I picked it up and immediately knew what I was doing, but at the 40-hour mark, I'm still unlocking things and figuring out the synergies between different card sets, artifacts, and card upgrades.

Really...if you like card games, this one can't be missed.  Spire is the only one I can think of that is its equal...even Griftlands is good, but not as good as this one.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a roguelite deckbuilder where the player controls an army of demons on a quest to reignite the fires of Hell after they were extinguished by Heaven’s angels.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

•	The significant gameplay twist that differentiates Monster Train from other deckbuilders such as Slay The Spire or Pirates Outlaws, is that some of your cards will summon minions who have their own attacks and abilities. Meanwhile your train will be invaded by waves of enemies whose goal is to destroy the pyre located at the top of the train. In a way this makes the gameplay feel a bit like a turn based tower defence game.

•	Deciding where to place minions can be very tactical. Each of the train’s three floors has a limited capacity which determines how many minions you can place there. Enemies will usually hit the front minion, so its better to put high health tanks at the front, and damage dealers at the back. Of course this is further complicated by the random draw order of your cards which means you might not always get your ideal setup.

•	Many minions have special abilities, for example, sweep is an Area of Effect attack which hits every enemy on the floor, while spikes will deal damage back to any enemy who hits that minion. Some minions will increase their health or attack every time they hit an enemy or kill an enemy. Other minions receive a buff every time you play a spell card on that floor. If you’re able to make these abilities trigger often, your minions will end up dealing staggering amounts of damage.

•	Spell cards can damage enemies, heal your minions, give them special abilities or resurrect dead minions.

•	You can see a preview of how much damage each minion and enemy will take during the combat phase, and if they’ll die, which is really useful because there’s usually a lot happening including basic attacks and special abilities of multiple units, so you don’t have to worry about doing the maths and can focus on deciding where to summon minions or target your spells.

•	You can play as five clans which have different minions and spells, resulting in significantly different tactics. At the start of each run you’ll pick a primary and secondary clan, which means there are twenty different deck combinations to choose from. My current favourites are Stygian, whose frostbite attacks can stack up like Slay The Spire’s poison for massive damage per turn, and Awoken, whose healing spells are really useful for keeping minions alive. The others are Hellbound, who focus on fire magic, Umbra, who can summon expendable morsel units which will be eaten by your main minions to increase their stats, and Melting Remnant whose minions are wax candles that will die if their burnout timer expires.

•	Between fights you can spend gold to increase minions’ health and attack, or give them special abilities such as multistrike (attacks hit multiple times) or endless, which returns their card back into your deck on death, allowing you to resurrect them. You can also buy spell improvements such as reduce mana cost, increase power, remove consume (can only play once per fight) and holdover, which places the card back on top of your draw pile after being played, effectively letting you play it every turn.

•	You can also find or buy artifacts that give you passive bonuses, encounter random events, heal pyre damage, remove minions/spells or duplicate a minion/spell.

•	Each run takes around an hour to complete, but there is replayability in trying to win with every deck combination, playing through the 25 covenant levels which add new difficulty modifiers (like Slay The Spire’s ascension mode), and daily challenges which have special rules.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

•	The game needs more enemy variety, because you basically fight the same enemies in the same order during every run, with bosses having slightly different abilities. The developers have already started to address this, with a recent update adding two new bosses, but I think they still need to add more.

[h1]The Recommendation[/h1]

Monster Train is a really enjoyable deckbuilder. The focus on playing and upgrading minions makes the gameplay different from other games in the genre. If you like deckbuilders you should play for enough hours to justify a full price purchase.

title: Monster Train
review:
Lots of games have monsters. A few have trains. How many have trains that are actively being defended and attacked by monsters?


[b]This is the first game in my opinion to understand what made Slay the Spire good, without straight up copying slay the spire. [/b] 


[h1][b][u]GAMEPLAY[/u][/b][/h1]


The gameplay is familiar to STS, but unique at the same time.There are 5 clans in the game, and at the start of each run you choose one clan to be your primary, and another to be your secondary. Which one you choose for both will change how things feel a lot. On top of that, each Clan has two Champions you can choose from (basically an insanely strong unit that you upgrade throughout the run).


 In a battle you actively manage 3 floors, and have a static unmanageable fourth floor at the top which is where your health is. Somewhat like a Tower Defense game: enemy monsters will start on the bottom floor, and then whatever isn't killed at the end of the turn will move up a floor until they are killed. If a monster makes it to the top unmanageable floor where your health is (your pyre): an automated battle will occur where your pyre will get hit for X damage that the unit does, immediately followed by Y damage that your pyre does, and it will keep happening until one or the other is dead. If your pyre dies, you lose.


To kill them off before they reach your pyre, you use your own monsters/units to [i]defend [/i]floors. Your units have an amount of space they take up (capacity) to where you cant just stack them all on one floor. On top of that your units also have health to where they can die. Enemy units (outside of special modifiers) will attack whatever unit you have in front first, so it makes positioning your units on each floor important as they have different health values. 


[b]Overall I would give the gameplay a 9.5/10[/b] and would say that its originality in how it approached [i]cardbattle roguelite[/i] with the floor system as the defining reason, and the clan system being a close second.


[h1][b][u]STRATEGY[/u][/b][/h1]


You get a fair amount of say in the type of deck you're going to run, but not so much to where you can force it EVERY single run.You always need to be ready to adapt similar to how you would in any other roguelite, to what the game gives you as rewards.


Due to the floor capacity, you will usually plan out how many unit cards you're going to acquire/upgrade: as there is little use having 30 units if you can only ever place 9 of them at a time. This is one of the bigger areas where you have to adapt each run. If the game keeps giving you [b][i]incant [/i][/b]units (whenever you play a spell gain X), then chances are you should try to tailor towards that. 


You actively need to consider both offense and defense for a floor. If your frontline unit dies, your floor is now possibly in jeopardy which will then likely lead to all of your floors getting overran. Alternatively, if you only focus on defense: your pyre will likely get overran/killed since enemy monsters wont ever die before they get to it. 


I would say that the biggest con is that due to being able to sometimes force a deck: there are some cheesy/op strategies. However, even taking that into consideration you still have to know what you're doing to some degree. 


[b]Overall i would give Strategy an 8/10 as an overall game, and a 9/10 when taking into context that its a card based game.[/b] You have a lot of upfront knowledge/information displayed to you that you can use to influence your decisions, but at the end of the day you can only play the cards you're dealt.


[h1][b][u]DIFFICULTY[/u][/b][/h1]


In my opinion: this is the games best area. If you're absolutely terrible at strategy games, then maybe the difficulty will be too high.


HOWEVER, the game has an amazing difficulty progression. Your first few runs will likely fail to win. After them though you'll likely have a grasp on how the game is played and be able to claim victory! Now you can go up a difficulty level (covenant level) where an additional modifier will be applied to the run. Each time you beat a Covenant level, you will progress to the next one account wide (doesnt matter which clan you chose for the previous clear). The new modifier is now active, on top of all previous modifiers. The difficulty at Cov level 1 is a LOT different than say Cov level 10, and Cov level 25? Completely different approach required, and you better know the ins/outs of the game. If you manage to beat all 25, there are additional challenges that you can attempt. 


YOU DO NOT HAVE TO DO THE HIGHER LEVEL COV IF YOU DONT WANT TO.  If you desire to play at base difficulty 24/7: you can do so. If you want to nonstop play Cov level X nonstop: you can do so. So long as you have it unlocked, you can choose at the start of every run what level you play.


After you play X clan enough you'll likely figure out some strategies that you can attempt to force that will make things a bit easier. However, if you manage to get to Cov level 25 doing that; I challenge you to then play a different clan at level 25. You'll likely find it to be extremely difficult all over again. With 5 clans, 10 leaders, and having to select two clans each run: thats a lot of challenge so long as you're seeking it. 


[b]I can easily say that this game is a 10/10 difficulty [/b]due to the fact that the challenge is there if you want it, its not forced on you if you dont want it, and the progression of the difficulty feels smooth.


[h1][b][u]MISC.[/u][/b][/h1]




[b]Overall I would 100% recommend this game if you enjoy STS. This game is different enough, while still being familiar to be worth it.[/b]


[b]I would also highly recommend it if you enjoy Strategy games that have variation on each playthrough.[/b]

title: Monster Train
review:
I'm not sure if I like it more than the big cheese of the deckbuilding roguelike genre, Slay the Spire, but Monster Train definitely scratches that same itch quite well. It adds some interesting new spins on the formula by splicing in a touch of tower defense DNA and giving me a little MtG nostalgia with its two-color decks. 

It does get a bit busy at times with the multiple waves of enemies doing different attacks and stacks upon stacks of status effects, but the effects are well explained and the tooltips do a good job of reminding you quickly what different statuses are. 

Highly recommended for anyone who liked StS, played Magic the Gathering when Demonic Tutor was a silly controversy, 80's metal stans, or who appreciates solid game mechanics married to polished visuals and a fun theme. Not recommended if the word "hell" gives you the heebie-jeebies or if you're a boring fuddy-duddy who doesn't like a game that doesn't take itself too seriously.

title: Monster Train
review:
In Monster Train, you’re the driver and manager of an iron horse, blazing through a literal hell in order to reclaim the underworld and banish the invaders. It’s Slay The Spire’s loud, ugly cousin. 
Loud because of the bombastic presentation. Ugly because of the array of moving bits, always surprising you with new twists and turns as you explore the randomized tracks laid out before you. 

So while Slay The Spire methodically and slowly builds up an alien mythology with a more elegant approach, Monster Train spends no time hiding behind its fire and brimstone. It wears it on its sleeve. It’s a visual spectacle, exhausting at times -- to the point that a fare almost feels like you’ve been to hell and back yourself. 

It’s messy. But boy is it a blast to play -- every single run, every single time. So much so, that it’s quickly become one of my favorite video games to date, just because of how right it nails both the deck-building aspect and the tower-defence style of gameplay.

When I say ugly I mean that in a more game-design aesthetic sense. All of Monster Train’s moving, uncoordinated parts is actually also its biggest strength, as these nuts and bolts give the gameplay a feeling of limitless variety and depth. A huge flux of available cards, sure. But also thanks to the combination of distinct races you can pick, and all the ways the game turns a strategy on its head with game breaking artifacts and modifiers that change the core rules. 

It’s an extremely rewarding trip, whether you reach the end station or not.

The gist here is that you’re building a card deck of monsters and spells to aid you as you cross the nine circles of hell into the core. 

Regardless of how far you make it, the proceedings are identical each battle: enemies spawn at the first floor of your train, and for each turn you haven’t dealt with them, they move up one level. And before you ask: yes, the invading forces get to go first every turn, making this back-and-forth a challenging balance between defence and offence.

If you play your cards right though, you stop them before they reach the heart at the top and damage it -- saving you from game over and the accompanying trip back to the first circle.

At the end of this hell-spawned-rainbow lurks a final boss, an over-powered foe that’ll prove unbeatable alongside his cohorts unless you’ve spent your travels wisely and adjusted the right variables. It’s a classic example of having to make do with the hand you’re dealt, which has always been one of my favorite design pillars in games. 

And don’t get me wrong, you really are making it up as you go here. Your starting hand may be set in stone, identical each time. But what strengths and weaknesses you gather along the way is entirely up to you and lady luck, as each circle you pass gives a couple of excruciating decisions on what part of your hand you want to adjust. 

Do I spend my hard-earned cash to modify my existing deck of cards with new powers? Do I recruit more monsters or add more spells? Do I remove cards, to avoid old ones clogging up my hand as they lose value in light of new strategies? These kinds of questions represent the meat and potatoes of Monster Train, and often where you’ll unknowingly spend a lot of your time.

If you’re a sucker for these kinds of deck-building experiences, you owe it to yourself to give Monster Train a shot. It’s a great addition to your library regardless of how overflowing it is; with enough eccentricities to make you want to come back to it. A true hall-of-famer, as far as I’m concerned. Highly recommended.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like roguelites, card games, or slay the spire -- this game solves all those itches.  
While I could sit here and compare it to slay the spire, I think it does enough different that makes it stand out completely on its own.

At the start of each run, you choose your primary clan and a secondary clan. You will only get cards from these 2 clans. Your primary clan will give you a hero unit as well that has fantastic synergy with cards from that faction. To top it off, the most recent update adds an unlockable second hero with entirely different synergies! So there's a lot of customization and planning before the game even starts.  Each faction is completely unique as well, and offers various different ways to play.  Wanna use imps to do interesting effects then suicide them for even cooler effects? Want to create giant beefy monsters and heal them up a ton, allowing them to gain thorns and hurt units which attack them? Want to feed little units to a big unit and make him destroy everything? Wanna cast a ton of spells and in doing so buff the living hell out of all your minions? Each faction has some really fun playstyles, and the extra champion expands on this heavily. 

Your train has 3 floors for deploying units. There's a limit to each floor that can be raised, and certain units take more or less space than others. Each turn, a squad of units enters the train at the bottom. They attack your units, then your units attack.  After each turn they ascend one floor.  The fourth floor is the Pyre, which is essentially your health, and units can't be placed here. 

 You also have spells to use at your disposal.  These spells offer a large variety of options, some of which uniquely interact with this game's 'floor' mechanic.   To name a few different types:
*  giving your unit a significant buff but lowering your max mana over the next few turns. (+ damage, and a damage block) 
* entangling a unit, making it so it can't be moved up or down floors. This actually includes your own spells, allowing you to do some really cool things.
*that move a unit up a floor and heal them
*move a unit down a floor and stun them
*give you 3 random minions that are made to be fed to your other minions

Overall, the game has a lot more variety than I was expecting and it's pretty cool discovering all the different synergies.  The card text is VERY clear, and it's easy to tell what interacts with what and in which way.  

Worried about the game being too slow? The game has 4 speed options so you can play it however you want. 


Honestly, if you like roguelites or slay the spire this game is a no brainer.

title: Monster Train
review:
Sadly no, at least not yet. Monster Train runs through an uncanny valley of likeness to games like Slay the Spire, but with a sort of tower defense twist. It's a novel idea, but suffers from a kind of balance malaise that's hard to pin down in specific. And yet, you'll go through runs seeing card after card that doesn't appear to fit into any strategy anywhere. Predominately, runs often blend together with each faction feeling there's only one (maybe two) good builds per faction with a matter of luck to see if you end up with the support to make it happen.

Maybe check in with Monster Train on sale if you're really hurting for another deck builder, you certainly won't start to see the seams until 30+ hours in, and/or after a MT has had another year to develop.

I wish I could recommend Monster Train, I wanted to love it, but it just feels worse and worse as time goes on.

(Edit after playing the Friends & Foes update): Balance issues and UI readability issues remain. The new champions add some new options for specific faction combos, but the underlying problems remain.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like roguelike deckbuilding games like Slay the Spire, you'll like this game as well. 
Monster Train is the better game though, in my opinion. The game feels very polished, and there's so much more replayability.
You select a combination of two factions out of the five currently in the game. Each faction has two distinct heroes to choose from, and each hero has several upgrade paths to choose from.
The many cards in the game can often be upgraded to hilarious proportions by stacking effects, and it very much feels like the game is intended to be played that way. It is still pretty difficult once you start playing the covenant difficulty levels, but not frustratingly so.
Overall a pretty chill game. Highly recommended.

title: Monster Train
review: Very addictive game. I like the format of unlocking the different champions and clans, and finding synergies with the cards is always exciting. My only complaints would be that, like Slay the Spire, you can have some artifacts that do very little and others that are almost game breaking - but I think that's some of the appeal of the rogue-like format. Also, like Slay the Spire, I may get tired of the same musical pieces and background before long, due to the nature of repetition in the game, but for now it looks great and plays well.
