title: Monster Train
review:
I was really enjoying Monster Train, going through the progression and unlocking stuff per usual.

Until I got to the point where i had to play and win Hell Rush. Now usually Monster Train is a great strategy game with tons of options and replayability. However with Hell Rush all that gets thrown out the window and you are expected to speed through the game. If I wanted to play a quick multiplayer game I would pick up Fortnite. I purchased Monster Train to play a strategy game, but now in order to unlock an item I am forced to play this abomination. 

For the record at the time of writing I have played Hell Rush 11 times and won 2 times. Almost all of the times I've lost was due to "Times Up Autobattle", at which point you can no longer play any cards. This is extremely frustrating as when you lose you don't get any progression towards unlocking the item. The winrate is probably not as good as yours, but it doesn't take away from the fact the devs are locking content behind this mode that's different from the game you purchased. They are essentially holding players like me hostage, forcing us to grind out games and put bodies in lobbies for players who enjoy this mode.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train has the same kind of deckbuilding and progression system as Slay the Spire but with some major differences which makes playing it a fun and UNIQUE experience.

You summon monsters which allows for different types of playstyles and tons of different interactions. You got cards which buff monsters and sacrifice them. The monsters themselves also have various effects that can combo with other monsters or spells.
Speaking of different interactions, there are 5 different classes in the game, each with 2-3 distinct strategies. Not only that, but when you start a run, you pick TWO of these classes to take into the run with you. That's insane. It's like Magic: The Gathering where different classes will synergise with each other in different ways. There's SO many different decks you can build in this game.

You know how in Slay the Spire, each card can be upgraded once? Well in this game, each card can be upgraded TWICE (or three times if you get the artifact). It's not as straightforward as Slay the Spire though. The upgrade itself is much simpler. Add +10 power to a spell card. Make it cost 1 less mana.etc. Pretty simple, pretty boring right? Well, these effects can be applied to ANY card. +10 magic power on a multi-hit spell makes it pretty nice...but then I make it cost 1 less and now i'm hitting for 55 damage for 0 mana! Or how about this card which adds two dead monsters to my hand? I can make it cost 0 mana which is neat, but if I add an endless upgrade to it, now I'm adding so many monsters to my train I can barely fit them! Although these card upgrades are simple, they can interact with different cards in different ways, sometimes making cards powerful enough to change your playstyle and that means MORE deck variety!

It's fairly easy to upgrade your cards. The shops are numerous and the upgrades are relatively cheap compared to the amount of money you're getting. In Slay the Spire, the upgrades you can get are often sparse or risky to gain, but makes the game very satisfying to complete. This, combined with the shorter world map, makes each run in Monster Train feel quite short in comparison. However, the trade-off is a much more consistent and calculating experience overall. You can view the entire map from the beginning and make calculated decisions and planning to get you through.

Oh yeah, something that adds to the consistency in these runs are the champions you get. You select 1 of two powerful units to start with depending on which class you pick as your primary. These units can be upgraded during the run in a manner more similar to Slay the Spire, but with different upgrade paths. These effects are so powerful you can usually build your deck around them. Whenever you enter a battle, you START with them in your hand...and they cost NOTHING. Because of this, you can make very reliable strategies with relatively consistent first turns.

Some other things I should mention:
- The 3-floor gameplay in this game is very interesting. It plays like an auto-battler which greatly rewards careful planning.
- The music is incredible. It's probably one of the things that stood out most to me when I started. Props to the team for enlisting Jordan Chin!
- The ability to make any fight harder for a decent reward is another great thing that makes the game more consistent, yet allows for the risk/reward gameplay to still exist.

title: Monster Train
review:
Alrighty, so I really wanted to experience all this game has to offer before I wrote a review on it, and at 79 hours playtime, I have hit that point. So to make things easy, I'll write some pro's/con's and then a final verdict. Skip to the bottom for the TL;DR.

Pros:
- Really interesting take on the rogue deckbuilding genre. There's a lot of new things at play here. Having to manage 3 seperate floors and battles at once can feel a bit overwhelming at first, but it's really enjoyable and easy after about 5 minutes of playing with it.
- You feel really rewarded by making a good deck and picking good synergies.
- Really great time sink for those of us that like more 'passive' gameplay (you can watch youtube and play etc).
- There is a LOT of variety here. There are 5 different clans, every run you pick a primary clan and a secondary clan and are given a deck made of both. The most recent update added some new clan 'leaders' that you can choose from and a bunch of new cards/relics, which also expands the amount of different combinations you can have of primary/secondary clan.
- There are 25 different 'modifiers' to make the run harder that you unlock as you beat each modifier (similar to ascensions in Slay the Spire). This makes for some challenging gameplay towards the later levels.

Cons:
- The runs aren't very long. On average I spend between 15-25 minutes per run (even less without higher difficulty settings). I feel like this could be doubled, or perhaps have an option to go even further once you beat the final boss? (similar to STS heart kills).
- The difficult settings is synced across all clans. For example if I beat difficulty level 25 on one clan, it is unlocked across all clans. It would have made for a LOT more gameplay if I had to go through and beat each level of difficulty on every single clan combination. 
- A lot of the clans don't work well together. Most of the time I find myself removing almost all cards from one of the clans and just using the primary clans cards, as they usually have mechanics unique to each clan, which are not assisted by other clans cards. It would be cool if they allowed you to do runs with just 1 clan, instead of having to take a secondary clan.
- It kind of feels like an early access title. I can't put my finger on it, but overall the game just doesn't feel like a finished product. They have released a bunch of new content since I purchased the game a few months ago, but it still feels incomplete. I hope they keep rolling out content, as the game is interesting, but there isn't enough for me to stick around (apart from trying to get the 50k achievment!)

Verdict: The game is a lot of fun, its a fresh new take on the rouge deckbuilder genre and it has a lot of variety in terms of gameplay. However it suffers from a lot of drawbacks that I listed above (not enough to do once you beat the highest difficulty, which is too easy). If you can get the game on sale, then I think you wont be disappointed. Personally, I'd recommend wishlisting this till either they address the above issues,  or it is on sale.

title: Monster Train
review: Bought this because NL had me addicted to watching him play it, Now i'm addicted to playing it.

title: Monster Train
review:
A powerfully crafted strategic deck building experience, which unfortunately lacks the depth to make it as replayable as it boasts.


By far the most distinct aspect of the game is the lack of random chance compared to most card based games. While there is an element of randomness to the player's build each run the synergies of each deck archetype are very thoroughly present in their cards, thus requiring much less luck to establish a functioning synergy overall. Although progression is mildly gated by getting stronger unlocks over time it's completely possible to beat the first difficulty tier of the game with the default setup, unlike most roguelites. 

The main element of random chance is in getting a good draw on the first turn, as depending on the player's deck archetype they may need a second unit to defend their champion. So if they do not draw that second unit or draw a unit that isn't good at defending, the player is basically unable to protect the first floor on their beginning turn without their champion being knocked out. While this can be recovered from especially if the player just waits and puts their champion on the second floor, it severely damages the players position from the very beginning.

The game offers a refreshing amount of diversity with how players can upgrade their cards to influence their variables in completely different ways. While each individual archetype of cards doesn't have a huge amount of variety the ability to upgrade them in various ways adds a lot to the experience. Especially since players use two archetypes at once, which also adds an interesting element of synergy with pairing together the gimmicks of the different deck types.

There's a solid amount of detail to the art, animations and the music is actually somewhat noticeable. Although the fact that the game roots its world in cult mythology is bland, but at least the way the different mythological sides are portrayed is comparatively unique. It is also awkward that the game doesn't supply an explanation for how the world keeps resetting everytime the player wins or loses, and instead acts like each attempt is the last hope in this world.


Unfortunately the game really doesn't have the replayability that it boasts. While there is some variety to the cards in the deck archetypes there's not enough to stop players from generally being able to get the same deck each run nearly. The game has a lot of blatantly powerful and blatantly less powerful cards and upgrade choices, so if the player becomes aware of these it isn't long before every run essentially becomes the same meta.

The game isn't actually very interactive as all players can do is tweak the fight with abilities while all the units battle on their own. There's almost nothing players can do to change their unit standing order, the level they're on or the units they're attacking. It almost feels like a mobile clicker game in this respect due to the general lack of fundamental ways players can influence combat. 

Often the type of enemy unit the player is facing doesn't even matter; while they do have unique abilities their unique abilities usually aren't important enough for the player to change their fighting strategy. Even if it is, there's a limited amount of cards the player has which significantly affects specific enemies, so whether the player could even focus a specific enemy if they wanted to is situational. Most of those cards are just generic damage spells, there's actually very little cards in this game that inflict any form of strategic debuff or buff.

While at first the difficulty is fairly well balanced, the higher difficulties rapidly reach the point where players will basically only win if they happen to acquire the most optimal deck and upgrades. As at higher difficulties; enemies deal so much damage, have so much health and come in such large numbers that players cannot survive unless they happened to acquire a very specifically powerful deck beforehand. Even a deck that is overwhelmingly winning can easily lose the very last level because of how overbearing the so called difficulty becomes at that point. 

Between finding strong cards, finding strong upgrades, and getting good draws each turn; the entire run just comes down to random chance whether the player has gotten lucky enough to amass the super powerful deck required to out-damage race the last stage. Which unfortunately makes the later difficulties entirely dependent on luck, the result often only becoming evident in the final stage when the numbers spike; and suddenly a completely functional strategically designed deck can't function anymore.


It's still a fun game with some good mechanics to it, but the overall lack of interactivity in combat along with the lack of card variety and obvious metas makes it fail by its own claim of having infinite replayability. The lack of proper balancing in the later difficulties also causes the game to become less fair and more chance dependent the more players progress.

I've played quite a few deckbuilder games and this is definitely my second favorite. It introduces some unique gameplay elements and there are a wide range of viable strategies which make each run a little different. Almost every card can be viable in the right situation and there are loads of decisions to make each run. Also, it gets the difficulty level right in that each run feels winnable but it is a challenge to do so. 

Overall: 96.2/100

title: Monster Train
review:
Some games are so good they inspire an entire generation of games. The most notable example of this is obviously Dark Souls, but I would argue on a smaller scale Slay the Spire spawned an era of turn based deckbuilder videogames. In the same way the best "Soulslike" games are not mere cheap ripoffs, but rather build on and advance the ideas pioneered by their namesake, Monster Train stands head and shoulders above other "Spirelikes" as in my opinion one of if not THE best deckbuilders out there. 

Without going into detail on the specific mechanical distinctions between the two, the part of Monster Train that most improves on the Slay the Spire formula is the mix and match mechanic where instead of getting locked into a single class you are given five different "decks", from which you select a primary and a secondary, This combined with a few other smaller design choices ultimately results in an absurdly high amount of build diversity. I'm 80 hours in and still discovering new combinations and strategies I'd never considered. Sometimes the game does feel like it has strategies that are a bit broken, but I think that's less of a criticism and more of a design philosophy, it feels like the emphasis is always erring more on the side of letting the player have fun breaking the game than creating a strict competitive balance, and frankly, I think it's more fun that way.

title: Monster Train
review:
A finely polished deck-building game.   It's a pleasure to play, but it's also  in desperate need of more content.    

[b]The Big Con:[/b]

+ This is a huge: After three runs, you'll see all the enemy content this game has to offer.   There are no different levels, the boss rotation is anemic, the enemies are the same except for a random stat modifier.    Please, devs, mix it up!      

[b]All the pros:[/b]

+ Visuals, audio, and UX are very polished for an indie title.  It's very enjoyable to interact with the game. 
 Your minions make satisfying crunchy sounds.  The graphics are engaging and informative.  The fallen/angelic soundtrack fits your ride into hell perfectly.

+ Card design.   Lots of interesting combos await your discovery.

+ Strategy.  Your train consists of three floors, and each one is a place where battle can be waged.   There's a bit of tower-defense strategy here, as you try to anticipate when enemies will hop floors and optimize your resources accordingly.


The inevitable comparison to [i]Slay the Spire[/i]:  Monster Train is superior in every way, imho.   Game mechanic-wise, it's a v2 of Slay the Spire, with more gameplay variances and a better multimedia experience.


(edit 1 min after posting: grammar.  sigh.)

title: Monster Train
review:
Ya got 3 lanes, you want to stop enemies from passing them. You can use spells and units to do so. 
There are many build archetypes you can use, interesting mechanics, and almost nothing is overtly tedious unless you purposefully limit yourself. 
The game starts easy and gets very difficult as you move up in covenant. (the name of the difficulty system) 
There are challenges for the highest difficulty level. 

Only at the last covenants and for some niche builds will you really NEED rng on your side. For the most part, most builds that are good are not too hard to come by and you don't need a 100% perfect build to win, as long as you make the right choices on the journey. But again, on the last covenant levels, you will need some rng. 

It's a good game with good money-to-time value. At this point of the game's life, I can recommend it without feeling like someone might feel scammed by the game.

title: Monster Train
review:
I bought the game for 20% off at £15.59 2 weeks after its release, the last day of the release sale.

The game both plays and looks very similarly to Slay the Spire. It's a deck building rougelite with "floors".
As for the story, hell has frozen over and you, playing as factions from hell, try to reignite the fires. Heaven has sent beings to stop you.

I "beat" the game 2 hours in meaning I defeated the final boss for the first time but doing so I unlocked Covenant, effectively the same as Slay the Spire's Ascension.


- (Content) Because it is so similar to Slay the Spire, it also has its pitfalls: dead runs from the start and limited variation. However, there is slightly more variation due to having 5 clans and choosing a primary and ally clan each time means there's many unique ways to theme your deck.

~ (Story) There's a small story about the wars between Heaven and Hell.
~ It is VERY similar Slay the Spire. It has copied: artefacts, upgrades, Ascension and risk vs. reward fights just to name a few. Perhaps they are a staple to this relatively new genre? There are a few unique mechanics though: the levels on the train and the 2-class system. 

+ (Audio) Music sounds like a battle between heaven and hell. Strong clangs battling heavenly strings. The sound effects are also satisfying clangs or metal or blood squelches.
+ (Content, Replayability) Covenant ranks extend the life of the game making you want to repeat it with added difficulties.
+ (Replayability) The game is quick to pick (back) up and I definitely will be coming back to it in the future to further my Covenant rank and get victories with primary/ally clan combinations that I haven't gotten.
+ Discovering new combinations of cards and then beating the game gives a good sense of accomplishment.

Best: Building up a massive multistrike backline and spikes frontline combo and destroying a boss.
Worst: It feels too much like Slay the Spire and so doesn't feel fresh. If I'd played this first, it probably would be the other way round.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
This one really caught me by surprise. The comparisons to Slay the Spire are inevitable. But this game does enough new, and does it so well. That I think it deserves to stand on it's own.

The factions are all really unique, The ability to go into a run pairing two of the 5 factions together is really neat and adds for a lot of cool combinations.  And combinations are what this game is all about. A lot of other deck-builders or roguelikes depend on "synergies" between items.  But many of those make good synergies rare, bu not Monster Train. This game lets you get down into amazing combinations of cards and units really quickly!

So yes, it's like Slay the Spire. But it's so good, and does enough cool new things, that I'm sure we will be seeing many, many games come out that are "like Monster Train".  Because it's broken into it's own category of game.

title: Monster Train
review:
A FANTASTIC roguelite, with a combination of Slay the Spire and Magic the Gathering!

So much variation and customization between the combination of decks of cards and creatures you can bring.  Choose a "base deck" for your champion (choices between red high offense decks/creatures all the way to purple spell heavy Stygian Guard, and more), as well as a second deck for synergy of your choice.  Upgrade and combine them for absolutely BROKEN combos (If you are lucky/smart with your events and upgrades).  Profit and enjoy.

Runs are typically between 30 minutes to a little over an hour, and there's many pieces of this game to unlock just through playing the game to make your runs even more variable and crazy.  So much replayability, as is expected from a great Roguelite.  I'm looking forward to future content from this, and how this game plans to grow.

I personally hope to see more variation with Ice Cavern events, and even more decks and creatures in the future!  Absolutely loving this game so far

Got addicted to this game for awhile because it does a very good job of presenting choices of risk & reward alongside a crap ton of variety. 

Plays a bit like Slay the Spire but much faster in its, battle-choice of loot-event-repeat. Formula can get supremely addicting and it just now released content that added twice the content on top of its existing content. 

Slight balance issues with some starting hero combos (og wax burnout hero /reform cards too OP IMHO) but just so many choices that make every run quite flavorful. Highly recommend!

I love -- love --  Slay the Spire. Played it for a few hundred hours on the Switch. But eventually everything gets old.

This scratches that itch. It has enough similarities that you feel like you "know how to play" right at the start. But at the same time, it's different enough that it feels fresh and completely new. 25 hours in at time of writing and I feel like I'm still just starting to explore all my options. We'll see if it really goes the distance but it's already worth the money and then some.

title: Monster Train
review:
Slay the Spire meets Boss Monster.

I'm playing this after they released the Friends & Foes update (for free) and there's so much content that I barely have scratched the surface of.

There's so much variety in deck building with the different clans. This is also minor but I like how beating a run gives the cards you used in that run a fancy border because you "mastered" them. This encourages you to use different cards in subsequent runs to master them all.

The music is also pretty good! I've been finding myself still hearing it in my head, long after I stopped playing.

The balance of gradually strengthening your deck is probably not as finely tuned as Slay the Spire but it's still a very fun game!

title: Monster Train
review:
Usually when you say a game is "like another game" that's a bad thing. 

Not so with Monster Train.

This game is like Slay the Spire, but is different enough that you don't feel like you may as well just go back to playing Slay the Spire. So if you enjoy card battlers you *will* like this game.  If you liked slay the spire but have completed everything and exhausted all the good mods, this is your new home, for quite a while as near as I can tell 30 hours in.

title: Monster Train
review:
Game is actually rigged. I found an exploit where you could Alt+F4 during a battle, and restart the game to resume the battle.

The point? If your a going to lose, you can try again, and try new decisions, and sequences.

I've used this method to test causation tactics, and note even if i have a GOD tier crafted deck with insane cycles combos, the game will FORCE you to lose with NO decision resulting in a win. The reason? To kee you playing obviously.

Yes i beat level 25 - i could do it again, but it takes approx 50-80 attempts, for no real reason other than the game will set you up with conditions that forces you to lose. Even if it not intentional, it still is there. I've had enough with games that claim they use "RNG" - yet you can replicate a battle, and the sequence of "Random" is always the same proving that there isn't a true RNG logic being ran but rather a preset sequence logic, from there you can see that the battle is decided BEFORE you even play it. So what's the point? The out come is fix'ed.

Games like this you don't play, they play you.

title: Monster Train
review:
Would I recommend Monster Train? Yes, yes I would.

Monster Train is card game, a roguelite and a weird tower defense game in a single package. You travel along a the desolate wastes of Hell in your little four storied train, trying to defend the last spark of hellfire from forces of Heaven. There are eight stops along your journey where you must defend your train from the angels and their ilk. These angelic armadas assault your afformented abyssal ark from the first floor in waves, slowly progressing toward the fourth, where your spark presides. To win the game, the spark must survive through all the encounters. 

To defend the spark, you will take on the role of a strong, unique demon and marshall the forces of two daemonic clans to your cause. You have the Hellhorned who represent pure demonic strength, the Awoken who are the healers and tanks of you posse, the Stygian mages, The Umbral who constantly spawn small creatures and then procede to devour them for buffs and the weird candle-people of the Melting Remnant who possess very short and timed lives, but are enormously powerful (and have a tendency to come back from the dead). Because you are always combining two clans on every run, there is an enormous amount strategic variety in the game. And to make things better, every clan now has TWO champion demons to choose from. Oh my!

Every run you will also be able to upgrade your champion, your units and your spells not to mention all the random encounters, artifacts to gather and even adding mutators to the mix. There are currently 20 difficulty levels called covenants in the game to make it even more challenging and varied. There is A LOT to see in this package.

After each run you are presented with you stats, that you can share with the whole community, along with unlocks for the clan(s) you brought along. These unlocks include golden card backgrounds, new cards and new artifacts that fit the playstyle of the chosen clans. Grinding all the clans to max level and unlocking every golden card will take a good amount of time. After 22 hours of playing, I have all of my clans at almost the midway point, so I will have to play for at least another 20 hours to see what the max level rewards are. 

The game also boasts fun game modes and tracking. You can embark on community challenge runs and create your own, you can race you friends in a frenzied rush to the finishline, you can compete on global and friend-list based leaderboards. I've been sticking to the basic game mode, so I can't really comment on all of these, but they are there if you really need and want them.

Monster Train is a quality package that easily sits next to Slay the Spire on the pantheon of great card games. It's very robust, feels skill-based instead of driven by too much luck, is very fun to look at and has a banging soundtrack. The runs aren't too long and you can sometimes pull off very fun and degenerate combos. The clans feel varied, if not exactly even in power level (the Melting Remnant is stupid good and fun), but it doesn't really hamper the experience. The devs released a massive patch for the game that might have been paid DLC for many other games, but we got it for free - and the game isn't even that expensive to begin with.

I find almost no fault in Monster Train. Maybe some weirder strategies could be better compared to some of the more powerful ones, maybe we could have more variety in enemies and upgrades and maybe we could have a few more songs in the soundtrack. To be honest, I don't really care as the game is spectacular and probably one of the best modern pc games (for fans of card games and roguelites) that you can currently get.

I know it is for me.

I'm not as sold on the tiered nature of the fights. I often find enemies running past my units after 1 turn quite frustrating when the bosses fight to the death. I also find the UI a little cluttered you could be playing cards only to realise one enemy unit of 12 you are dealing with actually has the keyward to wreck your whole strategy. I also find the art style on enemies very samey. Makes it hard to remember which enemies have what abilities at a glance.

These are minor gripes however still a good game. Scratches that RNG roguelike card game itch perfectly.

title: Monster Train
review:
I've really enjoyed this game so far. It scratches that "Magic the Gathering(tm)" itch, without the abject poverty that comes along with playing it. I personally only play single player so I can't comment on the multiplayer aspects of the game.

This game strikes a happy medium between "puzzle game", "deck building card game" and "rogue". It also manages to do it all fairly well. Now you're definitely not going to find the sheer depth that is an established TCG here. There are maybe 80 unique cards per faction and 5 factions total, with a small pool of non-faction cards. (See the similarities already?). Each faction has 2 major heroes and each of those have 3 different variations that you get as you level up.

There isn't too much left to the RNG either in most of the runs I've done. Your deck being shuffled is the biggest, after that it'll usually be some trinket you've picked up that maybe procs n% of the time. All in all I've not found myself cursing it even nearly as often as I'd curse at the sky playing a TCG. 

In the end it all comes down to cleverly drafting your deck. You're going to start the run with a small card pool but you'll gain cards as rewards for events, battles and locations. It's this drafting that really becomes the meat and potatoes of the game. Learning how to manage your card pool, what to add and when to cull is the real root of all of this. If you've got experience with TCGs, this'll all be like riding a bike.

The graphics are colorful and a little cartoony; they're fun, not schlocky. Sound is adequate though for long play throughs you'll get tired of the same tracks over and over. I honestly turned the music down after the first few games and I don't miss it.

I can heartily recommend this game to anyone who loves TCGs.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is so good it makes Darkest Dungeon, Slay the Spire and Teamfight Tactics (each the titan of their genre) entirely obsolete in comparison. It's not every day a game is so innovative and so perfectly executed that it dethrones entire, brand-new genres of gaming all by itself - and every fan of the aforementioned games or card games in general owe it to themselves to give Monster Train a try!

The game looks, sounds, controls and has a soundtrack that is exactly what you'd expect from it and it runs like a charm even on integrated graphics cards (tested on an Intel HD 4000-equivalent). I wish there were more keyboard controls but I can't complain about the current control scheme either.

Other than needing to skip the non-playing introduction video (black screen) with a mouse click, it works flawlessly on Linux through Steam Play. Being an Unity game, it's confounding why there isn't a native download of the game at all!

title: Monster Train
review:
Edit as of the Friends and Foes update: The new content is nice and adds a decent bit of variety to runs, but it isn't enough on it's own to sway my opinion. However, considering that the developer is adding the things the game desperately needs, I am feeling fairly positive that they know what they're doing. Friends and Foes is a great start and I'm confident the game is going to be worth the purchase, assuming it isn't already worth it for you personally.

More updates like Friends and Foes please!
I'm going to leave my original review up unchanged below this edit, for the curious and since a lot of the issues I brought up are still problems for Monster Train.


The game's fine. The core gameplay is solid and different enough to distinguish it from other deckbuilder type games. The biggest problem is just how quickly it all becomes stale. There aren't enough events, cards, enemies, relics, et cetera. So the game ends up repeating things a lot. 
I waited a while to write this review, because I was waiting for the Wild Mutations patch to see if that would spice thing up. Sadly, no such luck. The new "content" adds very little to the game's overall variance and the new mutations are really just a challenge mode that you can opt into and customize, at the expense of it no longer counting for progression. 

Overall, I think this game is good fun for a 10-20 hours, though your mileage may vary. I can't bring myself to fully recommend it in it's current state though. Additionally, the most recent update leaves me feeling like they might not really have any fresh ideas left.
developer_response: Appreciate the thoughts! And I'm glad we got you for at least 20 hours and hopefully enough to be worth your money. Also - definitely would say you should look forward to our next update, it's taking a bit more time than Wild Mutations did, but we've got some fun stuff coming up that I believe will hit exactly what you're looking for.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
I was a big fan of Slay the Spire and so was drawn to this game after hearing of it's similarities. This game puts a lot less emphasis on the deck building elements, as each summoned monster will have recursive effects and you always start each combat with your champion monster in the starting hand. On top of this, enemies only do damage to 'you' by reaching the top floor, giving you three turns to deal with a chunky deck.

There is a lot of variety, as they have updated the game for free with new factions, bosses and cards. Unlocking gold frames, higher difficulty levels and the starting unlocks are great at reasons to keep playing. There's a few fun leaderboard based modes too, including the ability to make your own custom challenges.

Very addictive, can be relaxing on low difficulty or next to impossible on high difficulties.

title: Monster Train
review: If you like magic the gathering, or slay the spire or both, this game is for you. It has hours of content, with two free updates that brought even more. There are 5 factions with 2 champion and unique cards per champion to chose from and you chose 2 different factions per run, giving a huge amount of combinations to play. Not only that, you can add a little bit of madness to the game with the wild mutations content, there are daily challenges, hell rush where you face off against other players to be the first to the end, and the ability to send challenge links to friends. The game is one of the best deckbuilders I've ever played, and I 1000% recommend it.

title: Monster Train
review:
I'm not a great card game player but bought this one as it looked cool, had a high player rating and I like trains (yeah I'm a simple man!).

This game is surprisingly fun and entertaining. After 7 hours of "I take a quick look at this game" at 3am, I can only recommend it!


EDIT (@36 hrs in the game)
After a few more hours, digging deeper into the game I found some negatives, though.
The game suffers from 'typical trading card game issues': totally random card selection decides if one can win a run, or condemned to lose it. Some say "it's a card game, not a puzzle", but in fact, card games are logic games (just like puzzles...), therefore shouldn't be unwinnable scenarios - one's skills should decide. So it's frustrating a bit...
For example, I had a Hellhorned run with several "sacrifice your imp..." (and some other useless-for-the-initial-hand) cards offered, but zero imps...
Another time for Melting Remnant (favourite btw) I didn't get *any* "Reforming" cards. Zero. For the whole run, so I lost at the final boss for having a too low unit throughput (2 random per turn only -champion skill-). And I knew I'm gonna lose at the last card roll... Frustrating.

Long story short, random is far too emphasized, IMHO the game should focus more on skills / experience / strategic decisions, rather than random.
Would be great to have card selection, or at least a few tokens or something for every run, so one can reroll the offered cards to another (100% different...) set of cards to choose from, or such.

Maybe this is on me, maybe the math is there and every run is winnable - I don't know, devs didn't make a statement, but if all and every runs are winnable, would be great to save runs and being able to replay them, with making different decisions. would be happy to see someone defeating the scenario I found impossible. We live, we learn...


[Ended my career in this game due to the covenant lvl10 handicap. I don't like it, I find it too limiting. Still a great game, still recommended though]

title: Monster Train
review:
A fun and atmospheric deck-building dungeon run type game. At first, the number of mechanics can seem a little overwhelming, but it's actually not too hard to get a grasp of them and start to really appreciate the complex interactions they create, particularly with the clear descriptions of mechanics when you hover over friendly and enemy units.
The art, effects and brief, but evocative descriptions create a vivid, absorbing setting that feels really unique. Devils riding a train powered by the last shard of the destroyed heart of hell, being assaulted by zealous, oppressive angels? That's an awesome setting. The clans of devils all have a really unique identity in both appearance and mechanics, and pairing different clans gives you loads of unique deck building. Even two runs with the same clan pairing can end up going very differently.
Big thumbs up from me! Great game to play and entertaining to watch streams of too!

title: Monster Train
review: Holy S**t man, this is one of the best games out there. It feels so good to play. title: Monster Train
review:
I was a slay the spire player with several hundred hours in the game who had completed every achievement and was really looking for a fresh take on a rogue-lite card game. I just wanted to feel the same way I did when I first started playing Slay the Spire: Marveled by the game design, puzzled by the interactions I was in control of, and just in general enthralled by the seemingly endless replayability. 

While I'm only 25 hours deep into Monster Train at this point, I have to admit that I am extremely pleased to say that it is doing all of those things for me. If you're a Slay the Spire player, you'll recognize many of the effects instantly; HOWEVER, there is so much unique content here and so many differences and nuances in the specific mechanics and interactions of this game that skill in one does not transfer perfectly to skill in another. I'm getting to relieve the glory days of tinkering around with different classes, trying to figure out what works, and foiling out my deck. 

It's reasonably priced, it's got endless replayability, it's clever, it's witty, it's just genuinely fun. If Rogue-lite cards games are your genre of choice, I honestly believe that you would be letting yourself down if you did not give this game a chance.

title: Monster Train
review: Never left a review before. But this game deserves my incredibly rare praise. Don't remember putting 140 hours in this game because I was pogging out so hard. Love the factions, love the strategy, love the developer's love and support for the title. I hope to see so much more from them in the future. The perfect blend of rng and strategy for my taste.

If you like roguelike card games you need to buy this one.
The goal of the game is not to win once but to win the game 25 difficulty levels plus the 15 expert challenges after that.
In this way, you will understand and exploit the game to win and enjoy the complexity of the gameplay.
You do unlock some extra cards and factions, but understanding the game is what makes the difference between winning and losing.

I'm having a blast playing this game.
You have 5 factions that play very different from each other and with the last update you add a second champion for each faction for even more variety.
To add even more variety, you have quite a few modifiers to give your runs a bit more of a challenge or even make the run easier.
You even have kind of a multiplayer option with Hell Rush, in which you compete with other players in the same run with some modifiers.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is an incredible game that while semi luck based due to its rougelite nature balances this out by giving the player many choices, from what card/relic you obtain, which path to take, to how to upgrade your deck of cards - this makes the player feel very much in control.

It is very polished in terms of UI/Art/Music and tries to be unique by introducing the idea of clan combos instead of playing one character per run. While this adds variety and makes the game stand out from others (such as Slay the Spire), it could use a slight change to ensure better synergy between the clans, as often sticking to one clan seems to be a safer option. Other than that, gameplay wise the game provides increasing difficulty through its 25 "covenant ranks" which per level make a mechanic in the game less favourable to the player, and with modifiers/challenges/semi multiplayer mode, there is plenty of content to play through.

The game is very much worth its price, as it looks, plays, and sounds fantastic and has a large following with frequent updates. If you like rougelites and/or card strategy I would recommend you give this game a try.

title: Monster Train
review: I really do love this game. I bought it because I saw a review that said it was very much NOT a knockoff of Slay the Spire or others like it. It is a wonderful rogue like card building game built in the same essence of STS but it has it's own unique flair. It's easy to pick up, a little difficult to understand the minutia but you'll get it after the first run or so. I played about 8 hours before I actually "completed" my first run and it feels like I've barely scratched the surface. I can't recommend it enough for the price point, the depth, the ease, and the mastery! It was perfect when I wanna play something while I'm working or don't wanna jump into a full RPG or something. I got it for 18$ and it was worth it, but I'd pay up to 25 considering there's DLC and free updates always coming.

title: Monster Train
review: Everybody compares this game to Slay the Spire, and understandably so, but this game shouldn't be standing in any other game's shadow. If you like StS you'll love it, of course, but I personally believe that this is the perfect entry point for deckbuilders and roguelites alike. If you don't actively hate those genres, you really owe it to yourself to give Monster Train a chance to win you over.

UPDATE: 
After spending 100 plus hours, this game has taken over my Slay the Spire time. To be honest, I spent a good 400 hours across all platforms on Slay the Spire, so I was ready for something new. Monster Train has filled that void and I now love this game. It is way deeper than I thought when I first reviewed the game. I can't wait for the newest update. 

If you like these types of games, then get Slay the Spire and Monster Train. They are the best two in the genre.

title: Monster Train
review:
CHOO-CHOO - get aboard the Monster Train!

Okay, lame intro, I know.. But this game is not lame, I promise.  So, before I oversell it because, quite frankly, I'm hooked on this game and a bit biased..  I should probably let you know that this is a very niche type of game.  The best way I could describe it is as Magic The Gathering meets Defense Grid, with a dash of Monster Mash for personality.

In this CCG-TD hybrid, you are on a quest to reach the center of Hell on a train, full of monsters..  No surprise there.  What IS surprising is just how addictive the gameplay mechanics can get.  The random elements add a new challenge each time and there's many ways to play if the standard runs don't do it for you after a while.

Without getting too deep into the mechanics, there's a lot of resource management and deck balancing involved so, if you're into card games, real-time strategy, or anything of the sort, you'll definitely find something here to scratch the itch.  You'll get the opportunity to upgrade your champion (choosing one of two paths each time) and bump up your fire (i.e. mana/land), card draw, and train car/floor capacity (+1 at a time so choose wisely).  There are different playable races and tons of unlockables.  Each race/class offers a whole new gameplay style (and ways to break things in your favor).  

For example, Umbra has a bunch of squishy monsters that, at first glance, seem rather useless.  They tend to start off weak and get really strong late in each battle and overall run.  For me, discovering how to create a 

There's a lot of built-in balancing with upgrades, too.  You have two primary types of cards, monster and spell, each with a spell cost (represented by the flames, the fire in your train's furnace, a.k.a. your output each turn).  Say, you upgrade a spell to make it three times stronger, chances are you'll increase the casting cost and/or add "consume" (removes the card from play rest of the battle) or "purge" (removes the card from play for the rest of the run) as an effect.  Monsters can get really beefy...  But, buff them up too much, and you'll find yourself having trouble fitting them on your train or having the opportunity to play them at all.

Each run has randomized elements, making every session rather unique.  At the risk of sounding cliche, one could say there is a bit of "rogue lite" fun to be had.  For added fun, there's a slew of mutators you could add to make things even harder (or easier, if you feel lazy or just want to feel godlike).  After you do enough runs, you'll see some similar patterns but increasing your Covenant Rank will add extra layers of challenge, plus familiar battles will bring new mods (i.e. armored enemies or heavy penalties for relying on cheese tactics).

Before I forget, let me tell you about artifacts.  Artifacts give you permanent effects and buffs that carry on for the rest of your run.  This concept isn't anything groundbreaking but, man, does it change your gameplay immensely.  Score the right artifact and a struggling run can be turned around.  One of my favorite artifacts I believe is called the Iron-Willed Horn.  That one let's you stock up your fire/mana from turn to turn, which opens up HUGE options for strategies.  Some of the other fun ones have randomly-triggered debuff and damage effects, help you change monster positioning, or do clutch things like dazing and rooting enemies.

I'm a multiplayer guy but I have to say that the singleplayer here is deeply satisfying.  There is, fortunately, a growing a community and some multiplayer goodness.  This is where the game's potential is really going to shine long-term.

First, we have daily challenges.  You get one shot to complete a challenge or score as high as you can given a set of special rules.  Some things you may see in the mix include spells hit random targets, all units are fragile (one-hit kills), you start with a mansion (more train/floor capacity), or you lose more fire/mana each turn,  Some of these challenges are brutal, and others help you discover fun new ways to play a class or combo things up.  Regardless of your game mode, you always start off with a random deck based on your class (and sometimes strictly what you have unlocked so far), so these added rules keep things even spicier.

I really dig that, even though you're not competing against other players directly, you'll see real-time updates of up to ten players who are playing the challenge at the same time as you.  You'll see ghosts/avatars of the other players as well, giving you a sense of pacing and being in a world that's alive.  Finally, at the end of your run, you get to see how your score compares to other players.  Things like reduced Pyre damage (oh, that's the thing you have to protect at the front of your train) or beating bosses in less turns will earn you big points.

The second MP mode is Hell Rush.  I love the idea here.  It's a timed rush mode against other players.  The most I have faced off against is two other players.  Usually, there's a bit of a wait.  During the day, I could get a match going in a few minutes but, during the whee hours, it's tougher.

Hell Rush is intense.  You have limited time to complete each area in your run.  This is satisfying but also very frustrating, as you have to make your upgrade purchases and other pre-battle decisions super fast.  You get around three minutes to carefully make these choices, including which, if any, cards you will remove and which units and artifacts to go with.  To me, that part is very frustrating because it automatically puts folks with faster connections and computers at an advantage.  Your load screens, animations, everything counts against the clock.

What's worse is that there is no lobby so you just wait until someone joins your session (or you get lucky and find one).  Then a short timer starts and that is the window for someone else to join..  Or not.

So, it's not a perfect game but I would still give it a 5/5 just because it's so unique, fun, and highly replayable.  Just allow me to be bitter about how unfair Hell Rush is.  I think it would be saved by having a true lobby system with session hosts.. And customizable timers.  Three minutes has you scrambling to make decisions and make your moves, and it really takes away from the fun.  I would much prefer to see a turn timer rather than an overall timer for each area.  It's just not a design decision that makes sense to me, especially when you're already hard-pressed to find a match.

Before I beat a dead horse, the worst part about the timer is that, once you run out of time, everything goes into-autobattle.  You can't play a single spell or monster...  So you lose because you aren't some cracked-out youngin' with a super-fast computer, not because you lack skills.  Feels like us old folks who like to think a little more or lack in the "twitch" department are SOL.  LOL

But I digress...  That's probably my one and only gripe and, fortunately, that's something future updates can fix.  I really hope that this game takes off and maybe gets the "platform treatment".  It is well-suited for a seasonal approach like, say, DotA Underlords (another one of my more recent faves).

Get the game, tell some friends, let's spread the word.  I'd love to see the community expand so we can see the true potential of this game unlocked.  It'd be great to see more head-to-head options to keep things fresh.  Really, in spite of my belly-aching, Hell Rush is fun..  Just make sure you play it fully-caffeinated and focused because, as it currently stands, even the slightest brain fart or distraction will cost ya!

Okay, okay..  I had to get that one last jab at Hell Rush but that's not because it sucks..  It's because it could be soooo much better and more inclusive than what it currently is.  I love a good challenge though, so I'll keep going back, even if it's kind of unfair. =oP

In short, get on the train...  THE MONSTER TRAIN, yo.

;

title: Monster Train
review:
I can't believe I did not review this game yet. Here we go:
1) It's totally worth the price. The amount of gameplay ensures a good time.
2) Shiny Shoe devs, in this day and age, are actually putting out a free content expansion. Preposterous.
3) You collect cards by unlocking them not hoping to get them in a gotcha pack. So there is a bit of incentive for collectors (people are motivated by collecting stuff) while the deckbuilders actually get to build decks right away. In short: are you tired of free-to-play? Try buy it all at once and enjoy now.
4) Lovely visual design... and... I mean if you're from Czechia you kinda have to love that puppety animation. :D It's gorgeous.
5) Mutations are fun and I have to say I love the Daily challenge format, very clever and entertaining.
6) It's not competitive, but you can engage in multiplayer (did not try that). No stress.
7) Bonus point for cute imps. Also, I looove to feed them Gorgers.

If any Shiny Shoe dev will read this: Thank you for the amount of post-production attention you are paying to this game. It really show your love for it and respect for your players.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster train is just a great game for anyone loving games like Slay The Spire. It is a bit more forthcoming and honestly less difficult than Slay The Spire, while still giving plenty of challenge. Just boot up a game, and if you can't commit 1 - 2 hours, just stop halfway through and the game will automatically have your progress saved. 
It is like candy crush for intelligent people. Addictive. But without the microtransactions.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game inherits what's the best from Slay the Spire and exceeds it in many ways. With 2 out of 5 clans to choose from each run and the introduction of minions in the placement of 3 lanes on the train, the game offers more depth and variety in its core gameplay. Furthermore, the developer aims to update the game regularly, continually adding more substantial contents to enjoy. At the time of my writing, they have brought mutators to the game, with extra heroes for each clan on the way.

Overall, this has been the most solid purchase on Steam in 2020 so far, and I cannot recommend it enough to everyone who is in love with this genre.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is so close to amazing.  I enjoy every aspect of this game besides one.  For me the replay value is lacking.  I dislike that the increase in difficulty doesnt mean new enemies or additional stages. It means less resources.  This is great if you enjoy a challenge or unlocking 'achievements' but for me it doesnt motivate me to rank up.  I would love to see an increase in coins and the enemies are stronger so you have more of a challenge but at the same time you have more options and more epic battles.  Or when you rank up, there are more enemies, but shops are better.  Im a pretty casual gamer so take my review with a grain of salt.  I still highly recommend this game.  I just cant see myself playing for 100+ hours or staying up late at night to beat a hard covenant rank so I can see whats next.   I know whats next.  Everything is the same but now restock costs more. ect.

Id like to add, I know I can add mutations to get what im asking for (more intense and epic battles with increased stats on both sides) but the sense of progression still isnt there.   

I want to leave by saying I love most of this game.  The strategy required, the amazing feeling when you get the right cards and completely destroy the enemies, the art style and detailed monsters, the creative clan qualities and how each clan requires a different play style, I could go on and on.  Thanks for reading

review:
After my first few hours of playing Monster Train, although I enjoyed it, I wasn't sure why it was so popular. It took me a while to understand the basic combat and card rules, so the results seemed to be based too much on RNG. I think the game could do with an intro tutorial or even a few help screens to explain the basic rules and some of the terms that I'm not familiar with.

After making a few unsuccessful runs I started to learn more of the strategies and I began to appreciate how good this game is. Although it could be called a Slay the Spire clone, for me it is better than StS. I enjoyed playing StS but felt at times it was too RNG dependent. 

Developer support is excellent, they are continuing to add significant features months after the game has been released.

This is not a genre defining game or even an original concept. 
However what it does, it does great. 

It can best be described as a roguelite strongly inspired by Slay The Spire, Hearthstone and Mobile games such as Idle heroes. If you like any of these types of games, then you will without doubt enjoy this as well. 

There are enough different playstyles and paths to take to make the game interesting and well worth the price. 

Have fun filling your train with your very own horrible crew of bad choices, counter-intuitive
upgrades and gambles that don’t pay off, until you hopefully get the hang of it.

title: Monster Train
review:
tl;dr: this is a fun deckbuilding roguelite, with lots of interesting mechanics, which will undoubtedly give fans of the genre many hours of immense satisfaction. My play time speaks for itself.

EDIT: another big plus is that the developers are very active and also listen to use feedback. There have already been 2 major updates which have added a lot of content. Some of these updates could have easily been DLC but instead they are all free. 

This is a bit of a long winded review. I'm a big fan of rogue-like / rogue-lite games. I've spent quite a bit of time on Enter the Gungeon, and a decent amount on others like FTL, Void Bastards, Into the Breach, The Binding of Isaac, Crying Suns, amongst other things. I also really enjoy the card collecting, deck building subgenre. It is quite a niche genre, but Slay the Spire was immensely fun, Cultist Simulatorand I've recently started playing East of Eden. I'm glad to see this genre becoming more popular with more unique entries for me to try out! Now let's get to the actual review!

Monster Train is a lot of fun and a bit easier than its peers I'd say. So in the world of Monster Train, Hell has frozen over, and you are a train full of demons looking to go through all 9 rings of hell, taking a piece of the Pyre to the core to reignite Hell. The unique mechanics at play here is that the battles take place on the train, which has multiple 'floors'. There are 4 floors in total, with enemies appearing on the first floor, and going up a floor every turn, slowly making their way up to the 4th floor which contains the Pyre piece. The Pyre piece is your life, pretty much. Once enemies get there, they will attack it, and you will lose health. Once Pyre health drops to 0, you lose. Pretty straightforward!

There are multiple factions/clans that you can use, each with their own champion (a hero unit) and unique decks. You also get to choose an ally faction, which means you can get cards from that deck too. So essentially you can mix and match between two clan decks, and come up with whatever weird and wacky combos/synergies you want! You start off with 2 clans, and there are 3 more you can unlock, of which I have unlocked 2. All the clans I have played so far are quite unique and interesting to play, although I think there are some balance issues here. Tanks seem to be quite overpowered (especially the Husk Hermits), at least in my experience so far. I won on my second playthrough, which was my first playthrough as the Awoken. The Awoken seem to be the easiest clan to play so far, but what can make them really overpowered are the upgrades that you can get throughout your run.

Another fun mechanic available here is that you can upgrade all your cards. Both unit and spell cards can be upgraded with a variety of buffs. For example, you can add more health to units, make them cost less, make spells do more damage, etc. These buffs can make even your weakest unit into a powerhouse, so imagine what they can do to an already high powered unit! These upgrades are super fun to play around with, and mix and match. This makes you feel very powerful, no matter which clan you choose to play. I think this may be one of my favourite aspects of the game. In other roguelite games, you can feel quite weak at the beginning, with a slow dredge to becoming powerful. However, in this game, you feel like you're getting an amazing item or buff to your cards at every turn.

I would say that the game does feel a little bit easier than, say, Slay the Spire, but there is a similar system to Ascension from Slay the Spire, so I'm looking forward to ramping the difficulty up after winning with all the clans. Overall, this is a unique and enjoyable game that will no doubt have me hooked for many more hours to come. You will probably get a good feel of whether or not you will like this game in the first run you do (which should take you less than 2 hours), so if you're interested, give it a go! If it isn't your cup of tea, you can refund it after your first run! Now go forth to save [strike] the Spyre [/strike] hell.

title: Monster Train
review:
Awesome tower defense/card/rogue-lite game. If you're into Slay the Spire, you definetely should give this one a try, because IMO it's a lot better.

There are 5 clans to choose from, each with their own strenght and weakness, each clan plays a lot different than the others and every run you mix two of them, strategy variety is the name of the game here, since you wont get the same cards to viabilize the same strategy all the time, so you build the deck on the go.

Unlike in StS, majority of cards dont lose value or become useless on harder difficulties. It doesnt mean strategies that win on easier diffs will work on higher covenant lvls.

Last but no least there's the competitive multiplayer. Hell Rush mode is simply awesome, you get pitched with multiple players in a run where you have a limited ammount of time to complete each circle, highest score or the person who makes it further wins, this mode alone should be reason enough to buy this game. But there's more, the daily challenges are fun to try aswel and community challenges you can create to compete against your friends, which I havent tried because I dont have friends playing MT.

Theres a reason the reviews on this one are Overwhelmingly Positive, this is probably the best card game out there, the possibilities are infinite and you'll beat the game with a different strategy every time, because you dont need to rely on that single card that will make your life much easier, this minimizes the RNG influence on the run outcome, because you can start with something in mind and then a couple circles later you get cards that make another strategy much more effective and go for it instead. Monster Train is simply brilliant.

title: Monster Train
review:
I don't usually leave reviews but this game is amazing in my opinion, one of the most fun games I've ever played. I was struggling to beat the last 2 covenants (24/25) until I came up with a strategy, executed it in my next few runs and beat both. 

I'm excited for the next update that's going to add more champions to choose from, there's so many combinations and ideas for every new run you make that I look forward to seeing the new builds. If you like games like Slay the Spire then you will probably love this game too; I feel like Monster Train allows you to have a lot more power to decide your fate rather than hoping rng favours you. At first I was a bit thrown off by the concept of the game, but it didn't take long for me to play it for hours and hours. 

The card art is really cool, the monsters look awesome, and each clan plays very differently and combining clans adds a lot of complexity to the mix. Monster Train is sort of like a Tower Defence meets Deck Building game, try it out for yourself. 

10/10 I'll keep playing again and again.

review:
Hey, this absolute banger of a soundtrack comes with a free game! Neat!

Jokes about the frankly unbelievably good soundtrack aside (Seriously, Seraph The Traitor is probably one of the best pieces of boss music I've ever heard in any game I've ever played), this game is really damn good, with plenty of interesting mechanics that you'll figure out over time, and nothing feels better than getting to Covenant 25, setting up a floor that will obliterate Seraph, and then watching him die before he can inflict any lasting damage on you. And this is before the Friends and Foes update comes out, which will add 1 new Champion for each of the 5 clans, with new mechanics relating to each of their upgrade paths, and 2 new bosses. Do yourself a favor, and if you like deckbuilders, buy this game. It's already easily worth the price of admission, and it seems like it's only going to get better.

title: Monster Train
review:
I've only played the open beta, but if that was really engaging with enough variety to keep me coming back, the full version with more content and better balancing sure is. Very in-depth deckbuilder with a lot of potential win conditions, and neat presentation/lore.

EDIT: Can only second this after completing almost everything here. Despite the small card pool, the mechanics in picking paths, upgrading cards, and dual clans mean that every run feels completely different and engaging. There's enough content to keep you busy for completionists, and a robust daily challenge system. Meanwhile, it's not too overwhelming to learn due to simple cards/artifacts, but with a high skill ceiling as many cards can be used for diverse purposes. And the devs keep adding more content (another update soon!), giving more ways to play and balancing strategies. 

If you're on the fence, like deckbuilders, or strategy/tower defense games, I highly recommend it.

review:
BIG PINCH OF SALT WITH THE YES: Cool and fun but honestly, don't play this unless you've tired of Slay the Spire first. Its' not as good and honestly seems like they've added a bunch of mechanics and complications instead of simple stuff that interacts well like STS does.  Gameplay wise, it's a good solid roguelike deckbuilder game with a fun gameplay loop but honestly: Get through a few ascension levels in STS first.

Also the theme and style is just weird to me. I don't think I understand why the literal judeo-christian hell has factions that correspond to Bulbasaur, Squirtle, Duskull and Litwick (Hellborn does make perfect sense to me though). Not a huge fan of the theming overall... Seems like there could've been far better themes for this.. Hell, I can think of at least two more sensible themes this could've worked with.

title: Monster Train
review:
Extremely well made and endlessly replayable.

Monster Train is a rogue-like deck builder with a bit of a tower defence twist to it. Instead of building a deck around your attacks you collect units and spells. Units are placed in one of three lanes and attack at the end of every turn and spells are used to support them. A big part of the game revolves around finding strategies that allow you to adequately defend all three lanes until you get your wombo combo going.

With five different factions, each featuring numerous unique mechanics, and numerous game modifiers you can sink a lot of time into Monster Train. If you enjoy deck builders it is definitely worth a look.

Additional reading material that goes over how I enjoy finding new synergies every time I play: https://frostilyte.wordpress.com/2020/08/18/monster-train-and-synergies/

title: Monster Train
review:
Ok, so this game is obviously most similar to Slay the Spire.  If you were on the fence on getting this and needed a better comparison between the two, let me try to explain it here.

Both games are phenomenal, which I feel should be said.  Both games are inherently difficult, with Monster Train having different Covenant levels, which if you beat the game at the highest covenant level unlocked, you unlock another one, up to level 25.  Monster Train has 5 races, each with its own flavor and uniqueness.  You pick a primary race and a secondary race. They are essentially the same thing, except your Champion card, is from the primary race.  There is only champion per race as of this review, but I believe they will be adding more.  

A large difference between the two games is the length of the game.  Monster Train is a bit shorter, as there are 9 rounds to beat, with each round having multiple enemies on each floor coming in waves of the train (Boneshaker).  Each round has a mini-boss at the end that can be pretty difficult to beat at times. Every 3rd round is a big boss that can be very difficult at times.  One cool thing I love about the game is before each round that isn't a boss round, you can choose to select to make the enemies tougher, with a greater reward at the end of the match.

Monster Train at first seems like there aren't enough cards per race, but the upgrades you can do to each card gives it a lot of variety.  Although I would love for the game to get more cards, variety, and artifacts, the amount that is in the game is plenty.

All in all, a great game, with the devs putting a lot of time in this game, moreso than Slay the Spire devs.  and this game has MULTIPLAYER (race)

title: Monster Train
review:
I have been shortlisting Monster Train for awhile, seeing as I already have tons of Roguelites and Deck Builders. I finally decided to give it a try. What turned out to be a 'Let's demo this and see if it's any good", turned out to be an extremely exhilarating 2 hour "Demo session" which got me hooked, leaving me with an immediate "WOW" factor.

PROS:
+Great synergy and replayability as you mix and match your deck between two factions (Reminds me of Smash Up, which I love).
+Great production value and quality from the artwork and animations, making it feel very fluid and top notch (Reminiscence of Bayonetta as you fight the forces of Light).
+Decision making is exciting and propels you forward with choices rather than negative RNG. 
+Game is relatively clean cut and simple to understand with cleverly placed UI and icons to aid players comprehension.
+Great Soundtrack, creating a hyped up tempo.

To sum it up, this game has HEART.
<3 Ever wonder what the name of that kickass soundtrack currently playing is? The Music track pops up in this game.
<3 Do you like leaderboards when competing? You can receive live notifications on current daily runs from other players competing simultaneously so your run does not feel so barren.
<3 Small little touches like traversing the landscape from top to bottom (Very thematic as hell freezes over). 
<3 Do you like your patch notes being updated with developer commentary? Well, their YouTube page has that in spades and its obvious the developers care deeply about their game.
<3 Do you click to test every single options in the menu? Well, there is a particular Option called "Lore Tooltips" which i would normally click, but the game was kind enough to remind me that the Lore Tooltips is already viewable from the Logbook so I would not have to clutter my in-game with additional text, unless i desire to.

Final Thoughts: Monster Train is a very solid roguelite and deckbuilder on its own. However, the additional care and thought process that went into the game propels it to another level and is definitely a keeper, even at full price. And hopefully like me, you are left caring for this little gem, and thus, writing a review of this game in the middle of your run.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
The first time I saw Monster Train being played was on Jorbs' Twitch Stream. At first glance I was irritated by the over-the-top graphic and monster design. I found it way too "Hearthstone-y".
But... but - the more I watched it, the more I got hooked, and when I finally bought it, I got absolutely immersed in this bizarre world and its gameplay cycle.
Slay the Spire may have better balancing and more difficult draft decisions in general. But when it comes to pure fun (like the kind of fun when you were playing with water pistols as a child and pretended to be some kind of badass) yes, Monster Train is EXTREMELY fun. There are so many ways to alter your deck, copy cards, remove cards, make certain cards cost 0, double their effectiveness, give them multistrike... Monster Train encourages you to be as ridicilous as possible, because, in the end, this will be the only way to beat the Seraph.

Get it. Play it. And don't take it too seriously.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is a very good game. I had some trouble getting into it at first, but I'm glad I gave it more of a chance.

It's sometimes described as a cross between something like Slay the Spire and a tower defense game. It's not completely inaccurate, but I think it might push some players away. The game is less like tower defense and more like if you had to play 3 Slay the Spire battles at the same time. 

This means that on any given turn you have quite a lot of options for what to do. Slay the Spire is a game about making a ton of tiny decisions throughout the run. Monster train is a game about making slightly fewer, but far more complicated and impactful decisions. This makes it feel more strategic than Slay the Spire in some ways because how you play your deck matters more.

title: Monster Train

Also the social features are a nice step up.

title: Monster Train
review:
Good deck-building / Rogue like style game.

The fact that you pick two different factions and that each possible combination end up being a totally different gameplay (some factions are around having units with high attack, another one with high HP, another one around spells and the last two more around some game mechanics) 

This makes the game a lot replayable. Finding something that you like to play and experiment since you'll gain new card and artifact each time a faction get a new level.

There is also achievement and some of them are pretty hard to get but can either be achieved using custom seed or just by playing.

With my 30H of playing i've already discovered some pretty OP builds that are able to one shot every bosses (i'll let you find these or it's pretty easy to find on google)

Daily runs are also something nice, you play with specific factions and mutations (that can either be negativ or positiv or neutral) with everybody having the same ones.

Really recommend the game especially if you likes Slay The Spire (which is my case)

English is not my main language so please forgive any error I made.

title: Monster Train
review:
I have 600 hours or so on Slay the Spire, and I have played most games in the genre, this is the first game of the rogue-like deck-builders that really feels like it lives up to the bar STP set. Pick your path, draft your deck, adapt to the situation, difficult but rewarding, lots of replay-ability.

Mechanically I actually prefer Monster Train to STP, it is a really fresh take on the genre that incorporates elements of tower defense as well, and the fights are a lot less of  slog. STP is often about choosing what is the least bad option, MT is more about choosing what is best, you don't get stuck with bad paths like you to often do in STP.
Although when it comes to story, immersion, and aesthetic STP still wins by a long shot for me. STP has this strange and wondrous setting that keeps you asking what is going on, it is filled with secrets and lore. MT on the other hand, you are demons on a train, fighting angels, and at least so far that seems to be about it, which don't get me wrong is a pretty fun aesthetic to, and it is also nice that it is strait forward rather than really having to hunt for the lore and secrets. 
Given this may partly be because the game is brand new, I have my fingers crossed for more content and lore in the future.

The games are quite similar, the main difference is rather than simply guarding your champions life, you are trying to keep your train from being destroyed, and rather than a single character you have your champion and some extra summons which are both disposable each fight. In combat there are four levels, enemies come in waves, start at the bottom, and work their way up, giving you several chances to defeat them before they can reach the top level where they can do damage to your actual health. 

The other smaller differences are the ability to create hybrid decks between two factions, what build you pursue will usually be a bit more front-loaded as your most important choices tend to be early on, there are a lot less fights over all and there is no avoiding them, however each fight has many rounds to it with multiple waves. This leads to an overall shorter run than STP with less choices, but the choices you do make are more impactful.

title: Monster Train

I picked this up because so many of the writers at RockPaperShotgun liked it, and I now agree. It adds a couple of layers of depth to the now-classic Slay the Spire formula, and particularly one feels, win or lose, that choices and strategies really made a difference. You can still lose because of unlucky sequences of cards, but so much else feels less arbitrary and more interesting.

After so many near-clones, I wasn't sure that StT would ever be surpassed. But it has been, and I'm loving it.

title: Monster Train
review:
Fun game so far. Picked it up played 9 hours straight. Some concerns I have at least initially:
- The progression system seems pretty slow to unlock everything. After 9 hours still missing two out of the five playable clans.
- There is a reward for beating the game on harder difficulty making your card borders golden, I do not know if there is a way to disable using them. (I am not a fan of gold personally would be nice to toggle it off.)
- The diversity of the enemies seems small while the modifiers for what they do is large. Hopefully in future updates this will be addressed.

Other than that the game is really enjoyable. Each game feels short until you look at the time spent. You can save and quit whenever (Singleplayer.) I have yet to touch multiplayer but I am certain that will allow for much more replay value. The art is very cartoony, not my cup of tea but hey the core gameplay is what I care about. At $25 I think the price is a little steep but assuming there are future updates that grow this game I can easily see that price being worthwhile. 

7/10 would recommend.

Edits: After getting a lot more playtime in the game and some alternative borders (with the addition to turn them off. Plus additional content that came and will continue to come this game was money very well spent. Looking forward to the next update! Giving this a solid 9/10 rating.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is like all the things I love about Slay the Spire mixed with more formal tabletop card games. Everything is a resource. Your train's Pyre health is a resource. Your monsters are a one time use resource. You always get a rad, upgradeable hero to place on the first turn. Who is also a resource that is used completely differently based on which faction you choose. Every run, you can choose between one main faction and one sub-faction. They don't always synergize in the way you'd think, but they remind me heavily of MtG and it's multicolor decks. There is a snecko style randomizer artifact. There is card progression unlocks for each faction. There is a mode for prestiging cards for gold borders. Almost every fight has a modifier to make the fight harder for better rewards. Some of these are devestating since you know what the enemy types are but some are super manageable. This is another game that rewards you for repeated playthroughs but still rewards you at nearly every step of the way. 

If you want a break from some of the other card games you are playing, give this game a try. It will more than be worth it and has almost instantly become my favorite. Really excited to spend a few hundred hours in this one.
