title: Monster Train
review:
This review will be a bit biased. This game very much reminds me of Slay the Spire, and I loved Slay the Spire! It's a very similar game, except the fact that you have a few levels here with the pyre on top, and you can go up and down based on your cards. I look forward to the challenges everyday, sometimes I wish there were more. There are player made challenges now too, which are fun to try. 

Pros:
It's a rogue-like card game with a lot of replayability
Fairly easy to get into
Easy to create builds as you go
A lot of fun, with a lot of options
Community Challenges adds more replayability

cons: 
Some of the mutations are much harder to counter than others. Some mutations don't seem to fit, for example sometimes you get hollowed as a mutation (Friendly units get Heartless which means they can't be healed) and then get very unlucky and get a bunch of healing cards. Another crazy one is Permadeath, in a game where the point is to build a deck, if your units are going to be purged completely from the deck, then the game won't last long.

title: Monster Train
review:
Do you have too much time? Too much money? Enjoy agonizing through every little decision? Monster Train can help you with all of those problems! 

The good:
+Wildly entertaining, a deckbuilder that is deep, wide, and more forgiving and transparent than predecessor Slay the Spire
+Decisions matter, but often both your options have significant upside potential, so it becomes a process of deciding what's best in short term vs. long-term for your particular run / game state
+Tons of variety - each run feels very different, despite fighting same enemies
+Progression and pacing are satisfying, take it at your own speed
+OP combos not nerfed into the ground by devs but rather encouraged / to be discovered and exploited when you can
+Opt into more risk (and more reward) when you're feeling strong on certain fights - build an unstoppable snowball of hellish destruction! 
+Music, graphics and animation are all a win for me. Some may disagree, but they're wrong. When in doubt turn on googly eyes for a good time. 

The could-be-better: 
-Eventually I'll want more variety of fights, enemies, and backgrounds
-Music is great, but if you're putting in dozens or even hundreds of hours, it will get stale
-Price is a bit high to try it out (but if you decide you love it and pump tons of hours in, it becomes a steal in terms of value). I got it 10% off in Steam summer sale, but can recommend it at full price to anyone who already loves deckbuilders like Slay the Spire.

title: Monster Train
review:
Easily one of the best single player (with a tinge of online) roguelite card battlers.

Gameplay: 10/10
Music & Sound: 8/10
Graphic: 8/10
Replayability: 9/10
[b]Overall: 9/10[/b]

Reasons why:
[list]
[*]While it is hard to avoid RNG elements of card building, the shop system makes it possible to tweak the cards the way you see fit to make it OP. The ability to skip cards in exchange for gold, and choose between 2 different path with different shop/events/duplicate/removal options gives you so much more control. While having the consistent element which is your hero card, clan style and boss battle.
 [*]Adjust the game speed to your liking, players can almost skip all the animation and focus on the card play. The battle effects + sound hits the spot too.
 [*]Magic the gathering elements which allows you to mix and match different clans, with 25 ascension levels for high replay value.
 [*]Challenging and fun to play, isn't this the most important thing?
[/list]

Things I would like to see from the game:
[list]
[*]Entirely new map with new bosses, an expansion/dlc would be cool
[*]New clans and keywords to go along with it
[/list]

Conclusion:
[b]If you like slay the spire, you will like this too![/b]

title: Monster Train
review:
There are some easy ways to determine if you are likely to become a devoted fiend for the phenomenal Monster Train. The easiest is to ask if you like 2018's cult classic Slay the Spire - if yes, purchase Monster Train with no reservations. If you're a fan of the indie-darling Roguelike genre and/or of staple-card game Magic the Gathering or its many derivations, you are quite likely to enjoy the unique blend of gameplay Monster Train serves up. But if none of that means anything to you, hop aboard as we attempt to ponder whether this is in fact your Train. (Summary at Bottom)

Monster Train is significant in that it's become the second tentpole entry into the fast-growing Roguelike Deck Builder genre which Slay the Spire started. A roguelike deckbuilder is a game in which a given playthrough consists of several fights of a card-game-like nature (as in your character's attacks and defences are represented as unique cards you draw, play and discard). Between fights, you're given options which add and remove cards to your deck. Every playthrough begins from scratch with a new deck and randomly determines which cards, enemies, and other rewards are available. The reward of this genre derives not just from winning a game, but from developing a deck full of cards with synergistic effects, a feeling which is satisfying creatively, strategically, and probabilistically, as you can never quite rule out the effects of lady luck's highs and lows in a given run. And all of this plays out to a rapturous soundtrack by Jordan Chin, whose music will worm its way into your list of the most hummable, energetic, iconic game soundtracks out there.

So if this is your introduction to the genre and you're reading these descriptions with excitement, or if you're a player with strategy and creation on the mind, you're likely already feeling that you're in the target audience for Monster Train. Who, then, is not?

Well the genre doesn't have the best history with polished visuals, and Monster Train continues this regrettable trend. Many have remarked that some of its monster designs, while by no means unprofessional, feel at times uninspired. Some have been put off to the point of calling it 'mobile-game-like'. As an artist myself, I find the color choices for the environment and the titular monsters very by-the-book. The most iconic object in the game, the eponymous Monster Train, looks unique, but even it isn't seen very often and some of the concept art in the game depicting it is slightly inconsistent. In short, looks were not a priority in this game's creation. 

This sadly blends into the game's story. While implied background and lore abound, quantity does not quality make, and in my opinion, the writing is serviceable at best. Even if Slay the Spire's world was occasionally rough looking around the edges, it had a unique character which Monster Train never quite attains. And this is just the aesthetic angle.

While I found the game intuitive, there are a variety of rules to learn, particularly for someone new to card games of this type. While I haven't focused on the differences between MT and Slay the Spire, they are numerous and create an experience which is arguably deeper but a little more intimidating at the outset. When you just glance at the game, and see a 3 story train, many people are literally dumbstruck and don't know what's going on. And furthermore, if you're the kind of player who favors quick reactions or execution based gameplay, you'll not find that here. 

The last reason you might consider not getting the game, and the only one which is probably not worth entertaining is that you already have Slay the Spire and enjoy it. Perhaps you wonder if Monster Train is an inferior product or is in fact too derivative. Here all the things which make it hard to recommend for the newcomer become positives; its 3 level structure introduces the idea of planning for the next turn. Its custom card upgrade system encourages you to view every card not just for what it is or is destined to become, but what you could conceivably turn it into. In an almost indescribable way, it allows for combos which seem digustingly broken to the point where you can't imagine how this can't be a bug in the game that you're taking advantage of with a huge smile. But even its difficulty curve seems better tuned than Slay the Spire, easier at first, but ramping up gradually into a true mountain of challenge to conquer. 

So while Monster Train may not be for everyone, there's a large group which will absolutely revel in its depth and its gameplay. True newcomers to the genre may wish to start with Slay the Spire first, but once you step on board that rail, you're going to arrive here eventually. And for those who are stepping on just now, you're in for a HELL of a trip.

+Incredible creative strategic depth which builds on the genre conventions established by Slay the Spire
+Surprisingly intuitive and well-tuned, featuring insane combos and ever-increasing challenge
+Easily over 50-100+ hours of replayable content through roguelike random content
-Generic uninspired aesthetic
-Gameplay unavoidably involves cards and strategy which may be unintuitive or uninteresting for some
-Newcomers to the genre may find game overcomplicated and want to play Slay the Spire first

Train Steward (with Advanced Prototype Upgrade)/10

title: Monster Train
review:
The makers of Monster Train didn't need to advance the gameplay style of Slay the Spire this much, but I'm glad they did.

Because Monster Train takes the formula to new heights on several fronts. The theme is more creative, the early-game more diverse, the options more compelling and the strategic decisions more numerous and mind-bending. There are so many ways to win, even on the highest difficulty, that even after 130 hours it doesn't feel stale. But despite the varied routes to victory, the challenge is considerable too.

So if you like StS, give this game a go. It's not just another deckbuilder.

title: Monster Train
review: Best rougelike deckbuilder since STS, arguably improves on it, definitely worth the price

title: Monster Train
review:
Sorry, there's gonna be a lot of StS comparisons, but it's hard to avoid it as StS pioneered the roguelike card battler genre, which this game falls into, while masterfully crossing this genre with even more unexpected genres.

If you love StS and Tower Defense, there's little reason to not instantly fall in love with this game. Only issues is that runs seem a bit short, and while there is a lot of potential variety in "characters", you're still only allowed to choose two small pools of cards per run amongst the many different possibilities, which results in fairly predictable and repetitive results once you've tried every "deck" combinations. On the flip side, it greatly reduces the potential for RNG to screw you over as you mainly get cards and items relevant to eachothers. 

Otherwise, the game is incredibly well designed up to the finest detail, adressing even issues one could have with a game like StS while providing a very unique twist. It does not just "scratch the StS itch", it's a great game on its own, able to differentiate itself from StS and not being a "lesser" version of it. It's very different despite all the very familiar mechanics and cards, and just as good. If you're still worried about the lifespan of the game, keep it mind it also has 25 difficulty modifiers, to keep things fresh and challenging, aswell as the ability to add other "just for fun" modifiers.

Monster Train throws in a little bit of hearthstoney flavour by using units unlike StS (you also have a "champion", a stronger than average, unique unit that acts as your selectable character), and while it has what would be the equivalents of skills and attacks in StS, it still spices and switches it up by using a Unit system. That being said, it doesn't lose what makes a game like StS. I don't like hearthstone. I usually don't like the unit-based card games, yet i fell in love with it. It gave me something new to master despite being able to carry over my experience from StS to this game (it took me 5 tries to win my first run, compared to StS.

The terrain, and the flow of battle is very much that of a tower defense: You have a core to protect, here called the pyre, while the game throws at you many enemies slowly, inevitably approaching toward your core each turn as you try to stop and weaken them with spells, and units that act like turrets. The bosses which have a different and interesting mechanic in how they approach your core, which further makes the game interesting. Runs are made of only a few, very long fights with many enemies, as if you played 10 tower defense levels in a row, rather than having many small battles with one or two enemies. All of this creates an immense depth to the game with many different ways to approach a battle from how you use your units, to how you build your deck. It's still so well designed that you can learn the game in about 5 minutes. Still easy to learn, and just as hard to master as other games like it. In some ways, it also reminds me of Legend of Keepers, except even more fun. Be warned the last two fights, including the final boss, are very big difficulty spikes, which can be a bit frustrating, but it'll force you to perfect the way you build your deck a bit more each time, until you win.

One of the best games to have followed in the footstep of the roguelike card game genre StS popularized, somehow adding a defense tower twist that doesn't clash with the main genre. I love both genres, so i got addicted to this within the first run. I've got my eyes on Griftlands next. If this is a genre you like, don't hesitate, it's worth the price and the reviews speak for themselves: The score is very much deserved.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a rogue-like deck builder like the many that came out after Slay the Spire's success. It has three key areas that give it a lot of replay value:

- First, it has 5 races and you have to select two of them to play (primary and secondary clans), this makes builds so unique that it never gets stale.
- Second, you can summon monsters to fight for you, this adds fun role dynamics like tanking or damage dealers. You also have a hero-like character for every race.
- Third, enemies have to progress through 3 lanes in order to attack your core health. This adds a lot of fun strategies just by placing and moving your army around.

I loved Slay the Spire but Monster Train is even better.

review: This game is fantastic if you like Slay The Spire. The amount of fresh new mechanics that this game brings to the table is much appreciated. Super good game with a LOT of replay ability and I highly recommend it.

title: Monster Train
review:
2020 has been a banner year for indie games. Right now, Monster Train is my favorite, and I expect that will continue to be the case.

In the wake of Dream Quest and Slay the Spire, there has been a deluge of imitators. Monster Train is one of the few not content to iterate on the existing formula. By adding elements of the Tower Defense genre, Monster Train is transformed from a clone to the new standard bearer. I sank over a hundred hours into Slay the Spire; Monster Train has already surpassed that number, and I'm still looking forward to my next run.

The music is excellent, and the graphics are well above par for the genre. Aesthetics aren't make-or-break for a deckbuilder (as Dream Quest proved), but they sure don't hurt.

review:
- Last update change game play drastically, rather than keep restart game for 10-20 min for best starting set or ditch all weak card, more strategy seem viable at high covenant now.

The Good

The Bad

- Still lack of effects, enemies variety, and events that mostly just give a card.

- Artifacts is still kind of boring. (either useless or straight up over power)

title: Monster Train
review:
A fun deck-builder very similar to Slay the Spire.  The big differance is that battles take place in a train-car stacked vertically and you summon minions to battle and stop the armies of Heaven from invading and destroying your pyre-relic thing at top. The other big change is that you have factions to choose from and you pick a Minor and Major faction to start a run and they set what cards and Artifacts (relics) that will appear during the run.

The game starts off a bit simplistic and easy, and only has 9 stages to beat before you clear a run. However as you start to complete runs more difficult challanges unlock as well as cards and even factions.  For me this is a pretty fun deck builder with a unique battle system (I have seen games with similar systems before, not sure if there is a name for them).  It's likely not a game you will spend long sessions on, but it's great to spend an hour on a run and call it a day.

title: Monster Train
review: This is a great game - if you like Slay the Spire - this is as good but different.  It's still all about building a killer deck to fight the final bad guy and it teases you with lots of tricks - sometimes you will think the game is broken and other times you wish it was.  The variety offered with the 5 factions and then choosing a sub-saction is great - each one plays differently and each combination is a challenge.  I keep saying that I will stop playing and play something else but something about it lures me back in.  I love that you can play a complete game in less than an hour.  There's also something very fun and friendly about the whole thing.  Argh - I love this game!

title: Monster Train
review:
Usually too lazy to write a review.
But - hell yeah - this games deserves 5 stars out of 5!
If you are into games like Slay the Spire, any card battlers, strategy games or turn based combat, then this is a must buy.

It took me 2 playthoughs to realize that this game is really deep and the cards well though. Endless amount of combinations and playstyles. Great innovative ideas and game concepts. Motivating achievements. Leader boards and so on.

And then, just when I had won the games with all race combinations and thinking I would have to find a new game soon, they come up with daily challenges, timed races and community challenges. Everything well executed. Never encountered a bug. My game of the year. And I got a few hundred in my library.

title: Monster Train
review:
I wanted to wait until I beat covenant 25 to write a review for this game.

Do I recommend this game? Absolutely, I recommend this game for basically everyone. The art, sound, game design and music for this game is top notch and anyone who a game that they can play to wind down and relax too after a days work or play should absolutely pick this up.

I played quite a bit of slay the spire but I would definitely not consider myself a deckbuilder master, despite this fact, Monster Train is so streamlined and well balanced that regardless if you are a rogue-like strategy master or a casual gamer you can find enjoyment in this game and if you put the time in you WILL become good at this game.

That being said, this is not an easy game at higher covenants. As long as you are willing to take a loss and experiment you van push through the walls this game will throw game at you. And it's worth it to do just that. There are so many different combos and events to experiment with that I'm past 100 hours in and I can still say I'm learning new playstyles and op combinations.

On top of that each run is the perfect length to play a game a day and then for do other things if that is your gaming style.

Anyone who enjoyed Slay the Spire probably has this game, but even if you have never heard of deckbuilder roguelikes I say buy this game, I don't think you will regret the purchase.

-------------------

Very fun deck-building game, but with a twist. You defend a train bent on reviving hell! You can summon monsters and spells to defend multiple train floors, as angelic forces besiege you. There are multiple monster clans and you can choose two each game. There's a lot of room for replayability, both from the cards and challenges.

review: Best deck-builder game I have ever played. There's enough randomness that you're constantly adapting your strategy, but not so much that you feel like you don't have control. Card variety and being funneled in to mix-and-match between 5 distinct pools of cards makes for a lot of freshness and replayability. Best of all, it feels well balanced: you're more often than not at the edge of your seat fighting tooth and nail to take the bosses down and oh does it feel satisfying to deal the finishing blow. No, I legit struggle to think of much to critique here! Loved it!

title: Monster Train
review: A fantastic deck-building game with some of the most interesting gameplay mechanics that I've seen in a long time. Despite the complexity, the game somehow makes everything feel extremely accessible right from the start, and only deepens from there. If you're at all interested in deckbuilders or rogue-likes, you won't be disappointed in this.

title: Monster Train
review:
One of the best, if not at least the most fun single player deck building game all time.

There are five clans, each having a whole set of cards and starting setup. You play with both a primary and an allied clan, which already mixes up how each game is going to be played. Increasing difficulty will add random starting cards (from both the primary and the allied clan set) which you'll have to use to mold your deck around.

The possibilities seem endless. I already have about 90 hours in and it still feels like I've just started scratching the surface.

There's a lot of mechanics to work with. Of course there's the expected card cost, damage, health, armor, mana management, healing, magic spells and so on and each clan adds other interesting mechanics. Most noticeably are the Umbra clan with their Gorge ability (eating little Morsels to increase stats) and the Melting Remnants with Burnout + Reform, having a dead timer on units and the ability to bring them back to play with enhanced stats.

Graphics are very likeable. Music tracks are amazing and so are the sound effects.

On top of all that, the UI is amazing. A logbook keeps track of almost every aspect of your game. You can create custom challenges or share your runs with friends. There a whole unlock system so you won't get overwhelmed when starting to play the game. It's just crazy.

Game of the year material for sure.
Very addictive.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is up there with the greats. I'm talking about games like Slay the Spire [i] (which influenced a plethora of deck building roguelike games)[/i], Deck of Ashes and Griftlands. Or even Curse of the Dead Gods which copied Slay the Spire's awesome map progression design. Monster Train did as well, which is fine. If it's not broken, don't fix it. And Slay the Spire did quite a few things worth repeating.

All that being said, Monster Train somehow manages to feel extremely unique. The art of battle in this game is just so damn addictive. I mean, I guess I could be biased. I'm a huge fan of Tower Defense games and Monster Train has that sort of feel to it with it's layered train fights. You must defend each layer as the enemy works it's way up to your Pyre. Sort of like a Tower Defense game where the enemy follows a path to it's designated finish line and you try to stop them. In Monster Train, your goal is to stop the enemy from reaching the top layer of your train. I know, I know... it's weird. 

If you're like me and passed on this game because of the name.. [b]Don't[/b]! I know it sounds petty. And, well, it is. I didn't purchase this game at first because I thought the name "Monster Train" was just silly and low effort. That is, until all the amazing reviews started pouring in. Coupled with the Steam Summer sale. And now here we are. The devs could have called this game Choo Choo Dukey Drop and I am convinced I would still love it. 

The cards are diverse and gorgeous. The heroes are very well crafted and each one unique. At first glance I hated the art style and animation, but the devs keep updating it and now I've really fallen in love with it all. The cards are animated and they look [b]amaaaazing[/b]. (Hello Valve/Artifact, this is what we need right here)

I don't want to give too much gameplay away. You should just dive on in and figure it out yourself. 

If you're a fan of Slay the Spire, Tower Defense games, roguelike deck builders, or if you are a fan of card games and you are looking for something that stands out from all the rest... I highly recommend Monster Train. 

Dumb Name. Incredible game. 

I look forward to future updates!

This game is like gambling, but not in the way EA does it. Every run instills you with the hope of that jackpot; that you will stumble upon the right cards and strategy to topple the angels, only to watch it crumble before your very eyes time and time again. 

Your carefully constructed deck annihilated by an unlucky draw, that one unoptimised spell card, your own stupidity, or a train warden you just couldn't get rid of. When you finally stop bashing your head against the table, you immediately click "next run" and do it all over again.

Love it.

review:
0-10 hour is intoxicating. 
10-20  feel this game is way too easier compared with STS..
20-30 kind of boring.  (poor seraph..)

the good part:
a combined taste of roguelike, deck building, rpg. tower defense etc..
music is cool.


the bad part:
too easy.(relics too strong,cards over powered)
imbalance cards between their energy design, races and  upgrade overpowered.

although I only played to level 7 so far, but i won the very first round. （i have about 450hr+ sts playing though)
the game is easy because you only need to fine picking the very first 2-3 battles with good units then rest is no brainer.
if you happen to be bad luck, then it will be tough but still easy enough to win.

A pro player can potentially have a winrate higher than 90% as I estimate even with Lvl25. 
This is not a real roguelike in that sense..

anyway, I will recommend a buy because even a dozens of hours already worth the bill.

title: Monster Train
review:
Seeing all the raving reviews I decided to give this game a try.
It does a lot of things well, but in the end I didn't really enjoy my experience.
The game starts off incredibly easy, where you can defeat the final boss in your first or second try without too much effort. This means that right off the bat, you've seen almost every challenge you'll face going forward, it makes the whole game feel like a bit of a grind, where you're facing the same content over and over again with small modifications.
The faction combos are interesting, but it felt to me that most combos I tried just didn't work together all that well. The factions are highly focused on doing one or two things, so the second faction often felt like cards and units you'd skip most of the time.
The covenant system is a classic system to increase difficulty. My issue with it is that right off the bat, they increase the difficulty in very un-fun ways. Two of the first covenant effects are "Add a Dead Weight card to your deck, and start each run with a set of random cards". The dead weight is just an annoyance at all times, and in my opinion it does not make the game more fun. The set of random cards mostly just adds to the pile of cards that I'll need to remove before my deck starts being efficient. 
I think making the game harder by making the enemies do more interesting thing, would have been more fun than gimping my starting deck more and more. 
Overall, decent game, but it won't keep me playing like Slay the Spire did.

title: Monster Train
review: Awesome game, alternating with slay the spire and darkest dungeon.

title: Monster Train
review:
Hot damn this is an excellent refinement of the deckbuilding-roguelite genre. Fewer individual combats per run than many other similar games, allowing each of those combats to have more weight. The game straight up tells you which of the various random final bosses you will face at the beginning of a run, and this lowers the frustration significantly. Increasing challenges can be piled on to increase difficulty, unlocking as you clear with all the previous challenges. Devs are refreshingly communicative and open about both what they're doing and why, and having changes explained slightly better than "X nerfed because strong, Y buffed because weak" is very good for a game's health. As a cherry on top, the setting is kinda interesting as a novel spin on heaven and hell.

If you like similar games, this one is very good.

title: Monster Train
review:
Did you like Slay the Spire? 

You'll love this. I didn't even wait for a sale, it's that good.

PROS: More complex than Slay the Spire. You pick a MAIN/ASSIST each time, so you have more combos to replay. There's also a difficulty scale that increases the encounters with more rewards. AND each mini boss has a challenge if you toggle it you get more rewards. 

Trinkets/artifacts/etc are often RNG 

The FINAL BOSS is pretty meh. It just feels like another mini boss but this is on lower levels, I haven't worked my way up yet.

So far this is actually MORE fun than Slay the Spire, but that may be the 'newness' of it. It clearly took a lot of inspiration from that game in all the best ways.

So yeah, if you liked Slay the Spire buy this now, don't even wait for a sale. You'll love it.

title: Monster Train
review:
I don't write many reviews, and seeing how this game has so many positive ones already didn't think I'd want to write another one. Then I played the game. I have over 200 hours in Slay the Spire, many people want to compare this game to that and it's really not the same game. It's rogue like deck builder so I get the comparison, but game play is very different. 

[b] This is more like a tower defense deck builder with rogue like elements then Slay the Spire clone [/b]. I could write a small book on how to play this game, but really you can buy this game try it out for a hour and if you don't like it by then you won't like it. The progression is fast, 34 hours in I have been playing on random clan combinations since I unlocked the third clan and have most of the content unlocked. I will probably put another 200 hours into this and still want to play Slay the Spire since they are very different games. I have never played a game that had lane control/deck building and pulled it off like this and it's really worth paying full price and playing this game. Bought a friend a copy of this game and he's hooked as well. If you don't believe me, just look at the reviews. This game really is a gem for it's price and worth time and money being put into it.

title: Monster Train
review: Take the roguelike deckbuilder base of Slay the Spire, use minions and spells (eerily similar to Hearthstone) instead of attacks and blocks, add levels / stories to the environment to give it hints of a tower defense and you've just scaled up the average game in this category to be much greater in scale, action and intensity all while being more customizable with more choices and ways to experiment.  Feels like I could play this game dozens of different ways right now and with more content in the pipeline I'm glad I've already got my ticket for this crazy train.

title: Monster Train
review:
I hopped on a bit late on the Monster train , but the ride so far has been very enjoyable ( pun intended ). I enjoy the fact that even though some combinations and archetypes seem to be incomparable to other combos on the power curve cards seem to find their way into winning decks and still not feel like complete dead weight.

Also infinite damage/gold/heal etc. are really hard to build and require a lot of rng even with good deck building and a lot of experience. If/when you manage to pull off one of those that run feels memorable and extremely enjoyable since it's really rare and hard to replicate again. It's a game that similar to Slay the Spire made me feel like I should be recording my runs to share with people later, yet I never do.

title: Monster Train
review:
Love it, totally addictive, maybe slightly better than Slay the Spire.  I really want more games like this.  You can play it so easily on a laptop even while eating.  I just love the way it lights up different parts of your brain while you figure out how to face every new situation. 

What I don't like is the same orders of monsters which are very limited and since they each have a single method of attack, you can predict everything they will do.  Cards need to be more randomized in encounters which tend to give the same cards depending on the combo of clans.    It's not as bad as it sounds but you notice when playing that areas could be more randomized.  Overall I love the game and still play it a lot.   This should come to IOS so I can play it on Ipad which would be ideal.  It is pretty cool on my phone through Steam Link though.

title: Monster Train
review:
I enjoyed Slay the Spire, and I liked this even more.

Chance plays a part in every run, but you still have a decent amount of agency over the outcome. When I lose, I usually can look back and see a better strategy I could have taken advantage of. There's enough control over deck composition that you can alter your strategy as you progress. No hoping for a single run-defining card or artifact to make the different.

The possible card pools are smaller than Slay the Spire's, but I enjoy that. It cuts down on the possible pool of cards you'll see, so you can actually plan ahead towards some possible synergies. Some artifacts are very powerful while others are so-so, which makes getting a good one make a run feel unique.

title: Monster Train
review:
Seriously, one of the best rouge-like card game I have ever played. The setting is inspired by Snowpiercer while the gameplay is a mix of tower defense and slay the spire.

There are multiple positives:
+ 25 covenant that increases difficulty in a meaningful way and 15 expert challenges
+ 5 factions that plays completely differently (select 2 for a total of 20 combinations)
+ Lots of Lore! Seriously, turn on the lore in the menu. The lore and setting is amazing.
+ The music! The OST, especially the credit song, are insanely good. No idea why they hide such a great song after credits.
+ Lots of multiplayer content
+ Being able to see final boss' BS skill as well as the map ahead is a huge blessing, especially for high covenant.

Some negative that come to mind:
- The graphic might be a bit to cartoony, but you will get used to it
- Need more boss variety, adding just 1 more boss type per level would be enough.
- Currently, the only difference between sub and main faction is the hero
- Some upgrade path or units are quite weak. Luckily, the dev might buff them later

title: Monster Train
review:
MONSTER TRAIN: Choose a hero, and defend your train as it goes through the 9 rings of hell. 

The deck-building gameplay is very similar to Slay the Spire, and its art lends from hearthstone. A basic run in Monster Train is doable, and winning runs to rank up and increase the difficulty is part of its normal gameplay plan, whereas with StS I never tried Ascension mode as I found the base game challenging enough to complete with all characters. Monster Train as such is more accessible, and scratches a few different itches. Choosing class combinations, upgrading units or spells and duplicating them ... you have more means available to try out different combinations.

It's a hell of a lot of fun. My favorite combination to start off with was Awoken + Stygian, with either spikes or heal to damage builds.

title: Monster Train
review:
I enjoy the game, but some of the cards are extremely overpowered. The Shadowsiege has 200 damage and 150 health... to put that in perspective, most units have 0-10 damage and 10-50 health. So if you copy the Shadowsiege a few times you are pretty much guaranteed to win. If you get the multistrike card your Shadowsiege or hero can attack as many times as you copy and apply that card which is another one that is too strong. Other than some obvious balance issues the game is still fun, and with 65 hours played I can say I feel like I have gotten my money out of it.

Edit: They changed multistrike (good) so they are still working on balancing which makes me really happy.

title: Monster Train
review:
~.__________....__________...._______/
~|..............................|..|..............................|...|................../ SLAY
~|....Card Battler...|..|....Deckbuilder...|..|..Roguelit| THE
~|__________|=|__________|=|______\ SPIRE'S
~OO|OO==OO|OO'OO|OO==OO|OO'OO|OO==O\ BUTT
======================================\

Can't stop the train, baby! Except that you very much can if you sweep and sap my ass into oblivion, 'cos I have no idea how to counter that shit consistently. Don't mind the "picture", I'm just being cheeky. The game is alright, but it isn't better than Slay The Spire. Does it need to be compared to it? No, but I bought Monster Train on the premise that it might be as addictive. How many hours have I got in Spire? 151! Here, I burned out in 25 hours, which is good enough for a tower defense, I suppose. I'll probably play some more, but I don't think that it could hold my interest for much longer.

Maybe I'm just spoiled or simply fed up. And I almost feel guilty for it! This is still a positive review, okay? Just not overwhelmingly positive. The game's well-made, it looks great and has some fun mechanics, seems like the best thing ever at first, but then, with time, gets fairly monotonous and predictable. I simply stopped feeling that sense of wonder when launching a new run, and it happened sooner than expected, leaving me mostly content, yet also a bit disappointed. Wait for more content updates (the devs make them for free!) and a hefty discount is what I'm saying.

If you'd follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35305390-Big-Bad-Mutuh/?appid=262060]my curator[/url] I promise not to defile ASCII art ever again.

10/10 Would Recommend

title: Monster Train
review:
I love deck building games. I did before they were cool, back when I was addicted to Dream Quest. I thought Slay the Spire sucked something that resembles a Metapod. All you had to do in Slay The Spire was beef your defense excessively high and apply a few kill cards. Horrible game, but only because you can exploit its flawed mechanics. 

Hell On Wheels (aka Monster Train without cowboys), is much better than Slay The Spire. I don't know why they are compared so often. There are other deck building games. The few similarities this game has with Slay the Spire are: a good UI, a deck building aspect, relics, you start with 3 actions are turn, and you know the damage output from each enemy. That's about it. After that, it's its own game.   

Do a Smash Up of 2 factions, start the game.

How do you Monster Train up in this "B"?
Here are the phases:
-Get Cool Stuff
-Battle
-Repeat 1 and 2.

How do you battle?

Tower Defense. Deck Building. Darkest Dungeon/MTG Autobattle. Oh yes, its all those things. 

- You have a 4 story house. I call it Run's House. The attic is your HP. If the HP is 0, you dead yo.
- You summon some dudes in the first 3 stories. No one is allowed in the attic. 
- Bad Guys enter through the Basement floor. You say, get outta my house! Smack'em with a demon.
- The bad guys fight your guys in an autobattle for 1 round on a floor. Whichever bad guy lives elevates to the next floor up. Until they reach your attic.
- The game displays the outcome of each fight before it begins.

Game Length:
Once you beat the game, it gets harder. This happens 25 times. It is enough game to go around.

Summary:
I give it a 9 out of 10. There isn't really anything I think need to be added that isn't already there. 

My suggestions are have more clans, more enemy types, more variation on their starting enchantments, but they have enough.

Important note, make an option to have it so the "enhance the enemies for an additional reward" thing always begins ticked.

This game is great. It may be added to my top 10 games of all time. Summary done.

title: Monster Train
review:
Game needs to be rebuilt a bit, the balancing is far off, some clans are very strong, others are pretty weak. Some clans have good combo's with other clans, but then some clans don't. It's pretty fun,  but you'll have runs where you just have no hope of actually beating it due to rng. There are also far too many cards, that are completely useless, so you'll find yourself passing on most of them, which  makes it hard to gold border every card. I wish they  went for more of a balanced play of everything, than oh here are some overpowered combos... so don't bother getting any of these other useless cards. 

I think there was too much focus adding  as many mechanics as they could, rather than fine tuning a couple-few. Just for an example, adding spikes too  non-boss  enemies in order to get a trinket... cool! Losing much of your life because your units are still weak in the 2nd round and end up killing themselves, only to get a trinket that doesn't even work well with you clans... garbage. Just too much RNG, you should get options, like 4. Same goes for when you pick what monsters to add from landing on a spot on the map, there should be 4 monsters to pick from, not 3. This would help a bit more on the RNG factor. I hate having a good start of a run, then it being completely ruined because 1/2 through I don't get anything to actually help my build.

Anyways, 5/10 pretty average for this type of game, just with even more RNG, would have been much higher if even little changes were implemented. And because of that massive RNG, I can't really recommend it to people.

Still garbage RNG... still 5% of the cards that work well... They still need to learn  how to make a game.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like card games you'll probably get some fun out of this. I don't typically like card games but this still caught my eye and the way it was described to me I figured I'd give it a shot. I got roughly an hour and a half into the game when I quickly realized that this game may not be for me. So before I went over the two hour mark I decided to pass.

My main issue with the game wasn't the fact that it was a card game/tower defense mixed together. I actually liked that idea a lot. My issue was the power spikes. I played three runs. The first run I got absolutely destroyed, it lasted all of maybe ten minutes. My second run I got really far in comparison. What happened was I got a really good card, duplicated it with some good modifications, and between it and my hero card I had a single slot left per floor for a powerful imp card I found. This power spike literally carried me through the entire run. I made small modifications to a few others but they were on cleanup duty taking out whatever was left of the mangled enemy that crawled it's way up the stairs on the next turn. Point is, it wasn't even a contest. But on the third run (after you "beat" a run it goes into another run but NG+) the enemy got it's power spike and rendered everything moot. I didn't make it two more than two stops on my train ride. And therein lies my issue. 

This game is wildly inconsistent and all over the place. This isn't a bad thing, I can easily see people liking this. It's how rogue-like games thrive, in chaos. But it's not for me and I imagine not for others as well the lack of predictability leaves me feeling like I have no control over the outcome. You can perfectly play a level and still get roasted. 

Overall, the game is well built and the developers should be proud of the work they did. But it definitely won't appeal to everyone.

review: This game had some of the things I really enjoyed about slay the spire. I would strongly recommend it for fans of the genre. One thing will say though, is that it does lack some of the simplicity of sts, as well as lacking in enemy variety. You fight mostly the same enemies every run with slightly varying mechanics. It does, however, have a good amount of card variety for the player, and the many different choices for starting clans helps keep it interesting. It is fun, it just didn't click with me the same way sts did.

title: Monster Train
review: The game is fun and feels fair until you get to the final covenant. At the last "level", you can try challenges that give your run certain conditions that are fun or sometimes difficult. The problem I have with this game is that it dooms you from the moment you start, too many times. The challenges aren't very hard if you get a deck that makes any sense. Lastly, I'm sick of playing runs that are over before they begin, it is a waste of time. The more  you play; the better you will get at spotting a useless deck at the start. Once you notice this, it's better to just start a new run until you get the cards you need, where's the challenge in this? This game doesn't make me think at all, I just run the same cards over and over until I win and throw the rest away. It was fun for a while but I'm completely sick of the formula now....

title: Monster Train
review:
In my opinion, this game is the best take on the roguelike deckbuilding genre to-date. Before the most recent Mutations update, Monster Train already presented a game with superior balancing of a wide variety of playstyles that allowed me to take on the gauntlet of enemies with any strategy and card combination that I could imagine. Now with the new update, the game has even more replayability than before.

There are five factions with twenty different faction combinations that you can play on your runs, each with a unique cardset that will never look the same run to run. Hellhorned faction features ragebuilding armored units contrasted with dimunitive imps. Awoken features healing and big-bodied tank units that don't go away easy. Stygian has an aim to freeze out the opponent or tear them apart with damage spells while triggering minion abilities. Umbra is built around morsels, tiny units born to be eaten by your own minions to reach maximum power. Melting Remnant units deal incredible damage as you attempt to play cards that prevent them from melting away... and if that fails, just bring them back to life even stronger than before.

All factions share similar winrates while being completely different in playstyles, and the escalation of difficulty as you move through each level or "Covenant" feels fair yet challenging. If you like roguelike deckbuilders, it would be a mistake not to give this a go. Cannot recommend it enough.

title: Monster Train
review:
There is far too much RNG for the game to ever feel satisfying past your first run.

Once you beat the game the first time, it entirely shifts it's philosophy of allowing you to pick your cards your self.

You instead get 3 random cards forced into your deck that in most cases have zero synergy, maybe one of those cards isn't awful, or doesn't cost 3.  You also need to make sure the cards and upgrades that you are offered are not hard counted by the random abilities of the boss you randomly get assigned.

So after many re-rolls you get something playable and start off and the second phase of "starting" begins.  In this second starting phase you need to win the first fight on the challenge difficulty to get another chance at a draft.

You can't skip this fight on the challenge difficulty and have enough resources to beat the last boss.

If you don't accept the challenge you will not beat the last boss due to not having enough use able cards.  If you get hard counted by this challenge, which happens often, you lose.  You will either take too much damage and lose due to lost resources, or you will just lose all of your non respawnable monsters and die.

So, In short in order to actually complete another run past your first all of these RNG things need to line up.

1) You got 2/3 cards that can synergize in your first assignment
2) You got a selection of initial upgrades that aren't hard countered by the random boss
3) You did not get randomly hard countered by the first challenge
4) You beat this challenge while taking no damage, typically on the first floor.

Now the actual game begins and now you have to get VERY LUCKY to get offered enough cards, in the initial synergy you selected.

If not, again you lose.

If you want a couple hours of entertainment you can spend them here, Its just not balanced well at all past the first run.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game gets compared to Slay the Spire and I'm not sure if I like that comparison, yeah they both use cards and it's a semi-roguelike where you do a lot of runs but in my opinion that's where the similarities end.

Slay the Spire is about trying to make sure you don't bleed out, it's about "you took 5 damage in that battle, 5 damage in the next and that is how you're going to die". Monster train is more you are barreling along on a train, you cannot avoid combat, so you have to get stronger and trample the enemy whatever way you can so they don't just trample you. I think that's a big distinction between the two, you can actually lose the first fight in the game and continue on but you're vulnerable, and you can recover from that. If you take too much damage early on in slay the spire you might as well just stop because you're never going to survive an encounter with a gremlin nob.

That's why I like this game better, on Covenant 4 I managed to pull a win out of a failing run with the melting remnant with less than one attack from the final boss left on the Pyre. Most of my Slay the Spire runs feel like I should abandon them if a battle goes badly because it's a sharp downturn in my slow death that I won't even see for another 30 minutes of play.

I really like this game and I like it even more after this last balance patch, things went from "I don't like playing the Umbra or Melting Remnant" to "I've won a couple close games as the remnant, and the Umbra don't feel like they are being punished for using their mechanics anymore" with very minor changes too. This game could have been custom made for me frankly and I love almost every aspect of it.

Now for the things you should know as a perspective buyer:

There isn't as much variation in this game as Slay the Spire, you know what you're going up against and the differences will be in how you build your deck, upgrade your deck and which factions you pick, and which relics you pick up.

It's a roguelike, you're expected to get your money's worth of playtime out of it through trying again and again to try and win, you likely will not win on your first try.

It's a roguelike, you will have runs that just end earlier than you expect because of bad luck.

It's a deck builder, because of the way it's designed you need to wrap your head around the idea that removing cards from your deck can be a good thing, and something you might even pay for.

You need to pay attention to the final boss that you get for each run, because it will show you at the very start, and if you ignore this people on the forums will never shut up about it. The game doesn't really highlight it beyond the start and the people on the forums act like you should just remember it or know to hover over an icon on the to bar to look at it rather than actually helping you out.

title: Monster Train
review:
It's like Slay the Spire, but you play as the Spire, deploying permanent monsters and temporary spells to prevent waves of enemies from grinding their way up your train to your health pool. 

It's like Artifact, using a "3 lane" concept in a digital card game (except in Monster Train, these "lanes" are sequential instead of parallel), but with less RNG and better conceived for an addictive gameplay loop. And without the extortionate monetization that destroyed that game.

I'll be honest: around 50 hours of play time, I was ready to give this game a negative review. I felt like the game was throwing unplayable combinations of cards at me. But, like my 500-hour ascent through the Spire, the frustration I was feeling kept pulling me back into the game, and I discovered new playstyles and strategies I had presumed to be trash. There are lots of "Aha!" moments as you learn to play Monster Train, and with mutators and a major balance patch now released, I sense this game is in good hands. 

I ADORE Slay the Spire, but the much higher complexity of Monster Train has taken its place in my library.

title: Monster Train
review:
Don't get me wrong by the thumbs down; it's a fine game.  It's just nowhere near as good as the hype and is massively overpriced, compared to others in the genre.  

The game draws HEAVILY from StS, cribbing most of the major fundamentals of the game, but doesn't improve them (and some could say, dumbs them down to make hard choices less hard).  RNG is much more important in this game than StS (final boss spawns with the ability to get rid of your spells, but your a spell-centric? tough luck; start over).  You'll see all there is to the game within the first few hours of playing.  Deckbuilding is way simpler and less interesting than StS, as unit cards don't recirculate, your deck becomes more deterministic as the battle goes on until you're left with the same few spells, with the potential to get the same hand every round.  Battles are always the same major bosses, in the same order, 9 battles to a run.  Balance is stilted with massive swings in card value, but they're at least making progress on that.  Strategy is limited: dumping major monsters on the first floor is almost always the best choice.

Overall, I wanted to stop playing after the first five hours of getting the game.  I kept on going to unlock everything and see if it ever got better (broadly, it didn't).  If you're down for a repetition, are ok with RNG simply screwing you, and love StS, it's worth a shot.  Otherwise, I'd say there are more interesting / more challenging StS-esque deckbuilders out there and this is absolutely not worth the price premium.

review:
Enjoyable deck builder in the vein of Slay the Spire (also a great game).  One thing I like about Monster Train is that it feels like the random elements inherent to the deck builder genre are slightly more controlled.  I have literally never quit a run because I felt like my deck was going to be so useless that I didn't stand a chance later on.  It's a great feeling to always believe you can strategize a suboptimal start to victory.  I'm sure this won't always be the case as the difficulty ramps up (I've only cleared 6 of 25 difficulties).  

I thought the 25 difficulty levels were excessive at first, but the smoother difficulty curve is also another nice feature of Monster Train. I've spent more time experimenting with card combos than going straight to overpowered decks in order to keep pushing forward. 

If you like deck builders this is a very polished one and unique enough to feel like something familiar yet new.  If you've never played a deck builder this is a great one to start with.

review: It's a lot to figure out; each run has so many variables, and it's easy to screw up and get annihilated.  At the same time, it feels so good when you get an overpowered combination and stomp the enemies.  Each run has so much potential, and the art, story, and possible combinations keep it interesting.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you love Slay the Spire and want something more complex, Monster Train is for you. There are four floors in the titular train, the Pyre room and the three rooms below it. Your goal is to prevent the Winged enemies from climbing from the bottom all the way to the Pyre, or at least ensure minimum damage. There are five clans whose cards support a different playstyle, such as the Hellhorned with their heavy-hitting units and spells that increase attack. At the start you choose a primary clan, which also gives you a powerful Champion unit that you can place down immediately at the start of the fight, and a secondary clan for support. After each battle you can strengthen your deck by adding more cards, customizing your existing cards with unique upgrades, buying artifacts that add special effects, and more. Every time you beat Seraph and win the game, you unlock more stuff and your Covenant Rank goes up, making each run more challenging than the last. 

My only concern with the game is that the three bosses you encounter are always the same; their ability changes just enough to affect your strategy, but it feels like a regular battle with a debuff or enemy buff applied each turn. On the plus side, unlike Slay the Spire you always know what deck the final boss counters, so you won't automatically lose just because you didn't get lucky with the card rewards.

Overall, Monster Train is a well-polished card game dedicated to those who like a good challenge. Along with the gameplay, the lore found everywhere and the soundtrack will keep you immersed in the battle between the denizens of Hell and the Winged that froze their home. Will you protect the Pyre from Heaven's soldiers?

title: Monster Train
review:
If you love deckbuilders a la Slay the Spire, buy this game now as you will love it the same.  Think Slay the Spire + Tower Defense - all the fun of "new game+" Covenant mode and a super kickass completion/achievement tracking screen that will make even losing runs feel accomplished.  I love everything about this game and could drone on and on about it, but simply put - This is a great deckbuilder and is worth buying at full price.

I've been playing TCGs (Magic: the Gathering) competitively for 20+ years, and every deckbuilder game I could ever get my hands on, and this game introduces interesting Tower Defense mechanics that feel fresh and new.  Also, while most deck builders would work towards finding the best way to generate infinite loops of card draw, this game is much more focused on how you upgrade your units, how you place them, and setting up for future turns.

If you're on the fence, buy this game.  You won't regret it!

title: Monster Train
review:
This spire-like makes some smart choices:
- Simple but interesting path selection (as opposed to the pre-planned routing of STS)
- Broadcasts some important information ahead of time to let you prepare for it. (like the abilities of the last boss, which are visible at the beginning of the game)
- Strikes a great balance between long term planning on adaptive thinking on your feet.
- You always get to be solving the puzzle of "how do I make a good deck with this?" with lots of big effects and fun toys.
The soundtrack is a bop, and the world and creatures are quite neat.

title: Monster Train
review:
Really fun Rouge like deck builder game that has many original concepts compared to many others that typically act as a copy, and paste of "Slay the Spire" (brilliant game as well BTW).  Watching a video before playing this game will confuse you, but don't get intimidated because once you get into it a lot of the mechanics will be easy to understand and the combat flows wonderfully.  

I would give it a 10/10 if you are into Rouge-like card games.  The amount of different strategies that can play out, and how different each clan feels will keep you engaged for hours.  Although there are some minor balancing issues, the developers are doing a fantastic job staying in touch with the community for upcoming patches.

My only complaint is that there is one achievement that is incredibly lazy, and poorly thought out - the "50,000" points in a daily challenge.  Which essentially requires you to do everything perfectly on a daily challenge that has randomized modifiers.  It just kills the enjoyment of a run being required to have a perfect run because it forsakes many of flexible options this amazing game offers that makes normal runs incredibly engaging.  Although if you are not an achievement hunter by any means then this is a completely invalid complaint regarding the game.

The only other thing that I wish I could see would be mod support.  Although this game has a lot of meat to it that even if modding never becomes an option that it would be worth the $25 price tag.

In short: If you love Slay the Spire, and don't care about achievements then buy this game!!!

review:
No getting around the Slay the Spire comparisons, but I do believe that this game can really stand as it's equal. 

I feel that the developers do a great job at using Slay the Spire as a blueprint, but then throwing in a lot of their own ideas to make it unique. The synergies that you can have mixing 2 out of the 5 clans together is amazing, protecting your pyre gives the gameplay a little hint of "tower defense", and you have so much freedom on how you upgrade your cards.

I really hope more people play this game and the developers continue to support it, because I can see myself losing many more hours to this.

title: Monster Train

Monster Train (apart from being gifted of a terrible generic title) is a fantastic game. title: Monster Train
review:
I wanted to wait a while to write this review, since I really wasn't sure of my opinion of this game at the start.

Let's start with the obvious.  This is a deck-building game similar to Slay the Spire and Griftlands.  Presentation wise, it holds up very well.  The card designs and animated "board" you play on remind me of Hearthstone.  Visually, everything works well together, and the time and polish put into its design is very evident.  The only minor complaint I have on this front is the sound design.  Especially with the battle speed turned up, the grunts and groans of the units get a bit tedious.  The music, however, is great.  I simply reduce the sound effects in the options and problem solved.

Now the less obvious, and the reason I held off making the review.  My first game of this nature was Slay the Spire.  Needless to say, I started on quite the high note.  Having put in a fair bit of time with that game, my first few games of Monster Train felt a little slow and "samey".  I'm really not sure that this is the fault of the game, however.  Having played it a bit more now, I feel like my expectations were off.  I came in expecting all the options I had in Slay the Spire with everything unlocked and available.  Now that I have all the tribes, and most of the cards, unlocked, decks and strategies feel much more unique.  I do feel like the enemies and bosses could use a bit more variety.  Still, that doesn't keep this game from being enjoyable, and this will likely improve over time since the developers seem committed to the game.  There is already new free DLC for the game.  There are also a few modes that I haven't tried yet, like custom and multiplayer.

At the end of the day (or 23 hours at the time of this review), I definitely recommend the game.  Even after those first few games left me feeling a little underwhelmed, I quickly fell into the "just one more turn" loop and couldn't put it down.  Worth checking out for any fan of the genre.

title: Monster Train
review:
I have 200 hours on Slay the Spire (StS) and 70 hours on this game. I have a little bit of a history with card games, playing Netrunner for many years (never did get into Magic, though) and I consider board gaming to be one of my primary hobbies. Context for my review (I make quite a few comparisons to StS in here).

Monster Train is a rogue-like, creature combat, deck drafting game, essentially. "Heroes" are your units that battle the enemy units. You play them to occupy floors. You can think of the floors as almost a "lane" system, with enemies advancing from the bottom floor, to the middle, to the top floor each after a single combat round. Hopefully you kill them before they reach the top. Eventually, a boss will show up. The boss stops at each floor, from the bottom up, and rounds of combat are continuous until the floor is cleared or the boss is dead. Any units that overflow your top floor attack your "pyre" (like your health pool). The pyre has an attack value and will fight back a bit in continuous rounds of combat until its health runs out or the attackers die. When you run out of pyre health it's game over.

This is a great drafting game. The structure of the drafting is interesting. The majority of your drafting is for support spells and minor monsters. You are only able to draft a limited number of heroes during special draft events, and those drafts are front-loaded in your run. You fairly quickly have to figure out what your limited hero-pool will be and how to best synergize your team. From there you have to make sure that the support cards you draft match your hero makeup. This helps keep things a bit fresher, as most cards are situationally good and there aren't always the same "best value" cards in every run. I like this in contrast to StS, where it often feels like I'm trying for the same builds or using the same cards every time. You can further upgrade your cards to really customize how your deck is working. Many of my runs came together as I put powerful upgrades on particularly synergistic spells or heroes. And boy, when you find a power combo, it REALLY goes off in this game and that feels quite satisfying.

Card draw tends to be somewhat limited, so it's important to be choosy about what you draft-- you don't need a card from every draft pack! Thin decks are better decks, and card removal is also relatively plentiful in Monster Train. This is in contrast to StS, where sometimes it make more sense to dilute the "bad" cards in your deck by drafting large and playing best-value. I like that this game has you focus on making a "tighter" deck. The decision points at each draft opportunity feel a bit more impactful for it.

I had waned on Slay the Spire due to the same-ness that a lot of my runs felt. How similar my drafting strategy was as certain builds just seemed blatantly better than others. I came back to StS after The Watcher was released since she felt fresh and like there were more options. I continued to play her exclusively for many hours. That's the kind of feel that I get with this game. There are five factions (colors, if you will) in Monster Train and you combine any two of them for each run. The sheer number of combinations keeps the game feeling fresh. Sure, I have my "favorite" cards for each faction, but they are still a bit more flexible than, say, StS. Different faction combinations give different value choices for heroes and spells, and that leads to continually interesting value choices as the hours go by.

If you are a fan of deck drafting games, I cannot recommend this one enough. I'm usually not one for creature combat, but the variety of mechanics among each faction, the satisfying and powerful combos you can develop, and the progression system (much more forgiving than StS) keep me coming back time after time. 10/10 would play again.

title: Monster Train
review:
(Having played all the way up to and completed maximum difficulty with most of the clans, I think I've got an adequate grasp on it now.)

If you have any interest in discovering ridiculously powerful combinations in card games, you will enjoy this!  The developers are clearly interested in letting players discover these fun builds that just let your decks snowball against the hardest challenges they have implemented.  Further, they are very active in continuing to expand the game, adding new modes, new free cosmetics to unlock, and balancing the cards to help encourage use of the least picked cards.

Further, if you love digging into the lore of the game, there is a lot to discover.  Every single unit, both friendly and enemy, as well as each spell card and artifact has lore text written by an in-setting character.  Lore for friendly units, spells and artifacts are currently viewable at any time through the in game logbook (which you can access midrun), while enemy lore can only be seen if you turn on lore tooltips and have one on screen.  Hopefully they will add an enemies section to the logbook so that you can review their lore at any time as well.

Finally, the production values are great.  Each unit is animated in combat, most cards have animated images, 
and the soundtrack is really well orchestrated.  If you have any interest in deckbuilders, I think you will find something to enjoy in this game.

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1]CHOO CHOO A FINISHED GAME IN 2020? 
Next stop: Heaven.[/h1]

Nowadays, a game which releases publicly, aka hits 1.0, is an unholy trainwreck that needed more months (even years) of development.
Polish? Non-existent, expect tons of bugs.
Content? Yeah, not done yet, here is a roadmap for you to read.

Monster Train, a game made by some nobodies, somehow, hits the glory of old games. When they came in disks, because the game was **Complete**, fully done, no updates needed.
Who the fuck even buys games at launch nowadays? Just wait a year, to not only get that -50%+ discount, but also to get that "definitive" edition (because of course, the definitive/final experience isn't on launch)

So, you have a game, that somehow, reaches 1.0, no bugs, full of polish and [b]S O U L[/b], shit tons of content that can keep you playing for months like the games of old, and a lot of misc content no one asked for, like, full discord integration (with a button uploading your run on the official discord server for example), or mutators, or daily challenges... And they even overdid it, the madlads added even multiplayer!
Where you are literally rushing the fuck out of the game, against other players to reach the end of hell! (think of time-attack/speedrun, but actually polished so there is some kind of interaction, there are 8 players per hell rush and your goal is to simply surpass others, not win the game ;)

Most games I play, are either free (old games, emulatable or yarr), or bought at deep discount (60%+)
It has been literally [b]years[/b] since I last bought a game without any discount. And weirdly, I don't have any regret for this, since the game is well worth its price for sure.

As for the game itself, it is familiar, yet original. People saying it is a clone of Slay the Spire are doing it injustice. It is a mix of many many things, one of them being the niche Tower Defense genre. Ultimately, it fuses so much shit together, and it just works.
Soundtrack is surprisingly good, given its made for a freaking card game ngl.
Replayability is off the pyre room's roof! So much content! And that isn't enough, since the developers want to keep improving, even though the game is literally overfilled and finished wtf
If it had a little better artstyle (look combat pics), it would be GOTY for me.

I have played pretty much every card game out there and I thought I had seen it all...

title: Monster Train
review: A very competent, well made game hindered by IMHO terrible art style. I initially dismissed this game because of how "mobile-ly" and "Clash of Clan-ish" it looked. It was only when I saw a YouTube review of this game comparing it to Magic the Gathering that I gave it a fighting chance. What I found was a delicious, mechanically solid deckbuilder with just the right pacing to keep you coming back for more. I have thoroughly enjoyed my 14 hours of gameplay and looking forward to seeing more of what the game can offer. It would be a shame to call this a Slay the Spire clone as this game truly holds it own. I guess don't judge a book by its cover, but honestly can the cover be better? Thoroughly recommended (for its inner beauty)

title: Monster Train
review:
Slay the Spire but Fun ?

This game is potentially better than slay the spire for a few reasons

- More player creativity
- Better artwork
- 5 Heroes that can be combined for many run types
- More impactful choices
- Game feels more of a 'fair' roguelite
- Push your luck with more player choice rather than slay the spires you randomly die despite perfect decisions.

Overall this game is decent in current form and you get your hours for the price, that said its lacking in a few ways that I hope they work on within the year if not I would not recommend this game without a deep sale.

- 2 of the Heroes feel too similar in their buff focus which makes them feel pointless and undistinc
- UI needs work add logbook to the main menu obviously
- Make the monster train icon customizeable because its me on it !
- Add more heroes because theres certain kinds of hero missing you would expect to be there
- Enemies need to be more intresting and have more intresting deaths
- Bosses need more personality
- Reduce the starting pack duplicates so much of this game feels like card removal

I hope for the best because this game is certainly interesting

At first I thought this game looked pretty hideous - I wasn't a fan of the art direction at all. BUT, just like Slay the Spire it turns out that not only does the ugly art weirdly work, but it's ultimately irrelevant because there is a super engrossing and absorbing deck building game with plenty of new gimmicks that I have not seen mixed together before that just works.

Edit: Also this game has such amazing music - ever since someone pointed out to me that some of the tracks sound like a train chugging away I'm hooked on it.

There is so much to keep coming back for in this game, highly recommended

title: Monster Train
review: Really enjoyed the game. At higher covenant ranks, it gets to the point where you have to just keep resetting until you get a broken synergy to be able to beat it, which is a shame, but that only really matters at 15ish+. What really sucks is that the dailies are so poorly randomized. I played most dailies for awhile, until I realized that there it feels like there are only 4-5 affixes and all most of them do is make the game unfun, not challenging. Sometimes you get a good daily, but usually they are way to easy or impossible.

title: Monster Train
review: Has a much less linear build path than most other roguelike deck builders. Runs are pretty much the perfect length. Enemy difficulty scales incredibly on runs as well. With the way the game is designed it's pretty hard to have a "bad" run as well which is nice, you don't spend nearly as much time getting bad rng at the beginning to just have to start over (does still happen, just rarely). The amount of synergies and combos you can do is staggering. Very fun game would definitely recommend it if you like deck builders or just want to try something new.

The different clans all feel so unique and the ally system is a huge game changer. Once you unlock all 5 clans you can really start to play around with synergy and it's a blast! Nothing feels too easy (although some things do feel too challenging for certain deck builds... which is how it should be) and there are options to make each encounter, besides bosses, harder for better rewards. 
If you like rogue-like deck building games, definitely give this one a shot!!

title: Monster Train
review: One of the best STS style deckbuilder games I've played, and I've played a lot of them.  The tactical nature of running on three floors makes the game feel different from the other deck builders, and the graphics, gameplay, and sound are all on point.  Really impressed with this one.

title: Monster Train
review: entertaining

title: Monster Train
review:
Love this game. Very similar to Slay the Spire but with more variety in my opinion. Plenty of progression based rewards, such as new cards or relics associated with each of the 5 playable factions. 
Each faction has its own unique playstyle, spells, creatures, and champions. To further increase the complexity and diversity of each run, you get to pick a primary and secondary faction allowing you to create tons of different strategies. 
Run consist of completing a battle, then choosing a reward path to help increase your power for the next battle. During battles the objective is to defeat the enemy creatures, and then a boss, as they enter the train before they have a chance to reach the Pyre and cause damage, if the Pyre takes too much damage during the run you lose. 
To further increase replay value, if you successfully manages complete a run, you will unlock a new Convenant Ranks that will increase the difficulty of the next run. There are 25 of these ranks you can unlock.
Finally to end this review, they just announce free DLC not long ago to further add to the fun! I didnt even bother to mention the daily challenges and multiplayer mode. This game is great and if you enjoy it, will keep you entertained for HOURS!

title: Monster Train
review:
I love Slay the spire. You can check my hours and see just how much I love the spire. I really enjoyed crafting decks in fractions of seconds and just destroying runs on there. I thought that this was the best. 

I was wrong. Slay the spire is amazing. I'm sure it will continue to be amazing, with mods, new characters, dlc and who knows what. I will still play it. 

Monster Train is an improvement upon the formula. Of course there are similarities. Things you learne din slay the spire will bring you here. 

Of course this game is far more than slay the spire. You have more to worry about. More ways to worry about your builds. But your ways of playing through Ascensions, or Covenants, is not focused on one "character".

You have clans. A primary one, and a secondary one. Whatever you choose as the primary gives you their champion. And some spells. The secondary just gives you some spells. As you progress, you can add from either's groupings of cards. 

There are only 5 right now, but it is more than enough. Plenty to unlock, plenty to explore, and of course plenty to play. 

Say goodbye to your afternoon, your evening, and your night. This is not an easy game. But it is a fun one.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
This game has built on the foundation laid by Slay The Spire and, in my opinion, improved on it in almost every way. If you enjoyed Slay The Spire, you absolute should buy this without hesitation. If you haven't, but you enjoy good rogue-like games or card games/deckbuilding games - you should not miss this.

You should be prepared for a merciless difficulty curve -- however, losses rarely feel unfair and climbing through the Covenant (difficulty) levels feels really accomplishing. You'll always feel like you're learning the game better and continuing to find satisfying card interactions/combinations.

Ex: I had a monster that was going to die the next turn if i didn't kill a backline enemy, I didn't have any offensive based spells, but i did have a card that buffed a unit with more damage at the cost of a bit of health, I usually always saw it as a card for your units but I was able to use it on an enemy to kill them
