title: Monster Train
review:
Overall the game is good; the mechanics are interesting, races are fun and there are plenty of combinations and strategies each. 
A big con is the RNG; although somewhat controllable, it can destroy a fun run in a single battle. Every card games has its random factors and it is up to the player to take hold of them, Mons Train has the chance to 100% end a game on a single Random instance. Be aware.

title: Monster Train
review: With the current trend of deck-builder rogue-lites after Slay the Spire, Monster Train feels like the best one yet: it innovates enough things to keep it fresh and different from StS, but retains spirit of deck-building that StS defined. Personally I feel the game is easier than StS (which is a good thing) as their are more "classes" which only have a few strategies rather than a few "classes" with a lot of strategies in StS. If you are looking for a challenge the multitude of covenants to make your way through is more than enough.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you're a fan of the excellent Slay the Spire, Monster Train will be RIGHT up your alley.  There are similarities in the mechanics of the games, but this is NOT a clone nor a rip-off of Slay the Spire!  It's a familiar backdrop with a plethora of new and interesting things...spell and unit effects, and the clan system all work together quite well.

I got this game on sale with the Steam Summer Sale, but despite being early access it is very much worth it's full price!  For anyone that is a fan of rogue-like deck-building games, you cannot pass Monster Train up!

title: Monster Train
review:
It is good, you should get it.  Here's why:

-  Creative, engaging, much replayability the way you can mix and match your primary and secondary clan.
-  Deck building game, as you go along you choose routes that force you to pick through different upgrades/events.  Some have merchants, where you can exchange $ you earned winning fights on upgrades to your troops or your spells, or buying artifacts and other random events.

-  As you move along, you hew down and temper your deck, making it lean and mean.  You have to find a gimmick, or an engine, an exploit or hack to create a real kickass deck and get far.  

The meh: Graphics are fine.  Not the biggest fan, feels a little...mundane.  But still, super well polished game with solid gameplay loop.  

Also shoutout to the Lore guy, that's cool the way he wrote so much of the history of the clans, and their interactions with the antagonist of the game, the angels.

Tritely put: StS meets a deck-building + RPG + combat tower defense kinda, in that that the enemies you don't kill march upwards toward your "pyre", which, if it takes enough damages, causes you to lose.  

I usually don't write reviews, but I do for games I really endorse.  Which is not many.  Cheers --

title: Monster Train
review:
A fairly fun gameplay loop marred by terrible replayability with regard to the price point.

The content feels a bit sparse - you will see the same chain of minibosses and the same enemies with little to no variation every run, and the random events seem to repeat incredibly often, but this isn't a huge deal.

The big problem is the balance. The replayability is based on different faction combinations and deck archetypes, but the factions vary wildly in power - two of them can carry any 'minor' faction by just ignoring it altogether, and at least one of the factions is actively terrible - not just 'you wouldn't play it if it were a competitive game' terrible, but the mechanic it revolves around is so underpowered and hardcountered by so many enemy mechanics that it is actively unpleasant.

I don't know how often the devs push fixes or content, but it fairly desperately needs some fixes. Right now, anyone who wants a deckbuilding game who hasn't played Slay the Spire for a few hundred hours should pretend this doesn't exist and go but STS. Monster train still has a long way to go.

title: Monster Train
review:
A solid roguelike deck builder in the vein of Slay The Spire, but with some key differences it to make it a unique experience that stands above the hordes of StS clones. The multi-tiered unit-based combat is fun and strategic, with plenty of decisions to make per turn. The card upgrade system is fantastic, adding to the already impressive deck building scope built on a foundation of a plethora of interesting units, spells, class synergies and artefact effects.
Monster Train is another great addition to the roguelike genre, and one of the best deckbuilders I've had the pleasure of playing. Definitely worth picking up at full price.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like Slay the Spire, or any roguelike/deckbuilder games then you'll love this.

The game is fairly easy to get into, and it also has a gimmick going for where you play a mix of 2 playable races from the 5 options. You can decide before the game starts what kind of build will you be aiming for, or just leave it random for varieties sake aswell.

This game is quite surprising in a way, that while it lets you go out of control quite easily during a fight (having overly buffed units or giant combos going for example), you can still lose it just the same if you make a mistake. This makes it quite challenging and fun at the same time, in my opinion. The runs are also relatively short, and the soundtrack is something which also deserves a special note.

If you enjoyed any similar games to this, then you should definitely try this one out aswell.

title: Monster Train
review: good

title: Monster Train
review:
StS came from nowhere and hit my sweet spot. So I played it. A lot. Then Monster Train arrived...and now I got a new obsession. 

3 acts, each ending with a boss. Build yer deck. Fight the big bad. So far, so StS. 
But each battle takes place on a 3 storied train, so also shades of tower defence.

It does have an excellent rewards system, letting you customise cards hard...by act 3 some of your starter deck are massive hammers of hurt.

Granted, it's not anything new...but everything borrowed is amplified, polished and then stitched into the whole so seamlessly. The theme and art are great, it plays well, and while I think I've unlocked all classes/cards, I'm no master. I lose plenty, but less to the RNG than me being foolish..

In all, after all these years this is StS' first real contender. Could be it's just the new shiny toy, but I'm into it. The only question left is, how many hours will I clock protecting the furnace?

title: Monster Train
review:
It's deceptively easy to spend hours on this game. A run takes me about an hour and that time is filled with constant progression and leveling up. Satisfying. That's how the game feels. Yes, it's frustrating to lose a couple of runs in a row on level 6-7 but it doesn't feel like a huge deal to just try again. 

I'm a big fan of deck building board games and this scratches the same itch and gives something extra that would not really work in physical format. I like that the combat resolution is completely deterministic. So first there's the puzzle on how to optimize your deck and then there's smaller puzzles in each battle.

I think this will be one of those few games that I will complete.

title: Monster Train
review:
It's been a long time since I wrote last review, so just some thoughts on the title:

Monster Train.
Awesome game for tacticians, don't be confused by 'card builder' description, I'd say it is turn-based game, cards act more like 'RNG' than like actual cards.
First run and impression - "hmmm.. seems very easy and stupid..", then after you are beaten by AI angels - "whaat? lemme try again.."
Second run: "not that easy, just need more experience to win..."
...
After first win: "woooaa! there are five (5!) total clans" (clans can be combined, 'main' clan defines your 'hero'), "and so many clans combinations"
After numerous losses and second win: "wooooa it was the first 'easiest' difficulty? challenge accepted!"

Game runs on windws and linux (running on linux normally means auto thumbs up for me, but this game fully deserves it)

review:
I've only had the game for a little while and i've already played 8 hours of it. Very good game, quite addictive, you know the old "just one more turn"? well this is like just one more fight. 

Many people tend to compare this to slay the spire. I somewhat disagree. 
This is like slay the spire if slay the spire had depth.
Theres multiple champions and each champion has its own cards and usually a few different play styles, but thats also added to by your secondary. You don't just choose one type to play you choose two, primary and secondary. The way the two interact and help (or hinder if you do it wrong) each other is awesome. 
Extremely good game, best of its genre to date. 

Heartily recommend. Though a word of warning. You will lose track of time playing this...

title: Monster Train
review: For those who enjoy the addiction that the assurance of incremental improvement and repetition provide then look no further. There is an enormous amount of fun here for those of us who like to do the same thing over and over again whilst expecting slightly different results. The playing of video games does often require a mindset of stubborn optimism and suspension of disbelief for which we are rewarded by being able to progress in a way that is more obvious and measurable than in real life. This game satisfies that part of our mind that realises that time is indeed to be wasted on idle and fruitless pursuits.  In return for our wasteful nihilsm, we might be rewarded with the perverse pleasure that addicitve video gaming can bring. Your brain will be so engaged by the all encompassing gameplay that the rest of existence will smply become peripheral. So, yes, there is enjoyment to be had here but don't blame me if you suddenly realise, several months from now, that you wasted the best part of your summer playing an invidious deck builder instead of going out and living your life. It is, therefore, highly recommended for play during a pandemic!

title: Monster Train
review: If you like Slay the Spire you will love Monster Train.

title: Monster Train
review:
I honestly don't know how they've done this. It's like Slay the Spire had a baby with three or four slightly different versions of itself, and somehow it still works and is shockingly well balanced. Instead of picking a hero, you choose two clans, one primary and one support. There are five, and they have a nice progression of complexity:

Hellhorned: Brute strength offense
Awoken: Healing, regeneration
Stygian Guard: Magic, control
Umbra: whaaaaaaaat
Melting Remnant: whoaaaaaaa

I love how the first three clans are very much like M:tG red, green, and blue, leading you to think the last two are going to be black/white analogues. But then you unlock them and they're just...something else entirely. So cool.

I can't say enough good things about this game. But I'll try to say a few.

[list][*]All the information you need is available at all times. You can see your entire deck, what's in your draw, discard, and consume piles, and even what the outcome of the turn will be if you end it now. Very well presented.
[*]You have a nice logbook that tracks all your different runs, scores, unlocks, and compares to your friends. You can check it without interrupting your current run. Neat!
[*]There are many ways to build something that seems hilariously overpowered, but most of them have some kind of achilles heel that you'll have to prepare for. 
[*]There is a perfectly medium number of special abilities that creatures can possess. Enough to create a huge variety of interactions, but not so many that it's hard to remember what they do. Same with spells. 
[*]In about 30 hours of play it hasn't crashed, glitched, or slowed down once. It's rock solid.

Highest recommendation. Don't wait for a sale. Just get it.
[/list]

However, this game is different when compared to other rogue-lites in that you focus on buffing up a train full of heroes to battle it out against the enemies. If you haven't played slay the spire, I would suggest checking that one out first. If you like that game, then this is in a similar vein. title: Monster Train
review:
Now even though I selected not recommend, I want to say this comes with a lot of caveats.

I would still recommend this game to those who wish to sate their thirst for a decent deck building, rogue run game, but currently this game still lacks polish, even when in comparison to Griftlands, a game still in early access.  Therefore I won't recommend it to anyone new to this sub-genre, I would rather point them to Slay the Spire instead.

For one, other games in this sub-genre like Slay the Spire and Griftlands, all recognize that it is frustrating that a half an hour to one hour run can be easily ruined by a bad draw in the first one or two turns, so they mitigate it with setting certain cards to be drawn on the first turn; this is a feature that Monster Train sorely lacks and has resulted in many of my runs ruined.

Certainly RNG is an essential element of this sub-genre, yet when other games do it better, it is hard to see Monster Train as anything but lacking.  I have some other minor gripes but they don't come as close as to the one I just mentioned.  I know it is unfair to compare this to Slay the Spire, an older game that had more time to fix itself, but when an early access game can do it better, then I see no reason why Monster Train can't improve on the same thing, especially when there are other examples to borrow from.

So yeah, here is a bit of my rant.  Hopefully it doesn't come as too condemning.  I still like this game and don't regret buying it, but it still needs a lot of works.

review: A refreshing take on the rougelike deckbuilder, Monster Train provides an interesting and addicting take at the formula. At first I looked at it wondering if it felt different enough from similar deckbuilders like Slay the Spire, and after playing I feel the answer is definitely yes. Runs are shorter and faster, with bosses that feel more powerful, and managing space for your units across 3 floors makes the game unique compared to other games like this.

Really fun deckbuilding roguelike.  It's like Slay the Spire, except you're the Spire this time.

Could definitely use some balancing checks, but I'm optimistic the devs will support that.  It very quickly goes from "nothing gets to attack me" to "I just got one shot" real quick at the final boss or two.  That or you get a super OP Artifact right away that basically ensures you'll win.  But the gameplay is super fun overall.

title: Monster Train
review: This is a very fun game. The replayability is very high since each run is different, and you choose both a primary and an allied faction. Each pair of factions will play differently and each faction has 3 champion types, resulting in a ton of different options. The daily challenges also completely switch things up with the addition of mutators that can make big changes to game mechanics.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is 100% my jam. It takes what I loved and spent hundreds of hours on in Magic Duels, Slay the Spire, and Dicey Dungeons, trims away much of the busywork, and isn't afraid to let you come up with near-broken combos. In fact, it expects it.

The almost tower-defence aspect of the three level train is clever for opening up varying strategies at different meta-layers (per turn, per battle, per run). The compressed boss rush at the end of each battle is genius at limiting their length and preventing the kinds of degenerate strategies that in other games let you laboriously eke out a win but take dozens of turns. Here, if you want to win you need to set up your engine (in the form of units) quick smart.

Monster Train is as close to a pure "series of interesting decisions" game as I think I've ever played. It's great.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
I only recently discovered the joys of Slay the Spire. And then the Monster Train rolled through and took me with it. What a ride! 
>30 hours in and there is still so much to do, so many combinations to master. Every run is its own thing. The choice to combine two of five very different clans to set up your deck is genius. Finding the synergies, weaknesses and strenghths of the decks you can build out of these (depending of what you get in your current run of course), together with upgrades and artifacts, is a lot of fun. There is a surprising amount of depth here. Yes, some combinations are more potent than others, but it is still fun to go for a more unlikely combination and lead it to victory. The covenant ranks keep things interesting, even as you progress. I'm honestly not sure if I will ever reach rank 25, but that's not gonna stop me from playing!

Highly, very highly recommended!

The minions are both your main character and expendables, this makes for tough choices, or at least meaningful choices, nearly all the time. Spells also have a lot more variety since they need to be relevant for more types of situations.
There's also a very good amount of replayability, and 5 different factions, each accompanied by one of the 4 others.

As long as you have some affinity with the genre, or are curious to try it out, this is definitely something you should buy. Maybe wait for a discount, but I think that fullprice it's nearly worth it, so if you're itching to try it out, you should be satisfied even with a small discount.

title: Monster Train
review:
I love Slay the Spire and other deck builders with roguelike elements and when I saw Monster Train I was initially turned off because the style looked totally different... checked out a few Steam reviews and decided to give it a go last week... already 28 hours on record & I can confidently say this game looks like it has another 50-100+ hours of replay enjoyment easily.

Overall, Monster Train is very innovative and different from any other game I've played and its differences are extremely strong and fun in their own right.

Cons:
- EDIT: after reaching higher difficulties both my initial "cons" were proven inappropriate. I initially thought over-powered card combinations were too easily accessible, and that final boss fights were rarely "epic" (either landslide victory or defeat)... won for the first time on max difficulty after 5+ losses in a row (OP cards aren't too accessible), and after the final boss killed all my floors my Pyre squeaked out a victory with 9 health remaining and some frostbite assistance from the graves of my allies (final boss fights can be extremely epic).

Pros:
- TONS of room for creativity combining the 5 different clans.  When you pick a primary clan, you also pick an allied clan and the possible synergies in combination are incredibly high and very satisfying to explore.
- What the game might lack in epic final boss fights, it more than makes up for with the satisfaction of refining your defenses like a well oiled machine.
- Most of all: Monster Train hits a grand slam with the tower defense genre:  If you're like me you've probably tried 5-10 tower defense games in the past and enjoyed them for a bit, but ended up feeling like they're mostly shallow and tedious once you learn how to exploit the game.  Monster Train is essentially a tower defense game executed near flawlessly in terms of the nuanced, challenging, & meaningful decisions you make at every step of the game (both within battles and between battles). You always need to adapt to the options available to you, and like most good rogue-lites it feels like a victory is possible (or would have been possible) if you play your cards right.

Overall, the game is way more fun than reading this review. If you made it this far, it's a 100% buy IMO.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you love slay the spire, you will love this game. I believe at the time of this review I have just shy of 100 hours logged into STS. I FINALLY beat the final boss in STS and now am basically just grinding all my champs to 100%. I was beginning to get a bid bored of that and a friend had recommended me this game so I picked it up.

It is similar to STS in a LOT of ways but it is NOT the same game. With this game you have a train in which there are 3 floors and 1 room with essentially your nexus / heart. If the enemies climb from the bottom floor to the hear they will attack it and it can fight back but once it dies its game over. So you basically have to play 3 different floors of strategy at the same time and have to worry about your heart. 

It can be a little bit chaotic but once you get the hang of it, it is extremely fun!!! I have about 10 hours logged into it now and there are probably 30 something different combinations in which you can pick your "Heros" and each one has its own deck, similar to STS with Ironclad, Silent, Defect and Watcher. So you get to fine incredibly good combos with the deck building and sometimes it will be a good deck up till the last boss fight, sometimes you die on the second boss.

Overall it has a LOT of replay-ability and a LOT of potential. I am very excited to see some new updates in the future but in the meantime I will continue to play and try to get 100% on this game as well!

review:
If you are patient enough to get past the initial stage, the game is pretty good. Unfortunately a lot of viable strategies rely on things you have to unlock first, so early on there's not much to do. Combine that with the biggest difficulty spike happening between difficulty 0 and 1, and you might get a little frustrated after your first win. You CAN go back to 0 though. And you probably should.

30 hours in, having every card just unlocked, I can definitely recommend this. There are some issues with balance, but it's nothing that makes the game unplayable. Just know when it's time to abandon a run. If the game wants to improve, this is the biggest thing. A lot of runs are doomed 1 minute into the game. Things like the game tracking "win streaks" isn't really helping there either. It's best to ignore.

title: Monster Train
review:
As basically all the other reviews say, this is a fantastic entry to the deck-building genre. 

If you're new to this type of game, give it a try, it's very approachable, with easy-to-learn basic mechanics and a gradual increase in difficulty that never makes you feel like you go from "challenging" to "impossible" in one jump. (And you can always choose a lower difficulty for any run)

If you've played any others like this (probably Slay the Spire) then you HAVE to get Monster Train. The graphics are great and the soundtrack is really something special. More importantly, the game offers some new mechanics that really work well and add to the experience. Most notably the multi-level battling and the ability to choose 2 of the 5 factions for each run, creating many more possible deck builds than StS offers.

Read some more reviews if you want, But then buy this game, you won't regret it :)

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Hunter is a masterful deck building game, with multiplayer challenges and even a dueling multiplayer mode. There are many difficulty levels, and lots of interesting card combinations between the 6 factions. 

Its Slay the spire, with a pile of twists. You pick a main faction (deciding your upgradable hero minion), and a secondary (extra spell/artifact/minion options). Spells and mobs can be upgraded at shops, there are random encounters in the form of ice caves, and many artifacts (items that give buffs to your run) to aid you along the way. Mobs spawn on the first floor, and move up every turn. Each floor has space to cast your own minions, and most spells only effect one floor. If mobs get to the top, they fight your "pyre", attempting to chip away (or sometimes just one shot) your health pool. 

Pick it up if you like deckbuilding games.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is so fun. There are 20 different combinations of starting loadout, made even more varied by starting champ/artifacts. The combos are satisfying, the minions are fun to kill, and consuming morsels to make a unbelievably huge monster is extremely satisfying. 

Only complaint is that the enemy sprite count is a tad lacking, but you will be fighting many different iterations based on Trials and randomly selected enemy composition, so it's mostly a visual repetition thing than it is gameplay repetition (which is good).  If we could get some unique visuals on enemies (which first dlc might just do) I wouldn't really have anything bad to say. 

If you like Slay the Spire but want a creature-casting combo-rific slaughterfest on a train in Hell, this is for you.

title: Monster Train
review: I originally heard about this game from one of the people at GameInformer the day after I added it to my steam wishlist. The game plays similar to other card playing games like slay the spire for example, and it brings together a fresh take on the genre by adding three levels to an already interesting unit-summon/spellcaster style game. The game stay fresh and is easier to play for long periods because they added a two alliance system when you start your run. You can pick any combination of two factions of the five available and each has their own respective champion with 3 available specs that can be cross bred mid run to make a hybrid of your champion. The games visuals also make the game really fun to watch compared to other games with a grasp of depth to your train. The game progresses by winning your encounter and picking which path you want to follow with your monster train. whichever track you follow is lined with upgrades exclusive to that path until the next battle. With your path of travel locked in to your selection, you then get to access upgrades respectively to whats on your path. One path may allow you to remove two spells from you deck you don't want or it may contain the ability to attune your spell cards with upgrades. What keeps me coming back is the large variety of options and ways to play and the increasing difficulty with what the game calls covenant ranks. Beyond the first time you make it to hell's core to relight the fire put out by the winged, you have 25 covenant ranks to beat until you can call yourself a master. The game tracks win streaks and shows you what difficulty you've beat with all of the pairs of factions. I think I've been playing for 4 days now and I keep appreciating the small features this game has from the tracking of stats to the ability to create challenges for other players. I could not recommend this game more if you like card battlers like slay the spire. You can even have cards that make your trains pyre (your health crystal that powers you train) to obliterate enemy units. Its just so freaking cool.

title: Monster Train
review:
Update: 7/3/2020

My Overall Rating: 9 out of 10

Pros+
+Great Selection of Cards
+Artwork is on point/aesthetic
+Music is a perfect fit for this game
+Unique Plot
+Plenty of replay value
+Challenging but fair

The list could go on! This a great deck building game with an interesting take on this genre in my opinion. 

Cons-
- Artwork may seem mobile like to some people.
- RNG aspects can be frustrating at times and sometimes it seems as if you are destined to lose no matter the strategy on certain runs. (However this is in my opinion a way to make you think and strategize more)
- Sometimes the cards descriptions may not be real clear on how powerful or weak they truly are. This is part of the challenge I think but I do notice some of the information on some cards seems to be off point but this a very rare occurrence so far in my game-play. 

There are probably some other negatives somewhere that I am not noticing so far but overall this is a really solid game. If you like these style games (like Slay the Spire, deck building games, Yugioh, etc.) then you will likely enjoy this with little to no problems.


Original Post:
So far this game is really fun and makes for a great time waster. If you like card games then I would bet on you liking this game too. I will update again after I play more but so far it was worth the purchase.

title: Monster Train
review:
Early on, as I was learning how Monster Train worked, I managed to get to the final boss. He comes in three variations and you're told which one you'll face when you begin a run, but I didn't pay too much attention because, hey, I'm learning and was prepared to lose. Upon reaching him and checking what I was up against, I learned his version of the final boss would remove the first spell you played every turn from the game (normally, spells get discarded when cast and then re-shuffled into your draw pile to potentially be used again). I looked over my artifacts I'd picked up and realized something: I had an artifact that gave me a free, 0-cost damage spell every turn (with the bonus that it would also give me +1 draw on the next turn).

I'd completely negated this boss's intended downside!

Monster Train is a single-player deckbuilding game that gives you a semi-randomized initial batch of cards, a multitude of decisions to make as you travel down the tracks to save Hell from renegade angels, and tasks you to break the game before it breaks you. 

Each run, you pick a main faction and their champion unit, and pair it with a supporting ally faction; these determine what cards you come across, and thus your potential strategies. Before each fight, you have to pick from either a left or right path of shops, healing, or other events. Every fight, you have three floors to work with before invading enemies chip at your core's health. Winning brings gold and card draft choices (and maybe more if you take on each fight's optional challenge risk). 

Between the five factions, three main floors + the core's floor, oodles of cards and upgrades and buffs for them, enemy and boss variations, Ice Cavern random events, passive artifacts that can further twist how you might play, there is so much emergent combos and pitfalls to risk that it tingles the mind.

You're presented a new problem to tackle every run and turn, and this is made all the more appetizing by great art and an infectious and epic RPG-quality soundtrack.

If you're a fan of other deckbuilder-style games, you need to give Monster Train a try. If you're a fan of video games in general, you should give it a try.

Great game, can not wait to see what future updates add.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is fantastic!  I feel like it really hits what is essential and fun about deck builders, while removing some of the annoyances that have plagued it.

1.  Its removed a lot of the high swings of randomness.  I feel like I can win almost every game, and never feel the need to reset.

2.  Its properly paced.

3.  Deck strategies and combos are fun.

4.  There's a random set of rules and restrictions in multiplayer every day.  Even if you don't care about the board numbers, they're often fun.

This game is a polished gem in the pile of deck builders.  I highly recommend it!

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is clearly heavily influenced by Slay The Spire as everyone else has pointed out. I'd say it doesn't quite achieve the greatness that StS has, but I'd highly recommend it.

PROS:

- The 3 floors and combat flow mechanics are what separates this game from StS primarily, and adds a nice variety to the game play that has a different feel to it than StS. It also opens up a lot of interesting strategies.
- The artwork in this game is great, especially on the cards. The card art is all animated and looks trippy / amazing
- There are something like 4-5 'races' or deck types, and you can choose a primary deck and an 'allied' deck. It makes each run seem pretty unique and adds a nice variety to things. It felt at least on par with StS in terms of the deck feeling unique each play through.
- Cards can be upgraded with various items that can do things like lower cost, make spells more powerful, buff monsters, etc. It adds to StS's basic card upgrade system and is pretty cool
- The music in this game is really really good, and I think edges out StS. Both soundtracks tend to favour classical instrumental soundtracks. StS was focused more on horns while Monster Train is more bow-instrumenty.

CONS:

- Would've liked to see more variety in the bosses, there are fewer than in StS but the bosses in Monster Train have modifiers on them. I hope they improve this and the monster variety in future updates. This game is new so it's something that's quite probable.
- The balancing in this game seems a lot more loose and less 'tight' than in StS. I'm not sure if this is such a bad thing, but StS just feels more elegantly balanced. Often the numbers just happen to work out or whatever. This game the numbers and what things do varies more wildly.
- I would've liked to choose between more than just 2 paths per encounter. I think the 'pathing' in the runs were more interesting in Slay The Spire

Conclusion: This game is a no-brainer for any existing Slay The Spire fans, and also just recommended as a good game in general for anyone who enjoys strategy games.

title: Monster Train
review:
What a flawless combination of two different genres. Smashing together a tower defense with card rogue-like comes this gem. It is a game you will have a hard time putting down, trying out different combination, harder difficulties, unlocking all the content, even some real time competitive play. This is easily the most replayable rogue-like deck builder than I've played.

You will not be able to put this game down the first day you play it, and for a few days after as well. You will just want to keep trying out different strategies until you realized 35 hours have already passed.

If you are a fan of any popular rogue deck builder, then pick up this game. You won't be disappointed.

title: Monster Train
review:
I'm a huge fan of Monster Train. Here are my thoughts:
* The mechanics are very intuitive, especially for a game of this genre and given how many interacting mechanics there are.
* The clans are well-done: they're all different and the pairings are very interesting.
* The difficulty ramps up well.
* RNG is definitely still a factor, but there are so many things in my control that I almost always feel like I could've won a run if I'd just done something differently (and not that it was RNG's fault).

To address the inevitable comparison between MT and Slay the Spire:
* I feel like MT has less variance and I have more control over the changes to my deck/cards.
* The upgrades are more impactful;
* Therefore each fight plays out noticeably differently than the last.
* If I make some bad decisions (with upgrades or in a fight), I'm going to find out immediately. In STS you can lose a run but not find out for a while due to attrition. I prefer immediate feedback.
* Knowing which version of the final boss you're going to fight is a great change. 
* There are only about three variations for each fight. It doesn't take long to have them memorized. This can be a pro or con depending on the person. For me, it's a pro because there's so much variation with my clan pair and cards/upgrades that the fights still don't feel repetitive.

Best deckbuilder I've ever played and I love the genre.

Maybe the artstyle is not your thing, or the trailers seems too... casual? But in reality this is far more complex than Slay the Spire, with a lot of statistics and possible synergies combining all the clans.

There are 25 levels of difficulty, 5 clans that you can match with one another, lots of different upgrades for the cards...

Look for Northernlion let's play if you have doubts about the game.

The only thing that could improve the game is maybe more enemy variety, I guess they will go to that (or another clan) for possible DLC.

title: Monster Train
review:
Although I have put in a lot of hours into this. I have also played about 100 games and have only won about 16. I am currently rank 14 out of 25. Each time you rank up the game handicaps you more. 

The problem is it seems to lean on the side of luck probably 65% of the time. Where you can have a decent build, and due to the heavy RNG nature of this game you end up losing. Most of the time. 

The game seems to be pretty well playtested but they leaned a little bit too far into the rng factor. It makes it not fun to play when you lose like 50 games in a row where more than half those losses are not the players fault, no matter how good they are. 

The high ranked players are only high ranked because they are lucky. The game is all about getting a lucky draw. I would almost say this is in the same world as a gambling simulator.

title: Monster Train
review: A fun card game that combines elements of tower defense. Currently there are five classes to choose from allowing you to mix and match two classes for a starting loadout. Each class have their own niche and strategic playstyle. It's a fun game that takes the good points from the Slay the Spire and incorporates a lot of their own unique mechanics. However, as of now I feel like there isn't a lot of deviations of playstyle for each class. There is not many surprising strong strategies aside from the main obvious routes in which the class heavily favours. Yet, Monster Train has the same addictive formula in Slay the Spire that makes it a obvious choice for fans of the genre.

For example this has heroes, floors of the train where enemies move, and your deck is always a combination of card types. The combination comes from choosing a main and secondary clan. title: Monster Train
review:
73/100 - Slay the Train! A very enjoyable rogue-like deckbuilder with all of the ups and downs of the genre. Good for a few hours, but if you aren't sure you'll love it, I'd recommend waiting for a better special. Full review below.

= Intro =

Picked this up on Summer Sale. Wasn't...quite what I was imagining, but gave it a good whack today.

= Gameplay: 80/100 = 

Oh man, this game can be fun, when it wants to be. It plays similarly to Slay The Spire, expect now you are placing units, casting spells and the like to fight incoming enemies.

Unlike Slay the Spire, this throws balance out the window, into an open volcano and shoots spitballs at it on the way down. Some of the card interactions are insanely strong, while some are very, very weak. Naturally, this does exacerbate the standard issue of RNG - I found myself either sailing through runs and flipping the final boss the bird or dying before the halfway point.

Like Spire, you move through a preset number of levels, with a period of (random) vendors, upgrades and events between them. And in the theme of this game, these can be very powerful or nearly useless depending if the dice like you or not. 

But the kitten-eating frustration is very much a part of these games, and when a truly great run comes together, you'll be up past your bedtime for the next one. Although, unless you are a nut for this sort of game, you'll find fighting the same enemy sets and bosses every run a little tedious after a while. It feels like the game was meant to have a second half that never got made.

However, the big issue with the game is another issue with Spire clones in general - a lack of progression outside of runs. While you can gradually earn new cards to be thrown into the mix and unlock new races (which you choose 2 to combine at the start of a run) once you've done that the only thing at present to work on is cosmetics.

I've always thought this genre leans too far towards roguelike and needs to go more in a rogue-lite direction, with talents and the like that you can level after runs, and some permanent deckbuilding options.

= Graphics & Audio: 61/100 = 

Quite a pretty game at first glance, with bold colors, crisp looking visuals and fun creature designs. However, you quickly realize that there is essentially no variety to the backdrops or levels, which makes everything sort of turn into a firey blur after a while.

Not to mention that some spells don't even have a visual attached.

Sound effects are quite good - beefy and impactful, and the music, while somewhat generic, won't have you reaching for the mute button.

That all said, while it all looks and sounds good, some more visual variety is definitely needed.

= Style & Feel: 85/100 = 

A nice, original take that honestly feels way more fun than Spire, even when it's making you want to swing your mouse around like a morning star. 

Controls were a little odd to start, and I still occasionally drop cards on the wrong floor - but this is mostly a me issue.

= Value: 41/100 =

As cute, fun and all-round enjoyable as this game is, it does start to feel slightly hollow quite quickly. 

Either you are going to enjoy going through the same runs again and again (with the only changes being RNG or the incremental difficulty unlocked later) or not - and after a few completed runs in I really wanted something more. An endless mode? Some more variety in bosses/enemies? A more permanent deck building option? 

Remember in Spire how you'd unlock the second half of the campaign as you went? I was genuinely waiting for this in Monster Train.

I don't know. I'm sure that some people will end up playing for hundreds of hours. For me, I can't see it lasting more than another 6 or 8. And that's sort of a pity, because what is here is really great. 

I just wish there was more of it. 

= Overall = 

+ It's another rogue-like deckbuilding game!
+ Lots of fun, crazy combinations
+ Some genuinely creative cards and ideas
+ Wonderful (if slightly tedious) visuals
+ Punchy audio
+ 5 decks to mix and match with

- It's another rogue-like deckbuilding game...
- Enemies, backdrops, runs and bosses badly need variety
- Needs some progression outside of cosmetics
- RNG-tastic
- Feels like it's missing half a campaign mode and a few other modes.
- Covenant difficulties are not going to be for everyone.

At the end of the day, it's a good game. A very good game. But  I'm not sure how much replayability it's going to have for people who are burned out on the genre or never liked the repetition.

That all said, if you are a fan of Spire, this one's for you.

The biggest twist is that this occurs over 3 floors where space matters so you can't just dump everything directly onto one floor and let that be your meat grinder; you need to be clever and resourceful.

Or abuse game mechanics until your enemies cry.

title: Monster Train
review: It is a simple game. Never really thought I'd get into a "card" game. It plays out so easily. You have a first round on the demon train. You lose, its quick to start again. But the more you play it, you'll start to see how the cards work, you even start to unlock more. You start seeing more of the other factions and their cards. You start forming favorites... you can see the way each card could change the outcome. You form plans of attack. The music and the interaction keep you going. You finally step in to multiplayer... You find out that you don't need to join a server and directly interact, but the game shows you that you are playing against others. Your nerves pass because of this. You start doing the daily multiplayer challenges without fear of being called out for terrible card plays. You just keep coming back and back again. After all It is a simple game.

title: Monster Train
review:
I can't give this game enough credit for screwing up my sleep schedule. I do like Slay the Spire and games like it, but I LOVE this one. Something about mixing the factions with a primary and secondary clan make the runs feel so much more diverse and enjoyable. Easily my favorite part of the game.

10/10 would go to work on 3 hours of sleep again.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you are looking for a Slay The Spire experience, you just found the absolute best deck building roguelite game on the market. Just buy it. Period. There are some aspects of this game that actually exceed Slay The Spire. Seriously, buy it, thank me later.
TL/DR: If Slay the Spire was your game, buy this game now!
Full explanation below:

1. The game is just as strategic, possibly even more so than StS. There are 3 vertical levels before enemies start attacking your heart. Player units and spells can be placed on each level. Enemies and bosses begin at the bottom and ascend to your heart. This makes unit choice and placement incredibly complex, especially synergize with spells. Oh, add major game changing artifact pickups to this equation as well. 

2. You use 2 decks per run. Each deck is a flavor unto it's own, and every deck synergizes differently with another. Super fun and lots of replayability

3. You have 2 paths per interlude between stages. These 2 paths greatly affect your run by your choices. Again adds tons of strategic depth.

4. Once you unlock the later decks, they are incredibly different from the beginning decks, and the new synergy possibilities turn mind-blowing.

10/10 best deck building since StS

title: Monster Train
review:
TLDR: Exceptionally good Deck Building game. Well worth the money considering the play time you can get out of it.

**** First Play through is about 2 hours. if you don't like playing it again and again with a tougher Experience every time this game is not for you. ****

This game is perfect for anyone looking for a “Deck Builder” game. The single player experience is all I have done so far but even though it is solo there is still a level of connectivity to it. Having your steam friends Covenant rank on the left side is a nice addition on making it so you can see where you match compared to friends. 

Things I liked this Deck Builder had:
- NewGame+ Features
- Variety of unique decks to choose from
- Having to choose 2 decks to start a mission with
- Forcing 4+ cards into your deck that’s out of your control I.E. makes you flip between more magic or DMG
- multi level combat

title: Monster Train
review:
I'd give it a 6.5/10. 

Pros: 

+ Combat & art style are interesting. 

Cons:

- Audio during boss battles needs to be rethought, hearing the boss scream 3 dozen times with the speed set to super ultra is very annoying. 

- Runs aren't long enough to create interesting deck/artifact builds, basically if you don't have cards that mesh well together after the first boss fight, might as well restart as there are no additional rewards at the start of a run based on the previous runs success. 

- Synergy between different clans is lacklustre.

All in all I don't agree with the comparisons between this & Slay The Spire. STS is much more interesting.

title: Monster Train
review:
At the time of the writing, the reviews for the game are "Overwhelmingly Positive", so my review is here to balance this 96% positive reviews.
The game is a mix between deckbuilding and tower defence: you have spells and units in your deck that you can play to prevent the enemies to reach the top of your train. Every turn, the horde climb one story out of the three you can play on, the fourth one being where your pyre is. Spells cycle trough your discard and draw piles - what you're used to if you've played a deckbuilding game before but units can be played once per encounter. 
At the start of each run, you choose two clans, which determine your starting deck and the cards you'll be able to draft. The difference between the two clan you choose is that the main one determine you champion (a uber unit). Each clan play very differently, which is great.
So why the negative review? Well, it's too random: you can have a vision for your deck that's doom from the start if you don't get the good option for your first champion upgrade (there are 3 paths for each champion, with possible multi-classing, but you only have 2  choices per upgrade), or don't draft a good unit early on, or don't get a good selection in shops... and the randomness is made even worse with covenant (think ascension) levels: for example, the first (second?) one fills your deck with five random cards, which can really help you or make your deck completely useless.
There is also the issue that your (well, at least my) deck is based around a handful of cards: have one of your main units die early or fail to draw your main spell at the critical moment, and you can kiss your run goodbye for you'll probably have no chance to adapt.
It's a shame because there's a lot to like here, but deckbuilding has given us some great games, and this one is merely goodish, so you should probably give it a pass, at least as long as you haven't rinsed its competitors.

I don't know if I would give it OVERWHELMINGLY POSITIVE. I find the end boss to be quite cheesy and not a very fun encounter. I also don't know that it has the replayability of Slay the Spire. It is a good game overall though. You will find yourself doing a lot of the same builds over and over because a lot of cards just aren't valued properly. Many cards that have a cost of 3 should be 1 and some op cards are 1 with easy options to make them 0. 

I guess deckbuilding games are just hot right now because the reviews are crazy about this one but I'm not really feeling it. It's still a pretty fun and good game though.  I wish there was more of a five star system instead of just thumbs up thumbs down.  I'd give it a hard 4/5. Using morsels to block attacks is pretty op.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a REALLY well done roguelike deck builder game. Similar to Slay the Spire. You build your deck as you go along, trying to create a deck engine that can overcome challenges and make it through the final boss.

There are so many well thought out game principles in this game. Everything is "plannable". You know ahead of time how each turn will play out with live preview numbers as you consider different cards to play. You know what the final boss' "gotcha" mechanic will be, so as you go through you're run, you're constantly working on weaving your deck in a way that is going to be powerful against that particular boss.

It's a super great game for people who enjoy puzzling, planning, and figuring creatively.

title: Monster Train
review:
Similar to Slay the Spire in that it's a deck building rogue like game, but rather than a single character you choose a primary and secondary faction to determine your card pool.
Enemies will spawn and advance up floors each turn. If they reach the top floor they will attack your pyre, which will defend itself to an extant, however if it dies you lose. 
Your turn will consist of playing unit cards on a floor (with limited space available on each floor) that will fight each turn and stay until they die and spell cards that will have a 1 time effect and then be either discarded or removed for the fight, depending on the card.
Features different upgrade options for your primary factions champion, and cards can be improved more customly rather then a single upgraded version.

title: Monster Train
review:
Long story short, Slay the Spire is the better-designed and balanced game - Monster Train is the more fun game. It's not on my Steam, but I have ~400 hours of Slay the Spire on console. Watched countless hours of the game. Slay the Spire is, IMO, one of the best games released in recent memory - to me it is a game-of-the-decade contender (ofc, this is because it aligns well with several interests of mine... deckbuilding, roguelikes, etc.)

But I'd be wrong to say MT isn't more fun. It has way more polish visually/sound design. It has way more effective content (5 factions all with distinct card pools, every run your deck is comprised of two and the factions have all these synergies, etc). The run times are slightly SHORTER than StS so it's that little bit more "one more run"-able. It's just so sexy and bitesized compared to it's eldest... I can't not recommend it, it's a great game. It is the most fun of these kind of games that I have played (and I buy them up every opportunity I get).

title: Monster Train
review:
This game combines some of my favorite genres (deck building, rogue-lite, and tower defense) into a game that is fun and full of depth. There are so many ways to play this game that the replayability is through the roof. I will admit the art style is a bit off-putting, but the sound design fits it well enough that it is easy to ignore. I remember when I first saw the game I thought it looked like a mobile game ported to PC and was immediately turned off. But my attention was drawn back to it by a friend and I gotta say I'm glad I tried it. 

The multiplayer is unique and surprisingly fun. I wouldn't think a deck-building game could support a multiplayer aspect, but I would be sorely mistaken. I'm happy with the approach they took. It really puts your decision making skills to the test against others in a battle for survival. I would like to see maybe a mode in the future where you could buy things to hinder your opponents as well. 

The single-player content is still very enjoyable too. My only complaint is that the harder difficulties become a mode of "get broken or get broke." It's still a lot of fun to challenge myself with the insanely difficult modifiers added to the run. 

If you like deck building games, it's a definite must try.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a must buy for anyone even slightly interested in games like Slay The Spire. (Scoring below the paragraph)

    I know how tiring it is to see games compared to other games all the time. It feels a little demeaning and like you HAVE to enjoy the other game in order to enjoy this one. But in this case i feel like its warranted. If you've played Slay The Spire you'll get the just of this game. But in Monster Train everything is cranked to an 11. The amount of depth they put into the whole system when it comes to random generation (which will get my buy on most any game) is absolutely fantastic. Every run feels new and exciting. Its absolutely addicting. I just cant seem to pull myself away every single time i start a run. And all of this nerd gushing praise means so much more from a narcissist like me that only sees the worst in every game. I just love every aspect of it and i can guess right now that my hours will probably easily hit over 100 on here.

Now here's some aspects i look for in a game put in a scale out of /10

Art: 9 (Its very stylized and general reception is they weren't interested in it cause the art style but loved it in game)

Immersion: 10 (The atmosphere is easily set up and shoves you right into it from the get go.)

Story: 5 (There isn't much to go on but there is a plot driving you. What are you expecting? its a rogue-like.)

Difficulty: 6 (You probably aren't going to win on your first run and the skill ceiling feels VERY high.)

Gameplay: 11 (The one thing i NEED in game nowadays is fluidity in the controls and consistent pacing.)

Replayability: 10 (Its a well done rogue-like.)


Overall Score: 9.5/10


If you got $25 (Or less if the games on sale which it does go on) and you enjoy deck building rogues of all the games you could buy with it i would say Monster Train is the obvious choice.

title: Monster Train
review:
In a currently exploding genre of deckbuilders, this seems to be one of the very best. It's structured in a way that means a complete blowout of a run rarely happens; your resources are balanced carefully in a way that you can usually get 5 to 6 floors into a run before you will hit brick walls. 

That is, however, not to say that the eventual brick walls are insubstantial. They will punish you for one mistake and require you to build a deck that can establish heavy damage and strong defence. Thankfully, the balance seems finally tuned in that it almost always seems fair and open to your own ideas of how to proceed.

Good luck on your train ride to save Hell.

review:
It would be naive to think that the creators of Monster Train didn't directly take things from Slay the Spire. It's more than just "inspired" by it. However, it's a really fun game, and the clans have some very interesting mechanics and combinations to be made. I can tell the artists are inspired by a lot of other video game/movie subjects, like Soot Sprites from Spirited Away, Kratos (God of War), Ludo from The Labyrinth, and most obviously, Slay the Spire. 

I definitely recommend it, but also, if you haven't played Slay the Spire yet, give that one a try too (maybe even first) considering Monster Train rips off it pretty directly.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster train is a rogue-lite deckbuilder with a surprising amount of emergent depth of play. 

The good: Like other games in its class (such as Slay the spire), the focus of MT is on building and enhancing a deck that can scale to exponentially increasing levels of difficulty. This is easier said than done, as the playing field has a fairly large number of variables to consider and balance such as draw count per turn, space for units on each level of the train, ember (action points) to spend per turn, unit defensive and offensive power, etc. 

To balance this out, MT provides a generally higher degree of player agency than other games in its class. Rather than being entirely beholden to the RNG, players are subject to making impactful trade-offs at regular steps along the way. 

A winning game session requires about 1 hour and 20 minutes at a relaxed pace. A primary/secondary faction system provides ~13 deck combinations for good replayability in conjunction with a system of gradually progressing handicaps.

The bad: MT is a mixed bag in terms of permanent player progression. Wins and losses unlock more factions to play, more cards per faction, some purely aesthetice enhancements, and an increasing difficulty scale in the form of player handicaps. The card unlocks, in particular, seem a bit contrived, as though players need to "earn" the right to access the complete game. The faction unlocks serve as a good way to gradually introduce players to the complexity of the game, but progression is very uneven. For example, I had to play close to 10 rounds to unlock the 4th deck, but the last two decks unlocked in two rounds each.

Finally, I would be remiss if I didn't note the overall *cringe-ness* of the overall game theme. I wince whenever the game forces me to click a button labelled "Hell Yeah!".

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train takes the Slay the Spire formula, scales it up with playable units, and improves it in almost every way, while throwing in a dash of tower defense.  It's been the most satisfying single-player deck-builder I've played.

The two biggest issues that made my time with StS comparatively short were a repetitive early-game, a cramped pathway to deck-building, and an overall lack of variety.  MT (after the "tutorial" playthrough) gives you some random cards and a potentially game-altering relic from the start, choices about upgrade pathways (themselves more fun and varied), and you're always playing two of the five unlockable clans in some combination, so twenty-five possible deck compositions, themselves able to be played out in any number of ways.

Which wouldn't matter if the cards themselves weren't balanced or fun to play.  Monster Train has done an excellent job of balancing cards both with each other and with possible upgrades to make almost any card playable in the right circumstance.  Cards that I couldn't find a use for for 60 hours suddenly became a game-breaking force when it finally was in the right set-up, and there are comparatively more opportunities to trim your deck of cards that don't serve your deck's play-style (though it's still something you need to consciously prioritize), so creating fun, playable decks is a joy, and no two playthroughs have felt the same (even if you could claim the enemies can be repetitive).

You'll want to turn it up to Super speed once you learn the mechanics well enough not to need the stilted animations playing out to show you what happens each turn, and in comparison to some videos I've seen online I now realize that on my machine the game is chugging a little, and even Super speed doesn't resolve some combats as quickly as I'd like.  Not enough that I find myself being impatient, but I do realize that by the end of a playthrough it may have added another 10-15 minutes to my game time all together. Playing cards, as well, doesn't feel as snappy and responsive as StS, and while with this genre the game is certainly still playable, I felt the difference as Monster Train just controls a little clunkier (although there is more going on on screen, to be fair, and I am on a years-old general purpose laptop, not anything a gamer would consider state-of-the-art).

Art and music style are subjective (I prefer Monster Train to StS), but one thing I did appreciate is that some effort did go into world-building.  Cards have flavor text (although annoyingly only visible in the Logbook), your game has a narrative arc, and while it falls into the background of the mechanics, the different clans do have different characters, styles, and descriptions behind those mechanics.  Sure, defending a train making it's way to the center of Hell to re-light the Pyre, frozen by Heaven when they broke the Covenant, is still just a macguffin.  But it's a slightly fleshier macguffin.  

I'm not a guru of deck-building games by any stretch; I've played the big ones that have gotten attention, and have always wished for one that could make single-player a worthwhile experience.  Monster Train fits the bill.

title: Monster Train
review:
What a fantastic game!

If this game doesn't win some sort of award at the end of year game awards, then there is something very wrong with the industry.

For such a simple premise, I was surprised at how much scope there is to the game. You only fight one battle per round, but those battles are momentous affairs. It's a fun watch too, if a little loud. You'll turn your sound down playing this game, but that's a harsh thing to take away brownie points for.

As much as I was enjoying myself on my first run - I have only played 1.7 hours, and done one run at the time of writing this review - at first I felt the game was a bit easy. I was slaughtering bosses with surprising ease, making tons of money and boosting cards to a point at which I thought I'd be unbeatable.

Suffice it to say, I was mightily mislead, and I love that! The final boss wiped the floor with me! Truly. I'd like to say the hands I drew were terrible. That would be sort of true, but it's a weak excuse. There is so much depth to upgrading and picking cards, and it's only going to get deeper as you gain cards and boost your deck.

I've played games that are similar to Monster Train before, and I do enjoy the genre, but Monster Train had something extra. It's hard to put in to words. Part of it is that the run seemed shorter and less tiring than other games of the genre. I won't take away from the depth of planning that can go in to boosting your chances of victory with the cards you pick, improve or discard, but the fact that you fight just once per level makes things "short but sweet". Playing those other similar games I often could feel drained from the sheer length of a run. Monster Train had just enough in to feel full, yet not bloated. I also very much liked the fact that between each battle you could explore a level of hell to improve your deck without having to worry about what was behind you. There was a freedom to deciding which way to take your deck, but not without risks as you could only chose one path.

Not that any of the above means this game will be over all too quick either. When I finished my first run (not the way I'd have liked to) I was presented with a book of achievements and progress. I turned a page and was honestly astonished at the number of unfilled spots I saw. I look forward to exploring all that.

Now I see, whilst writing this, that the game has multiplayer. I don't always partake of multiplayer, but something tells me it could be a joy in this game. Like I said, if this game doesn't win something at the end of the year then a misdemeanour has been committed. The gaming police will need to be called.

Honestly, get this game. Today.

title: Monster Train

Like many games inspired by Slay the Spire, Monster Train aims to take the roguelike deck-building genre in a new direction. I would say that Monster Train succeeds in improving on Slay the Spire's formula by adding a new dimension to the genre by adding a multi-level unit placement mechanic.

10/10 - Monster Train is real good, and I can easily see myself putting over 100 hours into this game.

review:
I sank 100 hours into this game in a month, which is a lot for a 35 year old dad gamer with a full-time job. Its such a great deck-building rogue-like. The synergies are so fun to discover and exploit. The increased difficulty that gets tacked on each time you complete a run (called covenant levels) is a great way to add replayability. I completed covenant 25 (the last level), and I can say that I had an absolute blast along the way. I'm coming back to beat covenant 25 with each combination of main/secondary clan, and to see what goodies the devs add along the way. 

Easily my favorite deck-builder out. Insta-buy if you are at all interested in games in the genre. 

Quick nitpick for the devs - can we get a way to sort our cards when viewing our decks? I want to filter by card type, dmg, health, cost (etc), to make it easier to pick my upgrades at the different stops.

title: Monster Train
review:
Very enjoyable strategic game, similar in mechanics to slay the spire but plays out very differently.  I feel you are less at the mercy of RNG in this game comparitively, although there are still runs that will stick you with very difficult situations.  At over 150+ hours I am still learning how the different faction combinations work, but it has been an engaging and enjoyable process.  If you liked StS you will likely have fun here as well, perhaps even more fun.

At its basic, a rogue-like deck builder with meaningful choices and some RNG.  IMHO, the RNG is not quite as punishing as you are given a lot choices and abilities to modify cards to create strong decks.  Most of my runs end because of my bad decisions, not because of RNG, which is what I prefer.

There is also a good amount of replayability as there are 4 factions, of which you play 2 of during every run.  Meaning you have a number of combinations to work out the best synergy and card interaction.

Currently bug free (for me at least), polished and free DLC in the works, highly recommend if you enjoy deckbuilders.

review:
Very fun and highly addictive deck-building game.

There are five clans in this game. Each of them plays very differently and very unique. And since in every single run you can bring two clans (one main clan and one ally clan), there are 20 clan combinations to play with.

Each run can last from 15-30 minutes, so this game is good for a quickie if you don't have much time to play. The game is casual friendly but also pretty challenging, especially if you have the highest Covenant unlocked.

I'd give this game a 9.9/10. The missing 0.1 is room for improvement. Would love to see more clans to be added to the game.

title: Monster Train
review:
The deck building genre of rogue-lite is all about optimizing the deck and card sequence when in combat; Synergize your cards, then play them in the right order. Monster Train adds a new layer (actually 3) to this idea by having vertically stacked battle grounds, but one hand to manage them with in each encounter.

The only drawback I think think of after 75 hours of play is that for people who are focused on maxing their 'Covenant rank' (ascension for those of StS lineage) will find the grind tedious at times because the malicious added each rank can create perfect storms of failure that doom a run before you drop your first Train Steward... besides that, its all good news in every way.

This game is "the" next deck builder and will be remembered in the genre as ultimately what grew out of Slay the Spire.

You like this genre, you love this game. End of story.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like Slay the Spire, you will like this too. The mechanics are similar (deck building, artifacts, path choosing etc.) but you also get monster cards as opposed only having one fighter to buff, and 3 floors of your train to manage. Additionally, you get to pick two different clans, which affect the cards available to you each round. Some have pretty good synergies that are satisfying to discover.

Overall I feel like the route choosing is fairly straightforward / doesn't require much thought when compared to STS. You get two options each level, each of which have a few bonuses (a card pick, extra gold, a shop, etc.). 

When you're building your deck you need to track how many units you have vs. how much you have space for on each train, to make sure you don't end up with units that you can't play. This adds an additional element that makes deck management much more interesting.

The only downside of the game is that the fights on each floor are pretty set in stone, with optional trials for additional rewards. If you play through a couple times, you've basically seen it all and know what to prepare for as you progress through hell. This can make the gameplay seem somewhat stale, but having 5 clans to pick from makes the way you play against those same enemies different each time.

Basically if you liked STS, you have no reason not to get this game. It's worth it, even if it is just to give you a break from STS for a day or two.

title: Monster Train
review:
Good game. Would rate 8/10

Pros:
- It's good.
- It's fun.
- There is little like it. (it's not quite like Slay the Spire)

Con:
- Limited replayability.
- There is no enemy or map variations. You fight the same 9 "rooms" in each run, with identical waves of enemies in the same order. 
- This gets really tiresome after 10 runs. Would rather play something different.

Multiplayer is early access:
- All players are doing individual solo runs. It's not really multiplayer. The player going further with the better score "wins".
- You can't inspect other player decks.
- You can't spectate other players.
- There is a horrible timer forcing exactly 5 minutes per room, before proceeding to the next room. Except a room takes only 2-3 minutes to play and you're bored to death waiting another 2-3 minutes to continue playing.

The game is good but doesn't deserve more than 8/10 due to the lack of diversity and replayability. 
Don't expect to get more than 10-20 hours out of this.

review:
This game should have a warning because it's sooooo good it's addictive. One of the most fun games I've ever played. 10 out of 5 stars. Only thing I can even think of is missing is maybe the possibility to play this game with a game pad instead of a mouse, though this might still be added and I'd much rather prefer they add it later but refined (slay the spire has this implemented really well in my opinion).
It's so cool that they're still adding new (endgame) content. I have to say, after unlocking everything and getting all achievements I do not play the game a ton anymore, but it still took me almost 140h to do so, so that's absolutely fine for me and in any case absolutely worth the money. I do still watch videos on the daily challenges because I love the crazy combos used there (costumization to more directly try some of that would be a cool addition I think - maybe like a "training room" where you can freely set up enemies and define your deck). Also, I will definitely come back to it once the new content is available (wouldn't even mind paying for it to support the game) and again, better add some solid endgame content later than just anything boring. Amazing game! Thanks a lot!

(Btw bought the game after I saw a streamer play it, so that kind of marketing worked for me and I also think it's a cool way of promoting new games)

title: Monster Train
review:
Very Slay the Spire-ish game with interesting mechanics. I think the branching paths are better executed with more meaningful choices - do I upgrade my spells, my minions? do I get an artifact or rather remove cards? - rather than just how many elites and how many campfires I'm going to get.
The game is more snowbally in nature, and you often end up with some broken combo by the end of the run. This is reflected in the enemies' HP which progresses much more exponentially than in Slay the Spire. This also means the balance is more sensitive and randomness can have a meaningful influence.
Nevertheless, Monster Train is really addictive and rewarding when you get things right. It feels less clean and polished than Slay the Spire, but it dares try more ideas mechanically speaking.
A very refreshing game.

title: Monster Train
review:
After logging over 1200 hours on Slay The Spire I was looking for another good Rogue-lite Deck Builder and Monster Train has nailed it! It is a blast to play. 

Where it shines brightest is in the tactical game; Set up your monsters across the 3 floors of your train to protect your Pyre. Attackers will board your train and combat your defenders before advancing to the next floor. Defeat them before they get to your Pyre.

Once the Boss arrives, it will relentlessly attack all creatures on that floor until either your defenders die, or the boss is dead.

Move your train through 8 fights to secure victory.

Oh and it's got freakin multiplayer too! 10/10 game of 2020.

title: Monster Train
review:
As someone who loves card games, and especially the deck-building kind, I can wholeheartedly recommend this.

Pros:
- 5 very distinct clans, each with a handful of different playstyles. your deck combines 2 clans, which might uncover some really cool synergies.
- Nice art style with nice attention to detail, such as units adjusting their size based on how many slots they take up.
- You can enable combat preview, which is very handy (I'd even go as far as calling it a must-have) as it helps you track very complex interactions.
- You can pull off some insanely powerful and fun combos, and it's incredibly satisfying when you do so.
- Great replay value, as you can always go for different builds and/or increase your difficulty. 

Cons:
- This is not a train game. The train is there just to add some flavor to the game and its lore, but nothing more beyond that.
- It could use more content of some kind, such as more cards, artifacts or more scenarios to play through. But there is some more content coming, so this is really just a temporary issue.

title: Monster Train
review:
Amazing deck building game with that stands out differently to the traditional style.
I haven't tried any multiplayer at this point as I'm still grinding out levels to unlock all the cards from Melting Remnant.

Big seller for card games for me is the availability of gaining all the cards without having to make additional purchases or loot box style card packs. The upfront payment is all you pay for which is awesome. 100 hrs in at this point and I'm feeling like I should be playing other games (only so that I don't play this so much). 

There's so much replay ability even in Single Player due to the RNG aspect of the game in that the run is a continual draft after each stage. Each level also brings up the difficulty, up to 25 levels so for all the players that love a gradual challenge this is definitely a game for you.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is a solid addition to deckbuilding games. It has "unlock" mechanics, but they're not straight upgrades and it comes out the gate with enough depth that you feel like you're playing the real game right from the start. It's sufficiently challenging, but very beatable in a few tries... and then it reveals that there's a couple dozen harder difficulties. There's enough interesting mechanics to give a large number of viable build strategies, and interestingly they tend NOT to revolve around the multi-stage mechanics. This isn't a one-trick, "Slay the Spire but 3 battlefields" pony. The mechanics are thought through carefully. Like Slay the Spire, choosing your flavor at the start of the run influences the cards you find along the way, which means the set you're drafting from is skewed toward cards that might actually combo in your deck. But in Monster Train, you choose TWO flavors to mix together, which adds a lot to the replayability; plus, the artifacts (passive buffs) you find are also pulled from a generic set plus your deck's 2 sets.

With most games being solidly divided between "indie" or "AAA" this might seem a little pricey, but there's a lot of satisfying art and sound. I usually say that graphics don't matter; but the fact is that they do need to be good enough that you're never distracted by it, and this game delivers. The gameplay also has the kind of depth you only get from incessant playtesting and experimentation. This game is definitely a fair price for what you get.

title: Monster Train
review:
There ain't no gettin' off this hell train we are on! Well okay, there is but only through untimely demise against a bunch of winged freaks. 

This game is a great little deck builder and unit management game where you do your best to relight the fires of hell through a combination of various factions each with their own strengths and weaknesses. There are quite a few combinations and each one requires a certain finesse, especially as the game continues to scale its difficulty on every single successful victory. 

I find that I am quite awful at the game but it doesn't stop me from enjoying it and I hope they continue to flesh it out as time goes on. If you had any enjoyment playing games like Slay The Spire, you will likely enjoy this.
