title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a deckbuilding roguelike, with a fantasy theme. If you think that sounds like Slay the Spire, you're right, but it stands on its own unique merits.

The theme is fantasy but with a twist: The fires of hell have been extinguished by angels, and it's up to the player to drive a train containing the last pyre of hellfire through the nine layers of hell, defeat the angels, rekindle the flames, and make the world safe for demons again.

The big difference is the format of the combat: where Slay the Spire focuses on a single character fighting battles against very small groups of enemies, Monster Train has exactly nine battles which play out like tower defense: enemies advance up the four floors on your train while attacking, and you play creatures and spells from your deck on the first three floors to stop them . The last enemy in each battle is a boss with special abilities and many more hit points. If an enemy reaches the top of your train, it deals damage to your pyre. If your pyre runs out of health, your game is lost. If you manage to defeat the boss in battle nine, you win! A winning run typically takes about an hour: a failed run can be a much shorter experience.

Available cards are divided into five "clans" of demons. You begin every match by choosing a starting clan and a support clan. Your begin the game with a deck consisting of a champion from from your starting class, five basic cards from your starting clan, five basic cards from your support clan, and four clanless "train stewards". You begin every battle with a hand of five cards from your deck, one of which will be your champion. Just like Dominion, you draw five cards from your deck every turn. If your deck is empty, your discard pile gets shuffled back into your draw pile.

At each layer of hell, you'll be able to draft clan cards for your deck, remove cards, and upgrade cards by adding modifiers to them. Just like Slay the Spire, you'll absolutely need to optimize your deck to defeat the increasing difficulty levels of each of the nine battles. Also like Slay the Spire, beating a run unlocks a "covenant rank" which adds difficulty modifiers that make the game more challenging to beat. There are 25 covenant ranks in total. Monster Train also has leaderboards and daily challenge, in which everyone plays with the same random seed.

In short: Monster Train is quality. The game provides you with a series of interesting choices, and the outcomes of these choices are very meaningful, both in deckbuilding and in playing your cards in each battle. Win or lose, the game has that addictive "gotta try one more run" feeling. Wins are satisfying, losses can be heartbreaking, and most of the time, your choices completely determine the outcome.

TLDR; If you liked Slay the Spire, Monster Train is a very easy recommendation, especially at the $20 price.

title: Monster Train
review: Deckbuilding games such as this one are really engaging, with multiple routes to victory as well as a huge amount of game-winning, and often unexpected, strategies. With a simple difficulty curve (each covenant adding some additional challenge to your run) as well as tracking wins, each level rewards the player for optimising their gameplay. The golden frame system is also very satisfying, encouraging players to try out new strategies rather than use previous ones which worked. In the few days in which I've owned this game, I have already clocked 30 hours. While each covenant does get increasingly difficult, it is not impossible - the ability to 'restart' a level by going back to the main menu might help ease newcomers into the game too. Would recommend, 10/10

title: Monster Train
review:
Good game, obviously a rogue lite card game. It does come with its issues as any other game, such as the mechanics not really stacking up correctly or fairly for that matter, especially considering it is a card game, so luck does play a role. However id still recommend it, maybe 7/10. Its fun and can kill some time, but the random power ups the enemies get as you progress can stop a run cold in its tracks if you've not made the right decisions. being a rogue lite that means youve got to start from 0 again.

each run doesn't take long though, maybe at most 45 minutes. once you know what youre doing each run will take you about 10-30 minutes depending on various factors. It is correctly priced, feel like i got what i paid for, you can tell the developer gives a shit about the product they put out into the world, and that is important.

title: Monster Train
review: Tremendously satisfying deck builder. If you love Slay the Spire, this is a must play. This game is clearly inspired by Slay the Spire, and almost feels like a love letter to it, while at the same time adding new and exciting mechanics that make it feel entirely new, while comfortingly familiar. The amount of content is staggering, made evident after your first game (win or lose). A delightful learning curve, that I know is just waiting to ramp up in crazy ways. If you're *thinking* about getting this game, as I did for a while, don't hesitate, jump on the train and enjoy!

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is amazing. I couldn't put it down during the first week I bought it. My first impressions were that the 5 clans felt completely unique from each other, what with their individual champion/cards/trinkets/ and upgrade availabilities. I was originally afraid that each clan was going to play one of three ways every time, but the amount of choices and combinations are absolutely amazing. The addition of selecting one of the remain 4 clans as a sub class adds so many strategies I never could have thought of if I tried. 

The minion based combat of having to manage three different levels opens up so many paths to tread strategy wise. Example. You can put all your strength in your first level to try to kill enemies straight out the gate and have weaker minions in subsequent floors as clean up. Alternatively, you can leave the first level empty and put your team on the second or third level to buff them up in some way before the enemy reaches them. I have also had runs where I had very few minions and just beat bosses with a slew of endless spells. It's little decisions like this that keep me coming back and make the deck building and drafting that much more fun.

My only complaint so far is the boss pool. There are three main bosses you will fight every single time you play. They change slightly by each having 3 different passive and active effects, but generally the game play is usually the same against them. Other than that each of the 5 remaining minor boss areas have 2 different bosses it can randomly select from so at least in that regard the variety changes a bit. I would love to see the developers add some new boss and possibly some new cards in the future. Having read their FAQ they seem interested in supporting the game for a while, it seems like just a matter of time.

All in all, I highly recommend this game especially if you are into deck building games.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game feels like it could be called Slay the Spire II, in a good way.

This game perfectly captures the original vibe of STS but gives it a really fresh spin.  Instead of one hero fighting multiple monsters you're able to summon multiple creatures to fight the enemy hordes. You also control 3 different levels of your train to fight in. If the monsters survive the first floor they then move to the second floor where you, hopefully, have some creatures summoned to at least damage them. If they get past the 3rd floor they'll damage your health but also take damage from your train.  When you defeat all the enemies, you then fight the level's boss who is much more difficult than the rest of the creatures.  

Moving from area to area is very "Spire-esque" as well.  You start in an area with different things to visit, such as remove 2 cards, get some gold, upgrade your cards, etc.  The way cards are upgraded is very fun and different than STS.  You are able to take your cards and give them additional powers.  Spells and creatures can be upgraded in ways that almost feel like you're cheating, if the game wasn't so hard.

The idea works very well at being unique enough from STS to have the feeling of very different game. In other ways Monster Train draws heavily from the feel of STS in many of it's design elements and UI features, giving it a very comfortable and familiar feeling that makes it easy to play.

The deckbuilding, unlockable cards, random artifacts, random events, unique enemy and boss structure, insane combos, skin of your teeth wins by playing just the right combo of cards, very cool and interesting factions and combinations, all has me loving this game.

title: Monster Train
review:
[code] [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36948155-Card-Game-KING/] FOR MORE REVIEWS ABOUT CARD GAMES, CHECK OUT OUR CURATOR PAGE: [b]CARD GAME KING [/b] [/url] [/code] 

[h1] [b]TL:DR[/b] [/h1] 
Scroll down for full Gameplay

Another entry in the roguelike card game genre and what a hell of an entry it is!
With the addition of customizable card upgrades, introduction of unit summons and the ability to create sick combos, Monster Train stands proudly among other titans of the subgenre. Things really start to heat up once you unlock more clans, cards and difficulty levels. Plenty hours of fun, card diversity and fun cardplay, earns it a very warm recommendation (promise, no more puns).

[h1][b]The positive[/b] [/h1] 
+ Excellent card play. The core card mechanics and the way cards combine offer plenty of great deckbulding opportunities.
+ Card customization. The ability to upgrade both units and spells, is by far the most fun aspect of the game for me as it opens the player to experiment with pretty crazy combos.
+ Diversity. Anywhere from picking different starting champion units, over different starting clans to just picking and upgrading different cards, the game offers near endless diversity in how you make your deck work.
+ Fairly quick runs. Defeat doesn't feel as bad, as a single run can be done within an hour.
+ Aesthetics. Personally I enjoyed the art style and on top of that the cards are slightly animated which is nice touch.
* Empowering players. The players are given a ton of tools to create their own perfect deck, with plenty of options to remove cards or duplicate the strong ones. This can make runs less difficult, but most runs will not be as easy as it may sound.

[h1][b]The neutral[/b][/h1] 
* Math problems. Although the game does the hard calculations for you, sometimes it's very difficult to foresee the output until you actually play the card, especially for units. This could be resolved by showing results before you play a unit card, but the game currently does not support that.
* Slower unlock rate. The last clan together with some end cards take a bit more time to unlock than I would have liked personally. Thankfully, the game is fun enough so it doesn't feel like a chore.
* Some items seem a bit overtuned. This can make some runs a lot easier, but at the same time broken combos can be super fun to pull off. Some players may be bothered by it, but I found it more enjoyable than not.


[h1][b]The negative[/b] [/h1] 
- The single biggest downside of the game is the very notable lack of boss diversity. Each major boss has some slightly different mechanics, but ultimately you will be seeing the same faces over and over again. 


[h1][b]Gameplay[/b] [/h1] 
As typical with games in the genre, you will fight a series of fights, earning cards and items along the way, only to face the last boss. After each run you will be unlocking new cards and difficulty levels.

Aside from the tutorial, you start off by picking one main and one allied clan. The game introduces 5 clans (some locked), each with their own unique cards and mechanics. Some clans rely on summoning morsels which are eaten by your other units, other clans rely on summoning powerful minions that have a burnout mechanic,  making them expire after a few turns.

Each clan also starts with unique a champion, that can be upgraded into 3 different paths or you can even mix them up to align with your playstyle. 

Each fight you will summon units on one of three floors of your train and try to prevent waves of enemies reaching your Pyre, not unlike a tower defense game. Where and when you place your units is extremely important and positioning matters with the front units taking damage first and once they die, they can't be summoned back for that fight (with the exception of some clan spells). On each level, after the last wave the boss joins the fray, usually possessing an additional gimmick. Unlike tower defense games, the boss can't slip by, so if you have the damage/health to deal with the boss, you will. 

In between fights you can choose one of two sides of the railroad track, each giving access to different set of locations: shops where you upgrade cards or buy items, healing sites, sites to duplicate/remove cards or special events.

One thing that sets this game apart from similar games is the card upgrade system. Every card can be upgraded (spells and units) in a number of ways (e.g. stat improvements, adding special keywords etc). This small mechanic can greatly supplement your strategy. One example is adding the keyword Holdover to a card, which puts it on the top of your deck when played. If your strategy relies on playing some key cards, playing it every turn without having to clutter your deck with copies, can be immensely powerful and satisfying.

The game tries its best to give the player all the tools he/she needs to succeed with plenty of ways to remove cards from your deck, get new ones or duplicate/upgrade existing ones, all in the effort to create a super deck. 

Lots of fun, lots of diversity, excellent card play and deckbuilding.

Royally recommended.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a rogue-lite card game in the same vein as Slay the Spire, albeit with more options.

A game generally follows as such : Choose a deck and then choose a companion deck.  This allows a player to mix and match several deck types, granting much more freedom than Slay the Spire.

Initial battles are short and a lot of the decision making is actually done between these.  Yes, that's right, there are many fun options to choose from BETWEEN battles, such as upgrading units, duplicating cards, choosing new units, taking gold, improving spells, and a multitude of random events.  Awesome.

At the start of each battle the player is given the option to accept the Trial, or run the fight as normal.  If a player accepts the trial a bonus will be awarded (the bonus is stipulated pre-battle, usually for $$ or extra units).  The bonuses can help a lot, but they can also be dangerous creating a good incentive for the player.  Winding up with an extra few damage mods on friendly units, extra artifacts, or removing cards that do not fit your current deck can do wonders for beating the last boss.

And that is what this game is all about, beating the boss.  From the very BEGINNING a player is aware of what unique situation will occur in the last boss battle.  Upon beating the boss the player raises a covenant level and the game gets ever so slightly harder.  Not harder in the annoying way that Slay the Spire ends up getting REALLY fast.  It gets hard enough to make the game more challenging and punish a player for not playing smart and thinking ahead about the fights (because it shows units pre-fight), but hard enough to make ranking up FUN.

Also, when a player beats (for example) convenant rank 5 with a certain clan, he can try for covenant rank 6 with a completely different clan.  No need to go back and start all over again.

Overall, Slay the Spire was an amazing game (but I absolutely hated the artwork).  Monster Train is not only a better game, but it also has much better artwork.  Highly recommend.

More variety, more items to earn, more modes (Well one more since Monster Train has multi-player and Slay does not), more everything.  Slay will always hold the throne when people talk about the genre, but if you asked me to recommend one game over the other for pure fun factor...I'd choose Monster Train every time.  That should say something.  

If you enjoy the genre at all, pick this up.  You won't be disappointed.

title: Monster Train
review:
Like many others have written, the best way to gauge whether you'll like this game is whether you enjoy Slay the Spire, the current king of deck builders. Compared to StS, Monster Train is a bit of a double-edged sword.

On the negative side, Monster Train has simpler builds, in terms of cards and artifacts. In StS, some artifacts or cards can change your entire play strategy, and this generates a wealth of potentially viable strategies & builds. Each of Monster Train's 5 factions have two major mechanics each (the starter Hellhorned clan has armor and rage; the Stygian have frostbite and incant). And while being able to choose a primary AND secondary clan/deck provides some nice complexity, there's still much less depth than in Slay the Spire.

On the positive side, Monster Train's simplicity makes it less random. In StS, you'll often choose a build to pursue based on the first card choices you get, but then those builds often depend on several linchpin cards or artifacts. And if you don't get them? You're done. So I put maybe 80 hours into StS before I quit for good, simply because of how often I lost through no mistakes of my own. 

By contrast, in Monster Train, I'm currently at Covenant 22 (of max 25, with each new covenant adding a difficulty twist), and I've managed some significant win streaks (7 in Cov bracket 1-10, and 5 in Cov bracket 11-20). There's definitely been some annoying RNG moments - of course there are, it's a deck builder! - but they feel rarer. That's thanks to the overall design as well as small touches like knowing which final boss you're facing from the start.

That said, the game has started to lose much of its charm in higher Covenant ranks. For me, much of the fun in deck-builders is to experiment and win with wildly different builds. But as you increase your Cov rank, that fun begins to dwindle considerably. For starters, by the time you're up to Cov rank 20+, you're STARTING with like 17-18 junk cards in your hand, so every game means half your hand is the same basic, boring crap. But what's worse is that, at these higher difficulty levels, you're also restricted down very narrow paths if you want success. Because of this starter card bloat, spell-based builds become largely non viable; instead you have to build units and within those units, what you can build is very narrow. You need a tank, you need a back-rank killer (can be the tank, if it has spikes), and you need some form of exponentially growing damage setup. 

Because of that - and because you only have a few opportunities to get units - I can often tell whether the run will be a win or loss from the very first unit/card choice I get. That loss of player agency is, to me, the epitome of bad design.

Not to end on a bad note, though: working my way up to this point has been a wild and fun ride, and I hope my review gives you some sense of whether you'll enjoy it or not.

review: Honestly thought it was just a cheap Slay the Spire clone, but it really is an entirely new experience. title: Monster Train
review: You might be wondering "Does Monster Train bring any innovations to the deck-builder roguelike genre"? And the answer to that is no. Deck-building-wise, it's pretty close to how things work in Slay the Spire. However, it does bring some pretty major innovations to the [i]tower defense[/i] genre; Monster Train somehow manages to be a tactically deep and turn-based tower defense game, with the three floors each being a chance to stop enemies from reaching your Pyre (your Pyre being your "true hp"), and the way you have to build your deck so it can manage both large enemies and numerous small enemies to prevent any of them from slipping by mirrors the similar challenges found in more conventional tower defense games. As for how it compares to the biggest title on the deck builder roguelike market right now, Slay the Spire, I would say its shorter playtime and smaller number of larger, more tactically complex battles helps make it if anything more fun. It also somehow makes it simultaneously possible to achieve absolutely ridiculous numbers and final builds while still being difficult with a risk of losing if you don't think things through, as a result of the demands on the player it inherits from the tower defense genre; going through its Covenant system (a series of special difficulty-changing modifiers) involves less of a demand for a fundamentally different playstyle and more like it requires more thought with each action compared to StS's Ascension system. Its clan system, where each run contains cards from two clans of your choice, also helps keep gameplay fresh, because, not counting the potentially major differentiating factor of the Champion (a unique unit that receives special, often transformative upgrades at regular points, including the start of the run), there are already 10 possible total card pools a run can have in the game in its current state.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is the first game to very clearly be inspired by and based on Slay The Spire that I truly feel like lives up to the bar that game set, to the point of being arguably a better overall game. The tower defense / lane elements add a very nice touch and the clan system and a couple thoughtful tweaks by the developer do a lot to soften the relatively boring and repetitive early game before your deck really grows into it's character. Bottom line: If you loved Slay The Spire this game should be an insta-buy unless you're an absolute maniac when it comes to deal-hunting and sales, in which case you need to wishlist it now. If you have no idea what Slay The Spire is but the idea of a roguelike deck building tower defense game appeals to you, I can assure you that this game manages to pull all of those off in an enjoyable and very repeatable way. 

If I had to offer criticisms, I'd say that on the higher difficulties I just don't think every run with every clan combo is viable. Sometimes your starter cards/artifacts are going to have no synergy and if I ever get to the point where I'm trying to get Covenant 25 (highest difficulty) runs for every clan combo, I'm positive I'll be doing a lot of start-scumming. Maybe I'm just not good enough. Regardless, starting over is easy to do, it's a relatively minor quibble, and I heartily recommend this game to anyone reading this that feels even slightly interested at this point.

Great price and well worth the cost.

title: Monster Train
review:
As a dedicated DC deck builder, legendary, and slay the spire fan, I am always on board when a new "deck building" experience is available. Monster Train offers unique and challenging game play that utilizies technical lessons learn to create a new experience while implementing user experience of its sister and brother games to improve on the diversity of the core game play loop. This creative deck building ride (attempt at a train pun) provides players the options and flexibility to craft a distinct Monster team full of unique modifiers, abilities, stats, and clan mash-ups. 

Players familiar with deckbuilders will pick up on upgrade prioritizations, "combos", and effective builds relatively easily, while the increasingly difficult covenant ranks offer challenging modifiers to the game experience. The only variable that disrupts the strategic elements of deckbuilding only comes into affect at higher ranks - the random nature of the cards being added to your deck at start. Players seem to be doubly hindered with the addition of completely unsynergistic cards and blights added to the deck at the start of a run. I also fully support the alternative perspective that this is a core component of the monster train game play loop. I only question if players see this as a reason to continuously reset their higher level runs in seek of synergistic/higher performing cards (to each their own!)

I recommend Monster Train to any fan of deck builders, strategic games, or puzzle games!

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is Slay the Spire, except better. Let's be clear here, I love Slay the Spire, it is one of my favorite games of the past decade and basically invented an entire genre. Monster Train takes that formula, and improves on it in every way. Choosing 2 clans essentially lets you mix colors, meaning that there are 20 different clan combinations to master. I loved this, as my biggest frustration with Slay the Spire was that there was a very limited amount of characters to choose from. The game starts out easy, but don't let that fool you! Once you start climbing the ladder, the games difficulty ramps up significantly. Some days I will go 4-5 runs without a win! That is okay though, that is the life of a rogue and I wouldn't have this game any easier.

Buy it now!!!

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is an absolute blast. It's a lot faster paced than Slay the Spire, since you get going a lot faster and don't have to deal with the miserable early game of StS. The UI isn't as elegant but it's still quite clean and does the job well. There are many possible playstyles and you can use the decks in a variety of ways. My favorites by design are the Melting Remnant and Umbra decks, which have so many different ways to play. The Hellhorned plays a lot like the Ironclad in StS, which is a great intro to Monster Train. 

Runs last about an hour, and there are 5 unique clans to play with, each with a few different ways to play. The OST is great, and overall the game is a huge blast to play. Highly recommend if you've gotten a little bored of StS (I think I actually like this more) and want more chances at awesome galaxy brain combos like whirlwind + necromancer tome in StS!

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
Absolutely phenomenal game! If you like Slay The Spire then you'll love this, and I truly think it makes StS seem basic in comparison.

What I love the most about what Shiny Shoe have done with the formula is really worked on combating the early-game staleness that other card-battler roguelites tend to get: Selecting a primary and secondary deck that combine together feels fresher than just a single character with a single deck, you get given a random selection of cards from those decks along with a choice of an artefact right at the start of the run which stops the first fight being the same every time and the card upgrading system offers many more choices.

The events system is far more positive than StS too; the only negative effects you'll receive will be alongside positive ones, and the game always allows you to choose none of the given options.

I highly recommend :)

title: Monster Train
review:
Good game - the game feels like a successful amalgation of hearthstone and slay the spire, both in terms of gameplay and visuals. Most runs feel quite different from one another, as do the 5 different classes, partially due to the myriad of mechanics present in the game, all of which feel quite fun, viable and have a lot of support from other cards, resulting in many satisfying card combinations.

However, one of my gripes is that, due a a number of causes, the runs themselves seem to have relatively little variation in the combat phase. You draw a hand and it almost always plays itself (unlike sts and hearthstone). That is partially caused by starting cards being complete dogshit (worse than sts....) and decks usually only having one big thing going for them. As a result, most of the actual choices in the game are made outside the combat - which would be fine if the combat wasn't by far the longer phase - the phases in betwee, during which you upgrade cards, etc are relatively short.

Another problem that is see is that there isnt as much variation in enemies as slay the spire, and enemies do not seem to test a specific area of your deck (e.g. scaling, burst, defensive options...) quite like sts, resulting in a same-y experience during most runs (sometimes you just get 100-0'd by an enemy your deck cant handle at all though...).

Losing is fine - but one of the redeeming factors of rogue-likes are that they usually terminate an unsuccessful run fast and painlessly for you before you get far. This seems to rarely be the case in monster train, which can result in one hour runs randomly losing at some point :(

Regardless, very solid game, nice visuals (after some getting used to the theme), and I'll keep coming back (though probably less than to sts). I'd give it an 8/10

title: Monster Train
review:
Very much like Slay the Spire, but with an emphasis on tactics. It's sort of a blend of StS and tower defense games. If you enjoy rogue-like deck building games, this one will not disappoint. 

Overall I love the game and the way it plays, but my one complaint is the disparity in clan difficulty. The red/purple clans are much more difficult to win with as primary than the green clan and the yellow clan (Umbra) are frustratingly difficult to make work. I kept on failing run after run until I unlocked the final clan and I'm on a 3 win streak with them as primary and I'm not even that good. I like how different each clan is to play and the emphasis on synergy between them, but some of the cards are just diametrically opposing strategies and it makes it a struggle to even get past the first fight.

7.5 or 8 out of 10, great game.

title: Monster Train
review:
I haven't played Slay the Spire, but I heard about this on a gaming site and it seemed appealing. Little did I know that I was about to experience the purest form of gaming crack cocaine that I've come across in recent times. It's a CCG / deckbuilder, with 2D graphics influenced by Hearthstone, combined with mechanics of an auto-battler, with tower defense elements thrown in to boot. The lightest of Rogue-lite mechanics are sprinkled on top, and garnished with a polish to the graphics, interface, and achievements log that far exceed the quality suggested by critics that call it out for it's "flash game" aesthetics. 

Don't buy it if you value your free time.

title: Monster Train
review:
I need to learn not to trust the steam reviews, steam has too many masochists that like these sorts of games.

If your a masochists who does not know what fun is then this game is for you.

This game has no difficulty curve, no tutorial, and no point.  It is very difficult at the outset, out of something like 20 attempts, I won twice.  This is at rank 0 or 1 difficulty.  The longer I played and the the more I learned I found it didn't really help my chances, unlocking more stuff didn't really help all that much either.  In other words there is no ramp up in difficulty, it is an immediate wall and the gameplay loop was just an obnoxious grind that I didn't really enjoy.  There was no indication that things will change by 'progressing' so don't see the point in playing further.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a deck-bulding/rogue-lite card game heavily inspired by much beloved Slay The Spire, but instead of being a direct copycat it takes the inspiration and improves upon it.

[b] Pros: [/b]
+ Many combination and unlocks to gather for starters.
+ Nice concept.
+ Artwork & sound is worked on. Nothing superb but they do their work.
+ Combo and card mechanics are designed well.

[b] Neutral: [/b]
~Multiplayer is unnecessary.

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Problem of the genre persists, once you unlock everything, theres nothing to go about except repetitive and boring challenges (yeah i was bored with Slay The Spire after a while too).
- Once you progress, you will soon realize that enemy variety is very low and every run starts to look the same.

[b] Final: [/b]
[h1] 7/10 [/h1] Monster Train was a fresh return to the genre after Slay The Spire but unless some designer comes up with a major innovation, wel, it seems overhype of the genre will surely decay fast. Once you unlock everything, Monster Train too becomes a borefest but until then i nearly had 40 fun hours so theres no complaint in that department; got my money's worth.

pros:
- it scratches the Slay the Spire itch;
- it's fun while you open and explore factions;
cons:
- it combines enough features from other games/genres to not call it a rip-off, but you know it is. 
- it's kinda too simple: I think I shouldn't just win runs while first-time exploring factions. It's really hard to mess up a run.
- It isn't deep enough to play it after you opened up factions.
- It just feels generic in many aspects.

title: Monster Train
review:
I first posted that it was slay the spire for kids in full detail after having played it for only 10 hours. A friend of mine challenged me to finish it, stating it may get more challenging if you go on. So I took my review offline and accepted the challenge to finished the game.

So after having completed lvl25 I have to stick by what I previously stated. 
In a whole it is rather unbalanced, some cards are completely useless and others are overpowered. It feels like you have options, but if you want to win, you don't have any. Some artifacts are overpowered aswell, beginning with the right one means you won before you started, later in the game at around lvl20 it meant you have a 75% chance to win. 

I finished the whole game with a very basic strategy (but then, there are only basic strategies as you have to use the ones that correspond with your clan of choice) and mostly the same cards. Some of the clans were a terrible match, I wish they had put in more synergy options. 
The further you progress the more the first two draws of monsters and upgrades count. After that, it was a sure win or a sure loss and not even worth playing in my opinion (I only did so to finish the game). There were plenty of runs I could only lose no matter what and games I didn't even have to try. So in all the game plays you instead of you playing it, making it more like a casual game in my opinion.

Is it a bad game? No it is not, it looks good and has some creative aspects with the exception of some bad steals from other games. For example: Putting extra unplayable cards in your deck to make it harder doesn't work with this game. They are not annoying at all since the monsters you place are out of your deck and card draw is easy enough to accomplish. 

I wouldn't recommend it unless there is a pandemic and you haven't got much else to do.

title: Monster Train
review: S'good

title: Monster Train
review:
For a fan of rogue-like deckbuilders, a must-play. Best described as Slay the Spire's younger, happy-go-lucky brother. 

Replayability is high, owing to the simple trick of creating multiple sub-factions, letting you pick two to combine and then keeping track of successful runs for each combination. But this breath of options comes with a price: in contrast to StS's tight balance, in Monster Train anything goes. The degree to which the game allows you to break the mechanics is absurd, but that also means there's a number of runs that from the word go basically have no shot of making it to the end, doomed to die at the first boss. At least, that's my experience at the middling difficulty level.

Some runs are impossible to get going, some runs are impossible to lose. Most runs have you searching for the seam to exploit and crack open. If a Slay the Spire with higher highs and lower lows sounds appealing to you, it's an easy recommendation. If you're interested in trying out a rogue-like deckbuilder for the first time, it's also an attractive entry point that doesn't take itself too serious and isn't afraid to have fun.

Easy recommendation.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you're a big fan of Slay the Spire, try it, it's awesome. Similar play-style to StS, but you have units and spells instead of just spells, still have the chapter bosses, choosing which path to go etc. It got time leaderboard, daily challenge run and custom run as well. A bit challenging than StS, mainly because you need to manage your units well, and also tower defence element which makes it pretty fun.

TLDR for game mechanic:
0. You pick 2 classes at start, 1 main clan for main champion and deck and secondary clan for support.
1.Each fight has 4 floors, you have a core on top, if core is down to 0 hp, you lose.
2. You have to place unit to defend the floors, each floor has a max. capacity of unit placed, enemies will move up a floor each turn, final boss can freely travel between floor.
3. You have limited mana to play cards.
4. You have spells to damage/heal enemies(you can damage your units as well), heals, draw etc. like StS
5. You cannot replace a unit until its dead.
6. Choose a path to go, either you have upgrades, remove cards or random rewards.
7. Final wave of each fight is like a deathmatch, your units and boss hit each other until one is down, so prepare well.

Game is definitely worth buying even on full price, although I hope that the dev can push more content in the future. ngl, I end up liking the game more than Slay the Spire at this point.

title: Monster Train
review: I don't write many reviews so forgive me if I get of track a bit. Monster train feels like the strange offspring of Slay the Spire, Binding of Issac, and MTG (Magic the Gathering) after a wild night and no one really knows who's kid it is. The game revolves are using 5 base decks that all have their own specific themes as well as champions that also have different play styles to them within that base deck. You play two decks at a time between any of the 5 base decks with one being the main one that your champion is from and the other being a deck you just pull cards from.  For instance the hellhounds, one of the first decks you play is pretty similar to something of a goblin deck from MTG at times. Where the monsters synergize together to be far greater than the sum of their parts, with a heavy emphasis on aggression and relatively well stated early game monsters. And the second deck you have access to at the start  is a lot like a usual green deck from MTG with large monsters and an emphasis on large health pools and ramping damage, ect. Even though I say that, that doesn't necessarily mean that you will be locked into those kinds of play styles. How you play that deck and champion will be based on what kind of drops you get, the stats of your champion,  and what ways you can best make use of artifact synergies and events that happen in a run. Now take the MTG systems and add in vertical layers along with the usual roguelike elements, random artifacts that could drastically change any given run, random events, shops to beef up spells or monsters with different semi random effects or stats. The amount of wildly different and viable deck styles I have won with already is absurd to be frank. With me only being 13 hours in, the single player alone seems to have a couple hundred hours worth of content before you have seen all the different possible combinations. This doesn't even include the multiplayer which has weekly challenges,  mutations akin to hearthstones brawl's, as well as races with other players to see who can finish a run the fastest. With this much content at this price point if you are even remotely interested in Slay the Spire then I think you will be hard pressed to not find something to love about this game. I am very much looking forward to what comes next for this game and its developers.

title: Monster Train
review:
One last turn becomes one last run.  Anyone who loved Slay the Spire would very likely enjoy Monster Train.

Monster Train takes the solo deck-building genre and adds tower defense/lane mechanics to make a very thought invoking game. Your goal is to defend the Pyre which will help restore Hell from the frozen wastes it has become. As you continually attempt to free your kin from the forces of Heaven, you will unlock new cards and factions which allow for countless synergies. Finding these strategies and watching them unfold is a joy and losses feel like a learning experience.

For those looking for a challenge, there are covenant ranks which increase with difficulty as you beat a run, although looking through the ranks; some of them seem a little artificial. When completing runs, you even get gold versions of the cards you completed your run with!

On top of the single-player deck building experience, there is the usual daily challenge to place yourself on the ladder.  Hell Rush is a multiplayer mode where you race other players in a timed battle to see who can score the highest, something I am still a little intimidated to try; but look forward to as I continue to play.

I look forward to the continued development of Monster Train and would recommend this to anyone who loves deck builders, Slay the Spire, the solo adventures in Hearthstone, or just card games in general.

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1] [u] Long Story Short: [/u] [/h1]
It's Slay The Spire (which I love) but without the frustrating bits and without some of the tedium. The runs are quick and satisfying, the snowballs are fun and the decks are all pretty unique. Highly recommend!


[h1] The Good: [/h1]
The strategy is multi-dimensional due to the nature of having three floors to place units and cast spells on. This is a great dimension to the game that other similar turn-based-games miss. You will find yourself building a specific roster to achieve or abuse a certain mechanic on a per-floor basis which is extremely satisfying when it pays off. The mechanics are all balanced well enough to allow for some serious synergies without it being too easy to do (without some luck).

You unlock decks which keeps the game feeling fresh and giving you something to achieve. The last two decks you unlock I loved. So unique and well designed. The game UI and design is all very high quality. It feels like it has the same level of polish as Hearthstone. 

You unlock more cards and artifacts for your decks and runs you have through reaching new XP levels. You unlock a cosmetic reward for the cards when you achieve victory. The gameplay loop is addictive, its one of those "oh just one more round until its 2am" type games. Achieving victory feels satisfying but not impossible.

Art style is beautiful, love the uniqueness of the world and how you're "defending the Pyre of Hell on a train". It's unapologetically its own thing. Each set of enemies is varied. They have funny quips in speech bubbles. I think the "lore" and "unknown events" are better done in "Slay the Spire" but it's not far off - you may like it better.

The difficulty is very fair, you can choose to increase the difficulty of your run by modifying enemies abilites/stats for a bonus reward- which can make or break a run. When you rank up you unlock additional "run modifiers" called "Covenants" which is the real 'difficulty level' if you will. I am determined to finish every aspect the game has to offer.

[h1] What could be Improved/What are the cons: [/h1]
- It can be obvious early on if a run will be worth sticking around for - no reason to stick around
- Not enough ways to save a run - I almost want a mulligan/tribute/sacrifice event to help turn the tides of crummy decks
- Too much snowballing - some of my decks would become easy after duplicating OP cards - maybe duplicating cards should negatively affect its stats/buffs/runes.
- Add more variance to the "unknown events" and add hidden stops.
- I found the fifth deck too easy (deck balancing)
- I found the third deck the least consistent (deck balancing)
- Healing the Pyre past max health should give some bonus - Maybe healing above max health overflows into gold, pyre damage or armor
- Housemates concerned about weird noises when fighting the Fel Boss on Ultra Speed ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

Overall, amazing game - highly recommend. So glad I picked it up.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is a very well crafted game. It shines with polish and masterful design decisions.
Compared to Slay the Spire, the premise are the same, but differences are enough for this game to stand on its own.
Absolutely enjoyed it, it is easy to grasp and has a very nice difficulty curve. The combos and "synergies" feel great and I feel like my strategies pay over time.

However for nitpicking there are two issues I had with this game,
1. One of the main ways difficulty scales is increasing HP pools of enemies, while this makes sense, it makes it impossible to track how many turns to kill this enemy, and tactics depending on such peculiarities are denied from the player.

2. I said the difficulty scales well, what I meant was it actually scales "too" well. (Disclaimer: I am not sure about this, take with a grain of salt.) 
I would not be surprised if there was a simple algorithm which measures the performance of the player and changes tweaks the difficulty accordingly. While this increases tense moments and fun gameplay for beginner players. For the hard-core players it actually bars them from showing off their best tactics since the enemies will always try to match your strength.

title: Monster Train
review:
I personally think this does Slay the Spire better so if you like that, I think you'll like this. You unlock all the different classes relatively quickly which is nice but you're still left with card unlocks for a while to keep the game fresh for some time. The Covenant ranks look interesting even though I've only unlocked up to level 3 and it's a bit more interesting than Slay the Spire with the various different effects that occur. The concept overall is pretty similar to Slay the Spire, build a deck, play cards and fight "Monsters". It is however a lot friendly in terms of calculating everything up front for you so you don't need to worry about all the mental maths and reducing the whole routing thing. You might say that reduces the interesting decisions but frankly I find this a simpler, more enjoyable model without much of the loss.

It looks like there's a lot more stuff here for the stats people too, it tracks various things that you can use to compare against friends and the wider players.

If you like deck builders,  either electronic of physical, you should pick this up.

title: Monster Train
review:
A very unique deckbuilder. 

At first glance, the story progression might seem similar to games like Slay The Spire, but it is very different. The biggest differences are in the battles themselves. The game has many unique core mechanics that make it entirely different from anything else. 

Rather than describing it as a battle, each encounter is better described as a battlefield. Three battlefields. The way monsters will move from level to level is a unique twist with very interesting consequences for gameplay that makes it feel entirely different from other deckbuilders.

The balancing at this stage is far from perfect, but it is decent, at least that's how it feels after 3 runs. 

Graphics, music and sfx are good and immersive. Very good for a roguelike deckbuilder game in fact.

Strong recommend.

title: Monster Train
review:
Very highly recommended.
I loved Slay the Spire and I also love this.  I would say that Monster Train is far more approachable in terms of its much easier difficulty.  The game has a more obvious and surprisingly well balanced array of builds it can direct the player towards which is a ton of fun to see through.  I also love the choices Monster Train made with regards to consistency and information given to the player vs RNG.  
The 5 classes are all fun to play and the idea to multiclass was brilliant as it can all work but there are some that clearly compliment one another better leading to its own little difficulty mode for players to enjoy.  The addition of random class cards and an artifact at the start of each run is what really makes this game feel special as these small things really influence your direction and lead you in a fun way to trying new things.

9/10 game.  Given the hours I've put into this its hard to imagine it won't be my game of the year.

title: Monster Train
review:
SUMMARY: A must-buy game for fans of deckbuilders and deckbuilding Rougelikes with a twist, Monster Train combines cards, strategy, resource management, and tactical planning.  With plenty of unlockables, options, challenges, and ranzomization this is a game that will provide you plenty of entertainment while pushing you to up your game.  It also is loaded with atmosphere.

Let's get this out of the way: it's easy to compare Monster Train to Slay The Spire.  This is inappropriate because though there are similar elements and some obvious influence, the games play very different.  So just because you liked - or hated - Slay the Spire doesn't mean you'll feel the same.

So let's get to the review!

The plot of the game is interesting: Angels and Demons were once at peace due to an alliance called the Covenant, and a railway through Heaven and Hell.  Then, the Angels attacked and destroyed the heart of Hell.  Only you, with the last flames of Hell powering your train, can hope to breach the center of your homeland and rekindle it.  If you mouse over cards in your logbook or other elements of the game you can pick up more.  You don't need to follow the story, but if you do, you realize there's a RICH atmosphere here, which takes it to the next level.

At the start of the game, you'll be able to select which factions are with you, which yields you some initial spells and a champion.  More factions unlock as you play, giving you five total, which means plenty of combinations to try - and the factions are radically different.  

You start on the outskirts of hell, which gives you some options, then it's off to battle.  Each battle takes you deeper into Hell, and after each battle you get to choose two paths, which give you access to various resources such as gold, stores, recruits, random events, and more.  Some levels have common resources, but in many cases you'll have to choose.

Every level sees various enemies storm your train, sometimes assisted by a Boss, and at the end of the level the boss begins a full-on assault.  This means having to think ahead, because you know the big bad is coming.

But that's not all.  Your train has four levels - three where you can deploy troops, and the top level where the Pyre is, the last flame of hell.  If enemies reach it the'll attack it - and though it does damage to them, they may survive long enough to break it.  That means you've got to summon creatures and invoke spells from your deck - and that means thinking ahead.

Your deck contains creatures and spells, often with wildly different traits.  You draw cards and have a certain amount of power ("Ember") to call up minions.  It sounds simple, but . . .

Some enemies go from level to level, climbing your train.  Others might be able to sneak up an extra level close to the Pyre.  Some bosses move about and assist their minions.  Some enemies grant whole groups special powers  You have to pay attention to three levels of the train each turn, figure out where to deploy troops and cast spells, and figure where the enemies may move next.    You have to think about what's in your hand, what's in your deck, what's going on, and what may happen.

This leads to a variety of interesting tactics - and ways to fail.  Do you put high-powered minions at the bottom to clear out the riffraf - or at the top to protect the Pyre? Position in the train also affects what may happen and who can attack who, further leading to important decisions, such as using knockback.  The synergy of cards and artifacts (more on that later) and your choices can create radically different results - and failures.  Plus you always know that boss is coming . . .

As you  win battles and travel you can also find cards and money, modify your champion (everyone gets one big monster to start with), and modify cards.  Cards have "slots" into which you can add improvements, evolving them to do more, and occasioanlly changing them.  This also requires you to ask "do I customize monsters, spells, or both?" depending on your troops, spells, and strategy.  Modification lets you further create your own strategies, making cards your own.

As you play you unlock new cards, and winning yields "covenants" to let you boost the challenge.  And if that's not enough to drive you, you can chose to up the difficulty of any level with a "trial" that makes it harder but gives you a reward.

The game has a lot of options, a lot of unlockables, and all of these come together with a tactical deckbuilder to make sure you'll have plenty of challenge.  Plus, you can play a full game in maybe thirty minutes.

Basically, it's a fantastic game.  I think this is one that's going to be remembered for years.

So who's this game for:
* If you like deckbuilders and want that with a twist - the tactical and positional elements - then its for you.
* If you like deckbuilders you may like it - as long as the addition of the tactical/position element is something you don't mind or are curious about.
* If you like defense-type games that involve positioning and planning, you might like it.  It depends if you like or are interested in the deckbuilding aspect.

Gets boring losing to RNG.

The gameplay isn't intuitive. The trick is to build small decks with cards that can fill out your train with units and then buff them. I haven't played another card game that encourages small decks and dropping cards. I only figured it out after long hours of boring grinding, not getting anywhere.

Then, given this winning strategy, RNG plays a big part if your run is successful. One wrong creature death and you'll lose the run. This was on a low difficulty too. It's like gambling, but without the winning for a victory.

Otherwise the aesthetics are nice. The game also has polish. It's just too random for my taste.

title: Monster Train
review:
So Monster Train basically a combinations of deck building and tower defense. And of course it is not Slay the Spire despite being similar genre so please don't make comparison whether which game is better, cause this game is on a different league of its own. 
A quick recap of the game's content: 5 clans (classes) so five different themed decks, and you have to allied (combined) the 5 clans with each other to build a strong deck over the course of going through hell and beating enemies coming into your train. If the enemies drained the health bar of the core (Pyre) of the train, you lose.

As much as i loved this game, the first 3 clans( Hellhorned, Awoken, Stygian) are much more well-rounded and fun to play rather than the other two (Umbras and Melting Rem) and these other twos really need some better adjustments and changes to their cards. Also it is quite frustrating to play these two clans on higher levels as they are really weak compared to other clans imo. But overall the game is really fun and though the game have value in its replayability  (because of the amount of decks' combinations you can have), but to be honest, since there are certain cards and relics that spawned way too often, the game gets extremely stale. And because of this, you don't usually have much viable options outside of the usual deck combination that already ingrained in the clans' theme, for example, Stygian being the mages so in order to win, you have to go a roundabout ways with lots of damage spells and over the course of building the deck, you would usually have to completely disregard your allied clan to win or survive. Since the game system forced u to paired up with other clans and most of the time some pairs just can't synergize at all and even hinders deck building at the start.

tl;dr: the game needs improvement on the given allies' cards at the start, and the game needs better changes to the Umbra and Melting Rem, but a fun game nonetheless, so i would recommend anyone to give this game a try.

title: Monster Train
review:
[b]Slay the Spire: Protect the Pyre Edition[/b]

An excellent entry into a criminally under-served genre, Monster train comes with a few interesting twists and meaningful improvements to the obvious Slay the Spire comparison.

1. Interesting class dynamics with the ability to select primary and secondary clans.
2. Strategic lane-based combat, often resulting in tricky and compelling enemy lethal puzzles with depth.
3. Unprecedented control over your deck and the contained cards with modular upgrades.

Not all is perfect with the game though, in my opinion falling flat on enemy variety and often lack-luster boss fights. Although, the looming presence of major bosses off the front of the train is a nice touch to making the boss fights feel interactive beyond the final 3 turns.

Overall, I would definitely recommend the game for any interested in the rogue-like deck-building genre, and possibly even to those interested in general strategy games.

I haven't gotten that far (only 4 clans and 5 covenant), but the game feels easy in comparison. Will update this review if I feel like that changes, but Monster Train is still a recommend.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is a well-oiled machine. A machine, on a track, headed straight to Hell.

When I opened the game, it dropped me right into the action: It gave me a deck of cards, showed me some enemies, and told me to just play. There's no traditional tutorial; instead, with a combination of intuitive interface, wonderfully helpful tooltips, and slow ramping of mechanics, the game explains itself, just by playing it. As a game should.

Over time, you'll unlock more cards, more abilities, and more challenges. The game pitches you tougher battles, with tougher boss abilities, and give you more and more interesting, complex means of defeating those enemies. As a game should!

Monster Train isn't just a good deck builder. It isn't just a good roguelike. It isn't just a bigger and better Slay the Spire.

It's an example for every other game developer, for how to make an engaging, delightful, challenging video game that grabs you from the very beginning. There isn't a single part of this game -- not a single button, not a single card, not a single UI element -- that hasn't been finely-tuned towards that objective. The result is a masterpiece, and I'll warn you in advance: You'll get addicted.

title: Monster Train
review:
TLDR: Buy it on sale if you're new to genre.  Buy it now if you like this genre.

I was new to the genre with Slay the Spire, barely making it to A5 after dozens of attempts.  Nothing really clicked right for me.  Highly enjoyed it though, and this game was being hyped as a good successor. (Note: I don't watch streamers or YT'ers or other crap like that; I read reviews and browse forums and go with my gut on whats shills/real)

So this game, I'd say is easier overall, much more approachable for people new to the genre, and each faction gives you a more clear direction on how to build, with more options.  Whereas in STS, you can get yourself killed in the first area pretty damn easy, this game you can make it more than half-way with a non-efficient build/deck.  And then you learn the mechanics being able to do so.  The first time you use umbra you'll probably think they're dogshit, but once you understand the playstyle they might be your fav (mine is the CandleCrew).

The game has a GREAT interface with lots of post-game summary screens, etc.  The only negative I have is that sometimes placing units can be annoying when you have many stacked.

On the subject of negatives, my biggest one is the length of a game.  Entirely too short.  Could use some filler battles or a longer campaign that goes past the current one.   I don't know if this actually happens at higher ascension levels, I didn't bother to google it.

Some hints for newbies:
HOLDOVER is OP.  The description is vague. the dum dum version is: "If you use this spell, its in your hand the next turn".  So you take a spell, you upgrade it with Holdover + minus cost or more power/stronger buff and all of a sudden its a passive bonus every turn, especially if you get cost to 0.
Don't start with Stygian main.  At least for me, they're the hardest to work with because your hero is a little babby with babby HP (THREE, fucking THREE HP).
Ascend/Descend sound like useless spells, but what they don't tell you is that you can ignore the space restrictions for a floor if you use these cards (All floors have a 7 unit limit though).  There are strats based around spawning on one floor then pushing them to another to stack and rape.
Hover over enemies to learn their abilities.  Stuff like "+10 armour when a spell is cast on this floor" can really fuck you.  If you're using a spell that spawns//draws other cards, use it on an empty floor, then use the card you've spawned on the floor with one of these enemies.  Don't use a weak spell on a guy on a floor with this ability,   Your 6 dam is negated by +10 armor unless he's under 6hp!
Spikes/Frozen can be hard to make powerful.  If you don't get the right artifacts and cards early, it ends up being a bad idea cuz the enemy will end up wailing on your torch with several turns to live before the latent damage catches up.
AFAIK you can't save scum / alt+f4 poor decisions / misclicks like in STS. This game saves your progress almost constantly.

title: Monster Train
review:
Awesome take on Slay the Spire formula with Hearthstone art and deployable units.  You pick 2 of 5 clans (a primary clan and then an ally clan), and then engage in 8 battles.  In each turn, enemies enter at the bottom floor of the train, fight your deployed units, and then surviving enemies advance to the next floor.  Your Pyre sits at the top floor, and the game is over if the enemies deal enough damage to it.  After each battle, you can collect upgrades, cards, and health.  Short, sweet, and simple, but solid.

My only complaint is that there is no mod support.  With only 5 clans and 3 bosses in the base game, I think there is a lot of room for Steam Workshop content.

title: Monster Train
review:
Definitely rips Slay The Spire off in many regards (5 card default hands that cycle out to a discard every turn, 3 energy default, many of the same mechanics, many of the same type of relics (and relics in general), ascension levels, etc.

And while I'll say Slay The Spire is definitely still a way better game and much more deep of a game, Monster Train is the first Roguelite CCG outside of StS that has captivated my attention.  It's a really fun game, much more casual than StS without nearly as many difficult choices, but I'll be damned if it isn't addicting and super fun to play.  There's also really cool multiplayer aspects and also comparisons to your steam friends and just a ton of random stats that get tracked throughout your runs, as a data lover I will always support anything of that sort.  Definitely worth the money and maybe one day could give StS a run for its money.

title: Monster Train
review: First there was Dream Quest, then Slay the Spire, and now Monster Train.  It’s the next step in the evolution of the deck-builder rogue-like and improves the genre considerably.  Take Slay the Spire and add more classes, more and more varied upgrades for spells, multiple units, multiple battlegrounds, more or better everything.  And it’s still really tight.  Some of the classes are really unique in their mechanics as well.  Kudos to the developers.  This must have been a bitch to balance as well as they did.

title: Monster Train
review:
Very deep roguelite deckbuilder.  I've spent 25 hours with it, feel like I've barely scratched the surface.  Steep learning curve to just basic understanding (at least 30+ keywords to learn after first couple games, maybe more???).  I'd imagine an extremely steep learning curve to mastery.  I imagine this is one of those games where you'll see lots of people with 1/2 hour played (immediately intimidated/turned-off), lots of people with 20-30 hours played (tried to learn, failed), and lots of people with 500+ (mastered).

That said, if you are willing to put in the time, Monster Train is quite rewarding.  I will probably find myself in the 2nd category, don't see myself really investing the time to get great at the game.

But I'm certainly not disappointed with my purchase and if I was missing a game in my life with much depth (right now I'm focusing on my chess game), I could see this taking its place.

Casual players beware, too deep to give you a good experience I think if you are trying to go up Covenent levels (basically the games' hard mode).  I also think it's hard to understand why you lost, so the loop isn't particularly forgiving unless you really sit back and analyze what went wrong.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is a weird combination of a card based game reminding me of Magic the Gathering draft decks (you have a champion at the start, draft units (creatures) and spells (mostly sorcery). This has the same artefact system as Slay the Spire (permanent effects for each battle) and there are 3 floors you need to defend. The 4th floor is your 'tower' that can take some damage and deal some damage.
There are 5 different races that are a mix of stereotypes of Magic: you have a side that concentrates on spells, power, fast damage, sacrifice mechanics and graveyard. Don't get me wrong. It isn't M:TG. It definitely took inspiration of Slay the Spire, Magic and Tower defence games but made it their own. I hope they add extra dlc as it seems a bit limited in cards and bosses. But definitely a nice game for 10-20 bucks.

title: Monster Train
review:
Much like slay the spire, this game takes the deck-building genre (pioneered by Dominion) digital, with flourishes only a digital game can provide. The focus is on quick games of gradually increasing difficulty, random loot providing the opportunity for combinations, and whilst clearly derivative in many of its features, introduces new mechanics through the use of multiple, simultaneous fights.
It is very good, deep, and interesting.

review:
I streamed the game on launch and people loved it! Now I stream it frequently and its always a blast. Really awesome game, feels challenging but in the same run it feels rewarding to keep you going.

Only aspect I would hope the Devs might add something in the future is the multiplayer. I love to do the hellrush race mode with friends or with my community, however because of a missing option to invite people or create a code people can join my game its always quite the task to get at least some people into the same lobby.

Would really love if the devs would improve this and add an option for an code or password so you can create races together with selected people, since the multiplayer is just for fun and giggles it wont break the game in my opinion.

All factions play entirely different and you can combine them freely to create even more unique playstyles.

Really enjoy it!

title: Monster Train
review:
Tl;dr version: It looks like a mobile game with it's meh graphics, quite fun and addicting but is lacking in content (bosses, cards, modes, etc.) especially for the price. But if I had to rate the game, it would be around 7 or 8/10. Not really worth $25, but on sale for like $15 I would say is pretty alright.

Long version:
It has 5 factions and they are all somewhat unique with their play style. A primary faction chosen from the five (Your champion with spells/units specific to that faction) and a secondary faction (one of the other five aswell). 

3 major bosses and like 4 or 5 bosses that can be another boss of that stage (like hulking bird with axe could be swapped with muscle bird with iron head). An ok amount of enemy units you will encounter.

Covenants which you unlock. These covenants make the game more and more difficult, up to 20 I think.

Like 3 or 4 different modes (normal, hell rush which is multiplayer race against others, daily challenges and custom challenges you can make).

This game needs more content for me to be satisfied. The $25 for what is given is not justified to me. Definitely more like $15 or even $10. But that's just me and my feel for this game.

title: Monster Train
review:
TL;DR Monster Train is like Slay the Spire, and just as good. Story is a bit overboard, but gameplay is solid and super well balanced.

Monster Train is a roguelike deck builder very similar in feel to Slay the Spire. The mechanics and strategies are very different from Slay the Spire, but I think it is pretty safe to say that if you like one you will like the other.

There are a lot of cards to unlock and strategies to choose. At the beginning of each run you pick a primary and secondary clan from the 5 available (3 are unlocked by playing), and each of those clans has about 2 or 3 archetypes you can follow. That is a lot of options and combinations. Which is why it was so surprising to me how well the game is balanced. That is seriously the most impressive feat, that you always have a shot no matter what strategy you try to go for or how the RNG plays. You can often pinpoint the failure of a run to a missed oppertunity or mistake. Also, you star off where 2 damage is a lot, and end up with dealing 100s of points of damage utilizing some of the same cards, and it just feels good to combo to a level that seemed impossible at the beginning of the run. This, along with the multitude of unlockable cards, makes playing this game enjoyable.

The story is a bit overboard though, if you ask me. You play as the last hope for Hell, trying to rekindle the Pyre to unfreeze your beloved home. There are somber interludes where you look over the carnage wrought by the invading army of Heaven, and the music swells as you fight them, struggling against these impossible odds, fighting so desperately for your right to exist! ... which is great, really tugged at my heart strings there for a moment, but it gets a bit ridiculous when you are on your 30th run. Slay the Spire did a clever thing, where it kept it mysterious and it was possible that you were making these runs over and over again as part of a larger effort against malevolent unseen forces. But in this game, each run is treated with this epicness like it is the last run ever to be made, ever, and that all hope rests with you! This is actually a pretty minor complaint, because it is fairly effective at what it does, but it gets a bit silly. It did make me not want to experiment with some suboptimal strategies because the game is making me feel like too much is at stake :/

Lastly, a complaint I have is that ultimately your "allied" clan, the second pick, makes very little difference because the clans do not mesh well. In general you have to focus on synergies and those just aren't present much between the clans. There are a lot of cards, but it much more feels like you pick one clan at the beginning of a run rather than picking a fusion of two.

Bottom line though, the mechanics and gameplay are great, the art and design polished, and even though the story takes itself a bit to seriously, you'll have A LOT of fun.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is undoubtedly one of the best deckbuilding games out there. I've had it less than a week and have over 20 hours of playtime, and that certainly justifies the price. I have about 130 hours of game time in Slay the Spire and while I love that game, Monster Train feels more satisfying somehow, it's hard to put a finger on why though. Unit based combat combined with spells and artifacts inspired by StS come together to create a cohesive experience. 

That being said, there definitely seems to be a couple build paths that completely outshine others, and the nature of MT means it's much easier to target a specific build. For example, I reached Covenant 8 almost exclusively using Frostbite + Incant Blue/Green decks, and while all the factions have awesome ideas and playstyles, it's hard NOT to play that to advance because the others feel mediocre at best.

That being said, it's still very early and other builds are still totally viable. I hope the developers are willing to adjust game balance as Mega Crit does. 

Highly recommend, excellent experiences to be had by all :)

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train has its good points; the presentation is excellent, and when your deck works it does press the FUN button in your head. 

Unfortunately, that's where it ends. The game is in no way even remotely balanced, and the devs have admitted that they have no intention of correcting this. There are not enough significant decisions to allow skill to mitigate the RNG of not getting the broken build you need to win or running into the ludicrously unfair enemy that hard counters you. And sometimes there's just no mathematical route to victory at all. I finally gave up and uninstalled after over 50 hours of trying when I lost a Covenant 11 run on the first fight.

I have frequently heard this game compared with Slay the Spire. Well, if you enjoyed Slay the Spire ... go play it some more. Don't waste your money on this.

title: Monster Train
review:
I'm revising this because it doesn't seem fair to play a game so much and give it a negative review. My complaints are the same, but it's still an enjoyable experience despite the annoying parts.
This game has a ton of promise, but the amount of luck of the draw and variance in usefulness of artifacts and if you get the right cards is absurd. 
It's not difficult to play this game well. There's a lot of strategy and synergy. Instead, the problem arises from being unable to do the super cool combos you want to pull off because you just didn't get the right cards.
For example, I got an artifact that gave me plus 3 to all x cost cards. Cool. This gives me a clear strategy of pursuing and upgrading certain x cost cards. And then I didn't get offered a SINGLE + x card. 
Another issue is that artifacts are absolutely not balanced. Some are miles better than others. That's fine for a game on launch. What's worse is that some artifacts are clearly good, but offer literally no interesting decisions, like giving your pyre 40 health. These artifacts do not affect your play style literally at all. 
Also, some of the statuses are an issue. For example, thorns. It's an issue because some unit leaders only have a couple of hit points, and it's not like you can stop them from attacking. Thus, you can play your leader and hope that he just never engages an enemy with thorns, because if he does he will die and there's nothing you can do about it, or not play your leader? I guess. Stealth is equally stupid. There's genuinely nothing fun about the stealth mechanic. It's just a boss taking 8 free shots on your units so you better hope you went with a beefy boy strategy, because if you went for a glass cannon big damage strategy you're definitely going to lose.
The foundation and variability is great. This is a fully fledged and well thought through game. But it needs a lot of work to get it out of the frustrating stage of just getting totally boned by bad luck.
Even offering 3 cards instead of 2 after each fight would go a long way, or have  a card shop, or any number of other things.

title: Monster Train
review: This game is incredibly fun as a singleplayer adventure. It combines rogue-like elements from games such as Slay the Spire with the graphical charm of Hearthstone and adds its own flavor of angels vs demons on a train to hell. You battle across the vertical levels of your train where the enemies move up towards your pyre after each of your turns. There's a slew of unlocks in the forms of cards, card types, card borders, artifacts and more. You gain experience as you play and the difficulty ramps up really well. I've played for 11 hours as of this review and I've consistently felt rewarded each attempt I've made. Currently, I see no reason to not continue my struggle against the armies of Heaven. I'd give this a 10/10 for a good time.

title: Monster Train
review:
It's enough like Slay the Spire that if you liked StS you'll like Monster Train.

But it also does its own thing enough that it isn't just a rehash. It adds a lot of interesting mechanics--units, unit placement, managing number of units on a floor, choices between multiple types of between-battle encounter at once, choosing a secondary class (ie. clan) in addition to your main one--that it breathes new life into the fledgling genre of roguelike deckbuilders. 

Immaculate design, solid art, tons of replayability, monstrously fun/broken combos to discover. Play it!

review:
So, this game is quite controversial for me. It packs a lot of punch in terms of playability and replayability because every run is different and you can keep unlocking cards for each "race"... still, there are some races that are too weak against certain types of anemies (for example morsels are useless if the enemy has some kind of sweep attack), and if you are not lucky enough to have the exact card or unit to destroy them BEFORE they attack, you are toast.
So, this game still needs quite a bit of balancing.
I'd like to see more races down the line, probably more types of units and spells too... but I think they are on the right path.
