title: Monster Train
review:
In a nutshell, this game is one of the best deckbuilding games I've ever played.

The deckbuilding genre has seen a renaissance recently because of games like Slay The Spire; where Monster Train succeeds is in the polish. One of my major gripes with Slay The Spire was that the cohesiveness of the card pool was not great, and playing more to unlock cards actually made the game harder, as it also diluted the card pool. Monster Train's card balance is such that although I've unlocked entire libraries, it never felt like I ever hit a card choice that didn't at least augment the deck I was trying to build. In those rare cases, there was always the skip button to get gold instead of a card.

The way the cards are partitioned into "clans" also makes it a lot easier to splash in another deck archetype to support your main deck archetype. When you start a Monster Train run, you pick a primary clan and your allied clan, which determines the pool of cards you can select from in your run. This complex interplay between your chosen clans is nothing short of magical. It allows for build variety but at the same time narrows your focus so that you have a much smaller chance of running into the diluted card pool issue.

The additional vertical element of the game also differentiates it from other deckbuilders. In Monster Train, there are three usable floors on your train. Each floor has a size limit, and enemies start on the bottom floor and work their way up. You have a choice of which floor to summon your monsters on and cast your spells on.  This adds a surprising amount of complexity to the game, but it never feels onerous. Here, I feel I have to also call out the attention to detail with the UI, as you can scroll through floors using the scroll wheel of your mouse. Such a small thing makes it a joy to play since it just feels right.

Finally, Monster Train provides information ahead of time about the enemies you are going to face during a run. This avoids the situation in which your deck works great for the majority of the game, but falls flat because of the final boss' particular gimmick. This sort of information hiding was one of my other gripes with Slay The Spire because I feel it unnaturally extends the replayability of the game at the cost of fun. There's no greater frustration than carefully building your deck, only to have the final boss be a hard counter to your deck archetype. Monster Train shines here because giving you this information up front gives you a greater sense of agency, even if there is still randomness involved.

All in all, I'm very excited to see what future updates have in store for this game. I'd heartily recommend it for fans of the deckbuilding genre.

Unlike a lot of the clones of Slay the Spire, this game has a good amount of mechanical differences so it really stands out.  The runs are significantly different from each other (admittedly less so if you start forcing things) and last in the territory of an hour to complete.  Being 14 hours in, I've only tried 4 of the classes and haven't unlocked all the cards or tried all the class combinations.  That's to say nothing of trying some of the more niche strategies.

review:
Fun fun fun!

This is the second legitimately good deckbuilding rogue-like that I've ever played, the other one being Slay the Spire.
The game borrows a lot of ideas from Slay the Spire, but puts a different spin on them, making the gameplay more dynamic and diverse and choices more numerous and meaningful. You can mix & match two clans("colors") which leads to many interesting combos and synergies.

If you've not played Slay the Spire yet, I'd still suggest starting with that one. It's less confusing for a beginner and has more polish. If you did, however, then definitely play this game, you'll love it!

title: Monster Train
review:
Slay the Spire comparisons abound.  Certainly Slay the Spire defined the genre, but Monster Train definitely refines it in a good way.  In the hours I have put into Monster Train I never really felt that the game just plain screwed me over.  Every failed run I can trace to my bad decisions, not to a string of bad ? rooms, or a fight that perfectly countered my deck.

Having the 5 different decks to mix and match creates a plethora of replayability.  Unlike its predecessor I find that after I have completed a run in Monster Train I don't want to put it down for the day, or a few months.  Rather I want to play again, and again, applying what I have learned and unlocked to see if I can finish just one more run.

title: Monster Train
review: So, I enjoyed the first 3 levels of this game it was casual and interesting. This equated to about the first 10 hours of play. I spent the next 50 hours trying to beat 4th and got increasing more competitive, knowledgeable, and frustrated about the cards and builds to try and beat level 4 to no avail. The second time the end boss had the exact debuff to beat my killer draft deck I quit playing. You do not get to choose your decks, you don’t even get to choose you’re champion, and before you guys in the back start up yes you can choose you champion but you only get 2 of the 3 choices for how to build him, so if you want to play Awoken Spikes you may have to re-roll 5 times. (that was the most I had to do) Not to mention you go through the same stuff over and over with random events, so it felt very grindy to me after 10 hours of doing that. So, if you love difficult draft games built on grinding this might be for you, I however do not, and I wouldn’t recommend it to others.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game was clearly inspired at least in part by Slay the Spire, and they seem to have taken all the right lessons! The gameplay takes deep thought both in combat and building your deck outside of combat, the skill ceiling is very high, and so far the balance seems (fairly) good. As long as they keep tinkering with balance a little, this game will be nigh perfect!

My one nitpick is the music. I find it repetitive and boring, and it quickly started to annoy me. This was easily resolved by muting the music and turning on my own instead!

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1]Slay the Spire on Crack[/h1]

Think of it as Slay the Spire but with three levels to battle on.  Also five different clans to combine to make a lot of synergies available.  Add to that 25 levels with increasing levels of difficulty and you got a metric s&$@ ton of replay.  If you like Slay the Spire, Neoverse or Deckbuilding games it's a must have.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a compelling, thoughtful entry into the deckbuilding roguelite genre.  If you enjoyed Slay the Spire and want a game with a broader variety of gameplay, Monster Train is absolutely worth the purchase price.

If you found Slay the Spire a little too capricious, though, steer clear.  Monster Train is even less forgiving than Slay the Spire at higher extensions. The random deck elements can put you in an unwinnable scenario which isn't evident until you've already spent 20 minutes on a run.  Unlike most roguelikes, there is no guarantee any given run can be won, even with perfect play.

title: Monster Train
review:
tl;dr Better than StS

It's a deckbuilder on a train. It's not a serious game but it has a surprising amount of subtlety and, more importantly, is fun to play. It doesn't punish you as hard at the start as StS did, letting you play around and build up knowledge without feeling like a failure. You'll discover some ridiculous combos and put together some massively overpowered decks. But the difficulty does increase, and the challenge is there if you climb to the higher covenant levels. It feels well-designed and polished, with lots of nice UX features. I can't wait to see what kind of expansions they come up with.

title: Monster Train
review:
I'll recommend this game, but it still feels as though it's struggling to find its way to being a great game like Slay the Spire. While StS is polished and smooth, Monster Train feels a bit bumpy. 

For example, the Relic system feels largely unbalanced - When offered a choice in game, I tend to get either 1) really great relics paired with quite poor relics, or two poor or mediocre relics. I feel like either more choices need to be offered (eg. 3 or 4 choices) or have these relics offered more frequently throughout the run. Since the game is so short as well, I sometimes only pickup 2 to 3 relics throughout the run - I feel there is room for more of an expansion here.

I also feel that some of the energy costs for cards just feels bizarre - some really great cards are 0 or 1 while some other cards cost 3. But maybe I'll figure out how good they really are later. That being said, I didn't feel this way playing Slay the Spire - the card cost was clearly associated with its power or importance.

I think the Clan dynamic is great and the mixing of these clans allows the game to be more diverse - there's lots to explore with these combinations.

Maybe a nit picking thing here, but the top HUD just seems "mobile game" to me - I think it could look a bit more polished.

I haven't encountered any game breaking bugs or glitches yet. Everything is smooth and looks great otherwise.

Overall, as I said, I'd recommend it. I think MT is a game that is trying hard to emulate Slay the Spire, but falls short in several ways. I can't shake the feeling that MT is, for lack of a better way of saying it, much more aggressive having the player die / lose runs. In StS, I lost because I didn't have the right cards or relics unlocked or made a bad choice - unlocking better cards and unlocking better relics made the climb not just easier, but smoother - each run felt more about skill and how to use the cards in specific situations. I don't feel that quality is present in MT - it feels more like its trying to brute force its way. That being said, I feel the potential for MT to improve is there. Judging from what I've seen from the developers, I think they can.

I hope there are more updates to come to smooth out the many train rides I feel I'm going to be taking in the future.

title: Monster Train
review: Super addicting. The perfect "one more try..." game.

title: Monster Train
review:
Hodgepodge garbage. Severly unbalanced, essentially the game punishes you for trying out new clans, as you can have the best, strongest setup, just to get steamrolled by normal enemies in the next area that have dead-counter abilities to some clans, e.g. penumbra builds around smaller units getting devoured by larger ones, enemy gets +15 armour for every goddamn unit that dies, allies as well as enemies. The enemies have insane hitpoints later on and anything but clearing out a floor in one go is a death sentence in many cases, as they have much, much stronger abilities than ANY f*cking boss. You won't die to a boss as often as you will die to severly, stupidly unbalanced units that are essentially "kek, no!" units against pretty much entire clans (which you get your cards from). 

People say this is as good as Slay the Spyre. I say they are wrong. Severly so. Compared to this, slay the spire is thousands of times better, I wish I would have stayed under 2hrs so I could get my money back.

Tried it some more, gets even worse. Whoever designed those units should stay away from game design forever. Some enemy units are impossible to kill straight out and will bankrupt your mana entirely. Some designchoices seem like whoever was responsible just threw something together without the slightest consideration of consequences, allowing units to hit all your units and applying a horrendous debuff while doing so which will make you pay mana upkeep for the unit in question, effectively trapping you in a forever loop of "well, looks like you can't do sh*t, given you have no mana". You have NO say in that, e.g. you can't just not pay and sacrifice those units. You just end up with no mana. Grand game design, leading up to "press button to lose 3 turns". 

I am NOT saying this game isn't beatable, it's just sh*t as in it isn't fun in the slightest. Every interesting strategy can be countered by a normal monster in the next area, essentially you should be overhauling your deck all the time, and anything YOU want doesn't virtually matter.

If you want a game that plays you more than you play it, by all means, this is for you. If you want a game where your strategy choices actually matter and don't build around knowing every possible enemy unit, effectively trying to counter EVERYTHING that exists, play something else. Anything, really.

This game does everything other deckbuilding games do, except worse, with a few interesting twists, e.g. the tower defense theme, but these are so badly pulled off, it's mind boggling. The longer I played, the more I got the feeling that every mechanic I encountered I know from other games, while the way the game [i]needs[/i] to be played in a very specific way that creates a frustrating illusion of choice. Strategically it is an ocean of possibilities, with a viable handful amount of things you can actually do that could fit in a thimble. 

Etherlords, Slay the Spire, MTG, you name it, every deckbuilding game of the last decades is better than this garbage.

review: This game have a bad mechanic. Too many variables at every run, and it just in a short journey. One of the final boss especially design just to make you fail, sap sap sap your characters damage so they reach 0 damage and cant even attack enemy, all of them just waiting to die. The artifact are not balance, most of them are useless, some said it was a game changing, yeah only 1 or 2 are useful, and they are too many, diluted your option for a better one. You will rarely get a good one, and the other are completely trash. And there is a leveling mechanic for clans and convenant ranks, but it just give you more pain and without benefit at all. title: Monster Train
review: Such a stupid name for such a great game.

title: Monster Train
review:
A new take on the Slay the Spire model of game and one that is fresh and unique enough to have all the fun of playing Slay the Spire for the first time again! 

Similar to Slay the Spire, you will progress along a path, though in Monster Train that path is much shorter. One could summarize Slay the Spire in the following way: You do 3x 15 levels, in which there will be 2-3 resting spot campfires and a litany of random events that you choose to encounter based on the path you travel through that level's 15. Speaking in the same way, Monster Train can be described as doing ~9 levels, where each level has 2-3 boons for your deckbuilding and ends with 1 combat, and about every 3rd level is a boss combat.

Based on this, you can imagine that Monster Train is a much shorter game than a run of Slay the Spire. That's absolutely the case, but that's also totally fine.

In Slay the Spire, you choose a class which defines the types of cards you will find, and from the RNG of what you encounter as you climb, you shape a deck. In Monster Train, you choose a primary and secondary Tribe. Your starting deck has a Champion card from your primary, as well as supporting cards from both your primary and secondary. You can mix and match tribes as you see fit to create different synergies in your deckbuilding. Your Champion card does a lot of work for you if you learn how to play it right, and you usually build your deck around the theme of that Champion card. Here's the thing though: The Champion card gets upgraded as you progress and has different trees it can go down. For example, I played one run through with the plant tribe. The three upgrades my champion got, I chose to give him "When healed, it deals X damage to the front enemy". By max level, it was doing 60 damage per heal... And I had built my deck with tons and tons of regeneration and cheap healing spells, so that way every turn it was 60, 60, 60, 60, 60, etc. Another build could make it so your Champion has Thorns, so when they are attacked the attacker takes damage. If I built my Champion that way, my deck would have gone a different direction.

Lastly, in Slay the Spire, outside of the challenges you present yourself when getting to The End, each level is pretty much the same as the last time you saw it. In Monster Train, you are offered the opportunity to give the enemy's buffs in exchange for a higher reward, such as hiring a new creature or getting gold. There are also global buffs to enemies if you want an even greater challenge.

Overall, really great game. It scratches the Slay the Spire itch without being Less Good Slay the Spire: The Knockoff.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like strategic card and deck-building games like Slay The Spire and Hearthstone adventures (like the Dalaran heist, which was a personal favorite of mine) Then this game will probably entertain you for a while.
It has a fascinating combat system based on floors on a train and spaces available on it. you start with 2 classes, each with a set of specific class cards, and as you play you unlock more classes, and more cards to appear when you play these classes.
Between battles you get to upgrade and alter some cards.
The only shortcoming in my opinion is that overall, it seems like the amount of cards in the game for each class are too little, and with very similar card texts. For example, One card gets spikes when you heal it, another gets damage and health, but overall they are pretty similar: you should heal this card to buff it up over the course of the battle. Same goes to hero upgrades, which you can only choose one of two, they generally fall into what feels like a more "dps" buff and a more "tank" buff.
The combination of little card text variation and few cards (there are not that many unlockable cards, either) make me worry that this game's replayability may suffer.
There's also a multiplayer battle which gives me anxiety (good thing), however doesn't seem like it affects your progress towards unlocking cards and classes.
Overall, though, I highly recommend.

title: Monster Train
review:
Fun for 2 hours and then you realise that the game is an unbalanced, overhyped bore-fest that appeals to casual gamers.

I paid $23 CDN and I noticed that the devs jacked up the price to $29 ( I guess because of the popularity + Steam summer sale is coming up in a week ). This is a $10-$15 game at best.

There are 5 different colour decks ( most are locked ). You have to grind with a red-green deck to unlock a third colour deck ( purple). Out of those three colours, you can only effectively tank with one of them, which leaves the other two colours as support. Since the bosses have hundreds or thousands of hit points, your build is *extremely* limited.

The Roguelike aspects relate to you praying to RNGesus for a decent starting hand, overpowered trinkets or key card draws.

When I lose, I roll my eyes. When I win, it's mostly dumb luck or powerful trinkets; a lot of the time, I don't feel like I accomplished the win through my skill. Wins consist of the same rehashed strategy from the last run.

Part of the game's unbalance revolves around you grinding for hours, for card unlocks ( the other part is poor boss design and a lack of synergy between colours ). If you don't want to grind then you are SOL?

This game has nothing at all to do with Slay the Spire! ZERO!

Although the production value is high, this game has the strategic depth of a cell phone game. Shame on all these positive reviews!

It's very good.

I see a lot of (right) comparisons to Slay the Spire. Having over 600 hours in STS I don't think this game has the same depth or longevity. In particular, there is much less variety in enemies and every run feels very similar from an enemy perspective. It is definitely worth a buy though if you like card games and/or tower defence games..

title: Monster Train
review:
Slay the Spire is nothing short of a damn good game. I've played it a lot and I highly recommend it. From its Roguelike elements to its random events to the cards themselves and the very lore of the spire itself that your character is trapped within...

The game is just phenomenal. Many games since have tried to emulate and mimic Slay the Spire as it seemingly has set the bar to a new level within the Deck-building Rogue-Like genre that is so sensationally high that I never thought it would be possible to raise it further.

Until now.

Monster Train has many elements from Slay the Spire which is why you see so many comparisons and correlations to it. However Monster Train's unique take on the genre from its own very rich lore and incredible visuals to the cards and bosses you run into is just a blast to play. From the "professionals" (masochists?) that play the game on an incredibly high level at the highest difficulty to someone who has never before experienced the genre, Monster Train is truly an amazing game to play right from the beginning. The amount of possibilities that lie within its system of "take one clan as your primary clan and another as an ally" and all the various abilities and combinations that follow allow for a truly deep level of complexity yet introduces the player slowly and subtly enough that it never really feels overwhelming to learn.

The upgrade system seems better overall though a bit more RNG heavy than Slay the Spire. The difficulty can scale to truly masochistic levels so if you're someone who enjoys a challenge this game has that too.

Its biggest faults are that sometimes you just aren't offered what you need to win the run. And while that feels bad, it isn't so disappointing that it angers me. I usually just say something to myself along the lines of "Guess I'll see where the next deck takes me."

And that's the greatest thing about this game. Seeing what heights you can take your deck to soar at... or plummet below the gates of Hell itself.

Welcome to Monster Train! - the game where Hell itself has already been frozen over and your job is to reignite what's left of the Pyre at the center of the nine layers of Hell. Don't let the Angelic forces stop you though - they're here to snuff out what little hope remains. Will you succeed in reigniting the very Pyre of Hell? Or will Hell remain a frozen wasteland for all eternity? Only you can decide.

title: Monster Train
review:
The obvious statement to make here is that if you find Slay the Spire fun, then there is a good chance you'll enjoy Monster Train. At it's most basic you could describe it as Slay the Spire meets Magic the Gathering. 

However, MT has put in a lot of effort into innovating and changing up the mechanics and various processes to make it feel solidly unique. Even a lot of the common features are tweaked in some way to present a different kind of challenge. Difficulty wise, I find it slightly easier than Slay the Spire, but that's because I think MT is balanced in such a way that you have an easier time creating a viable deck without having to rely on RNG for a certain rare card or item to define the deck like Slay the Spire. It's less about "letting the game decide what build your going to work towards" and more on incorporating the various choices into your run. That said, there are a couple "build defining" items that do end up changing things like StS.

I bought the game blind after hearing that it was pretty similar to Slay the Spire, and I feel like it was well worth the price for the amount of entertainment I've already gotten out of it. If I had to have a complaint, it's that it could use a bit more of an expansion in terms of maybe more train track options, events for the various stops, etc. Regardless, the base game is 100% solid, it's a complete game right now. I don't think anyone who is interested in these types of games is going to regret even a full cost purchase, which on steam is a pretty strong compliment in my book.

title: Monster Train
review:
Awesome Slay The Spire-like deckbuilding roguelike, but instead of building a deck for your single hero, you're building a deck of hellspawn to fill the layers of your demon train. 

I'm just a few hours in and the game is satisfying and rewarding as hell (no pun intended.) Watching the synergies of your different monsters and spells activate each turn against those of your enemies is super exciting, and of course that feeling we all know well of stumbling upon that one awesome card that fits your build perfectly.

It's a bit easy at first (at least if you've experienced similar games) but still has a chance to rip that sense of security out from under you. Plus, I can't really complain about an easy win on the lowest difficulty since I had plenty of fun with it either way. I'm excited to play with the increased difficulty after unlocking it in my first victory run, and to unlock more of the clans to play with their different mechanics.

I would recommend this game to people who liked Slay the Spire and people who thought Slay the Spire was too random. No more do you have to spend hours chasing the high of getting that armor or poison build going.

title: Monster Train
review:
What would you get if you combine Slay the Spire gameplay with unbalanced gameplay? A game that is more fun apparently. Great addition to the card-game roguelike genre. You are constantly unlocking new things, or 'mastering' old things. There are 5 different classes which all feature distinct gameplay and their combinations really up the replayability by a ton.

The graphics are a bit of a mixed bag. The monster designs are unique and interesting, although they feel like initial drafts and could definitely use a more experienced artist to really polish them up. The splash screen and advertising graphics are straight up ugly. The sound design is okay, the songs are good - but some of the sounds the mobs make (and you'll hear them a lot) are a bit too much.

Overall though this is a great game, easily worth it's admission price. I hope they release more classes in the future, but as it is now I can highly recommend the game.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train has a ton of personality, a great soundtrack, a vibrant art style, fun combat and endless deck building possibilities. The diversity in strategy is a lot of fun to mess around with and the unpredictability of events and loot make each run feel unique in its own way. You are often times faced with difficult and meaningful choices that can really make or break the success of your run and I really appreciate having to make those choices so often in every run I do. I hope we get to see more clans added in the future to keep the game feeling fresh and expand the roster of potential clan combinations. 

The multiplayer seems like it needs the most work. I like the idea of racing other players in a run but I also feel like putting players on a timer kind of defeats a lot of the fun and purpose, at least for me. My choices feel less meaningful when I have to race against the clock. I don't get to plan as efficiently as I normally would but I can also see how that is part of the draw to a mode like this. I'm not quite sure what my ideal multiplayer mode would be but maybe it can be some sort of co-op where you and a friend get to both participate in a run and develop a strategy together. Or maybe you use the idea of competing vs. other players like in the current multiplayer mode but instead have players battle each other rather than racing against the clock. It could be similar to something like Auto Chess where players battle each other with their current decks and then have the upgrade rounds like in a regular single player run. 

Either way, the game as a whole is great and has a lot of potential to keep on expanding and progressing with future updates. I think they can take multiplayer in so many different directions and I'll be eagerly awaiting to see what they come up with. If you like card games mixed with rougelike and tower defense mechanics, then you'll love this game. Each region feels unique and brings their own bag of fun and interesting tricks to the table. It's not surprising to see the overall rating be so positive as the game does deserve a lot of praise and I'm extremely excited for where this game can go and what it can become!

And yeah, look at my hours. That says a lot too.

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1] TLDR: If you like Slay the Spire, buy Monster Train.[/h1] 

Monster Train is the best deckbuilding roguelike I've played, after Slay the Spire. The gameplay is a fusion of "summoning followers" style card games (MtG, Hearthstone), deckbuilding roguelikes (StS), and tower defense Games. 


[h1] PROS:[/h1] 
[*] [b]A lot of combinations.[/b] There's 5 classes, and in each run you have one as the main and one as the sub. So there's 20 different combination of ways to play with each classes' unique and interesting mechanics. After almost 10 hours, I haven't even tried the last class yet, as there is so many combinations to explore. 

[*] [b]Much less "grindy" combat.[/b] In StS, some of the beginning rounds can be absolutely boring to play. Monster Train solves this by having every fight have a boss at the end, and reducing the amount of fights needed to win.

[*] [b]The UI.[/b] Everything is clear, everything can be learned from the UI. You don't even need to do maths, the UI does it for you. One of the best game UIs I have ever seen.

[/list]

[h1] CONS:[/h1] 
 [*] [b]Balancing issues.[/b] Due to the insane amount of combinations, this was to be expected. The game is still new as of the time I'm writing this, so maybe the devs would work on the balancing. Holdover, Multistrike are two of the upgrades I find absolutely broken. One of the most broken card imo  is "Unleash the Wildwood", a 0 cost green card that heals everyone to full. At the first glance, I assumed it consumed the card. 

[*] [b]Weird Difficulty Curve.[/b] Imo, the early game is more difficult than the late game. Most of the time when you reach the Seraph (final boss), your deck is strong enough to beat him easily. However, in the earlier battles, you sometimes take so much damage in the first few battles, and it usually is completely out of one's control. Due to summoned creatures not recycled into the discard, some games, especially in the early game, can be over when your champion dies. 

[*] [b] Randomness affects runs too much.[/b] Compared to StS, there are much fewer chances to add cards into the deck, so the likelihood of the run getting ruined by bad rng is higher. Starting from Covenant 1 (this game's version of Ascension), you get random cards added to the deck at the start of runs. That can ruin the run, or make it really easy. Also some events are busted, like the make 5 duplicates of a card event. 

[*] [b]The sound[/b] It can be really annoying for the boss fights. Maybe add an instant end effect.

[/list]

Despite its flaws, Monster Train is still an amazing game, and I believe it would keep improving. At of time of this review, I have been playing at the difficulty of Covenant 1/2, so my opinions are based on that.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you loved Slay the Spire, get this game.

(Minor spoilers, first 15 minutes of the game type of stuff). Where Slay the Spire mostly focuses on "spell" type cards that have a single action, Monster Train mostly focuses on minion combat. Instead of clearing a set of minions to move on, minions climb up your train and you need to set up minions to fight them and not let them overrun your train.

It has a more expansive Hero selection, with 5 separate heroes that truly feel different, and you select a Major + a Minor hero for a run. So there are 25 unique hero combinations.

The game does lack when it comes to bosses to fight, they all kind of blend together and don't feel very different. There also aren't very many, so you discover all of them after only a few runs.

title: Monster Train
review:
I wish Steam had a middle option. I kind of like the game and many of the problems I have with it are very subjective so I give it a thumps up but I feel it doesn't really deserve the praise and overwhelming positive reception.
There's already a lot said about the positive points of this game: A lot of content, polished presentation, good music and smooth gameplay, toolbox tips are appropriate and cleverly placed, etc. etc.
But speaking about representation, what I miss is more personality. Everything looks so clean and unimaginative. Something like Slay the Spire had enemies that looked like some kid's drawing but that's what made them memorable and fun. And the tower defense nature of Monster Train doesn't help making any enemy type stand out. In fact, I can't remember how a single unit looked or sounded even after 20 hours of playing. But I will always remember SNEK from slay the spire.
The second point I didn't really like with this game is balance. In my first 5 runs or so I won 4 times with insanely imbalanced decks. Granted, because of my experience with other deck building games I was at an advantage, but it still felt way too easy. And yes, I understand that the higher covenant levels is where the game gets hard but it's still a strange concept to have you beat the game so easily and repeat the same thing making it difficult. That's also contra intuitive for the unlocking of new cards. As usually that would mean more combos and interesting stuff but here it's more like, oh well now it's harder to do one of the 2 or 3 possible combos the class has.
In short, the game is good and if you like deckbuilding games it's a lot of fun, but I prefer Slay the Spire to this game. Maybe I'm just not into this turret defense like game mechanic.

Hell yeah. Ironically, this game is God-tier good. Slay the Spire-esque but with a great addition of the 'Tower-defence' format too. It's got quite a difficulty curve but just keep trying and you'll get there, you can usually see why you lost and it never feels particularly unfair. 

After playing all the current possible clan combinations I can safely say they all feel completely different to play and require their own mastering.

If you like card games and value for money, for the love of Hell buy this game. 

Ps. If you're struggling at first, try putting units on the first floor down rather than zerg rushing everything bottom floor, can work wonders.

title: Monster Train
review:
[strike] Gameplay is good. Price seems good.[/strike] 

But I can't recommend it because the visual style is just too damn lousy. Generic, full of meaningless detail that leads to no coherent picture, lacking in personality but offering a profusion of fantasy tropes that go nowhere. You've seen this in a hundred games and other media, and not once did it make sense, look good, or help readability.

Getting an artist to come up with something that's unique, aesthetically pleasant and readable is difficult. I won't expect it. So could I just have all the visuals replaced with geometric shapes and text, please? That would turn this around.

Also, we're on the wrong side here! You're supposed to kill the demons, not help them!  hasn't DOOM taught you anything?

-------------------------

Edit: After some more time spent on it - no. I'd rather play more Slay the Spire, which has far tighter gameplay while offering far more interesting setting and presentation.

title: Monster Train
review:
UPDATE: Yes it gets a lot harder. Although RNG can be a bit cruel and some combos are definitely much better than others.

If you are a veteran of this sort of thing, the game starts out fairly easy. I lost my first game, and have won 2, 3, and am doing well on 4. The gameplay is quite interesting, however, and there's a lot of moving parts. The fact it will reach up to 25  Covenant means I will eventually have trouble, but my hope is that this is not due to unfairness! Time will tell. If you like Slay the Spire, this is similar, although some things are a bit less potentially OP. (You can't seem to re-shuffle and re-draw your deck forever, I made an infinite card draw engine but sadly it didn't work outside the entire deck once per round) I plan to keep exploring it, but am hoping it won't take too long to get properly challenged!

title: Monster Train
review:
I always liked the idea of Slay the Spire but never bought it. I felt the art direction looked a little uninspired and the classic style of guy vs monsters with basic fantasy cards just wasn't doing it for me at the time. I'm sure I would have liked the game but it wasn't enough to draw me in. 

Monster Train smashed through that barrier going 100 mph with demons and melted wax spraying off the sides. Some really unique characters and gameplay choices on top of deckbuilding makes it what I was looking for.  

There's lots of ways to mix up your play style among the cool classes. Some champions are good on the first floor like Stygian with spell weakness sweep. Some are good on the top like Umbra with trample to clean up the mess. Some are good in the middle like the Hellhorn(born?) with slay, that activate on kills so you want to buff it up with weakened units from the first floor. Adding the floor mechanics and unique synergies makes each run feel different and a lot of fun.

I feel some cards are bit stronger than others and after playing for a while I can see that there is room for some more boss/trial variability but the game is super fun and I can't reccommend it enough.

title: Monster Train
review:
The only things I could think to want from this game are: Workshop support, private multiplayer lobbies, PvP where one side has a heaven side deck, more factions/bosses/enemies to fight (more varied fights across different runs), and a longer run with more stages (either by default, or an extended mode). Workshop and longer runs are my top two right now, but I'm sure more varied runs will rise heavily the more I play.

But notice how all of these things are basically just MORE Monster Train.

I was HARDCORE HOOKED on Slay the Spire, and that's the most obvious comparison here -some godly mix of Hearthstone and Slay the Spire with a dash of Darkest Dungeon- but this game has a secret ace to play. Power levels. Like DBZ style. Let me explain.....

 Upgrades aren't small, rather they take 1 damage 1 health cards to 11 damage 11 health, or let your big damage heavy hitter get to attack a second time per turn. This means every run is more about thinking of a synergy, and what cards to make OP, and how to use the less heavy hitting ones you haven't put upgrades into. Now, I'm sure this seems like just upgrade strong cards do high damage at first blush, so let me talk about a lower damage card for a bit. (Also for scale, an example of a stronger card is a beast that can be upgraded in a way that it does 50 damage per turn and has 75 health).

Those 1 damage 1 health cards? Imps. They do almost no damage, but give buffs when you initially play their card, you can sacrifice them with some spell cards in exchange for powerful effects, and they take the minimum possible space on a lane. So do you use them to buff other creatures and sacrifice them to cast powerful spells, or do you buff them all and fill a lane with a bunch of attack instances to deal with shields? Or do you instead leave one on each lane and use spells and artifacts to reuse their summon effect? Do you use fireballs on the enemies to clear out the weaker backline enemies, or do you use them on your imps after they use their summon effect to clear the lane for more space? Do you combine upgrade imps not for more damage and health, but for zero mana cast? Do you combine that with a deck that lets you draw lots of cards every turn? Or do you focus on just imps that give you energy when they're summoned as a way to farm mana for big creatures, and then clear them out with sacrifice cards that let you draw MORE cards AND give you mana? ORRRR, do you completely ignore all of that and instead make them take up more space but do damage in the 20-30 range and instead expand your lane size to use 3 of them, so you have mid damage/health units that also have the advantage of buffs on play AND you can use occasional spell cards with them for maximum balance and maximum flexibility? And this is just all synergies with one type of card. Did I mention I only have 3 hours on this game, didn't use imps almost at all, and still could pick up on these possible ways to use them? Now that's some good game design right there.

All of those synergies have different levels of upgrade investment needed into the imp cards themselves, vs other cards you have, so some runs you might hyper focus on them, and others you might upgrade a lot of things just a little, or specialize heavily in just a few types of cards. The number of viable ways to invest in your deck is a little staggering for how intuitive it is.

This all adds up to give that power level feeling I was talking about; between every battle you will drastically increase what your units can do and how you can use them. Notice I didnt say drastically increase health or damage, because while that's pretty universally true, that's not what makes this special. What DOES make it special, is realizing that when your plant monster unit goes from 3dmg 3 times to 23 dmg 3 times, they're now useful for not only breaking shields and bleeding damage through a small enemy, they're also now good for dealing with larger health single enemies, AND dealing with long lines of small enemies above 5hp (5 is very common for small enemies). This means they not only do more damage per turn, but are far more flexible in how you can use them to deal with the unique threat posed by your current enemy's traits.

So, how do they balance against these massive increases if you're not scaling enemy health up by nearly as much? Well, they throw more things to deal with at you. It's brilliant. Seriously, like I'm a little envious of the execution and I don't even make games brilliant. You have more synergies you can make on the fly, and more raw damage to take out enemies, so they give you more enemies which poses different modifiers, and on different lanes at once, and with shields, and armor, and bombs, and debuff casters, and etc. You're constantly given these little puzzles to deal with, expanding in number and threat, but also more tools to deal with them.

So why does this feel like DBZ power levels? Because every single time you upgrade something between fights you can think of off the top of your head how many problems that unit or spell can now solve for you. You feel more capable. 1 damage to a 1 health enemy feels the same as 10 damage to a 10 health enemy after big number syndrome wears off, but being able to kill 3 enemies of a bigger weight class than before, while enemies begin giving you debuffs on death, that feels like getting stronger and taking a threat of a different scale from before.

My only real concern, is if they do end up extending runs, how they'll manage dealing with scaling considering it is designed in such a deliberate and careful way. But honestly, considering how clever this design is, and how smart all the shop upgrades are, and how clever and original a lot of the artifacts effects are, I'm nearly positive they can handle it.

TL;DR It's been a very long time since I've been so impressed by a game's design. If you like Hearthstone, Darkest Dungeon, and Slay the Spire, or even JUST Slay the Spire, I really highly recommend this game to you.

Final note, at the time of writing I only have 3 hours in the game, but I have beaten a run. So it may get too repetitive or reveal itself to be a little too easy with more time, but honestly if those do turn out to be its sins I'd still consider it worth a buy.

title: Monster Train
review:
A great deck building game. Very happy for what I paid.

I think my fav mechanic is using 2 factions (primary/secondary) to start your deck & define your champion (is from primary faction). so you have 20 deck types to start with & grow over 8 fights. So it doesn't get too long, I often find I want one or 2 more fights in a run, so I'm finding it has great "one more" valure to me.  It has a very involved tracking/upgrade list so if you like unlocking or getting gold in a number of categories  it should keep you going for a while.

The battles themselves happen over 3 floors on the way to your heart room. 1 have 1 round of fighting then the monsters move up a level, but your defenders stay on their level and face the next invaders.  Each round by default the the attackers go first, and then each of your defenders. Ss you dig into the game there are way to modify not just your units or thiers, but how the fight happens or where.

I hope others have a great time with this game too.

title: Monster Train
review:
After playing this game for about 70 hours now, I can confidently say that it is one of the best, if not the best deck building rogue-lite game out there. 

Monster train combines elements of rogue-lites, deck builders and tower defence game and serves it in a intricately woven package of pure strategic fun. 

This game will pull you in and keep you engaged through its variety of class combos and enemy variations. You will have to learn to adapt to the run every time, since the bosses have unique mechanics that can counter your decks needing you to build your decks around them.

The progression in this game feels awesome, from the gold card collecting from beating the game on high difficulty levels to the subtle unlocking of powerful cards which open up whole new deck archetypes with each level up. Having played a significant amount of this game however, I have discovered all the combos it has to offer. But the journey of that discovery was well paced and enjoyable.

Overall, I would recommend this game whether you like the genres it embeds or not. It truly is a one of a kind game in this age or one rip-off after another.

title: Monster Train
review:
It's a very good game! I was hesitant at first, because my first impression was that this game was a silly cheap spire knockoff which had that cheap mobile game vibe. But the more I played it, the more I started to realize that this game has a lot of depth to it, you can do a lot of interesting combos and synergies, and there is a real incentive to calculate lines very deep, because even a small decision can lead to a very big impact. I actually enjoy calculating lines more in this game than spire, because there are so many cool synergies and different factors to consider. Although some people might not like that you have to do a lot of arithmetic involving two-digit and three-digit numbers in this game, I would say it's easier to calculate in this game than in spire, since you don't have to worry about rounding up or down (no percentage buffs/debuffs). 

Also, the monsters are very cute! 

I'd recommend this game to pretty much anyone. I'm about 100 hours in and have cleared the highest ascension level, but it never ceases to amaze me how many different ways there are to win. In spire, there are only a few ways to win, and pretty much every game you play, you win in the same ways...get a bunch of strength, poison, frosts, whatever. In monster train there are so many different ways you can create synergies and win the game, and so many times I was surprised that I was able to pull off a victory using a weird strategy that I hadn't thought of, when my main strategy failed. It's a very cool game and you really have a lot of freedom to experiment with various cards in creative ways. I would actually say this game is way more interesting than spire, from a creativity aspect. And I have run out of things to say so I will end this review here. You won't regret picking up this game!!!

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
Perhaps the most engaging deck builder to date, Monster Train translates the typical tenets of a card game into a battle for the very fate of Hell itself.  Summon your monsters onto the three decks of the titular train of monsters, watch them as they battle off rogue angels.  Utilize spells to assist your demons, devils and creatures to hold back the onslaught of the heavenly host.  Take advantage of special cards that can move you or the enemies minions from one floor to another.

Monster Train is truly one of the most engaging card games, both mechanically and visually.  Forgoing the minimalist graphics of its predecessors for fully realized versions of every creature card, it truly brings the genre into a direction that I hope all developers creating deck builders in the future see as a benchmark and a standard for their genre.

There are 5 different factions with their own mechanics and you choose 2 each run, giving plenty different gameplay options and variety. Basic runs are pretty simple, but there is a mechanic like Ascension in StS that ramps up the difficulty significantly.
All in all, a very good Slay the Spire like.

review:
If you even remotely enjoyed Slay the Spire, you'll love this. Lots of similarities, but lots of differences and it's great in its own right, Hard to say which is "better," but if this gives me half the hours Slay the Spire did then it'll be worth every penny.

I only have 9 hours played and I'm at Covenant level 6, so it's challenging to compare difficulties between the two games. I'm certainly better at Slay the Spire because of all my experience doing A20 runs, so right now it certainly seems like this game is more challenging. I've only been doing random runs, and for the most part that's been very fun, though certain combos seem very difficult to synergize together. Namely red + purple. Red seems to be all about one shotting everything, but purple tends to focus on frostbite (poison equivalent) and slowly melting things. That said, I have 9 hours played, so what do I know.

Definitely worth the money though.

review:
This is the first roguelike deckbuilder inspired by Slay the Spire to really do it's own thing instead of just being a clone in my opinion. It does what it does well and it's far enough of a removed experience from StS that it's also very enjoyable. Personally I even like the game's combat system more than Spire's, even if the game as a whole feels a little easier and has a bit less depth. 

I was concerned about the longevity of the game at first but as I've unlocked clans and covenant (ascension) levels I'm pretty happy with the game. I doubt I'll get the hundreds of hours I poured into StS out of it, but I think that's going to be true of every deckbuilder that comes out after that masterpiece.

title: Monster Train
review:
Another roguelike deckbuilding game. But this time it plays like a tower defense: enemy units want to break the crystal at the top level of your train car, so you need to stop them with your own units and spells. Compared to Slay The Spire, this game gives you much more customization over your cards and a lot more choices to make; I especially like the "Trails" system where you make fights tougher to get better rewards.

With engaging gameplay and plenty of unlocks to be had, this is a good buy.

review:
Highly recommend. The fun mechanics, complex interplay between teams, and high amount of provided information make this easy to pick up and fun to explore. 

At the start, I didn't think that this would hold my attention as much as it has, but there are a huge number of interesting ways that the different teams can combo together. There's plenty of fun in the first three, but the last two really blow open the potential. 

Unique, bright style. The mechanics are clear with wonderfully transparent information for the player. Being able to do things like pick your order of operations through the intermediate zones helps the player feel like we have more agency and reduces frustration when things go awry.

title: Monster Train
review:
I bought the game about 5 days ago.
I have played it for 95 hours.

That's like ... many many hours each day.

Is it fun? Yeah!
Is it addictive? Yeah!
Is it totally similar in game type as Slay the Spire? Sure is!

I've just finished Covenant 25 (the highest difficulty level) for the first time and saw the credits roll - with an awesome soundtrack that made me fully watch the credits. Though I'm far from done playing it. Going by my experience with Slay the Spire, it has yet many many many more hours to offer before I grow bored of it.

If you enjoyed Slay the Spire, or if you think you'd enjoy a rogue-like deck building game - you'll quite likely be getting a lot of enjoyment out of this game.

I wholeheartedly recommend it.

(I'm not saying its perfect - there may be some balance issues, but there have already been patches and the devs keep working on it. But it sure does offer a lot of fun gameplay.)

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1]Pro(s):[/h1]
[list]
[*]Monster train card game rogue-like, with about a dozen different combinations [i](Which I recommend you experiment with, rather than look up online!)[/i] that will keep you playing for days on end. 
[*]It's easy to understand and learn, but awards knowledge of mechanics and forethought -- And even if everything doesn't go quite as planned [i](And it won't, it's a rogue-like!)[/i] there's loads of happy little accidents.
[*]Card customization is insane! A word of caution tho - As you progress you may assume that certain monster upgrades will still be available to you when you visit a Steel Merchant. [b]You assume wrong![/b] No spikes for your Umbra/Remnant builds unless you somehow acquire an Awaken card that applies them. [/list]


[h1]Cons(s):[/h1]
[list]
[*] The two starting decks probably won't be up to everyone's tastes. I personally quite dislike Awaken playstyle, and it takes a bit to get to Remnant [i](My favorite!)[/i] and Umbra. If this is the case for you, just remember this: Hellhorned Rage & Armor build. Keep your hero alive, and as tempting as Multistrike may seem, avoid it for Rage/Armor. You'll live longer and can rack up to 400+ DMG per hit if you stack your shit right and proper. Could probably go higher but most bosses keel over after a few hits like these. 
[*] Some build elements are just that, elements. Not enough to amount to a build, but enough to recognize that an attempt is made - Prime examples being Train Conductors and to lesser degree Spikes and Stings [i](Is that what those are called...?)[/i].[/list]

title: Monster Train
review: Basically Slay the Spire made sweet love to a train, and Monster Train was born. From the 'artefacts' to the ascending (or descending in Monster Trains case) gameplay mechanics, and the obvious deck-building aspect, it screams STS, but to me fairer in difficulty, and very well balanced in the card game they have created here. I can easily see myself putting tens of hours into this game, and even more with continued updates, its that addicting and fun. Highly recommended for anyone who likes deck-builders and the many mechanics in STS, with or without a discount.

title: Monster Train
review:
Like everyone else I would easily compare this to slay the spire. It's obvious that the devs looked at that game, saw what it did well, and decided to do their own version of it. I can't fault them for that, it's a really good thing! The game is fairly easy to get into and has a lot of content, especially for the price. There are lots of interesting combinations you can do with the cards and factions which give it a lot of replayability. 

I think I would have liked a couple more factions to give the game even more depth, and some variation in the enemies other than just modifiers would have made each run feel more fresh and exciting, but as it is I definitely recommend the game and I hope that the devs release more content to give the game even more depth than it already has!

title: Monster Train
review:
So overall I'm positive on this game - if anyone has played strategy card games (Slayer of the Spire is a popular one) then you'll probably like this game.  First, a bit of my own experience... I think I've played almost every version of strategy card game out there (a few of my favorites include StS, Meteorfall, Dream Quest, Guild of Dungeoneers).  Heck, I even used to play the grandfather of these games, "Magic, the Gathering".
So here goes:
Building crazy combos - that's what this game is built to do (you either build something so crazy that nothing can handle it, or you die... seems like there's not a lot of middle ground in this game because of how enemies scale)
Build variability (IE how many different combos actually work?) - I don't know yet... there's a total of 5 different factions that can technically be combined 20 ways, but in actuality it will play more like 12.5 (Example: Awoken/Hellhorn will play almost exactly like Hellhorn/Awoken, but with a different special unit).  Out of these variables I assume that each will have at least one effective combo you can build.

Play variability - right now this is the only real downside to the game.  You fight pretty much the same monsters... every run.  Do they have slightly different abilities?  Sure, but slight enough that you can virtually ignore them and they'll have very little impact.  Can you scale them harder?  Yes you can - the game scales effectively using a difficulty modifier similar to StS.  However harder monsters don't really impact the feel of the game.   All of the upgrades feel the same... they enable slightly different combos, but there really isn't THAT much variability in unit and spell upgrades.

TLDR: 
The great - Deck variability and combo generation
The good - graphics and story
The mediocre - playthrough variability w/monsters and similar rewards
If this game never adds some combination of new monsters, new upgrades, or new train routes I'll probably lose interest and move on.  It will be a game with great mechanics, but not enough fight variability to matter.  If they add a bit of playthrough variability this could beat out Slay the Spire.  Still I've played for ~10 real hours so feel like I got my money's worth either way.

title: Monster Train
review:
I don't usually write reviews but I'm only 5 hours in and feel that this game deserves all the praise it can get. To get it out of the way, Monster Train definitely took a lot of ideas from Slay the Spire. That's how all creative processes work though. That's why "Doom-clones" are now referred to as FPS games. 

It's impossible to not make the comparison to Slay the Spire, but that's also what I like so much about this game. While Monster Train does borrow a lot from StS, it puts a significant spin on the StS mechanics to the point where it's definitely it's own thing and I would argue that it's better than StS. Of course a lot of this is subjective, but here's are some things that I think Monster Train does better than StS:

- Presentation: The overall presentation, including the music, graphics, animation. It just feels much more lively than StS. Even things like the hit animations having the characters actually move toward each other makes each turn feel more impactful. And it ever grows old for you, there is an easy-to-access "Speed" button where you can fast-forward through the animations.

- Gameplay: One of the biggest differences, and probably the most subjective opinion, is that MT makes you feel more powerful than StS. By the end of StS if you get the right cards you're going to be a powerhouse, but unless you get super unlucky or play really poorly you're all but guaranteed to become a powerhouse in MT by even mid-game. When buffs are things like "+25 damage" and you buff a card that previously had 1 dmg, it massively shifts the importance of that card. You also realize that 25 damage isn't a ton in the later levels, but those buffs just seem super impactful.

Speaking of buffs, the system in MT is much deeper than StS. In StS while you can upgrade each card, every card has it's own upgrade and only one upgrade. In MT you can purchase various spell or unit buffs and assign two (or more with the right artifact) to each card. Many times in StS, for example, I was hoping an upgrade would decrease cast cost by 1 but instead it added 2 damage. In MT you have much more flexibility in how to buff your cards.

The "4 floor" setup of MT inherently adds a layer of complexity that StS is lacking. Not only is it like there are three mini-games going on at once, but you quickly learn how powerful cards can that move units to different floors. You can use this to move a powerful unit to a floor that is otherwise full, or maybe you move that unit up a floor to be behind a tankier unit so they have time to do more damage.

Just having more than one unit on your side makes things feel a lot more active than StS. There is a lot more going on at one time in MT, but the amazing thing is that this added complexity only enhances the game. Even though I have more choices to make each turn, the choices are almost always fairly clear so this hasn't added a lot of extra confusion to the game.

In conclusion, I will revist StS again I'm sure but I've been having too much fun with MT to even consider it at the moment. If you like StS, you will very likely love Monster Train.

title: Monster Train
review: So as a guy who loved slay the spire but didn't hold my attention as long as I thought, this game is essentially a take on Slay the Spire that just has me completely addicted. So much replayability, the absolute joy and challenge of trying to master cards, the main bosses are a little repetetive but I'm hoping that more will be added as well as future free and D lc's. Absolutely beautiful artwork and the music is stunning. The multiplayer Hell Rush is absolutely brilliant, a time trial of up to 8 people where speed is key and not to win a run but to be last man standing, leaderboards where copying the seed for a run is as simple as a single click to copy it post run and the ability to create custom challenges as well. Cannot reccommend it enough, quite possibly my favourite game of all time and I desperately beg for more content in the future such as more clans, bosses cards and enemies.

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1]Pluses[/h1]
Almost 20 hours in so far, haven't gotten bored yet.  That's much more than many single player games for me usually.

I really enjoy two of the later unlocked factions, the umbra and the remnant, I wish more games could be this creative.   I really hope they add more factions to this game.

The game is pretty varied and interesting, but I'd probably max out around 100 hours.  Nice for a single player game, but I still feel like its missing some levels of variation to make it a game you sink hundreds/thousands of hours into.

[h1]Minuses-ish[/h1]
The music is good, but kinda depressing, and to hear over and over it gets kinda annoying. I get it, we're in hell, but it gets kinda old the 50th time.

I wish there were different run layouts.  You do the same boss fights every time, but the boss might have different buffs.  It would be interesting to unlock different paths with different bosses.  Maybe leading to different progression or item choices. 

The game is kinda easy for a veteran player of the genre.  Most of my runs end in success, but I'm only at rank 7 or so out of 25 so far.  This will probably balance out as I get higher in rank, but right now I think the game is slightly too easy.  Maybe the factions I play are too OP, idk.

title: Monster Train
review:
There's certainly room on this planet for Slay the Spire and Monster Train to co-exist.  I love both games, but I'm giving props to Monster Train for being a faster game to play and the fact that I won my first game after only 4 hours.  :D  But, maybe Slay the Spire trained me to be a better deck builder, idk.

I really enjoy the primary and support clan game mechanic.   You start with 2 clans and you can unlock up to 3 more.  The third gets unlocked pretty early, but is seems like the remaining clans may take some time.  Each clan has a champion that you start with and during each game you can periodically upgrade this card to add additional buffs.  After every battle, you have the choice to pick the left or right path to continue on to the next set of battles.  Each path lets you perform specific tasks like upgrading cards, restore health, etc.

Once you enter battle, you have 3 floors to defend.  Each round, heaven's "monsters" spawn at the bottom floor and work their way up to your pyre.  Each round, if a monster isn't killed, it moves up to the next floor (with a few exceptions).  Once the monster reaches your pyre on the fourth floor, it begins to damage the pyre.  The pyre can attack back, tho, and will make quick work of normal monsters.  Boss monsters, on the other hand, will usually wipe out the pyre.

At any rate, there's lots of cards, artifacts, etc. to unlock and I'm pretty sure I'll be playing this game for a long time.

title: Monster Train
review:
Other reviews seem to do a good job giving details about the game if that is what you are looking for so I won't droll on about that.  The big surprise enjoyment for me was the clan system; having a primary and an allying clan does a great job of promoting specific synergies and makes the 5 clans feel much closer to 20.

The big deterrent for me initially getting this game was that, for whatever reason, the artwork evoked sort of a "bad mobile gacha game" vibe for me. If you happen to find yourself in a similar situation and are undecided, I highly encourage you to pick up the game.  The actual gameplay more than makes up for it and the later clans that you unlock promote their own unique visuals.

title: Monster Train
review:
[b]Score is at the bottom of the review, while you are down there, leave a like if you liked this review![/b]

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37072886/]Great reviews can be found at our curator page:[b] Devils in the Detail[/b] Join our growing devil squad for more great reviews like this one![/url][/quote]

[h1]Overview[/h1] 
A  turn-based card game, roguelike, tower defense. This game has quite a few genres crammed into it, and it only takes the best parts of each of these genres. The game is then supported by 

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]
[h3] Gameplay 🎮[/h3]
 
[u]Clans & Clan Heroes[/u]
The fist screen that will greet any player at the beginning of a run is the clan selection screen. There are five clans in all but only two are available at the beginning so as to not overburden the player with mechanics. The rest are easy to unlock and can be done so just by playing the game. When on the screen, the player must pick two clans. The first clan is the main clan and provides their clan hero to the player’s deck. The supporting clan only supplies their cards. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2117099244
Every clan combination is viable and there is an award on the stats screen every time a clan combo win is achieved. Clan heroes are strong units that can be buffed three times throughout a run at special upgrade stations, but they are still mortal and must be protected as they provide a lot of power during combat.

[u]The simple part of combat[/u]
At the beginning of each turn, the player is given a certain amount of “Ember,” which is the resource that is used to play cards. Combat is both simple and yet complex. The player summons units onto one of three floors. Each creature or hero has an attack and a defense stat. These two parties fight one another by hitting each other and then the heroes go up a floor unless they are dead or are under the rooted debuff. It is for this reason that it is so important to have all three floors defended heavily. This is the game’s simplicity at its core. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2117096944

[u]The complexity of combat[/u]
Where things get crazy are the various unit abilities, spells, and bosses. Unit abilities are varied and often powerful. One such example is the ability “multistrike,” which allows a creature to attack more that once. This is great when it is combined with a creature that applies a stack of a status effect or if a creature has a really high attack power in general. There are many other unit abilities, and some are hero only, but they make damage calculation difficult at times if one had to do them manually. Thankfully, the game has a great quality of life feature where it shows the damage that will be dealt to a creature or hero and if it will be enough damage to cause it to die. It makes this roguelike quite a bit more accessible as it allows for some trial and error instead of pure min/max math outside of the game. Spells are crazy cards that also mix up the gameplay in a variety of ways. Some spells are simply damage against a certain enemy or the front enemy based upon the card’s description. Other cards can buff creatures, create debuffs, and even drop enemies down entire floors. Finally, bosses appear at the end of every battle, with the final battle occurring at level 8. The three main bosses have different abilities that are randomly chosen each run. It depletes the feeling of sameness that is a pitfall that some rougelikes fall into. Other bosses, that are more like mini-bosses, instead have risk and reward powers for their hero units. One such example is that the non-boss enemies may have 10 extra damage. The reward for completing this challenge can either be gold or a random artifact. These challenges are randomized as well per run. After every battle is the time to choose which cards to gain and how to spend the player’s hard-earned gold.

[u]Shops and track choice [/u]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2117097601
There are three shop types in this game. The first shop type is the unit buffing shop. Players are given the chance to spend gold to gain upgrade stones which can be socketed into any creature. Creatures start out with two sockets, but this can be upgraded with artifacts, and when all the sockets are used up, there isn’t any way to remove them. The same type of system occurs with spells, but they get different buffs for the most part. 

[u]Artifacts[/u]
Artifacts change up the game heavily and can change entire game mechanics. The demon horn, for example, makes it so that any Ember that isn’t used after a turn is saved for the next round. This would be perfect for a deck with mostly free cards, but also some high cost spells or creatures that will annihilate one’s enemies.

[u]Difficulty[/u]
Once all run combinations are completed, it is time to try for true mastery with the Covenant system. This allows players to fight tougher enemies, and the rewards is a nice golden border around the cards a player wins with; besides bragging rights as well.

[h3]📚 Story 📚[/h3]
The story is a bit simplistic, but still gives good context to the basis of the entire game. Hell’s fire has been extinguished and it is up to clans of Hell to form an uneasy alliance to return their homes to back to the way it used to be while simultaneously returning the balance of Heaven and Hell.

[h3]🎧 Sound 🎧[/h3]
Monster Train’s sound design is crisp and satisfying. The sound effects relay a sense of strength in each attack or spell used. The painful reactions of the player’s monsters and the enemy heroes also relay this power. The music relays the game’s theme of the bad games being good this time. The music has a choral and orchestral feeling, but in a haunting and corrupted manner. This reflects the corruption of power found in the heavenly beings.

[h3]📺 Graphics 📺 [/h3]
The graphics are two-point-five-dimensional. The creatures and heroes are two-dimensional in appearance, but they are on a three-dimensional background. The creature and card graphics use a computer-based hand-drawn graphical style that fits nicely against modeled backgrounds. Every card art is also animated with intricate detail.

[h3]⌨ Controls ⌨[/h3]
The game’s control scheme is simplistically brilliant. It is a drag and drop interface with only a few clickable buttons. This game could run perfectly with a touch screen if one has a Windows tablet. 

[h3]⚙ Performance ⚙[/h3]

This game runs so well and I never had any bugs or crashes. This game can also nearly run on a toaster due to its insanely low spec requirements.

[h3]💰 Price to Content Ratio 💰[/h3]
I have played this game for close to 18 hours now and I feel like I have barely scratched the surface. I recently unlocked the fifth clan, but I haven’t unlocked all of the cards for the first clan yet. Every unlock diversifies the game perfectly allowing for nearly limitless builds. There are also 26 difficulty levels that will keep any play busy for thousands of hours. This game is a steal for $25 dollars.

review: Fantastically done rogue-like deck building game! It looks great, feels great and very intuitive and play and pick up. The music deserves its own mention and is superb. It's an original twist, not just a Spire clone, and has much more depth for planning ahead and player agency. review:
It may look like a cheap Slay The SPire knock off, and while a lot of its mechanics are heavily "borrowed" from it, this game has surprising dept to it.

Smooth gameplay, has pretty polished mechanics as well as a nice soundtrack. 

Only remark would be that the balance feels a bit off sometimes. Some cards feel game breaking, some absolutely useless. But these things will get ironed out over time no doubt. 

Definitely worth its price and your time!

title: Monster Train
review:
Think of it very much like accelerated Slay The Spire.  You have some cards at the beginning, and the game only has about 8 "fights" total.  So you need to improve your deck to handle those harder fights very quickly.

Big plus?  It's much more friendly to casual players than Slay the Spire, as it feels like it has a less steep difficulty curve.  I personally very appreciate this.

Big minus?  I've played enough to know it's probably not balanced as well as Slay the Spire.  I don't mind this, but you should be aware.

title: Monster Train
review:
The Stuff I Like
-A great card game and one I'm absolutely addicted to! I'm a huge fan of build around strategies that break the game wide open. Such as when I got a bunch of Offering cards, while also having a 0 cost "discard your hand" holdover card. My favorite champion probably being the Stygian.
-The Lore. Something I'd love to see more of. An interesting universe built up that we know so little of. Each unique circle of hell having its own little flavor. The world giving you just enough of an idea about how the world works without giving too much away.

The Stuff I Want but Won't Really Mind if they Aren't Added
-Branching paths and new enemies. There are branching paths, but I want these paths to have new enemies as well. I like the idea of being able to choose what enemies you'll be fighting by branching paths. Picking enemies that you will have an advantage over, at the cost of getting a different reward that you may or may not want.
-Aesthetic options: Changing your champions look or the look of your train. I just like customization.

title: Monster Train
review: Haven't switched to a different game yet since acquisition. Tons of fun, quick play, easy to spot potential combo's. Loving the different classes and play styles, I actually really like the specials way better than the rather straight forward Hellhorned. Really feeling the urge to make some fan art of the favorites, but I just can't put the game down.

title: Monster Train
review:
Holy crow. I love this game more than is healthy. :)

It's fantastic, guys. Great visual design, great music, great sound design. The Largestone upgrade _actually makes the upgraded monster larger_. They THOUGHT about it and did the thing you'd think they would do.

The spell upgrades are good. The monster upgrades are good. Finding something and thinking "yeah, that would probably work really well if I got this and that on it"... you're probably right. It's sublimely well balanced. I have no complaints.

The lore and the nods to story and the aesthetic and the fact you're fighting to re-light a frozen over Hell... yeah. It all fits together so nicely and I love it to bits.

I look forward to any content patches, because if they're as good as the base game is right now, it's gonna be even more of a good thing.

I can't speak highly enough about it. Yes. If deckbuilding roguelikes are your thing, this will be your new favourite game. It certainly is mine.

title: Monster Train
review:
A fun take on STS, this game made an interesting design choice. Rather than have event rooms that may be bad and items that have drawbacks, everything is an upside, but the fights are generally harder and more complex in exchange. Selecting the correct upside is key here. It's not worse, it's not better, it's another take on the concept, and it's very well done.
Further, they added some of the feel of a tower defense game to combat, further mixing the genres.
The art and music are very polished and professional, if you like that sort of thing. Great game, great buy, I do recommend it.

title: Monster Train
review: If you liked Slay the Spire, this is just more of that but with more depth to it. I prefer it over StS and absolutely recommend this game at full price. Definitely worth your time. Deck building and level-up mechanics are really easy to grasp but also offer a lot of unique playstyles, even within the 25 different combinations of demon "clans" that you play as.

title: Monster Train
review:
Get it!  If any of the words in the description sound appealing, you'll love this game.  

Pros:
- Very fun and addicting gameplay
- Strategies can be simple or deceptively deep
- Challenging; winning typically feels like an accomplishment 
- Card balance is pretty good.  There are OP combos, but setting them up is far from guaranteed due to the roguelike nature of each run.  
- Unlocking cards and factions adds complexity and allows new strategies/combos (although the game may seem limited until those things are unlocked)

Cons:
- Needs more starting hero types or hero abilities
- Being a roguelike, the randomness can utterly destroy your deck in such a way that it feels personal ;)
