title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a Deck Building Rogue Lite, bearing some similarities to Slay the Spire and other Deck Builders. 

Aesthetically it is very pleasing with pretty visuals and impactful audio. The general plot is that you are a denizen of hell, taking the last remaining pyre to the frozen heart to reignite it. This pyre serves as the health points for your run (situated on the top floor of your 3 floor train), and should it be reduced to zero your run is over. Your run will last for 8 battles with overworld sequences separating these. 

You start the game by choosing a guild and a sub guild; these have their own cards and strategies which in most cases will compliment each other. To begin with you have access to two, eventually accumulating 5 with a handy option to randomise your choices for some extra challenge. Your primary guild also decides your champion, a 0 cost unit that can be upgraded to become a powerhouse. 

The game is broken into the overworld, where you choose your route between battles, and the battles themselves. The route splits offer run-duration upgrades for units and spells, regeneration for your pyre, artifacts, troop recruitment points and other more interesting points such as card duplication and removal. Some of these are immediately more useful than others, such as removing two vanilla troops or spells from your deck at a single stop. You make your initial choices of starting artifact and champion upgrade at the start of a run and then you're on to your first battle. 

You're treated to a splash screen which displays the enemies you will face, and importantly their Keywords. Keywords include such traits as incant (gains buffs when spells are cast on the same floor) and sweep (unit will apply its damage to all of your units on the floor when it attacks rather than just the frontal unit). The game will also offer you the chance to increase the challenge of the battle at this point, and offer rewards for doing so. These are on a per battle basis thankfully, as your composition may not always be suited for the challenge, for instance an attack heavy deck may not be well suited to take on an enemy force where each unit has damage reflecting thorns. 

The battles as previously mentioned take place across 3 floors, with a fourth floor being your pyre. Each room has a population capacity, with creatures having a size stat. Your job is to prevent enemies from ascending the train to the pyre by placing monsters strategically so that they combo with one another on the same floor. Typical card game mechanics apply here, such as draw amount and the energy reserves you use to cast each card, with cards having an energy cost typically ranging from 1-4 with some exceptions. 

With the knowledge that the enemy troops will generally attack yours first you must weigh up the outcome of the battle, and then intervene by dropping stronger creatures, killing enemies with harmful spells or healing and bolstering your own units' attributes. after each scuffle, surviving enemies will ascend a floor. Certain rules allow enemies to ascend faster, but if they make it to your pyre they will begin to damage it. 

Thankfully your pyre takes none of their nonsense and has a sweeping and very damaging attack it will use once they have finished their assault, but this is a last resort and to be avoided if possible. After several waves, the boss will spawn. 

Bosses will attack the same floor relentlessly rather than ascending after a single round of attack. This means that Your floors need to be strong enough to take a sustained assault while also dealing enough damage and debuffs to hinder the boss. Certain bosses will be present before they begin their climb, laying traps and augmenting their units before making their final approach which leads to some great and flavoursome battles. Should the boss kill all of your minions on a floor, they will seal the floor in ice and render it unusable for the remainder of the battle. 

Killing the boss will take you to the rewards screen, with points deducted for pyre damage taken and every floor the boss successfully ascended. You are then offered a selection of cards from each of your guilds which you can opt to take or, importantly, leave. 

The joy in the game comes from finding silly combos, finding that way to perpetually feed sacrificial creatures to your tank, increasing its power every turn or stacking hundreds of stacks of life draining frostbite onto an enemy. The guilds are varied and each is genuinely a joy to play as. Finding the synergy between each is a lot of fun, especially considering the vast amount of card and artifact unlocks that factor into this endeavour. Optional "Covenant" levels add self appointed penalties which make runs more challenging, ensuring a challenge no matter your level. 

I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who wants a game that is accessible but has a learning curve that is not afraid to punish poor synergistic choices. As an example, I had a unit that would bring a unit back from the dead every turn. I ended up with a perpetual cycle of him bringing a morsel, (a small sacrificial creature typically destined to be eaten at the end of the turn) back to life instead of a worthwhile creature simply by playing the cards in that order without thinking. Well worth the retail price point for the depth, and the love that has clearly gone into it.

title: Monster Train
review:
Put simply, this is the most fun I've had with a deck builder.  It has a looser design than something like Slay the Spire, but it has a much greater variety of possible builds as a result.  

The main single player mode has 20 possible combinations of primary and secondary clans, and there are 25 Covenant ranks to climb, each with higher and higher difficulty.  I am currently at Covenant 10 and I can see that it will take a lot more practice to progress further.

The Daily Challenge and Challenge modes have a selection of interesting and entertaining modifiers available, and I have enjoyed the few I have tackled so far.

Hell Rush, the multiplayer mode, is also very fun and a surprisingly fresh approach.  You are placed in a lobby with a handful of others and much work against strict time limits to clear each combat encounter with the same initial setup as your competitors.  If you die, you are dropped from the competition.  If you run out of time, the combat will auto-resolve from that point on, meaning you can play no more cards and must hope your units last on their own.  Succeed, and you will be competing for score with the remaining competitors.

Simply put, if you enjoy deck builders and roguelites, this is more than worth your money.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you loved Slay the Spire, you will love this. No doubt about it, game is great fun, has a good challenge and has a great soundtrack, art and animations are cool too! 

It doesn't have as many fights as Slay the spire, but mainly due to the fact that the battles in this game go on for much longer and have a round based system to it. There are a variety of options with different clans to mix and match each run with which is amazing, each offering their own unique buffs, pros and cons. You can see all the cards and features you have unlocked in a reward book too and gives you good incentive to keep replaying to unlock the rest. 

Multiplayer is basically: Challenge friends for high scores, a daily climb and custom challenge where you can create a template and send this to people to try and complete.

Amazing game, this might be the best Rougelite/like deckbuilder this year and since STS! 

In the future I would love to see some new clans, locations, enemy types, bosses and maybe some new game modes too! 


Highly Reccomend this

title: Monster Train
review:
Very good game that builds upon Slay the Spire's legacy. I was sceptical when I read it had elements of deck building and tower defense (though I do love both genres), but I was very impressed at how they combine the two. 

The biggest gripe would be balance and variety. At least one of the classes feels much more limited than the others (hellbourne), and often times there seems to be fairly limited routes to true success for each class. As well, the enemies scale a bit too fast vs your monsters for my liking.

That said, there is a lot of depth here and what's already here is worth the price -- especially if there's a good sale. 

For those that like Slay the Spire, this is kind of a no brainer. Definitely a step forward for that style of game, though not quite the masterpiece that Slay the Spire is. 

Graphics - Great
Sound Design - No comment as I usually listen to podcasts, but from the little I heard it seems to suit the game very well.
Gameplay - Good to great. Engaging gameplay loop, fun upgrades, but sometimes finding the optimal strategy can feel constraining. 
Quality of Life - Great. Everything you'd want in terms of a low spec graphics mode, speed options, easy to navigate menus, etc.

title: Monster Train
review: Absolutely amazing roguelike card-game akin to Slay the Spire that does enough different to really set it apart. I love the way the battlefield is set-up, as a vertical train that monsters climb up floor by floor until they reach a pyre you're supposed to be protecting. The floors really open up some interesting strategies in regards to where you want to place your units for maximum effectiveness. I love how there are five different unique clans with cards built into the game on launch, with you mixing two of these at the beginning of each run by choosing a primary and a secondary clan. Overall it just works really well and I can see myself putting many, MANY more hours into the game. Can't wait to see what the devs have in store re: updates and post-launch content as well!

title: Monster Train
review:
If you are reading this you have probably played Slay the Spire.  And you have probably played several other games which were rip-offs or derivatives of StS that just feel like worse versions of the game. 

 This is NOT one of those games.  

While the deckbuilding aspect is familiar and similar to StS, the developers have perfectly combined it with the Tower Defense genre, including Unit cards which can be placed on the board (train) 

What results is a familiar but unique experience which also has subtle strategic decisions such as positioning and floor management. 

I cannot recommend this game enough for any fan of strategy games, rogue-likes, or deckbuilders.  

10/10 best game I've played this year by far

title: Monster Train
review:
As a big fan of Slay the Spire that got everything I felt I could get out of that game, Monster Train has breathed new life into the concept. By adding more variety and randomness to the start of the run, it makes the early game less tedious. The roguelike system encourages defeat, but an interesting beginning helps to offset the sting of failure. Unlike Slay the Spire, your deck consists of a combination of two colors instead of one at a time, and even when you pick the same pair, the sheer number of cards and playstyles prevents your runs from feeling samey even when you try to make it that way.

You can expect the average Monster Train run to last about as long as your average Slay the Spire run. ~1-2 hours if you win. Slay the Spire's game loop involves a large number of short battles with a few boss fights, while Monster Train has eight main battles that each have their own boss, with three of them being big bosses that act as the equivalent of Slay the Spire's bosses. The big bosses are the same every time, but they can have different abilities that change how you fight them. In terms of the other enemies, you won't know what you're dealing with until you start the battle, so you'll have to adapt with the cards and artifacts you have to avoid the tide suddenly turning. This game is very good at making you feel invincible and suddenly sweeping the rug out from under you by throwing enemies at you that counter your build. 

If you're looking for replay value and difficulty, look no further. In addition to the crazy amount of card and artifact combinations you can have in a given run, there are 26 difficulty levels that keep pushing your abilities further, the equivalent of Slay the Spire's Ascension system.  The game has no easy mode, so make sure you're prepared to fail quite a bit as you learn the game. If you've got some experience with Slay the Spire, you should find many aspects about this game very familiar, but expect a moderate learning curve nonetheless. This game adds onto Slay the Spire's mechanics just as much as it copies them.

This game took everything I loved about slay the spire and created an amazingly streamlined game that doesn't waste your time. It gets rid of many "small" choices in favour of a few key ones. The developers somehow did this in a way that doesn't reduce the amount of strategy involved, but rather makes every battle feels important and every card decision change the way you play.

review: I just love this game.  Your constantly building your deck in preparation for future fights- and making strategic choices for the long-term survival of your clan. It is also highly tactical - in that your need to make the best of the cards you're dealt in each fight.  I also like the fact that every run earns you rewards so that you're better prepared for the next run. Even when you die - you immediately want to go again and think "I'll do better next time!". With the variety of clans and cards etc - there is ample replayability. In short - this games is lots of fun and I highly recommend it.

review:
Game's godlike.

If you like "Slay the Spire" you'll LOVE this game. I wouldn't say its better than the other, they're pretty diifferent games while feeling very similar to each other.

The Primary/Secondary clan combination makes the game very intriguing and can makes decks a lot of fun. Some combinations feel more powerful than others.

It's challenging (but not impossible) at first, but once you start realizing what works, you'll start pulling victories left-and-right.

That being said, I feel Stygian Guard is a bit TOO good. If I just stick to Stygian Guard cards I tend to wipe the floor with these guys.

I'm looking forward to expansions/DLC that would include new deck-types!

title: Monster Train
review:
Everybody and their mother has been making roguelite deckbuilders since Slay the Spire skillfully combined the two genres to massive success. This one is actually good.

Like Spire, it strikes a near perfect balance between randomness and predictability, which deck builders sometimes struggle with.  This provides consistent pacing across multiple runs with enough variety to keep things interesting. It also hits that sweet spot where runs aren't too short or too long, making it far too easy to start another game as soon as the last one ends. I didn't even notice the hours disappear my first go and accidentally forgot to go to bed. Dangerously crafted work of passion. Fans of the genre will thoroughly enjoy this.

title: Monster Train
review:
Very addictive, great fun! It's like Slay the Spire but (in my opinion) more fun because you build around multiple minions instead of deck building with only spells. There's more strategy involved since there are multiple levels and there's a lot of modifiers that I didn't recogniize from other deck building games so that was a nice surprise.

There are 5 factions to play the campaign with and each run (I've been playing the most manageable difficulties) takes about an hour as long as you get to the end or nearly to the end. Not all factions seem equally capable of making it, but that could also be that I need to adjust my playstyle more. You always play with a main faction and supporting faction and in my last run I noticed some great synergies (Umbra and Remnant; give it a try ;))

title: Monster Train
review:
Very similar to Slay the Spire but has a bit more depth to it. I enjoyed STS but never really got into doing multiple runs over and over, but in this game I can enjoy myself for hours! I feel like it's easy to get into but hard to master, and you can make it as hard for yourself as you want to (with additional rewards as a bonus). The deckbuilding is a lot of fun, especially when you get an amazing synergy between a few cards.

So I'd say, if you like the concept of STS but maybe never really got into it (like me) you will most likely enjoy this game. Or maybe you played a lot of STS and are looking for a new roguelike deckbuilder. Then this game is definently what you are looking for! It's worth the full price but if you are tight on money, I'd say get it during a sale. You won't regret buying this one!

I'm looking forward to what the future updates (and maybe DLC) will bring to this game!

My only gripe - which isnt really one - is that I can think of about 10 cool ideas that they should implement that would increase the depth of play.

A new classic in the rogue light deckbuilder.

title: Monster Train
review:
So long and sweet of it is this is a Slay the Spire clone with much more color and multiple units to choose from. 
The game has a rather nice soundtrack which is honestly wasted here because most people I imagine just listen to their own music while playing and this OST could have been paired with a game that has an actual story. 
 
        The aspect however that isn't getting enough attention I believe is...how there really is very little challenge/variety in bosses. I personally found the boss encounters bland and repetitive. I beat my first run after about 30 minutes into the game and was disappointed there wasn't an 'end boss' grind or something to at least aspire to. Perhaps there is something I'm missing but...if I can beat the game in under 30 minutes what incentive is there to keep playing? Ideally I could unlock all the units and spells but to me, at least, the thrill would be a foe too hard to beat. 

     Naturally you can increase the difficulty higher and higher but somehow this level of challenge feels artificial. Imagine playing baseball and always beating the minor league teams and you want to one day win a championship in a large arena with a crowd cheering but instead of facing new and complicated challenges you just fight the minor leagues over and over with sandbags on your ankles. Yes it is harder but it is a difficulty that is self-inflicted and therefor robs you of some of your agency. 

       All this aside I felt the music, animation and user interface to be top notch. If you enjoyed Slay the Spire and want more of the same kind of grind then give this a try. I'm personally finished as I feel like I've seen everything I've wanted to.

review:
The decision-making in this game is so dense! This isn't the kind of deck-builder where you cycle through your cards like a program; you have to make tough decisions every turn. It's difficult to understand what the optimal decision is in any situation because each run challenges too-narrow builds, and completing the logbook or gaining score demands different strategies.

Despite all that, it's not a dry game. There are wild combo opportunities every run. Many of my ~doomed~ runs have turned into wins midway through after refining my deck. It's an ideal deck-builder.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is excellent. It's like Slay the Spire, except you summon monsters (a bit like MTG or Hearthstone) and with some slight tower defence elements. It works really well; you can tell that this has been really well balanced, play tested and refined.

The game is simple to learn and difficult to master. Very satisfying and addictive to play. Animations, music, sound design and progression are on point. You can choose from five different decks/clans to play with, using various combinations to build your deck. There are various difficulty levels and each run feels very unique with the assorted bosses, enemies and modifiers. Definitely hundreds of hours of content right here, highly recommended.

title: Monster Train
review: Huge value on this one with the amount of variety and replayability. They clearly borrow heavily from Slay the Spire and other deck building games, but they have plenty of their own twists and offer a lot more player utility than I'm used to seeing out of these types of roguelikes. I particularly like the fact that you choose between two of five clans/colors to work with each run through. The difficulty is moderate at worst for the first time through and you can add increasing levels of drawbacks as you wish or don't to future attempts. Loads of unlockables along the way in addition to some interesting stat tracking just for kicks. Fairly intuitive to anyone who has played anything in the genre, but detailed enough to allow for many different viable paths towards victory. Each playthrough is quite reasonably lengthed at just over an hour, though you can stop with a saved game before each fight. I very, very highly recommend this one.

title: Monster Train
review:
hehe monster train go woooo

Favorably compared to Slay the Spire for being a similarly well-constructed deck building roguelike, but blended with a sort of Darkest Dungeon Lite flavor to the combat. Ramping difficulty is cool. Choosing a main and support race is really cool. Having a champion for each one is cool but I wish there were more than one for each race, though the choices in building them is arguably enough. Maybe one more choice of upgrade for each one? I've only seen 3 different ones at max.

Could use more enemy variety (mostly bosses, two runs and you've seen them all). Again, the variety is a little padded with modifiers, but another couple bosses would round it out nicely. Slightly longer runs would be nice too. But then, it may be that they just seem short because I'm enjoying it so much, as the runs tend to be around an hour long each. Still, it can feel like you're just getting the ball rolling on a build by the time you reach the final boss, or you may have duped 5 strong, multi-attacking, sweeping monsters with front-liners to tank for them within the first few lucky rounds. Such is the fickle will of the cards.

In any case, this is a great initial release, and scratches an itch I forgot I had.

Edit: I said nothing of the online features, of which this game packs 3: a daily run, a race run, and customized, submittable runs with mutators and predetermined race choices, which makes this pretty robust overall.

title: Monster Train
review:
Legitimately one of the best deckbuilder games ever made.  Each of the clans plays differently and combos differently with their allied clan.  Your runs are always unique and different from one another.  It's a mix of Slay the Spire and Hearthstone.  The game has some of the most unique card mechanics I've ever seen (burnout is amazing for the Melted Remnant).

You get a sense of progression as you play, unlocking new cards that combo with the stuff you've already been using, so you learn to play the clans organically.  Each of the bosses has its own mechanics, but they also have variants of those bosses (like a boss that drops a bomb on a floor that you have to kill or it explodes - sometimes the bomb will have a spellshield, sometimes the bomb will explode twice, etc).

If you're into Slay the Spire or Hearthstone (or similar games), buy this immediately.

title: Monster Train
review: slay the spire, but with more homies on ur side

title: Monster Train
review:
When you first start Monster Train you will notice that it bears a strong resemblance to my Game Of The Year winner last year Slay the Spire, but as you play you will notice that while it is very much a deckbuilding roguelite it does enough to distinguish itself from the Crowd by adding strong Tower Defence elements.

The main premise of the game sees you riding a train which is being hunted by Angels trying to extinguish your pyre which is the last remaining piece of hellfire in existence.

Much like in slay the Spire you play a series of fights but the difference here is that as opposed to controlling a single character you control a clan of Monsters and place units on different floors of your train much like Plants vs Zombies. as well as your units you also have access to spells and artefacts much in the same way. There is a good mix of different types of classes to play These include The hell horns which are an aggressive damaged Focus class, The awoken which generally consists of large creatures and healing abilities, The Stygian Guard which has weak Monsters that creates spell weakness to allow you to use Direct damage spells, The Umbra a fun to play interesting class where you create small Monsters called morsels that get eaten by your larger Monsters to buff them and finally The melting remnant an equally innovative class that uses strong units that died after a few turns that you have to resurrect in order to get the most value. what is key, however, is that as well as choosing your main class you can also choose an allied class that you can access the main pool of cards. this gives lots of different combinations and lots of different types of strategies that can be concocted throughout the game.

As you play through the main campaign you unlock artefacts upgrade units in much the same way as you would expect but the fresh design and changes really make this stand out as the first deck building Road light worth owning since Slay the Spire.

As well as the excellent single player mode there are also a number of Multiplayer modes such as timed battles daily challenges and the ability to make custom challenges that you can share online.

Monster Train could have been an easy cash to grab but as it stands monster train is one of the best games I have played so far in 2020 and is the game that has restored my faith in the Indie scene.

This review was originally posted as a written and video review on our website. Please check it out for more review

http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/videos/game-tutor-grades/200528_game-tutor-grades-monster-train

title: Monster Train
review: This is my first time playing a rogue like card game and I have to say that it is really good. As you progress, you unlock some things and the game gets a bit harder like more attack from the enemies or starting off with less health. The only thing I do not like is that I noticed the game chooses your build for you at the beginning because they give you three "random" cards at some point (when you get higher in covenants) and your starter has specific skills to choose from. There are different variations of combos but you definitely get forced to make the deck to work with it. You can't really just "play" if that makes sense so you have to learn combos and what works well together to get in the higher covenants. If you don't work around that build, then you pretty much get destroyed in the later rounds. Other than that, you get cool gold borders around the cards and 20 different variations of deck combos as there are 5 decks to choose from. I recommend it for newbies like me.

title: Monster Train
review:
Ok, obviously I'm in the minority, but I don't think that this can hold a candle to Slay the Spire, and it duplicates nearly everything that Slay the Spire does and in such fine detail that it's offensive. It's an interesting premise -- "what if you just made Slay the Spire but you can have more units?" -- but its execution of every element that was not just a straight up copy-paste is amateur in comparison to the masterclass of mechanics and theme that is Slay the Spire.

I would be embarrassed to have made this. And sure, ok, it'll do well, it'll get good reviews, because how can you go wrong copying StS? But it really doesn't do enough new for me to rate it by anything except what it did differently: not much, and not very well.

[h1] Short Review [/h1]
It is very fun and explosive. The first impression is really great when you're exploring the demon factions and see the numbers go up. Monster Train doesn't concern itself with OP builds and let's you go ham.

But it is not really the thinking man's game like Slay the Spire, or Hearthstone, or, which i thought it was similar in party building sense: Darkest Dungeon. It does not have the same depth, or synergies. 
Unlike Hearthstone, you hardly have any units you can reliably make use of, as you can't really hold onto your hand. 
It is also more difficult to build a deck as reliable as Slay the Spire, due to the train overworld where you have to choose between only two different combination of rewards. and also because you have to mix two demon classes. So you really have no idea what build you're going for, and you don't get stores or events to buy yourself the cards for them.
It also doesn't make use of movement and positioning like Hearthstone or Darkest Dungeon, even though it has the mechanics for it with an extra layer on it which is ascending and descending between wagons.

So as the difficulty goes up, i feel like it will be very difficult to make reliable strategies without the RNG screwing you. But the good part is, this game is still very fun without making 300 IQ plays. Additionally, this game has great ideas and a great foundation and i really hope the devs continue working on it.

title: Monster Train
review:
There have been a lot of good PvE deckbuilders recently but this is definitely the best one since Slay the Spire. (It might even be better than StS but the jury's still out on that.)

The 5 clans are all very unique in terms of gameplay and theme and the fact that you combine 2 of them in a game is just [i]chef's kiss[/i]. You also have a lot of opportunities to upgrade all cards in various ways, opening to quite a lot of different strategies.

While PvP is not necessary at all to enjoy this game, I'm a little disappointed with the Hell Rush mode. Because of the UI, I thought it would be some kind of auto-battler game mode and I was [b]down[/b] for it. It's definitely on my for having an unrealistic expectation.

Overall 10/10 for main game, probably nice for for PvP too but not really my thing.

title: Monster Train
review:
First off, the game works well and feels polished; it's better than almost all of the games in this niche, and has some really good ideas.  The surrounding stuff to the game is done really well.

My only complaint is that currently it feels like you're pushed towards very linear strategies.  Many of the mechanics feel parasitic, and it feels like you're rewarded for hyper-focusing your deck rather than taking a balanced/blended approach.  There's also a few artifacts/cards that feel overtuned (eg. the double-gorge relic) which results in some overly bland/easy runs.  So after 10 or so games (going up to covenant 3), I'm going to pause for now.  

I think it's possible to resolve the issues here with balance.  Even Slay the Spire had some problems like this in development.  And even if it doesn't improve, you're already getting what I think may be the 2nd best game in this genre.

title: Monster Train
review:
Beautiful and brilliant mechanics are found in this game and it is so much fun!  

While playing Slay the Spire I found it could be fun to play repeat games with slightly different choices.  Here there are great card collections, a much more compelling mechanics system, and you find winning strategies based on combinations, artifacts, units, spells, and choices to upgrade what you wish and trim the deck as you go.

Each clan as well is like playing a new game with Hellhorned, Awoken, Stygian Guard, Umbra, and Melting Remnant having different play styles which when aligned as a primary and secondary team give you tons of interesting strategies and capabilities you can plan and improve as you play further.

Love it!

title: Monster Train
review:
Thank you NL for bringing this game to my attention. 

If you enjoyed Slay the Spire, you owe it to yourself to get this. It builds upon the deck building genre in such an effective way through the use of it's floor mechanics and the importance of selecting the right units IN ADDITION to the right spell cards.

I implore you to explore the depths of this game yourself.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game takes the awesome Slay the Spire deckbuilding formula and somehow makes it even better. There's less fights, but they're longer and more tactical (mainly due to it being on three lanes). Less decisions of where to go on the map, but more important to decide well. Two separate upgrades on each card. It also has more starting combinations, as you pick a main and a secondary class.

All-in-all, an exceptional clean design and a super fun deckbuilder.

title: Monster Train
review: This game is sweet. As you are aware it's slay the spire with tower defense. Where slay the spire is about incremental strength gain over the course of 50 floors, gradually making decision after decision to improve your deck over time, this game is 8 floors of very complex decisions that demands you get as overpowered as possible. What I love about it is that runs are super quick, and the gameplay feels super snappy. While overall i find that I enjoy the overall experience of sts more, this game is just as good and has a very nice presentation with very intense visuals and soundtrack that really makes you feel the ferocity of the combat

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is flat oustanding.

Not many games suck me in these days quite like Monster Train has. I have been practically a full blown addict of the game since my first playthrough and there is ZERO indication of that ever slowing down.

The card and unit gameplay is deep and rich and rewarding and has SO many ways to try the game and balances between the races it's just incredible. I have almost never once discovered something I found to be blatently imbalanced either in the realm of being too powerful or too weak, which is somewhat incredible. It's very hard to balance a card game and they really nailed it.

This is just a must-buy. It doesn't matter what kind of games you normally like, this is a stellar game all around for any audience.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is a wonderful game. The unit mechanics have a thoughtful and creative design, with diverse interactions between the different factions. The interface is informative without being cluttered. At it's core, the fundamentals of this game are rock solid, and the game is just plain fun.

But on top of that is an great design aesthetic. The art of the units, cards, and maps are all fantastic. The animations, while simple, are smooth and refined. The one small gripe I have is that the sound during combat can get excessively loud and abrasive, especially when the combat speed is set to max and there are lots of units slugging it out.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Slay the Spire, the tower defense genre, or is just looking for a very polished and enjoyable game.

title: Monster Train
review:
I love slay the spire, but found myself building the same decks over and over. Combine that with the 'Rona, and the lack of a cube format on MTGO or MTG Arena for the next few weeks, and I am hurting to build some decks. Enter Monster Train.

I lost two days of my life into this game, something that hadn't happen to me with a new game since picking up Slay the Spire last year. The difference though? After I cleared my first run, I turned around booted up another one. The ability to randomize your factions between games keeps things very fresh and make the game extremely re-playable. The scaling difficulties and multiplayer are a nice addition and make me hopeful the sense of variety in the game will remain. My only complaint is that I want to randomize the boss order like Slay the Spire. Great game, I'm writing this at 16 hours in and am excited to see how my feelings change as I continue playing.

title: Monster Train
review: I have 600h in Slay the Spire.  This game is good, but it's missing all the deck manipulation, complex synergies, and charm of StS. The 3 lanes mechanic isn't that interesting, and there's only paper thin strategy involved with it.  Relics, unlike StS, are helpful but don't augment mechanics in any meaningful way, so they aren't super powerful. The way boss battles resolve isn't fun as you've got to just be ready for the last wave and hope for the best.  Deck building isn't really important as you start with bad cards and just need a ton more as you go, so you take anything you can get and play what's in your hand at all times.  Ugh, I really want to love this game, but right now it's not doing it for me, I'll change my review if later on the game really hooks me.

title: Monster Train
review:
The first really good game in this genre since Slay the Spire.
Less random, fewer battles, and more variety in the player's cards due to the 5 greatly different factions.
You need to adapt to what the game gives you, and it can lead to a spell combo deck, big creatures with thorns, resurrecting dead creatues with increasingly powerful buffs, or feeding tiny minions to grow a single huge monster.
Initially, there are several ways to get really overpowered decks, but the challenges on higher difficulties rise greatly as well.
I had a lot of fun and played over 20 hours in one week, winning with all faction combinations on normal difficulty. Then the harder parts started... :)

3. Upgrade path on cards is very flexible.

title: Monster Train
review:
One long night of playing, and I would say I got my money's worth. I am having a lot of fun with Monster Train. I'll be back to update this recommendation after I have enough hours in to unlock and master things, but having gone through the first three difficulty levels and demon clans: I am having fun. I have had enough fun to merit the retail price.

Start with Slay the Spire's approach to deckbuilding, hands of cards, and relics. Mix in Hearthstone's approach to creatures and spells. Add a dash of tower defense lanes and waves of enemies. This is a good mix, not "toss in everything and hope it works." It is neither trivially easy nor impossible nor all that heavily RNG-dependent.

I am a huge Slay the Spire fan. You can see my comparisons of roguelike deckbuilders at KillTenRats.com. This game does a good job of recombining successful mechanics from several games into an enjoyable whole.

And sorry if I have typos or half-sentences here. I have had an all-night Monster Train binge.

Bonus note: the logbook has an attractive display of data. Want to see where you are with every clan, combination of clans, card unlocks, card guilding, covenant, win streaks... it is all there on one page, very readable.

title: Monster Train
review:
I've only played this game and Slay the Spire for rogue like deck building games but I've enjoyed both very much.
While Slay the Spire does a slightly better job in many aspects from my perspective, the main class + sub class system in this game makes it very fun to just play over and over again to see what kind of unique deck you can make with each combination of classes. I feel like a couple of cards are slightly overtuned and a couple are slightly weak, but maybe that's cuz I'm still on covenant 3 so I shouldn't be judging card balance quite yet.

I'd say the only change I really want in this game is for there to be more variety of the big bosses. Sure they have like 3-4 variations of what they do but it's generally the same except maybe Seraph who has a bit more of a defining difference so maybe Seraph can always be the end boss but having a bit more variety on the 2 mid bosses would be really cool for me 

overall a very good experience and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes rogue like deck builders

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like slay the spire, or card games, I can't recommend this enough. The game makes you split focus on improving units, and forging spells in order to create a deck that can withstand some truly harrowing encounters. 

Creatures are played from the deck, but it seems like if they perish during combat, they stay in the "expended" pool until the next fight. Keep that in mind, or enhance your favorites with holdover charms to keep them coming back for more. 

You are bound to come close to success a few times, but to truly beat your final boss, you must maximize your deck synergy, and keep your card pool optimized. 

I hope there's some more boss variety upcoming, as the same bosses can feel a little stale, but there are modifiers to keep it interesting, as well as challenges in the mid-tier to tempt your greed.   

A+ would punch ticket again.

title: Monster Train
review:
A lot of people I've talked to compare this game to Slay the Spire.  I've watched rather than played that game, so my words are to be taken with a grain of salt.  However, as a general statement, I'd say that Monster Train is a more mechanically involved game.  I'd also say they are different enough that you wont feel like you're just getting more Slay the Spire when you're playing this.  The strategy is different, but it is a deck-building game, and like all of those, card advantage is often king.
I recommend this game, but I would say the price is a bit on the high end as it stands.  It might be a good idea to wait for additional content releases (hopefully free, but you never know), or for it to go on sale.
I would say that with my 28 hours of play time, I still plan to keep playing for quite a while.  I haven't quite unlocked the 5th clan yet (though am very close).  At around the 50 hour mark, I'll update my review with any additional information.

-I run on Windows 10, and it runs smooth with the occasional odd hang when loading
-The visuals are good enough, though some cards look a little too similar and you have to read descriptions/titles carefully to not make mistakes when playing sometimes.
-A game of this seems to be shorter on average than Slay the Spire, but I really don't know by how much.
-My wins have, without exception, happened as the result of maxing a specific type of card or strategy as much as possible.  So far, I haven't found any strat that seems impossible to win with, but some are MUCH more difficult and may be impossible at the higher difficulty runs.
-The music is pretty good and I find myself whistling it sometimes at work
-There is a lot going on in the UI at times and it takes getting used to.  It's similar in complexity to StS, so if you've played that you'll catch on more quickly I'd wager.
-It's not like Hearthstone other than art style and the fact that you fight with multiple creatures in your deck.  Most other aspects are dissimilar enough to really make me wonder why people keep comparing them un-ironically.

That's about it.  Watch a game or two on YouTube or catch a stream of it first before you dive in, but I think fans of StS will absolutely love this game too!

Also feels more rewarding with a gradual ramp up of difficulty. 

I typically game a few hours a week, but I've put 9 hours into this one in the past 2 days. Will have to check back on longevity, but with all the unlocks this could be my game for a while.

review:
Really nice deckbuilder with auto battler elements. Some good features that help keep your runs feeling different. 
There are five clans to choose from, for each run you pick one as your primary clan and another as your secondary, with the primary providing your champion and both contributing cards to your starting deck and card rewards. Starting deck is different for every clan, and as well as the standard starting cards you get in every run you get five more from a larger pool (two primary clan commons, two secondary clan commons, and one primary clan uncommon) so each run starts with a different deck.
Runs consist of eight stages with bosses on three, six, and eight. Bosses are mostly the same each run except for their extra ability, though those abilities can have a considerable effect on combat and therefore on your deck construction.
Would definitely recommend to fans of Slay the Spire or similar games.

title: Monster Train
review:
Even as a regular Spire player, the tower defense aspects of this make it very interesting and unique. Characters like the wonderfully nightmare fuel-ish Umbra champion (personal favorite), and the Melted Remnants as a whole, show that a good amount of thought went into the characters. The difficulty is generally well balanced, some game breaking setups exist, but most of them can be countered by the AI, so while you may spend some time feeling invincible, it'll be well spaced between plenty of times getting stomped. Comparing Seraph to The Heart, in my personal experience, Seraph will kill you faster, but the heart is harder to set up an "I definitely win" against, so that's a decent tie.

I can resist the urge no longer, so this is a hell of a lot of fun, especially if you like the genre itself. Get the soundtrack too, there are some really solid tracks there.

title: Monster Train
review:
There are a lot of comments here comparing this game to slay the spire, and understandably so, but I feel that both games scratch a different itch. 

First off: If you like Slay the Spire you will like this game, I don't think there is anything controversial about that.

The big difference between the two games is that Monster Train rewards more micromanagement and short term decision making and Slay the Spire rewards a grander, more long-term plan.

As each fight in Monster Train resets your train cabins (the playfield and what is on them), you are fundamentally changing how each fight is approached on every encounter. Sometimes you may not even have combat between units until three turns in because you couldn't place your champion on the bottom floor, sometimes you pop off and destroy everything when they enter the train without giving them a chance to really fight back. 

In slay the spire, while it has an abundance of cards and builds, you are generally picking a build up to the first boss and then building around that for the rest of the game until you fight the final boss, where it pays off.

Both games are VERY good and we live in the golden age of these kinds of games, just don't think they are 1:1 comparisons because of all the reviews saying it!

review:
Amazing game. It has completely sucked me in like Slay the Spire did in those first 20-50 hours or so. I have ended up putting over 1k hours into Slay the Spire, and I kind of get the sense I may do the same with this game. The different clans all promote different playstyles, and the fact that you pick a primary and a backup clan every time means there's a ton of variety, and a lot of different viable (or viable-seeming, at least) strategies. 

If you're reading this because you generally like this sort of game but have become a little bit cautious (as I had) about buying slay-the-spire-alikes because so many fall short, buy this game, you will not regret it

title: Monster Train
review:
As has happened quite a few times, I bought Monster Train on the strength of the Northernlion Tries video about it. I'm only about 2 hours in, but I can tell that I'm going to play a lot of this game. Bear in mind, it is almost literally a complete Slay The Spire clone, with a coat of paint and the furniture rearranged. That's not a BAD thing. It's just the facts. In my first run, I came across an artifact (Relic from STS) that is *exactly* statted like Snecko Eye, as an example.

That said, it's a very fun game, different enough from STS so as to be engaging. If you liked that, you'll like this.

title: Monster Train
review:
Esports superstar and 30 year old boomer Ryan 'Northmillion Lionshares' Letourneau brought me to this game and I was initially sceptical about the 'train cart' gimmick but I quickly fell in love with the diverse and interesting card design. All 5 different hell races are unique and interesting, the ability to pick 2 per run adds much needed depth to deck building and an incredible amount of replayability. There is even multiplayer where you can race against your friends and compete for high scores in the same seeded run, a feature often neglected in roguelikes.

The game isn't without flaws, certain events feel extremely situational and are often just passable, a number of bosses hard counter certain builds and there's very little you can do outside of a handful of tech cards that you may not have unlocked, and lastly the stygian guard feel a bit below the curve in terms of power. 

But overall the game is a great card builder/roguelike and definitely worth the money.

title: Monster Train
review:
In short: Addictive, deep progression, thoughtful design, pleasing gameplay flow, plenty of choices to make (and which will have significant impact). A great game for those who love managing resources and developing decks + strategic combat. The presentation is mostly just OK, the art is decent and the music is strangely calming considering I'm the conductor of a hell train. The UI and navigation are simple and effective. 

On the other hand, I do feel the need to add that this game has taken *a lot* from Slay the Spire.  Obviously in life (and especially in gaming) a lot of people iterate on others' ideas, so I'd shy away from calling this a rip-off or a clone. After all, many beloved RPGs are little more than clones of others that came before in terms of gameplay essentials. But this game plays like a DLC of StS, and the similarities can be a bit surprising at times. 

And on that note, I kind of feel bad for the StS devs because although I really enjoyed that game, it lost me before long because it just felt like it was missing meta to expand on the basic run concept. It became repetitive and I didn't care about the end goal at all. And here comes Monster Train, providing all of that meta progression with the more interesting clan concept, and frankly I'd say even improving on the basics. So at this point I wonder... would I ever bother playing Slay the Spire again? Would I have if this game hadn't come along? The answer to both is probably no, so that's a bit unfortunate.

Anyway, this game is pretty amazeballs, despite its fairly weird train premise. Well worth a try and congrats to the devs because this will likely be as wildly popular as StS was. I'm really looking forward to more consistent updates than that game had.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is brilliant. 

For someone who loved Slay The Spire, but found it a bit too difficult when it came to the more complex characters, I think Monster Train is a bit more caveman brain friendly. That's not to say there isn't any strategy involved, the game is very in depth and rewards the player for being creative. You can honestly make just about any deck archetype work in this game, each faction plays differently and synergize with each other in unique ways. I decided from the start of a run I would use the tanky healing faction with the spells and spellpower faction and make a weird stall deck and it worked out swimmingly without having to be perfect. There is plenty to do and it has fun multiplayer gamemodes where you can either race to the finish or try for the highest score. 100% would recommend and look forward to playing more.

title: Monster Train
review:
I write this review with a heavy heart, as I believe Monster Train could be so much more. It has its pros, which many others have noted here, but unfortunately, I cannot recommend it as it currently exists.
I should begin by explaining that I have over 300 hours in Slay the Spire and I consider that game to be close to a masterpiece, so I am, willingly or not, going to be comparing the two in places. 
As a quick aside, I want to mention a few things which drag the game down but would not stop me from recommending it altogether. 
1. The art style is ugly. It looks like a mobile game which in my opinion is unacceptable considering the wealth of great and original artists out there. Slay the Spires art, which I will admit was somewhat jarring at first, fits so well and adds to its charm.
2. The world and story is boring and surface level. Compared to Slay the Spire which is enveloped in mystery and genuine imagination.
3. The last issue which is not a deal breaker, but is worthy of note, is the map. It is a one track path (pun intended) with a few shops along the way. Very dull. No choice on where to go next. One battle after another with no variation. This would be fine, if it were not for my final point, which is the one which stops this game from being worthy of purchase. 

Main issue. The enemy mechanics. 
While there are a lot of great cards and clan diversity, which makes for some interesting play choices, it means nothing when all your enemies behave in virtually the same way. Besides occasionally changing the floor on which your unit stands, or pre-emptively destroying a bomb, there is very little variety in how one handles a battle. What makes Slay the Spire great, is how you handle each fight. Gearing your deck around the next boss or playing cards that allow you to manipulate the playing field to survive.
In Monster Train, you either have enough health and strength, so you win, or you dont and you die. Every boss just attacks over and over again until someone wins or loses. Its so dull. And whats a shame is that it feels like this could have been completely avoidable. Some extra time spent giving enemies more to do and thereby creating a more interesting and challenging battlefield would have ascended this game to something that may have even competed with Slay the Spire. As it is now, its just a game that seems to completely misunderstand what makes Slay the Spire so ingenious.
My hope is that the Developers stick with the game and realise its potential, because I think there is a truly great game in there, but as it stands now, the combat (being the core of the game), requires a complete overhaul.

title: Monster Train
review:
To me this game represents the next step in the deck-building roguelike genre. While Slay the Spire is a great game, I always thought it was lacking a little bit of structure. There was no sense of "space", no positioning, no movement, it was all pretty focused on optimizing your numbers (maximize damage dealt, minimize damage taken).

Monster Train adds all of that! The three lanes do a lot for the game and make combat much more complex on a beyond-math level. You'll frequently find yourself making decisions between non-comparable alternatives, during battle as well as in between battles when it comes to building your deck.

The deck-building process itself is super well-paced too. You'll make a handful of decisions between battles that will move your deck forward, trying to find a balance between getting stronger right now to survive and building towards a scalable boss-beating machine.

While there kind of are "archetypes" built into the game, you'll deviate from them all the time as your choices are formed by the combination of your current deck (including some random starting cards), the artifacts you received, the upcoming sets of rewards and merchants etc. In combination with ascending through the Covenant (difficulty) levels, this easily has the potential to generate interesting runs for hundreds of hours.

Not to mention, on top there are custom and daily challenges with all kinds of modifiers, and "Hell Rush" which is basically 8 players competing in a simultaneous "last player standing" match with a super timer per battle. Another innovation you probably haven't seen elsewhere in the genre.

All in all, if you're even remotely interested in card games, roguelikes or (turn-based) strategy games in general, you should really give this game a shot!

The balance is pretty bad, sometimes I know I've won 10 minutes into a run (this happens because there are game-winning units, that don't require any support or strategy). In that regard Slay the Spire is still the better option. 

Other than that, it's still a pretty fun game. There are tons of units and spells to unlock, and the way they designed challenges and achievements guarantee that there's at least 30-40 hours of playtime. So yeah, definitely worth a buy.

review:
Best train simulator I've played to this day!

Jokes aside, its a great game for a great price. The Gameplay mechanic is easy to understand and pretty good to Master, you think! But then you get wiped out like you are a joke. Its learning by playing and playing to get better (cards). There is obviously RNG involved but if you have a good and healthy deck you don't have to fear losing to RNG. If you like turn-based combat, rogue lite games, card games, games that can be kind to you and 10 seconds later spank you, its the game for you!

What I also liked about the game is that you don't play the good side, you take control over the Minions of HELL! Who doens't want to be a bad guy eh?! 

Its a 9.5/10 for me atm (end of may) because its already a well functioning and great game, and I can imagine it getting only better after time. Buy it. Enjoy it. beat it! Have Fun!

review:
I generally don't care for roguelikes, I get tired of the repetitive gameplay loops and prefer a more crafted narrative. 

Having said that, this game has kept me absolutely transfixed.  I feel like I'm constantly making interesting decisions and finally putting together that perfect build after several failed runs is so satisfying.  

The presentation is overall quite good.  Two nitpicks that jump out to me: I think the train on the overview map looks cheap, as does the run summary page UI.  Information is clear, which is very important since there is a lot of it. I found the UI very easy to navigate.  

I appreciate that there is no undo button.  It forces you to be more considerate instead of just tinkering around trying to find the best solution.

Highly recommend!

title: Monster Train
review:
With hundreds of new deck-builders being created in the wake of slay the spire's paramount success as an indie title, one may expect the analogous formula presented in the same way from something like this game.

However, Monster Train is a very wonderful surprise.

The core mechanics are freshened in the form of unit placement, a simplified pathing system for the map, and new synergistic intrigue types among cards and spells alike, as well as a multiplayer feature for racing. 

There are 5 currently available "characters"/clans that can be used, each adorning their own champion card that you have the option of placing with other units on one of three floors below the pyre of your train, which is essentially the source of fuel for the train, and serves as your health. Enemies will enter the train to engage you in turn-based combat, sequentially climbing up the train's three levels in attempt to defeat your pyre, the thing you are trying to protect. 

The idea of being able to place units on different levels of the train is a very innovative way of adding layers of depth to a formula that has been almost perfected by sts, and is complimented by nice animated visuals and easy to understand systems. This is an example of a well thought out, "not just a cash grab" style of game that is highly worth your time if you enjoy these kinds of deck builders, and have been wanting something that exhibits mechanics with high replay value and polish.

My only complaint is that it might be a bit too easy. There seems to be an inverse difficulty curve atm because it's way too easy to build op combos. I beat the game on my 3rd run, 3 hours in. Took 40 hours to beat Slay the Spire for the 1st time by comparison. Maybe I just got lucky. The difficulty does increase just like Spire after you beat the game though.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is great! The 3 tier structure of the game allows for a whole new level of strategy. The game is simple enough to jump right in and complex enough to keep you playing. 
There is a point when everything isn't unlocked yet that the strategy gets a little repetitive. Once you get past that hump and everything is unlocked a lot more strategies are available. 
This game is more rogue like than deck builder. You can't pre-build a deck. You just select a main and sub class to play and its all RNG from there. 
That being said the game will want to steer you towards a certain strategy most of the time. It will offer you choices of rewards that synergize well together, you just have to play enough to know what to pick. 
I would highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys similar card based rogue like strategy games.

title: Monster Train
review: Fun mechanics and banging music

title: Monster Train
review:
GREAT deckbuilding Game that's kind of an evolution of Slay the Spire. 

Instead of copying the concept the devs smartly expanded it and gave it a very cool twist that completely changes gameplay experience!

This time you are the monsters and you need to stop these pesky heroes & Angels from snuffing out the last embe rof the fires of the underworld!
The gameplay is diverse, the concept is familiar to those that love deck building game yet brings a LOT of New concepts and ideas, It leaves you with this itch to instantly try this new strategy you just thought of when you finish (or fail) a run. The game is also pretty challenging which again is good as it spurs you to try new strategies.

The most amazing part though is the potential. I can already see 40 different avenues how this game can expand with DLC / more features very easily. More Heroes is no 1 I am thinking of. But also new artifacts, new bodies for the heroes or branching paths for the train. Maybe an overarching story as you climb the covenants!

Great great game and worth every penny. If you love deckbuilding games a must buy <3

title: Monster Train
review:
this is pretty hard for me. i want to give it a middle ground and not a thumbs up but it does not deserve a thumbs down.

the game is pretty good, it has a good baseline aswell as being unique from other cardbuilding rougelike. like being on a train to fricking hell sounds awsome and instantly got me to buy the game as i did enjoy my small amount of time i put into slay the spire.

but i got 3 problems with the game:

1. the game has barely any variety in enemies and here is why: although the game got a good amount of variety in enemies its just how the game is built to make the enemies feel less significant that makes it feel like it could be so much more. in slay the spire the bird occulists is a basic easy enemy to deal with but if you mess around it can quickly kill you, i dont feel like this about any enemy other than the last 2 big bosses in this game, the enemies are weak and easy to take down simply by you having minions and not a character making the enemies look weaker hence a need for more variety.

2. you get the silent in STS upon first beating the game, it could take 1 try or 20 tries but you got rewarded when winning with something really cool while you dont get anything from "beating" the game that already feels WAY to short, you get rewarded really slowly by simply playing the game. example 1, you get a different class when you have played X number of spells (this will always be the first one you unlock) and the next one feels like its an eternity away

3. build variety feels lacking in the small amount of time ive played the game. any time i swap away from red+green i get stomped simply because the other things are not strong enough. blue is cool with their status effects that stacks dmg and can reach an insane amount of tick dmg on a boss but their hero dies to everything that has sweep so not playable. having multistrike on your hero as red will never ever be better than having slay +10. having blue as a side faction as red does not work because both factions have low hp units forcing you to take the green faction. green faction hero is ass as it has 0 dmg and only there as a spike tank that other units of the same faction does 10 times better.

the game can use a good amount of more work but it looks really promising. follow this game and look out for future patches where they might expand or change things to make factions other than red green viable. also having mod support would greatly help this game in my opinion. rougelike´s always benefits from having it.

Just unlocked the 5th clan and I can safely say this game is up there with RimWorld for my "Just one more hour/run" kind of games. 

Gameplay:
Each clan plays uniquely and the way you play with two clan card sets adds more strategy than I thought would be there.  The whole train system adds a nice fresh take on the deck building genre where figuring out what lane to put your units in really adds to the thinking 

Graphics:
The art style really works with the hellish theme with Character Designs.  Loving the music as well! 

Audio/Music:
Soundtrack is amazing, the boss themes are pretty catchy...and the noises are fitting but not annoying 

Overall I say if you like Slay the Spire and looking for a new deck building roguelite, you can't go wrong!  But thats just me, watch streamers or videos on the game

review: Monster Train is a beautifully streamlined turn-based game. The floor combat system is an amazing treat. While it is heavily inspired by Slay the Spire, it adds something beyond it. After 40 hours I feel like I've barely scratched the surface of the potential interactions. At this time, the game is well balanced, but I expect it will eventually be amazing to see the full breadth of choices all with their pros and cons. Sometimes I am awestruck when I think about the complexity of choices in a single battle emerging from intricate interactions that I built with my choices.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster train is one of those games that is just unapologetically fun. It is often compared to slay the spire, but I feel it's different enough to warrent it's own spot in your games library if you liked STS, or even if you just like card games in general.

It's a game of building cards that really feel powerful, and then using them to utterly demolish your foes in what can sometimes be some hilariously one sided fights. Nothing is more satisfying than seeing that a boss will not survive attacking your current train segment, and then clicking the end turn button and watching the carnage unfold. 

It's got cute monsters, cool monsters, and a lot of strategic depth. You cans see the entire path to the end before you make your first real choice each run, and because of this, if you fail, it really feels like it was your fault, and not just RNG dealing you an unwinable hand. That's important in a rogue-like; RNG adds to the fun but doesn't make or break it.

In short, I can't recommend it enough for fans of deckbuilders and rogue-likes. It's great!

I have played many card games before like Slay The Spire and The Darkest Dungeon, this feels like a combination of both with all the unique cards and abilities and game changing artifacts. AND in this game YOU ARE THE SPIRE! You might not make it in the first go, but you will crave to push further and try one time, every time, until you finally beat the game. That's what gives it great replayability. I am loving it and I think this game is a very good deal compared to the asking price. Go on, give it a try!

And remember, THE TRAIN MUST NEVER STOP!!!!!

title: Monster Train
review:
If you enjoyed Slay the Spire, you will probably like this game too!

Monster train is a fun deck building game that is great for playing in bursts of 1 or more games. The duration of one game is about 45-60 minutes and it is very hard not to click the 'New run' button every  time.

At the start of a run you pick a primary and secondary clan, which limits the available cards to those two clans' card sets. This is great for replay value, because each clan has their own play style and it's up to you to choose the winning combination of spells, units, artifacts and upgrades.

There are only 8 encounters during every run, so the cards you pick and the order in which you play matter quite a bit. A misplaced unit could be the difference between victory and defeat.

The enemies you encounter feel a little same-y after a while, they only get a unique buff every time, which might influence your strategy.

I find some of the cards a little less useful, but maybe they just don't fit my play style. I don't pick upgrades that boost the Pyre (the base you need to defend), because I like to defeat enemies before they even reach it. Some other cards seem a little too situational, but that's okay.

I still need to try the more challenging modes, but I want  to unlock all available cards first, which will take me a while. The multiplayer aspect also seems interesting.

Overall, a very fun and addictive game to play with great replay value. Worth full price.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is by far the most addicting game to come out in 2020.

Much like Slay the Spire, you build a deck by drafting cards while navigating a map and engaging in battles, in this case, you are riding a train through the now-frozen 9 circles of Hell with the last vestige of the Pyre which can re-ignite Hell to it's former blazing glory.

What differentiates this is that you choose a combination of 2 factions, one which is your main and one your secondary.  The main faction will determine who your Champion, a special card, is while the combination of both will determine the contents of your starting deck.  The game consist of 8 multi-wave battles on your 4-level train as the forces of "good" try to climb its floors and extinguish your pyre which sits on the topmost floor.  You play cards either Units or Spells to defeat each wave until the boss Spawns.

Once you complete the game the first time, you unlock Covenant levels which are similar to Ascendancy levels.  Each subsequent level will give you penalties to make the run harder.

Another very nice feature is the ability to creature custom challenges that can be shared and played simultaneously among friends each challenge having their own leader boards.

I have over 900 hours player in Slay the Spire and I believe this game will have more longevity because of the multiplayer aspects and the multiple faction system.

title: Monster Train
review: Fantastic and wildly unique combination of deckbuilder and tower defense game. Lots of card/faction variety and the ability to develop unique playstyles on the fly. The game looks and sounds *great*, and your actions feel extremely satisfying and impactful, which enhances the gameplay experience dramatically. Certain elements remind me of Slay the Spire (in a good way!) like the relics, ascension system, and branching paths between "floors", but the game builds something completely new off of that basic structure. There's that same thrill of discovering a completely busted combo and then reworking your whole deck to revolve around it... but no combo is quite busted enough that you can afford to let your guard down! I won my first run yesterday and I'm excited to start climbing the ascension ladder and unlocking new factions... I can tell I'm going to be sinking a LOT of hours into this. This is a 100% buy recommendation from me.

title: Monster Train
review:
A fun twist on the deckbuilder formula. While comparisons to Slay the Spire are obvious, it's definitely not just "Slay the Spire but different". While Slay the Spire seems tightly and meticulously designed, Monster Train seems designed around breaking the game. You'll often find yourself saying "oh my god, this is so overpowered!", but the game is aware of this and expects you to bring out all your big guns. For comparison, an upgrade in Slay the Spire might make an attack do 9 damage instead of 7, an upgrade in Monster Train makes a spell do 22 damage instead of 2. Compared to Slay the Spire, decks tend to be focused around a few busted cards, rather than primarily being about consistency.

With 5 different factions, it's got plenty of different playstyles and things to unlock if that appeals to you. The multiplayer mode is a fun idea, and daily runs and challenges add some extra longevity too. I wonder if this game will have the same amount of staying power as Slay the Spire, or if it will become a "solved game" at some point, but it's definitely worth the price.

review:
It's like playing Slay the Spire again, but with different game mechanics!

It is clear that Monster train have taken a lot of inspiration from Slay the Spire. for instance most of the artifacts have an completely identical twin in StS.
But that said, it still have many new game mechanics. It's not just a ripoff, but more like StS2

Besides being a new StS game, one game mechanic i like in particular, is that you don't die from just 1 bad draw of 0 defense when the enemy makes it attack 56.You summon monsters that stay alive for multiple rounds, and they tank and deal damage for you.Of cause that doesn't mean you cant have bad rounds, but it means you have to have multiple bad rounds, and then you probably have a bad deck anyways and more likely deserve it :)
If you like StS, or in general like deck builders, Monster train is 100% a must try!

title: Monster Train
review:
Not many games can suck me in for 40+ hours within a week of release nowadays.  It is fair to compare this game to Slay the Spire, and I think many fans of Slay the Spire would really enjoy this game as well.  It plays much more fast-paced.  It is a well-balanced game, but not perfectly balanced, and I think that is intentional. There are 5 different decks and there are 20 different combinations of "classes" that can be created by smashing two potential 'decks' together, depending on which one you choose as your 'main'.  Each combination plays very differently, and gives a great amount of replay value.

Instead of perfect balance, the game expects you to be game-breakingly strong to in order to smash the final boss, which is satisfying and makes you feel like a genius.  A single run usually lasts an hour.

At $20.00-$25.00 it is a good value, whether you play through just long enough to unlock everything or if you decide to drop countless hours reaching the highest difficulties.

Wishlist for future updates:  
1. The multiplayer 'race' mode is fun, it would be even more fun to be able to spectate or review the choices made by your competition if you don't win though.
2. A large supply of random events, maybe a third 'blind' path through each level just to spice things up.
3. The design of the bosses is fun, and the variations of each are also interesting, more bosses would of course be even more fun.
4.  I would happily pay for DLC that adds more decks to the game.

My progress after 44 hours:  I've unlocked all the cards with the time I've put in and beaten the game with just over half of the combinations.  I've reached the 10th out of 25 covenant ranks (challenge or ascension levels)

There is an incredible amount of variance and synergy potential given the combinations of different factions. There are a ton of choices for building the deck and upgrading cards, each run really is unique. 

The enemies are interesting and each group has a way to counter a specific style of deck synergy, but there could be a slightly greater variety of enemies. The option to make individual fights harder for more rewards is brilliant and adds a great risk/reward system. The music, art and UI are excellent as well. If you're a fan of single player card games, absolutely give this a try!

review: I rarely take the time to do a review for a game, but I have to for this one.  Monster Train is just so much fun, even when I get defeated.  At first I got a little frustrated, but it's not long before you're giggling at some combination of cards and mechanics you just discovered, that just changed everything!  It's no joke when people say, no two runs are the same.  Even if you have a certain build in mind, it's not always going to play out as you expect.  This keeps it from getting boring.  I also like how I can play casually.  There is no timer making me rush my turn.  I can take my time to formulate a strategy, or pause to watch a Jenna Marbles video.  Just buy the game, You will enjoy!

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is quite unique despite taking many obvious influences from Slay the Spire. 

I can't remember the last time I played a game that respected the player's time as much as Monster Train does. Each run will average less than an hour and there's enough content to make them feel different and substantial.

The diversity in deck-building potential is vast with 5 playable "clans" all containing very different play styles. If that wasn't enough, each run requires the player to choose a primary clan (unlocks the clan champion [0-cost innate unit] to be used each fight) as well as a supportive or allied clan. This in turn allows different clan combinations to be used for further deck-building depth. 

Pros: 
+ Unique take on the deck-building genre.
+ Strong fundamental replay value. 
+ Palatable OST.
+ Respects the player's time. (By far the most important)

Cons:
- Devoid of story.
- The art style can be an acquired taste. 
- Some of the unit specific sound bites (both enemy and friendly) are quite annoying. This is especially true when they have the multi-strike buff coupled with a fast or ultra game speed modifier.

title: Monster Train
review:
Like many, I came from Slay The Spire, and was looking for an experience that was familiar, different, and better. 

What I found was a fantastic game that still left me slightly dissatisfied. I think the overall mechanics of the game are deep and entertaining, but I don't feel the balance is there yet. 

In StS, almost every run felt possible unless you gambled and traded your relic in for something garbage or got screwed by a bad transform/curse. RNG would emerge over the course of the run and help guide you to victory or defeat, but it always FELT possible. 

In MT, your success at higher ascension levels (I can't remember what MT calls them and I don't care) will depend on finding one or more synergies. While you can and will build synergies as you move through a game, the starting deck you're given is still crucial. A run that begins with 5 garbage cards (and yes, many cards are garbage unless tied to an extremely narrow niche deck) might as well be aborted immediately for all the odds are stacked against you. 

I don't care for that level of RNG right off the bat, and I think a better job could have been done in balancing it. My personal preference could be for the game to give you a 2x stack and 1x stack, then put one more event at the beginning stage that lets you choose a card from 3 and duplicate it, giving you your final 2x stack.
