title: Monster Train
review:
This game isn't bad, but it is poorly balanced.  Once it gets some fine tuning, if it's acceptable, I will change my review.  As of right now, you will often run into a few very annoying issues.  Your starting deck, for nearly every clan is stuffed with too many of certain cards.  You will find that you are constantly pulling an entire hand full of nothing but Regen spells, Morsels, or other spells that don't let you develop your "train" to face the upcoming waves.  And there are ZERO opportunities to tweak these until you clear the first train... even then, the next tile has to have spawned a node that allows you to remove cards.

Just to clarify... there are 10 regen/spell cards in the starting deck, and only 4 monsters to place down other than your champion.  So of the 15 cards in your starting deck, 66% of them are useless for developing your train layout.  Doing the math you will see why it's so common to get screwed with a hand full of garbage, instead of monsters that you need to place in your train.  I am all for having a bit of RNG and luck involved... this is a Roguelite afterall.  But these percentages are a bit extreme if you aren't going to allow us to remove cards from our deck before clearing the first train.   My suggestion, is limit the Regens/Torches/ or other spells to 4 each in the starting deck, and give Train Stewards or weak clan monsters to 6.

title: Monster Train
review:
I generally don't write reviews because most games don't scratch many itches I have as a consumer. But monster train hits a lot of these points to create a truly great game which I'm afraid many will miss. So if you're finding something niche, I hope you give this game a shot.

Also, my review assumes you played slay the spire.

Monster train is what a proper spin-off, homage and spiritual successor should be.
Every aspect of Slay the Spire, MT has integrated their own spin to the formula while leaving what makes StS fun intact.

MT has a dual faction system that offers a lot more replay value and mastery with being able to mix and match regions, creating deck-building variety like in Magic: The Gathering. Each faction has cards similar to how a character in StS has cards, different archetypes and they are surprisingly synergistic across regions.

Runs are also generally shorter (personally), one run is condensed to 7-8 boss battles as opposed to dozens in StS. These fights are still fairly long so runs can still take awhile if you want to methodically think about things but there is less of the annoying health min-maxing in StS ascensions and more focus on the decision making.

There is also a real-time multiplayer gamemode, each player is still plays as if it were singleplayer but they compete with speed and efficiency to gain score to see who scores the highest in end while you are on a clock. It's very intense and a good change of pace to the singleplayer mode and I highly recommend it, it has an adrenaline rush very unlike anything out there in the multiplayer market.

My only minor gripes about this game is that some UI elements are not clear, information is crucial, same with StS. There isn't a clear breakdown of overhealing/damage, at high values you will have to resort to a lot of manual calculation. There is also no way to see what each unit is doing to who, especially important when fights span between multiple attacks amongst multiple units. Lastly, the unit's speech can block the room size which is crucial in speedrun type playstyles.

Finally, I hope you don't judge a book by its cover. The visuals are a bit "crappy mobile game" but there is a lot of world-building delivered similar to StS, neat character designs and that subtle mysterious lore. Also the name is very mobile gamey and I hope that doesn't detract you from buying it because I know many will.

And if you do buy it, let me know about your experience and hook me up for a Hell Run! >:D

title: Monster Train
review: Never liked deck building games(never really played one before either tbh, genre just didn't interest me) or roguelikes but I like this game a lot. It's a mix of RNG(taking what the game throws at you and adapting) and building smart/synergizing.  When you lose it's generally your fault while on occasion you get screwed on the rolls which is fair. There could be more enemy variety but it is fun to figure out the strategies to beat the bosses.  The final boss, as it should be in a roguelike, is very challenging and will expose your poor strategy or build if you aren't prepared. Deck building roguelike games make more sense to me than a combat-based one like Hades where the builds are overshadowed by the mechanics (spamming dash or an overpowered ability you get).

title: Monster Train
review:
An excellent combination of deck building and rogue-lite elements, Monster Train lets you build a deck of units and spells to defeat the Hordes of Heaven in an attempt to re-ignite the Pyre of hell.

The combat mechanics are interesting and unique as you have combat on different floors at once, with enemies climbing from bottom to top - if they survive one combat round, they ascend to the next floor, where they can be met with an entirely different line up of your defenders. 

Another pro is the five different clans you can play. For each run, you choose not only a primary clan, setting you up with a unique Champion and a few starter cards, but also an allied clan, granting you access to another set of spells and units, allowing you to mix two entirely different playstyles into one.

Definitely worth it!

title: Monster Train
review: Lets see.... picked up this game today and I'm 12 hours in and I can't stop. Really great game with card mechanics reminiscent of slay the spire, but feels more refined. Unlike slay the spire you focus on placing units in a tower defense like fashion against the onslaught of "evil angels" trying to stop you from saving hell. There are 5 classes and I've made it through 4 of them now and they all play very unique. Each class is paired with another class of your choice so you have 25 different class card combinations to play through. The game has a lot to offer in terms of content, replayability, and progression. There are 25 difficulty levels to get through and the game will rank you against your friends so you can see how much better (or worse) you are than them. There is a multiplayer too, but I have only briefly played it. I think that the multiplayer is okay, but the game doesn't lend itself towards multiplayer because 1 train run can take 30 minutes to an upwards of two hours depending on what style you are playing and how far you make it. Overall, I really enjoy this game and think that if you liked slay the spire, darkest dungeons, or any strategy card game/ tower defense you should give this game a try.

title: Monster Train
review:
First off this isn't a noob friendly game.
If you aren't adept at deckbuilding you will likely end up regretting a rather expensive purchase (for an indie).
The screenshots don't do it justice. Videos on Twitch do not do it justice.
The game is crisp HD with an aesthetic that's close to but not quite as consistent as Hearthstone's.
The main gameplay actually plays more like auto chess than Slay The Spire (STS) but instead of playing casino games to get your units as is the norm of autobattlers, you go through the STS method of picking routes and battling for rewards.
There's a tower defense aspect to the game but I think it's wrong to misleading a tower defense fan into a game like this.

title: Monster Train
review:
Fun as fuck and surprisingly strategic. There are so many build options and strategies you can develop, but there's a twist, you have a limited amount of time and you have to deal with a random run each time. You might not get the strategy you want, or maybe you take a gamble and hope you catch the cards you need to make your strategy super viable for the end game. 

There are a few times I realized I was holding my breath in the last battle. You put a lot of thought and planning into each run and sometimes it comes down to your last few cards. It builds up a lot of tension and fun gameplay. Must have for a trading card/rogue like lovers. Must have for a strategy gamer. If the devs are reading... take my money for endless mode!!!!!!

title: Monster Train
review:
Simple to understand, but there is lots of depth that opens up to you almost immediately.  Game plays a lot like Slay the Spire, but has a lot more going on mechanically.  Difficulty gets brutally difficult as you unlock higher and higher levels that force negative modifiers on you that you have to work around. 

Class combinations are numerous, allowing you to mix and match any two of the 5 factions that determine what cards and, by extension , what playstyles are available to you in any given run.  Outside of the RNG of card draw, the game isn't super gimmicky with random events.  They are pretty tame and won't completely decimate your run when you come across them.

title: Monster Train
review:
I have been chasing that Slay the Spire high ever since putting dozens upon dozens of hours on the Nintendo Switch port. I tried Neoverse and SteamWorld Quest, neither of which came close to capturing the feeling I had with Slay the Spire.

Monster Train has given me that high. It matches Slay the Spire's strengths and adds on two mechanics that brings so much more enjoyment to the formula 

One is choosing two clans (basically decks) to combine per run out of 5 total choices, This makes going run to run super enjoyable since using different combinations make things vary so much. The other is having 3 floors of train to manage which has the enemy ascending each turn. If the enemy hits the top floor, they will fight with your pyre (your HP pool) til either the pyre or the enemy is defeated

For anyone wanting a genuinely satisfying deck builder after Slay the Spire, this is far and away THE one to check out

title: Monster Train
review:
An excellent deckbuilder that measures up to Slay the Spire, which is an incredible feat. I actually enjoy this one more than Spire due to the sheer variety of runs and card combinations that are possible, and unlike in Spire, are actually viable. You can make almost any card work, and more often than not I find myself surprised at the usefulness of a card that I initially deemed worthless on pickup.

I also enjoy how liberal the game is with cash flow, card pickup and card removal opportunities. It may seem too easy at first, but it allows for more experimentation with card and upgrade synergies, which makes the game initially more forgiving (and more enjoyable) as a result. But as you push higher difficulty levels your knowledge of these synergies will be put to the test, and some faction combinations are difficult to work with.

The logbook is a great feature as well, which keeps track of which cards and faction combinations you've used, along with the highest difficulty you've achieved with that combination.

And for the one percent or so of Steam users that play on ultrawides, this game is actually ultrawide compatible, unlike Spire.

With an emphasis is careful play and positioning, the game accelerates the deck building aspect of the game. You get extremely powerful quickly, bet never so strong to out pace your enemies! Choose carefully what challenges you want to excel and remember to always Save the Pyre!

title: Monster Train
review:
Maybe 3 hours is a bit early to leave a review but I LOVE this game.

If you're a fan of Slay the Spire you definitely need to pick this up. It clearly takes a lot from it while adding several mechanics of its own.

Edit: So after some more time I still like this game. But I will say I'm not so sure if it's.. balanced great? I'm still in low-ranked Covenant (think Ascension if you're familiar with Slay the Spire) but certain upgrades to your Champion card seem like no-brainers compared to others. A prime example is the last clan- Would you like your champion to have 50/50 attack/hp but die in three turns without a certain buff you're unlikely to have when starting the game? Or would you like him to have 15/15 and heal 5 if something dies? Considering sometimes the first fight starts out with 4 5/1 enemies (where sometimes killing them deals damage to your front unit) it seems pretty easy to decide to just wait to play your incredibly strong but short lived Champion later, when the boss shows up.

The game is still really fun (even though very few people are actually playing it despite all the positive reviews), I just hope some things will be addressed in the future.

title: Monster Train
review:
[b]Monster Train[/b] is a game that wears its [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/646570/Slay_the_Spire/]Slay the Spire[/url] influence completely unapologetically. It's impossible to not compare the two games, but really that only helps to highlight Monster Train's strengths. The primary difference between the two deck-building games is that while in Slay the Spire you attack with cards, in this game you use cards to strategically place units that enter combat automatically at the end of your turn.

I think my biggest criticism of Monster Train is that it's not called "Hell Train", which in my opinion is a much cooler and more fitting name. I guess they didn't want "Hell" in the title, in case it comes to consoles or something. "Heck Train"? Hmm...

(You guys ever played that 2009 WiiWare game [i]Final Fantasy Crystal Chronicles: My Life as a Darklord[/i]? Probably not, because it wasn't very good. Until recently I kind of thought it was a surreal, half-remembered dream, but then I played Monster Train, a significantly better game, and it all came rushing back to me. It's likely that the similarities between these two games are completely coincidental, but I just thought it was amusing.)

Any of the following would be acceptable.
By:
Alphabetical
Mana cost
Colour (Faction)
Rarity
Type (creatures / spells)
Amount of slots creatures take up

Come on, if you wanna challenge Slay The Spire at least give us a filter option. I know the meta is usually build a small deck but sometimes you wanna go wild and big a large sprawling deck. It is so user friendly to be able to search for the cards your looking for.

Example:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2109909999

As soon as a filter option is introduced ill change my nay to yay.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game took the best parts of a roguelike card game and mixed them in with a tower defense-lite game. It's really engaging. Not only is this a deck-builder, it's a card-crafter as well. It makes for really fun opportunities and allows for you to be a little more creative than Slay the Spire or other games like it. After about 7 hours of play, I am pretty obsessed with it. 

I played the first run, beat it in two tries, and was like, "Oh, that's too bad, it's really easy." But using covenants adds a LOT of depth and complexity to the game, which is great. You honestly aren't playing it the way it's meant to be played if you aren't using covenants. 

One of the downsides is that there isn't really a lot of variation of bosses- but I am not sure if more get unlocked later. So far, it's been a pretty samey sort of run. But with how hard it gets as you go, I think it's almost necessary to have some amount of predictability to prep for. I think the card crafting and ascension choices for champions makes up for a lack of run variation, anyway. I get to play vastly different decks with the same cards, just modded differently. I really like that. 

This game mashes a lot of genres together and is different than Slay the Spire in all the best ways. I still love Slay the Spire. They feel really different after you start playing it, though. Different enough that I honestly can play both games in the same day and still have fun with both. 

I really like this game. It is well balanced and engaging and has a ton of replayability. And honestly, I am glad it's got shorter runs than StS because those runs sometimes got too long. I think it's well worth the $25 pricetag.

title: Monster Train
review: Honestly, a great iteration on slay the spire and Autochess.

title: Monster Train
review:
An interesting deck builder that adds some new tactical elements with it's 3 floor combat system. Easy to learn, and good balance between random elements and common elements you can try and build your deck around.  The game might be on the easy side compared to other deck builders, but it is not so easy as to be unsatisfying. To start with, variety seems a little low, but as you unlock new cards, clans, and it seems to me that even events unlock, but that may just be luck. At first I kept seeing the same few over and over, now I've seen several new ones.

The production value is very high, with story elements on the cards, decent art, and some voices. I have not experienced any bugs yet. It pops up little progress windows after every game showing nifty new accomplishments you've made or comparing your stats to your friends. Also the multiplayer is an interesting element, allowing you to compete  against other players on leader boards with real time announcements. All in all polished and well thought out.

title: Monster Train
review: This game is what I'd describe as Slay the Spire meets an Auto Chess. The game is fun, challenging, and has straight forward mechanics. I have already put 20 hours if you count the demo and I can safely say I could put several hundreds of hours into this game with the class diversity and the covenant ratings. I would not be surprised if this game ends up being nominated for  an indie game of the year.

title: Monster Train
review:
Hi guys,
Fell in love with this really good and lovely game.
Kinda like Slay the spire but with more unit and floors to manage, has really some Hearthstone PVE flavor with it's own personnality and a lot of great ideas.
The two clans system makes a lot of different combination. I also really like the log book which trace wathever card you get, mastered, and how many wins with each combination of clans in a single page. The collector heaven.

After 12 hours I'm really fond of this game, for such a low price i recommend it to everyone loving Deck building and card games with a taste of roguelike.

If you have to compare it with slay the spire I would say:
- Less frustrating, you get more chance to customise your deck and remove bad cards
- Less RNG
- More variated with 5 different clans, making 20 different combination with different play style in each

title: Monster Train
review:
I've played a boatload of Slay the Spire, and I continue to do so. So when this game came out a few days ago one of my friends messaged me and asked if I had seen it. I hadn't, so I downloaded it on a lark, figuring if I didn't like it I could refund it - after all, spires don't slay themselves.
....
...
..
. 
Smash cut to nearly 12 hours later and I'm really really in deep with this game, trying to figure it out.
It scratches nearly the same itch - but since it's shorter in some respects than a run of slay the spire, the decisions matter more. Couple that with TWENTY! possible run combinations, given that you choose a primary and secondary clan each time, leads to that "just one more" feeling.  

I would recommend this without hesitation.

Easily worth the money and then some.

title: Monster Train
review: After putting in 12 hrs I can tell you that this game is in fact addictive. I play a round or two (takes about an hr for a round right now) and then go and do other things. At some point I get an urge to play me some Monster Train. The expansion of cards/leveling if you will is perfect. I'm constantly gaining new skills and learning new ways to play the game. The rogue-like is strong with this game.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
Oh, yeah, baby, that's the good stuff.

Slay the Spire turned me into a roguelike deckbuilding junkie. After logging 400+ hours in it, I've been on a two-year journey through a bunch of other games in the genre. I've played a lot of good ones, but this one deserves special mention. The Slay the Spire inspiration is definitely there, but it clearly served as more of a jumping off-point into its own game, and deserves to be talked about on the strength of its fresh new ideas alone, because it has a ton, and a lot of them are just fantastic.

First, the deckbuilding itself. Monster Train very clearly understands what makes a deckbuilder fun, and is built off of the idea of finding crazy unexpected synergies between its cards, artifacts, and champions. It chooses to focus on multiplicative scaling as opposed to additive, and it gives you a lot of control over which cards and units you choose to lean into with its upgrade system. You get to make a bunch of decisions constantly, and you're challenged to find the highest-value options out of a lot of interesting ones. The game is decently challenging, and if you make good calls, you're rewarded handsomely with crazy emergent synergies that just feel really awesome to pull off. But, the encounters scale exponentially too, and if you don't keep up, the denizens of Heaven are going to overpower you and shatter the last remnants of your Pyre.

The tower defense aspect of the encounters changes the flow up quite a bit as well, asking you interesting questions about what units go in which lanes. At first, it seems like a no-brainer to just shove all your big dudes into one lane and kill things before they can even get further in, but the bosses challenge you not to do that. All it takes is one time for a wave to catch you off-guard and break through the floor where you invested all of your power to understand the tactical importance of having a plan for every lane.

The presentation is great, and each faction has a strong identity in both its visuals and mechanics. My personal favorite is the Melting Remnant, literal candle people that burn out after a while, but use graveyard recursion effects to re-form new bodies out of wax and come back stronger. The music is good too, an enjoyable soundtrack that's consistent enough to be thematic, but also just varied enough to stay interesting.

The only thing on my wishlist right now is more encounter variety. You fight the same bosses in the same order every run, but they have different crests that change the mechanics of the fights significantly. However, it still feels like the same boss, and you might have to change your tactics turn-to-turn, but you don't have to build significantly differently to handle them. But, that's probably something that's more noticeable to someone like me (who's no-lifed this game for four days straight), as opposed to someone who plays a little more casually.

I could say more, but you get the idea, I think. A lot of this should be experienced for yourself, and if you even have a passing interest in the idea of this game, you should definitely pick this up. I've played a lot of good games in this genre, but this is the first one that I've logged almost 40 hours in in four days. 

tl;dr: game good, strongly recommend

title: Monster Train
review:
If you liked Slay the Spire, there is no doubt you will like this.  A lot more depth here in my opinion, as you are essentially taking 3 different fights every turn.   I don't think I have to explain much to the crowd that already loves Slay the Spire about the game play outside of that.

For people who have not played Slay the Spire, this game would appeal to anyone who like strategy games, turn based RPGs, or card games.  The game is polished, has a very good difficulty curve, and progression system.  I am unaware of how mods will be handled, but if it is anything like Slay the Spire in that regard, then this game will have even more longevity than it does in it's base form.  This is pretty absurd because I already see myself playing this game for 100+ hours.

title: Monster Train
review:
Fun as hell (no pun intended) and well worth the asking price.That's the long and short of it but I'll try to elaborate a bit more.

If you like deckbuilding roguelites like Slay the Spire then this is an absolute must.It borrows some of it's ideas like the ascension mechanic and artifacs but also introduces new ideas like the 3 stage arena and clan combinations ( essentially allowing you to mix and match 2 deck archetypes). Speaking of Clans ,there are 5 of them (2 unlocked from the beginning ,the other 3 trough gameplay), and all have very interesting and diverse gameplay.While the Stygian Guard is all about frostbite ,sap and spells , the Umbra are about the comsume mechanic and buffing units .Seeing how you can combine any 2 clans ,you have the potential to get some pretty juicy decks that are extremely satisying to play .

Besides the wonderful single player experience where you can climb covenants ala AScension in Slay the Spire; this game also offers daily challenges ,competing in multiplayer with other players in a "rush" style game mode and you can even create custom Challenges that you can post online so that other players can compete in them.All of these are great activities that offer Monster Train a lot of replayability.

Like I said : Great game ,great fun.It will be interesting to see where the devs thake the game next .Personally I would love to see more Leaders cards and floors and maybe even some sort of coop game mode.

title: Monster Train
review: Still early into my time with this game but just completed my first run. It's a fun game that deserves a spot next to slay the spire. It takes a simple idea of progressively moving through enemies using cards to assist in that process and adds depth to it that I personally didn't feel with other games in the same genre. I went from being on the fence on the fence about this game to buying it and being very thankful that I did. Highly recommend picking this up if you enjoyed Slay the Spire or like CCG's in general.

The game is extraordinarily replayable and the cards and clans are well-balanced. Instead of other ersatz that have copied but never equaled StS, Monster Train has extracted the best from it to offer us a game just as addictive. Let yourself be tempted!

title: Monster Train
review: This is a great game. It's got plenty to love: the graphics are charming and interesting, the lore is sporadic (in a good way) and leaves you on the lookout for more. It has all the usual charm of a deckbuilder-slash-tower defense, but it doesn't seem to get dry or boring after multiple runs. The bosses are varied each time, and the different faction combinations bring unusual synergies to your deck. Plus the upgrading mechanic makes you feel like you're not just relying on pure RNG. I highly recommend this game if you like deck builders & tower defense, or even just general tower defense. After I saw Northernlion playing this on YT, I was hooked & bought it when it came out. Give it a try!

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like Slay the Spire and would like a new challenge, this could be it.

You manage a train in a tower defense style, single wagon with 4 floors. The objective is to beat every wave of ennemies without depleting your crystal at the top. 

Equipped with your deck of cards (monsters / spells), you have to carefully choose which units and spell to cast on each floor in order to create a perfect wall agaisnt different kinds of ennemies. 

You have to think about unit positionning, managing the space on your floors (which is limited) for said units, the mana required to cast your cards each turn, buffing or removing other cards from your deck and gathering artifacts giving you various buffs for your current run.

In the beginning, you have access to a limited amount of decks (each representing a type of monster) with a limited pool of cards. Everytime you play you unlock experience for the deck you chose which unlocks more cards.

The idea is to go as far as you can everytime, clawing a little more experience, until you can get a good idea of each deck's strengths and weaknesses. After a couple of hours, it will be easy to reach the last boss regularly. 
With a good understanding of each decks, you can start adding "covenant" diifficulties, which are 25 levels of harder and harder runs to challenge yourself (and golden version of your cards)


There are definitly some things to adjust, such as hero cards balance, some of those can make your run a breeze while others are just fodder in your deck while trying to find a strat.

If you are new to the game and want an easier path to victory in the beginning while figuring things out, definitly play Awoken, as the playstyle is very straightforward and the hero is very strong (compared to the Hellhorn one)

Some decks are harder to understand than others, but once you get a gist of the mechanics, you can craft winning strategies relatively fast.

Since I finished Slay the Spire, I wanted a new game to scratch that itch, and, so far, this has done the job

title: Monster Train
review:
Wow! All of the comparisons to Slay the Spire are actually true. As someone who has played his fair share of StS, I can say that there is no other game that comes close to scratching that same itch as Monster Train. And it adds a considerable amount of features to StS. In all of the best ways this game is like a combination of StS and Legend of Keepers but on four lanes.

Pros:
Solid deck customization
Deep mechanics
Fast gameplay
Loads of cards, upgrades, and artifacts

Cons:
Because of the emphasis on quick play, the game allows to to ramp up your power level incredibly fast. It is very easy to outpace the difficulty on lower settings. The game might reward intelligent decision making, but I can't tell as I have not even come close to losing. I will update this when I go through some of the higher difficulties. 

Given that I tend to like higher difficulty games, the fact that this will probably be my go to game for a while should tell you how great it is.

Update 5/26/2020: Wrote this after getting three straight wins. After a couple more playthroughs, I had to start focusing more heavily on strategizing around synergies in order to win. Working on my current highest difficulty setting, and it is a genuine challenge. The game a does a good job of giving me the feeling of drafting at FNM, and arguably, the RNG is a bit more fair than that until the last boss on a run.

title: Monster Train
review:
Truly one of the best games I've ever played - people will draw comparisons to StS, and yes, they do exist. However, I would say that rather than a pure clone, they took the best aspect of StS - having the game follow a set structure of rounds while still retaining the feel of being completely novel on every play-through while doing something completely different. 

At its essence, it is a rogue deck-building with champion-specific cards and interesting artefact permutations - again similar to StS - but the way it links to an almost RTS style of combat is extremely fun to play.

I remember playing the demo for four hours at an airport and finding myself sad when it ended, and checking every day for when the game was going to launch. Even with such high expectations leading into a purchase and a first real walk-through - I have not been dissapointed thus far.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a good mix of rogue like elements and a card battler. As you win and earn more cards, the game increases in challenge through various means. What is encouraging is that there are 5 card elements like MTG and you use two each run, one main and one sub faction. These combine to create very unique combos, most of which I have not seen obviously. 

The combat has interesting mechanics, some you will be familiar with and some not (think armor and regeneration etc) and you can create some godly monsters in this fashion. 

Early days but this is definitely a game that you can get your moneys worth, sink a lot of time into and is straight up a blast to play. The graphics are clean and interesting and overall would recommend this to anyone.

title: Monster Train
review:
The game has some really nice mechanical elements and I definitely agree that Slay the Spire fans will most likely enjoy it in some capacity or another. If you are coming from STS, give it at least 10 rounds before you make your initial judgement because the loop wasn't entirely clear at first to me until I understood it a bit more (both the deck building dynamics and the layered strategy.

I think my only issues with this game stem from the art style and the "narrative" decisions with a really wonky "Heaven vs. Hell" backdrop. It's not too heavy handed and there are some components of the art that grow on you, but this game could be presented in a million ways with these mechanics and I'm not necessarily sure this was the most effective route to go. I get that I'm being a snob and it is called "Monster Train" after all, but maybe I'm bummed about the aesthetic/narrative choices because the game is fun and that's the piece I get the most bored with. I may dislike the vibe of the art, but the execution is very good and clean.

For most gamers, I give it a very solid 8.5/10 on mechanics and overall execution but it's pretty much a 10/10 home run if you enjoy Slay The Spire but want something different.

Without it, no matter how fun the game is my interest drops. With this game there filling out the logbook is going to take a long time and I am going to love every minute of it. 

10/10

title: Monster Train
review:
Incredibly well polished for a game coming out of nowhere. Music is great. Gameplay is great. Synergy between factions is great. UI and multiplayer elements are great. It not only stands on the shoulders of giants of rogue-likes past (heavy emphasis on Slay the Spire), it vaults off and soars. I genuinely hope this game doesn't get ignored. 

The only weakness I can foresee would be a lack of proper scaling to keep it interesting after enough runs. I've only progressed through about 1/5 of the levels of difficulty available. I get the feeling the difficulty will ramp up at a reasonable level, and there is still tons of progression left in the way of unlocking new cards. There just needs to be a point that hits that perfect balance of "hard" and "rewarding". I have felt that the limited chances to add combat units to your deck can win or lose you a run depending on their quality. I will probably update this review if it plateaus hard, but for now I don't feel it.

Outside the above, I just hope to see more updates released for the game. New factions would be amazing, but there might not be huge amount of design space left. Re-balancing as things go, and new modes would also be great.

If you enjoy deck building rogue-likes. Or Darkest Dungeon. Or most other modern turn based strategy games I would highly recommend you pick this up

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster train is exactly what it looks like. It would be hard not to draw parallels with slay the spire, but the addition of a 2 dimensional play area really spices up the formula.

You are a hero of hell, on a train called the boneshaker, on a voyage to bring the last shard of Hell's pyre to unfreeze hell itself. You do this by playing units on one of three levels of your train, and playing spells to bolster your units and hurt or hinder your enemies.

Each run, you pick two factions (smash up style) to play together, and your primary faction determines your hero. Your hero is the quintessential unit of your faction, costs 0, and gets upgraded during your run. The two factions determine your starting spells, and which spells and units you'll see along the way.

The first three factions (all I've unlocked so far, though the unlock conditions are clearly presented) are essentially Magic: the Gathering's red, green, and blue colors. Red is all about units that get rage and armor, and direct damage spells. Green is all about big units and healing. Blue is all about manipulating and destroying your enemies via spells, and a stacking damage over time freeze.

I've played several runs (maybe 5-7 at this point?) and the game is super fun. When you win a run, every card in your final deck becomes gold bordered, so you can easily try new strategies on later runs.

I'd say the first few runs have been a tad easy so far, but that's probably from watching NL's videos and getting some knowledge ahead of time.

title: Monster Train
review:
The king is dead, long live the king.

We should salute Slay the Spire for being the first of its genre and defining the standards, but Monster Train outshines it by far in terms of gameplay, pacing, aesthetics and... fun. In fact, I'm uninstalling StS right now, because I for one welcome our new master. Exit the sadistic RNG, the stupid boss artifacts you have to refuse because they will f**k your run up and the murky fights spent waiting for an unfair death. 

Monster Train is smart and fair. Get it.

It works perfectly on Linux (thanks to Proton).

Most if not all cards do not feel fun to play. The balance between classes seem very imbalanced. There aren't enough synergies between classes to make the primary/secondary class mechanic interesting or fun, most of the time you skip secondary class cards. Most artifiacts feel bad and the ones that are good are always a no brainer.  

The replayability of this game is pretty low. It becomes repeitive very quickly. Either you highroll early or eventually run out of steam and lose.

title: Monster Train
review: This is an excellent and unique deck builder/tower defense game. Watch a streamer play it for a bit to get a grasp of it but it is worth the 25$ it costs when its not on sale. The negative reviews say 1. it gets stale, and my answer to that is that the genre isn't for everyone. 2. "it's too easy I won on my third try" if you've ever played Slay the Spire, it has "covenant" (ascension) levels where it gets harder the more you win. 3. "it wiped 3 hours of my game play" that is not a wide spread issue and it was 3 hours get over it. I'm sure they will do some fine tuning and add plenty of content in the future. My point is that the negative reviews were written by people who are so ignorant there is no way they'd have fun playing this game anyways.

Highly recommended for any remotely interested in deckbuilders.

review:
I've only played this six hours and I can say it is amazing.  I enjoyed Slay The Spire but this feels way more streamlined.  I felt like in StS there were just some garbage battles I didn't care for.  This game feels like fewer more ..."epic" battles.  

I don't know if i'll ever be "done" w/this game but I assume it'll get me well over 40 hours if not over 80.  I had 88 hours in StS and I didn't even beat the real last boss.  

I will say the graphics initially made me hesitant to buy this game...just wasn't for me.  That being said no review on youtube really captured what this game was for me.  You can always return it if you don't like it within two hours......but I don't see many people not liking it.  If you know you enjoy these type of card games this one is a must.

title: Monster Train
review:
Quite simply, this is a great game. While a comparison with Slay the Spire is inevitable this game functions quite differently and the way the mechanics play out is substantially different from other games in the overall deckbuilding genre.

A brisk and vividly imagined game where each run is concise enough to tackle in one sitting but varied enough to be engaging time after time. The factions in the game play substantially different and some cards that are typically dead weight have been made intriguing based on some incredibly creative design. In particular I thought how the Awoken faction implemented healing in a way that made simple creature heals potentially very powerful was quite interesting. While many familiar ideas are here, cards can be upgraded for example, their implementation is highly original and well crafted. On many other levels Monster Train is just a completely new take with elements of tower defense layered into a compelling strategic experience.

If you're a fan of deckbuilders at all you owe it to yourself to check this game out. The overall design, story, sound, music, and animation are all fantastic and serve as excellent trappings on top of a compelling and original game design. If you're new to deckbuilders this is an excellent introduction bristling with character and variety.

title: Monster Train
review: Okay, so this review is for people such as myself that have never played StS or other, i guess, roguelike/roguelite (no clue) games.  Also, not a big card game/deck building type of player, but this game is really fun.  Every single run through is different based on the buffs you might receive through artifacts, cards and power-ups you use on your cards.  I sat down after buying it and almost 4 hours of my life disappeared.  So for those of you whom are uninitiated to this type of game I highly recommend it or if you are looking for a way to cut down on food consumption, I recommend this as well; as you will forget to eat!  Great job devs and the price point is really a deal.  I have not done any online playing but even that looked promising with online dailies, etc.

review: Most of the top reviews already cover what makes this game great, but I wanted to make sure potential buyers knew that they have options to turn off the moving backgrounds and camera shake.

title: Monster Train
review:
Seriously, this game is addictive. I have played CCG games for decades. CCG games in video games have always been a bit hit or miss, but this one has all the right ingredients.

PROS:
* In depth game mechanics allow for basic and complex play as you get more comfortable with the system.
* In game card modification system adds an additional layer of strategy.
* Graphics create an atmosphere that is engaging and interesting at the same time.
* Learning curve is beautifully hidden to the point where you tend to learn as you go without knowing it.
* Scaling difficulty that you have to unlock as you progress making it feel like a reward to be challenged.
 
CONS
* Can not build decks before a run. Entire game is draft based deck building.
* Very few game modes making every run feel the same to play even though you're getting different things.
* RNG heavy while being draft based, this means an entire run can fall apart simply because the right cards never made an appearance.
* You can NOT create your deck in advance of a run.
* You can NOT influence what artifacts that your run will roll with.
* No ability to prepare before the run begins like most CCGs allow you to do.

I recommend this game in it's current state. However, if the DEVs would add a few more modes and modification options for runs, it would be much better. Such as; Arena Duels, Premade Decks, Starting artifact selection from your entire unlocked artifact collection. Just to name a few. Either way, if you love CCGs and don't mind playing a draft heavy game, then this game should be on your must play for 2020. Let's see how it holds up, but I can see this game becoming a cult classic with a following very quickly.

And also i like it that the gameplay doesn't just boil down to just tanking up enough to survive or not take damage and doing some offensive action with the little resources you have left. In this game being defensive and offensive is  intertwined. If you just get tanky stuff they can just walk past you towards your reactor (lifepool) and if you go too offensive the enemy might just take out all your resources before the final wave

From time to time when I play certain cards that generates a duplication effect such as a gorge ability or something and duplicate it with another spell my PC locks up entirely forcing me to hard reset. Other than that this game is extraordinarily enjoyable.

title: Monster Train
review:
Picked this game up due to its similarities with Slay the Spire. 

I do wish each run could have more battles, but I think the general time it takes for a single run is pretty well done.

I've played every clan and allied clan combination, and I have to say I'm impressed by how unique each clan feels in the game - and also how many different ways it feels you can build within that clan. I think my enjoyment of the Melting Remnant's burnout+reform playstyle tops anything I experienced in Slay the Spire.

I would like more customization when upgrading units and spells. Upgrades are pretty generic for spells, though there are a few cool effects for minions like multistrike and quick.

Overall, I would absolutely recommend this to anyone who enjoys Deck-Building Games. If you enjoy Slay the Spire, you have to own this game.

review:
So far so good. As many reviews have pointed out.. yes its like Slay the Spire but with a twist.

However, there is one fundamental aspect of this game I've discovered which this game does a lot better than StS, and it's the far more ample opportunity you have to remove cards from your deck in a playthrough. It allows you to keep your deck slim, build great synergies and experiment with ease as well, whereas in StS I found you could often be saddled up with dud/obsoleted cards and bloated decks.

I will add that I 'beat' the game on my 3rd run in a bit over 2 hrs, so I'm looking forward to the increasing challenges.

title: Monster Train
review:
I almost did not pay attention to this game when it was recommended to me. I thought it was about "training monsters" (especially with the tiny imp being the front left character in the logo). Still, I read a few reviews and watched some gameplay. Turns out this is a great variant on Slay the Spire (and all other such games). 

The game mechanics are similar yet different enough. There are some great quality of life features. The main one for me being the damage display. The boss has 2000 hitpoints vs your first row spike ability + regen + freeze combo? It will take 20 turns to sort out a winner, but you know exactly right from the start who will come out on top at the end. This allows you to focus on making the important decisions (make a stand on the first floor? Build up 2nd or 3rd floor?).

Great synergies between the various cards and factions. I have only unlocked one faction and maybe 55% of the cards for the first two factions. There are already plenty of interesting combinations. I'm only five hours in, but it's enough to know that this game has plenty to offer and a low frustration factor.

Overall seems to strike an excellent balance between control and randomness. 

I was not a fan of the art style initially, but every faction and creature has personality and the art has since grown on me. 

If you enjoy this type of game, this is one of the best. Worth it.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you in any way enjoyed Slay the Spire, think of this like an even crazier, zanier and more in depth game. The unique clans along with mixing a Primary and Secondary, create some extremely unique situations. The boss variety is...unfortunately not as strong but, it makes up for this with the clans and units that allow for far more variation in your build paths and types.

This game is an easy recommend from me in its current (May 25th 2020) state, and I'm excited for future content and balance shifts. Easily one of the best types of deck building, slaying action you can get. I wasn't sure I'd be able to recommend it over Slay the Spire but, after some time, I can easily say you OWE it to yourself to pick this up if you at all, enjoyed Slay the Spire. Stop reading this. Go play the game. No really...do it. Now.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is your classic roguelike deck builder in a similar vein to Slay the Spire.  I've sunk quite a few hours in a very short time and feel it's worth the cost so far.

There is enough different in here to other similar games to make it fresh but it is quite familiar to others in the genre.  You start off with a vanilla style deck and will over the course of stages upgrade, thin out and refine your deck to a hopefully well oiled machine to tackle the end game boss.  The unique factors are the tower defense style play.  You have multi level train and enemies ascend to the top.  You choose units and utilise spells to whittle them down before they get to your pyre (hit bar) at the top.The card upgrade system is very satisfying allowing you to tailor make cards to suit their situation.  I definitely feel that early  to mid game there are interesting choices beyond thin out bad and collect good cards.

Right now there are four factions and you jam two together to define the card pool available to you. There are daily challenges and  challenge maker to keep things fresh.  I suspect in time I will find the game become repetitive ( no more so than others in the genre) but I'm not sure when that will happen.

Great soundtrack and decent graphics.  If you are a fan of the genre it is worth your time.  If you are dipping your toe in the matter for deck builders then this is a decent choice and I would say grab either Slay the Spire or this depending which is on sale.

review: Slay The Spire is still the definitive roguelike deckbuilder, but Monster Train has some fun twists on the genre that make it worth a look. Getting to play with ten different combinations of five clans gives the game a lot more immediate diversity and replayability, and the three-tiered combat systems gives the game some extra turn-by-turn tactical play, but I haven't played nearly long enough to know if it has the strategic depth that has made Slay The Spire such an enduring classic.

title: Monster Train
review:
You will lose track of time while playing this game! I somehow logged 21 hours in just two days and loved every moment of it. I feel like it's obvious that this is aimed toward fans of Slay the Spire, but this is the first game since StS that actually feels like an evolution of the genre rather than just a clone.

My favorite feature hands down is the faction / ally faction system. It is a clever way to add a lot of variety to runs while keeping the number of cards low enough to allow the devs to balance things well. Additionally, I feel like there are a lot of opportunities for player skill to compensate for bad RNG. It is still a card game, so the element of chance is very central to the game (as it should be); however, one bad draw isn't going to spell the end of your run nearly as often as it might in some other games.

review:
This is definately a worthy successor to Slay the Spire.

This isnt a clone trying to capitalise on the success of what came before.  It takes the premise and builds on it in its own unique way.

title: Monster Train
review:
Great deck building game with its own unique twists! I view it as almost Slay the Spire meets tower defense - easy to enjoy this game if you love either of these genres. 

Pros:
- Pick 2 out of 5 interesting factions. The factions have strong archetypes and unique champions, e.g. tanky, spellcasty, which allows you to create synergies within and between them. 
- Tower defense twist to it, where you have to stop monsters from reaching your 'heart' while striking a balance between offense and defense. 
- Fun power spikes. No boring upgrades like '+1 to attack' here, every upgrade can easily boost your deck strength by 20%, 50% or 100%. Yet somehow, the game is still balanced, it doesn't ever becomes too easy. 
- Fun game play. Just a lot of fun, everything is at the right pace, animations are fun to watch, game play loop is satisfying!

Suggestion
- Will be great to make it faster to unlock factions. I've won 3 runs with the 3 factions I unlocked, but still only 2/3 way to unlocking the 4th faction, and 1/3 to unlocking the 5th.

title: Monster Train
review: Seemingly simple at a glance, deceptively complex. Unique planning needed with the format of the train levels, infinite potential strategies, customizable cards to fit your playstyle, 5 clans to choose from that can be mixed and matched. The game is made for replayability and due to the sheer number of possibilities as you gather more cards and difficulty levels, it has yet to feel repetitive. Depending on what relics, cards, customizations, and just luck on any given run, each and every playthrough is vastly different than the last. When I looked at the game I was hesitant that it may be just another half baked, childish card game not worth the time. As it turns out, it is one of the best card games ive had the pleasure of playing. I think the best part is that even if what ive described sounds daunting, know that it isnt. The game is easy to pick up and pre planning goes out the window as soon as the game begins. It isnt a game that makes you prepare in advance, rather, you adjust to the cirumstances youre given. Cannot recommend it enough for those who enjoy strategy.

I just unlocked the 5th class after ~10-15 hours, and I haven't even turned on the hard mode yet (looking forward to it, once I figure out a couple class combos that I love). Whoever made this game should pat themselves on the back and relax with a nice cold beer. You deserve it.

review: Great game, very quick to pick up especially for people who have some basic level experience with other card games. title: Monster Train
review:
A really great game about card management and deck building, though I wish there was more layers to delve through in a run outside of the 9. I do really like the clans, but feel like some could use some work, especially with how their Clan leaders are. 

Below is my very amateur take on the clans and the mechanics they have.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hellhorned: Overall the worst Clan, victory can really only be found through having big heavy units and getting armor cards. They get Rage (Flat Armor Buff), Armor (Buffer to defense), and Imps (units that give lil effects when summoned). Their faction leader is so dang soft...it makes it hard for him to build up to get even better so those armor cards are really necessary, which is tough when there's than random factor of what you get card wise. 


Awoken: Big beefy plant folks, they get benefits when they are healed. Their faction leader is only good at being a buffer compared to their units which get massive stats when healed. They get spikes (deal damage a set amount when hit) and regenerate (heal a certain amount at the end of turn). Their Faction Leader is a wall, straight up. Gets some benefits from heal with one of her specializations, but I really think spikes are the way to go considering pretty much ALL the late bosses have multi-attack.

Stygian: Aquatic Folk with the powers of frost, discard, and spellpower! Really strong when they get spell cards. With actual spell damage. Otherwise, their discard mechanic is heavily dependent on getting discard cards to trigger them, otherwise they are too expensive. Can get really strong with their innate "incant" ability which gives them buffs when a spell is cast on their floor. 3rd best Clan, their leader is so so soft though...ONE FELL SWEEP and it's over. Oh and spell weakness is really strong. Honestly, the buffs they get with their faction leader and how the group synergizes with spells so well make them so good. 

Umbra: Shadowy folks with the Gorge and Morsel mechanic. You put a unit in the front and stuff morsels behind them! BOOM unit gets bigger and triggers their gorge ability at the end of the turn. Their faction leader is the strongest. 2nd best.

Waxen: The best Clan, with the mechanics of Extinguish ( which triggers an ability when a unit dies), Burnout (which causes the unit to automatically die when the counter reaches 0), and Reform(Revive a unit with a burnout counter on it). Their leader can get any of those 3 abilities and it's super easy to trigger the mechanics. Strongest and most versatile leader, AND their units are the only ones who get access to stealth with some of their card abilities. They got beefy units, strong units, and overall have the best synergy with one another. Your run won't suffer if you happen to have a mixed team. Only problem is that you've gotta kill 1300 enemies to unlock it.

title: Monster Train
review:
A brilliant roguelike that can be best described as an equal part mix of 
- Slay the Spire, 
- Darkest Dungeon,
and a Tower Defence game.

It is fast, has deep mechanics that combo of each other, and a lot of replayability value even by the genre standards.

If you liked ANYTHING mentioned so far, chances are, you are going to enjoy this game. There is really no point in enumerating this game's pros, since it got A LOT of things very right. From designs, to artstyle, lore, clan combos, difficulty scales, sound design (morsels are wonderful), gameplay systems -- see what I mean? The list just keeps going.

Monster Train does not have many cons, and the ones that it has are minor at best. In fact, I have only managed to think of two so far:
- The game ramps up too fast. You can go from hitting for 2-5 damage on round 1 to a 35х2 multihits by as early as round 2. I really enjoy gradual progression in these types of games more than an abrupt leap.
- Due mostly to the first con, the runs are very short. It lacks this epic feeling of "I've been building this deck for a long time and now I am finally ready". 

Hopefully these two can get annihilated with some content patches or DLC, 
until then it is still a solid 9.4/10

Looking forward to playing a lot more.

title: Monster Train
review:
Most of the time the game plays out like a card game.  You play your hand of cards, a round of combat happens, and then monsters progress like in a tower defense game.  This was a pretty good idea and it feels balanced and interesting.

But then for boss fights, they use a completely different system.  You play your hand once, and then the combat auto battles until one side loses.  Essentially any hand-based strategy you'd want to do is pointless after about the first boss, because nothing scales as well as smearing as many buffs on your guys as possible.  To succeed you must spend every round building up one lane that can win a boss fight without your input.

Ultimately it doesn't feel like you have nearly as many options as when playing what I consider the better entries in this genre.  This game is ok, and the production quality is high, but I'm done with it after 14 hours and don't see myself playing again.  This is worth grabbing on sale if you've already played out Slay the Spire and Monster Slayers.  Otherwise spend your time and cash on those first.

title: Monster Train
review:
Yes, this game is very much like slay the spire, but it's not a direct clone even though I will compare it to StS for this review. StS set the stage for many other games to try to copy it and i think this is one of the only 2 games out there to do it successfully. (the other is Griftlands, in my opinion) This game has an entirely different playstyle and pacing. You are not one singular character, like in StS. and the health you must manage to survive is not the health of one of the units on the battlefield, but instead it's your train's "heart". You essentially summon minions and cast spells to slow and kill the enemies advancing to your train's heart. 

Some of the big differences in this game is that the runs you play through are quicker and more standardized with pacing. The process of a run is 8 battles where you get a set amount of events/shops to edit your build/deck in between each battle. Unfortunately you usually won't be able to perfect a deck like you can in slay the spire due to a lot less time tweeking your deck to perfection. (I'm hoping they change this in the future) However, this game still has all the great things that make a really good deckbuilding experience like: card upgrades, artifacts/relics, permanent unlocks for future runs, ascension/covenant levels, different class options, etc.

Some really nice things this game has that many other games of this genre don't have is modular card upgrading, which allows interesting combinations,  a lot of custom game options, and the really fun one, multiplayer "stuff". When I say multiplayer"stuff" I mean it has a way to do the exact same run with other people in real time, so you guys will get all the exact same options but compete to see who made the better choices, you can also do this after you had a really cool single player run, just copy and paste a url type thing to a friend and they can replay a run you did previously and try to do better than you.

Overall I think this game is REALLY good, and I highly recommend people buy it and try it if you enjoy StS or deck builders in general.

Notes to the devs if they read this: really great game I think adding more variation options to events/card upgrades could go a long way. Also, it feels too simple to upgrade cards to golden after 1 single win, maybe have multiple upgrades you unlock after a certain number of wins with the card? for instance: golden card after 1 win then new card chroma/color after 25 wins, new card art after 50 wins, etc. Also in order to upgrade starter cards you need to keep at least like 2 or 3 in the deck all the way to the end to show you actually "mastered" it. And of course, as with every other great game in the deckbuilding genre...... add more cards/classes..... will pay cold hard cash for more content. I really think you guys have great grounds for dlc pack of additional classes. And of course don't stop adding new stuff to original classes and neutral cards/artifacts.

I had not heard anything about this game at all and bought it only because it was topping the Steam charts, something I don't normally do, and let me say it was a great decision.

At first it feels a bit to easy, but once you climb the ranks a bit you'll realize it is quite a challenge.

title: Monster Train
review:
Wow. Bought this two days ago and already 19 hours playtime clocked. It's midnight right now, but I think I need to make this review now.

This game is crazy good. It's a roguelite deckbuilder with unit placement strategy, upgrading and meta-progression elements. None of these things are things we have not seen before. Indeed, when I first loaded up Monster Train the garish, hyperactive art style reminded me of a hundred god-awful free-to-play mobile games. I went in with fairly tepid expectations.

19 hours. I've played 19 hours in two days.

I think I'll try to list the things that I love about Monster Train so far:

- YouTube's Sir Swag once said of the great mob-dunking simulator Warframe "No one can be overpowered, if everyone is overpowered.". Monster Train allows you to obtain seemingly ludicrously overtuned units to place into battle, and then allows you to enhance those units even further until you seriously start to wonder how they could ever be killed. The game then allows you to enjoy the min-max bliss for just the right amount of time before it starts throwing its own godlike behemoths at you. Somehow this system of countering bonkers with bonkers feels challenging but not unfair, empowering but not exploitable.

- The game has a pathway system between battles, similar to Slay the Spire, but with important differences. Between each battle, you only ever have two pathways to choose from, but this is an improvement on the formula in my opinion. Each pathway has 2-3 excellent ways of buffing your team, thinning out your deck, improving your spells, obtaining powerful artifacts (Spire relics), gaining gold, you name it. Very rarely will there be an obvious choice which way to go - you will want to go BOTH directions. But you can't. Sorry. This self-contained method of progressing within a given run prevents needless "scouting" of your route, and keeps the game flowing.

- Meta progression in this game is off the chart. There's too much going on for me to even summarise here, but essentially when you finish a run your brain will scream ONE MORE DADDY ONE MORE and you'll say okay babe and then it'll be one in the morning and you've got work.

Okay that'll do. The only thing I dislike so far with this game is that the audio can get exhausting after a while, especially if you are playing on any speed above normal. The characters, particularly the bosses, utter the same vocal outburst every single time they get hit by an attack, and they get hit by a LOT of attacks. But whatever.

Do you like deckbuilders? Buy buy buy.

title: Monster Train
review:
My vote for the best game of it's kind!

The emergent "Deck Crawler" genre is most popularized by Slay the Spire, though personally I consider that sort of near the middle of the couple dozens games out right now (production values in StS are fantastic, don't get me wrong, but the card game is good rather than great, really). It's a real "Shut up and take my money" niche for games in my book, and there's steep competition near the top of the pile for my affections, with games like Nowhere Prophet, Chrono Ark, and Gordian Quest making competitive cases for my stop spot...

At least they did, because I feel like Monster Train just blew every other game in the genre out of the water for me.

Oh man, this game is so good, I don't even... I'm gonna have to bullet point this so I don't gush past the review character limit

- The game involves a mechanic to modify individual cards in your deck. You can really strategically run wild with novel combinations of traits in this sort of system, but to date, other games I've seen try is largely faceplanted because it was too difficult to balance these mechanics... Monster Train is the first game I've seen not only make it work, but nail it in a deeply satisfying way.

- Balance and difficulty is always an issue in these games, and Monster Train takes the approach of "It everything is overpower, than nothing is unfair". You can make so many busted combinations in your own deck it's headspinning, just "it feels like I'm cheating" with how severely you can break mechanics... thing is, you NEED to do that, because the later bosses are JUST as relentlessly unfair and over-powered... you WILL NOT beat Fel or Seraph without some form of exploit, so "Break the game" is built into the game due to a difficulty curve that would be unrelentingly savage if you don't... Even then, you'll be surprised how often a deck that feels unstoppable can suddenly lose due to a complex misplay... with 25 difficulty levels (apparently, I'm not very far into them), if you ever feel like things are too easy, the upscaling of challenge is quite high... it's an excellent balance of rewarding high strategy, being approachable for more casual players, but offering a huge difficulty cieling to hardcores. 

- The game involves doing runs with a modular 2-faction deck, similar to card games like Smash Up... but whereas the biggest difficulty I find with those cardgames IRL is seperating the decks after every game, it works excellent in this digital format. The faction choice influences the two halves of your starting deck, what cards will be available to gain in play, what traits will crop up to add to those cards, what passive-granting relics will crop up, and your "main" faction will even grant you a powerful "Champion" unit that costs 0 mana to play and starts in your opening hand each fight, which will eventually "Evolve" down a tree to 1 of 10 final forms, which will likely be utterly crucial to your strategy in most runs.

- The 5 factions all have a few themes connected to them... Umbra are ramp, sacrifice for buildup, and X-Cost; Horned Devils offer aggressive attack units, direct damage, and on-kill effects; Awakened have ample healing, defense as the best offense tactics, and units that have lot of potential for enhancement; Stygians synergize incredibly well with spellcasting and can dish out savage damage via debuffs; and the Remnants offer rapid minion spawning, deck thinning, and sacrifice effects. Any of these factions can chose to focus on just one or two of their mechanics, and of course you have two faction sets to choose from... this makes replay value almost staggering, as Remnant/Awakened, Stygian/Remnant, and Awakened/Stygian are likely to look UTTERLY different from one another in terms of strategy for a run. 

- The game prides itself on a mechanic of having multiple floors you need to defend, forcing you to make calculated decisions about where to place units so as to best use your resources and minimize weak spots in your defenses. This is probably the LEAST interesting of the innovations to me, but it is novel and works well... The implication of it I like more is that it creates a game of 9 long battles rather than dozens of short ones... which sounds unpleasant at first blush, but actually works well... rather than choose paths of "Fight/Treasure/Camp/Shop", every match WILL be 9 battles, and you get an "Intermission" of the other things in between each, making your choice "Do I want to enchance spells, cull cards, and heal; or would a random relic, an event, and unit enhancement be better for me right now?" and so on. It makes an interesting "preparation phase" between each combat... the "One more turn" effect is so REAL here, after every fight, you want to do the prep phase to check your spoils, after every test phase, you want to do another fight to test out your new tricks.

- Production qualities are solid... the graphics are charming, but more relevantly, the soundtrack was downright impressive... there's a lot more tracks than you tend to see in these games, and I REALLY liked the majority of them... I usually put on a podcast while doing dozens of hours in these games, I tend to just listen to the OST with this one.

On some level, it's hard for me to even know what to say reguarding why you should buy this game... it feels like a no-brainer. If you're into strategy, board/card games, roguelites, and DEFINITELY if you're into deck crawlers, you really MUST try it, it's the best game of it's kind to date.

title: Monster Train
review:
Love it!  This is a visually pleasing, strategically deep, deck builder.  I can't recommend it hard enough to anyone who likes those words, especially strung together!

This game will get a lot of comparisons to Slay the Spire, as a video game deck builder.  I've played quite a number of them recently, and this game is by far the best spiritual successor to Slay the Spire.

This isn't a clone.  If you are coming from Slay the Spire, take note:

Choose your upgrades.  Card's don't upgrade in just one way.  You choose how to upgrade each card, when upgrading.

Your deck is a mash up of two factions, chosen at the beginning of the run.  Your deck will contain cards from each of these two factions, allowing for dynamic games.

Each run _starts_ differently.  In StS, your run starts with a minor change based on what you choose from the whale.  Here, you are given random cards to your deck which will help shape your decisions going forward.  (starting with ascension 1).

"You" aren't the one doing the fighting.  You summon creatures to lanes, while trying to protect your health.  In this way, it's more akin to a tower defense game.  

Each room, you can chose to increase the difficulty for better rewards. 

---

In conclusion.  Buy this game.

title: Monster Train
review:
The game has 5 clans and a run consists of a primary clan backed up by another one which results in 20 clan combinations (the two starting clans have to be different) and that`s only the beginning. Each clan has a champion with 3 possible evolution paths and it evolves 3 times during a run which again adds to the variety of the run. When you add on top of that a large number of clan cards and shops that can upgrade those cards along the way and artefacts that actually influence the run, you get huge replay value.

The game also has daily challenges and a "multiplayer" where multiple people start the same run and everyone has to play against the clock and the winner is the one with the most points. 

Also, the game is very polished and the UX is for the most part very good. I`m struggling to find negatives for this game, but one of them would be the unintuitive interaction between spell shield and damage shield with some spells, artefacts and effects. Another example would be how silence and “remove enemy buff” effects are again not what I was expecting them to be. These negatives are really minor and can be figured out with trial and error, but I couldn`t come up with other negatives.

title: Monster Train
review:
I purchased this game on the day of release without having heard of it before the day it showed up in my Steam queue.

Monster Train is a deck building rogue-like. Expect to play through the game many times (this isn't a bad thing). Here's how it works: You'll choose a primary and secondary faction to join you in your quest to protect your demon train as it travels through the tracks on its way to relight the pyres of hell. At each stop you'll face a boss and its minions. You'll play cards to bring out minions of your own. The object of each level is to keep the angelic minions from reaching the top of the train and destroying the last pyre of hell.

Okay, it may sound a touch confusing, but it's super easy to learn.

If you like deck building games, as I do, you'll probably like Monster Train. Each game can take up to an HOUR to play through, so it's similar to a digital board game in many respects. Maybe you make it to the pyres and relight them, probably you'll get killed by Fel ... or that ass with the bombs. But you WILL have fun along the way.  I've played it ever day since I picked it up and I've been having a blast.  I hope you do too!  #Recommend

title: Monster Train
review:
This is my first ever review. 
I feel cheated by all the positive reviews for this game but mostly because of the price tag. 
*I have edited this review based on what people have commented. I also want to point that this is my opinion of the game. If you like, great. Keep playing. I found it a little stale. 

The game is far too easy (beat it on my 2nd try, and then again very easily on Covenant 1 and Covenant 2) and using the only viable strategy I found to win. Boss fights work by having the boss constantly attack on each level until your units or the boss dies. This means to win you need units that can take a punch with a damage unit behind it.
There is only one final boss and all the fights are always the same making this game stale very quick. I didn't bother to unlock much (unlocked other races and a few cards) as this game got boring in about 6 hours. 

The lack of variety and the game play isn't necessarily bad. Actually the game is fun but not at the current cost. This game is worth maybe $10 for the content and replay value.

title: Monster Train
review: Slay the Spire, but you're a train. Absolute banger.

title: Monster Train
review:
It's Slay the Spire in many regards, except instead of a mission to try and defeat an evil Spire, you are delivering a burning Pyre to reignite the flames of Hell. I do feel like Slay the Spire is the more elegant, timeless game of the two, but Monster Train has a lot going for it in terms of build diversity with the varied clans and their synergies. It takes many notes from it's predecessor, and while in some regards it does things worse, in many ways it offers some interesting new ideas, like upgrading cards and the multi-floor strategic layer. Monster Train may be a bit more cluttered in it's design, but it is definitely scratching the same itch as Slay the Spire. 

RNG is still king here, but in many ways I feel it's a bit more manageable. Runs are not super long in general, and the graphics and sound design are top notch. It warms by cynical heart that the goal of the game is to save Hell from oblivion, and that the 'Winged' (aka Angels) who have frozen Hell over are depicted in such a dark manner. The lore tidbits attached to cards make for an interesting read, something I feel StS lacks. I do hope future games in the genre take notes from some of the design choices made here. There have been quite a lot of these roguelite card games of late, but this is the one of the few that I feel moves the genre forward somewhat. Highly recommended.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is a beast : Best game since STS.
It's different, yet really funny.
You get 5 differents classes and start with 2 (which allows a lot of combination).
You get gamebreaking events, ascension difficulties : everything a great roguelike cards has.

I'm 15 hours into this game and I feel like I'll be playing around 100+ hours, like STS.

Multiplayer could use some upgrade since it does not reward you anything to win. Don't play this game for multiplayer, just a tip :).

Good job Devs! Finally a game that lives up to STS !

title: Monster Train
review: If slay the spire and trains had a baby

title: Monster Train
review:
For a long time I was waiting for a worthy Slay the Spire successor - something that will finally scratch that itch, something close enough and good enough that will give me that StS fix, but also new and fresh enough.

Finally, it arrived in a Monster Train of all things. This is it, and it's great. Similar in many ways, but also definitelly different. 11 hours in I'm hooked.

While many aspects feel very familiar - like drawing cards and using energy to play those in your hand, discarding, exhausting; ways of gaining energy, healing, blocking; events with choices that are not always obvious, some risk/reward; attacking enemies, giving buffs, debuffs, status effects etc. synnergies and combinations that can sometimes get broken (as in, op)...
While all that familiarity, there is a main fresh aspect in having 3 train rooms, from bottom to top where you put your minions to protect and fight enemies (spawning on the other side), cast spells etc. and final room with pyre (your final health) to protect. A little tower defense twist that makes a big difference.
So fighting feels pretty distinct, and it works.
Also the ammount of content seems to be pretty big: after 11 hours of gameplay, I have only 3 clans unlocked out of 5, none of the clans have all the cards unlocked yet and I have seen less than half of relics (here called artefacts).

On the downside, contentwise - there appear to be less fights and bosses compared to StS, but still there are some random variants that are different from playthrough to playthrough.
Not to mention multiplayer that I have not even touched, so all in all I feel I'm getting more than mu monyes worth, as at 11 hours I am only on thebeginning of this Monster Train journey that is just very fun. There is many strategies and tactics to be discovered, cards and artefacts to unlock, covenant levels to climb (StS ascention counterpart - 25 levels here of increasing difficulty.

And did I mention that everytging looks beautiful, with good music and high degree of polish? 
At this point, I can't tell if this game is great, or only very good - I'll need to spend much longer with it to discover if it will stand the test of time, the way Slay the Spire did, being still fun and interesting after hundrets of hours.
But as it looks now, Monster Train seems like the best candidate to reach this level. I am going to enjoy finding this out.
