Duplicating OP cards just makes things even more silly, but it is fun to ROFLStomp the computer, I must admit. So, to sum up, great fun, great graphics, needs balancing, and maybe a few more levels.

Hellhound + stygian support

title: Monster Train
review:
I'm not usually a fan of deck-building games, as I don't like relying on luck or card counting to get results. That said, I've found this to be quite fun. It's easy to just say "one more run" and then be up until 3:00 in the morning. 

Compared to Slay the Spire and other games in that vein, I like that the map isn't overly convoluted/complex. Each level gives you a choice of two paths, which makes it easy to weigh the pros & cons of your choice. I also enjoyed the layered train car, which adds an extra layer of strategy to laying out your creatures & spells. Each battle gives you all the information you need without cluttering the UI, and the boss encounters are basically a countdown, adding their own interesting complications to the fight. 

All in all, I'm having a lot of fun with this, and I'm looking forward to discovering the depths of this game.

This card game does so many things right.

title: Monster Train
review: Wow, what a refreshing take on this genre. The card element of Monster Train is integrate so seamlessly into the other aspects of the gameplay that if I were to describe this quickly to someone, I might forget to mention that it's technically a deckbuilder. On paper this is a lot like slay the spire, sure, but the multiple layers of the train are strangely akin to Artifact, and the presentation is much more elegant than slay the spire's map and icons. Highly recommend, I can see myself putting many more hours in.

title: Monster Train
review:
Gameplay is solid, a very high quality deckbuilding experience akin to Slay the Spire.

Multiplayer worked fine from what I've played, it is a real-time time attack mode against other players.

I haven't ran into any gamebreaking bugs so far, and haven't spotted any text/tooltip errors.

My only complaint so far is that once you start climbing difficulty levels, there is a nonzero chance you may just have to immediately restart a game if unsynergistic cards are added into your starting deck.

Also possibly a pro or a con, getting a win usually involves some kind of absurd stat scaling.
One game I was able to stack 16 double spell damage debuffs to one shot the final boss, another time I stealthed my main team for 20 turns, so I could kill the bosses undetected.

Nevertheless, if you enjoy deckbuilder games I highly recommend this game.

What are you waiting for? Get on the hype (monster) train.

Looking forward to content updates in the future.

title: Monster Train
review: As a big fan of Slay the Spire I felt right at home with the game loop.  It adds the ideas of multiple levels of battlefield and creatures you summon to battle the opponent's creatures in a wave-structure.  The slow deckbuilding elements combined with a very clear risk-vs-reward mentality make for a truly enjoyable game.  When you get a reward there's always the option to take some amount of gold instead which is really nice coming from StS where often you only get the choice to add to your deck or skip a reward.  More to the point after unlocking everything StS had to offer I'm loving starting over with Monster Train unlocking new cards and loot for future runs!

title: Monster Train
review:
Good game, definitely, but has some significant differences from Slay the Spire (which is fine).  The card upgrades become much more significant as they do not provide a linear increase in power curve (like they do in Slay the Spire), but a much more dramatic step change.    These are still necessary to move forward, which means that the power curve of the enemies is much more dramatic than it is in Slay the Spire.  This isn't necessarily a problem, but it results in progression feeling a bit odd at times.

The other issue I have is that the game simply doesn't feel that long.   A single run is only 10-15 battles I think?  That's significantly less than what you would find in Spire.   I think this may be related to the power curve, because, if they let you progress much farther there would be no chance of maintaining balance.

Again, I think it's a good game, but I don't think it will have the immense level of replayability that Slay the Spire does.

title: Monster Train
review:
A tower-defense, turn-based, rogue-like game inspired by Slay the Spire where you need to think carefully about unit placement, play-style (Big Magic DPS, stacking stats e.t.c) and overall the choices you make in order to re-kindle the flames of hell.

Things I love about this game is that although you move from area to area, gaining strength and adding/upgrading spells and units, is that you don't necessarily feel weak straight from the start (but maybe this will change as I climb the difficulty levels);
- Given random cards from the 2 factions you choose initially (making every experience feel somewhat unique)
- The variety of playstyles from needing to choose 2 out of 5 factions.
- The system that calculates damage taken, dealt and if units will die (numbers get big and rather than trying to calculate everything, you can focus more on decisions you need to make such as sacrificing or losing pyre health).
- The pyre being able to attack is a quirky feature.
- Thinking my deck is overwhelming and then being overwhelmingly crushed by the Seraph.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like slay the spire, then getting this game is a no brainer. The developers have no qualms about the fact that this game was inspired by slay the spire (going as far as offering a 20% discount for STS owners at launch), but has a huge number of variations to make it a different game on its own. There is an extra element of strategy involved in unit placement (borrowed from tower defence games) which can make or break your run. In one of my runs, I got destroyed by a boss because I forgot that he can directly climb from floor 3 to floor 1 and floor 2 had my most powerful units. Apart from this, there are 5 clans at launch, with a number of cards to unlock and get this, you get to play not as 1, but as 2 clans at the same time, which means that there are 20 combinations possible. 
The game seems fairly balanced and you can customise cards depending on your run, during the course of the run. How many times have you thought, in STS, man do I wish this card cost 1 energy less, well, you can do that in this game. With some card combinations it's possible to breeze through the run, only to have the game kick you in your balls and tell you bitch, you ain't shit. 
To summarise, this game is STS but with tower defence and crack.

title: Monster Train
review:
Love this game and totally having a blast playing it! If you enjoy deck building games (think Slay the Spire) or even games like Magic The Gathering, you will probably enjoy this one. 

Lots of combinations or "clans" to choose from, each with their own set of creatures, spells and potential artifacts. Every clan has an obvious 3-4 mechanics to center around, with many more possible due to the flexible upgrade system for creatures and spells.  

Want to buff up your imp army? DONE! Want to sit back and have creatures destroy themselves attacking you? That works too! Like to smash face with big, powerful demons? Of course, who doesn't? Prefer slinging spells? CHECK!

Nice mechanics, graphics and very polished. Looking forward to what comes with more DLC. This game is already worth it and has a TON of future potential.

title: Monster Train
review:
First off, if you already own StS and haven’t bought this game, what are you doing? Go and buy it! It’s extra discounted for Slay the Spire owners! 

Anyways, I got the game today by finding it on the “roguelite” section of steam. I ended up playing the game for 9 straight hours...of course with some food and bathroom breaks. I’m just happy a game can get me this hooked the way StS does without being a clone of it. 

My favorite additions to this game if we compare it more to StS is that you choose two factions/characters at a time instead of one, so you can mix and match combinations and builds. 

You are guaranteed upgrades and bonuses before each fight instead of going back to back fights with no resting period. This doesn’t make the game easier though. 

Finally, off the top of my head of cool additions, you get a champion creature that depends on which faction is your main one and you can buff them throughout the run.

Had a great deck but got screwed on last fight by a +3 sap debuff on units when summoned AND the boss applying the same debuff as it's special ability. If the dev reads this, pls remove 1 of the debuffs or make the debuff a +1 sap instead and keep both. It is borderline impossible to beat. On the plus side, this combo only happened 1 out of my 10 runs so far so it's not extremely likely as far as I can tell. title: Monster Train
review:
I actually think its better than Slay the Spire.

The added layer of 'tower defense' strategy adds a lot to the gameplay itself. The runs are just long enough, and decks usually become cohesive by the end, even if it isn't the direction you originally thought it would go. I've never felt totally screwed when it comes to RNG, except with a specific encounter when playing Umbra late game. The clan system is genius, and I would absolutely pay for a clan dlc, since even a single one would add so much depth to the game. Though the bosses don't change, their modifiers do, so its usually important to take note before getting a deck going, so you know what you'll be up against. Some may see this as a problem, but I take no issue with the bosses, as the tactics used to approach them usually differs. 

My only suggestion would be a victory lap of some sort. The decks always seem to come together right at the final boss, or the floor before, so it would be fun to play with it a bit longer before having to end the run.

Thoroughly enjoying my time playing Monster Train so far. Monster Train is actually a fair bit different to Slay the Spire, with Monster Train mixing it up with some fresh takes on the genre, notably the multi floor combat and unit management.

review:
A fantastic new twist on the Slay-The-Spire genre. Focused on building a small evolving army rather than a single hero traversing a dungeon. 

The game features a wild array of unique monster archetypes: Everything from rapidly suiciding units, to monsters who eat their teammates, to spell slinging nukers, to armored behemoths. Each archetype plays out in vastly different ways and requires a very distinct mindset and deck build to pull off.

In addition to the standard randomized daily mode for score, you can share and be ranked on friend's customized seeds, and there's also a true multi-player mode called Hell Rush which really puts the pressure on in a live head to head dungeon race for up to 8 or so players, which is fantastic for a group of friends.

review: As with Slay the Spire, Monster Train has a fantastic difficulty level and run length. You can make it harder if you want to however. title: Monster Train
review:
This is basically Slay the Spire in another skin, and that's a good thing!
Okay, okay, to be fair, the combat in this game is a bit unique, as you have 3 layers of combat field and a heart to defend, so it's more like Slay the Spire + Artifact. Still, you build a deck, decide what goodies to pick up, you create synergies or at least you hope you do, etc. etc. - a roguelike deck builder.

There's a fair amount of replay value and I really like the combat to deck building ratio. In Slay the Spire, you often just get stuck in a string of 3-4 fights back-to-back when you just want to get to the next ? room. In Monster Train, you get to do these miscellaneous stuff after each and every fight, guaranteed and with how long the fights are, I feel like this is paced perfectly. Quantity wise, I think there's more cards to mix and experiment with than StS, but slightly less miscellaneous stuff like mystery rooms and artifacts (which are this game's equivalent of StS' relics).

The production values are particularly noteworthy, everything is crisply animated and well drawn. On the flipside, the music does not grab me whatsoever. It's a game about a fantasy Hell army riding a train through hell to fight some angel and instead of some kind of powerful metal or what-have-you, there's just a random, whimsical fairy tale soundscaping going on and it doesn't have anything memorable. The voices are kind of phoned in, too, and one particular winged angel boss will make your household think you're blasting porn on your PC with maxed volume.

All in all, if you liked Binding of Isaac and Ascend the Spire, this is a must play for you. Though it doesn't reinvent the wheel or blow your mind, it doesn't have to, because it's good.

I've been playing on Covenant 25 (which is this game's equivalent of Ascension 20 in Spire). Maybe it's easier. I haven't decided yet. There's so much more to learn. It's one of those "Learn it in a few minutes, master it in a few hundred/thousand hours" deals.

If you're into strategy games and deckbuilders, I can't recommend this game highly enough.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train is a Rogue-Like deck building with elements of a tower defense game. Hell has frozen over, can you take it back?

Monster Train utilizes RNG to distribute its many cards to the player after encounters/events. The unique take of Monster Train is that you can choose what two clans of units you can see throughout your run. This leaves up to 20 different variations of builds that can be tried out.

There are 5 types of clans, which can be described if anyone has played Magic The Gathering (MTG) as such.

The Clans Are as Such:
 1. Hellhorned 

The Hellhorned playstyle is based on aggression, cards are heavy hitters with low health. However some card effects may grant armor to combat the low health. This would be compared to playing White or Red decks in Magic.

 2. Awoken

You like to build up tank units and make the enemy kill themselves on your units? The Awoken are for you. With Awoken units you can buff yourself with healing items to buff the strength of your units, and build around multi-hitters and sweeper units to keep defense high and attacker protected. This is compared to playing Green decks in Magic, or Defense Ironclad in Slay The Spire.

[spoiler] 3. Stygian Guard

Magic and Spells are your best friends! With this clan you have units that utilize their buffs when playing spell cards. This clan can be utilized with discard synergy to help get the deck moving. Compared to playing Blue in Magic, and Silent in StS. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] 4. Umbra

C O N S U M E. You will be sacrificing units to power up units to grant special powers, by either eating said units or sacrifice larger ones to make space for the small ones. This clan is about making super powered units for fights, alongside play space and spells to get as many units consumed. This is a hard clan to compare to for a single color in magic, but would work as a Blue/Green deck, as this can also be compared to Defect with its orbs in StS. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] 5. Melting Remnant

Melting away to comeback stronger, with a heated passion for battle, these Wax fighters will burn away during the fight. The death can be delayed with other cards, or if one desires, instant death. The clan strives on death, as units power themselves up when other allies and enemies die on the floor. The twist is that you can bring back your fallen units to fight again, powered up this time. It is necromancy at its finest. It is compared to playing a Black deck in Magic. [/spoiler]

This game is a fine deck builder if you enjoy this genre of game. If you enjoyed Slay The Spire, you will sure as HELL like Monster Train.

title: Monster Train
review:
Total: 7~8/10, Worth buying if there are more updates to come

Outstanding/Not-satisfying Aspects:
1. Game Mechanic: 9/10
Though against the first expression, its game experience is not quite like Slay the Spire, but more similar to Hearthstone. It's all about choices between the health of the core and minions exchange, tricks to turn the tide, and positioning. And, thanks to that, you'll get LOTS of decisions to make in EACH battle. Lets say, that should be what we call it strategy, er?
2. UI/graphics: 5/10
I might be harsh, but I really think the UI and the graphics can use more details. assets repetition, and the UI that doesn't fit into the tone of the back ground. I admit that in the most of the time I was focused on the numbers and waiting eagerly to see the result of the combat, but that doesn't mean that the graphic is not important. With such a outstanding game mechanic, it would definitely be better with polished graphics.
3. Number balance: -
I don't want to judge the balance of a game by only two runs (and yes, I cleared the game in the second) but, given you can easily get about 5 to 10 times higher damage/ healing with a single card update, you really won't want to have ANY useless not-upgraded card in your deck, or you'll have to face minions with 5 to 10 times higher atk/hp with them. I'm not saying it's not good , but I do think there could be more love for those who want to check more cards before settling the winning strategy of their decks.
4. Music: 7~8/10
Catchy, these tracks can gives you the feeling of fighting against the holy army. If I have to say something against them, well, a good game could always have more tracks right?

title: Monster Train
review:
I think this is one of sharpest deck-builder roguelites that exists.

There are a handful of mechanics that elevate it above Slay the Spire and Iratus:
The multiple train levels all fighting at once creates a delightful tension on where to focus your attention.
Each monster clans has at least a couple of viable strategies and in combination with each other, some fantastic combos can be pulled off.
The pace of the game is substantially faster both inside and outside of combat. Upgrading your deck is more frequent and more rewarding.

title: Monster Train
review:
Having watched some pre-release videos of the game before it came out, I was very much looking forward to playing the game.

However, once I got to play the released version, it did not take me long to realise that the game is absolutely imbalanced and even outside of incredible luck with the RNG (which yes, it's a deck-builder game, it's expected to a certain degree, but in this case it's absolutely ridiculous), there are only a couple viable "builds" or "strategies" that are capable of winning a run.

Either you are able to create a beat stack in one room, which is capable of outlasting the incredibly exponentially-scaling enemies and especially bosses (while there only a couple options which "exponentially" increase the player's capability to keep up with the nonsense), or you manage to get a rare cheese combo of effects that allow the absolutely pathetic damage spells to nuke the boss.

Not to mention that you are forced to start with a "dual-land" deck, in a game, where synergies between the 5 available card factions are very lacking.

Overall I truly hope the "balance" gets addressed in one way or another (nerfing the enemies/bosses, buffing most of the cards and faction mechanics or slowing down the pace and adding more "rings" to Hell, in order to smooth out the scaling curve, etc.)

TL;DR: At the moment, the game is a hilariously imbalanced RNG-fest, even for it's sub-genre, and I do not recommend you buy the game now, unless you're okay with such.

title: Monster Train
review:
Monster Train adopts a lot of the best parts of Slay The Spire, then flips the whole thing on it's head. This game is unlike any other deck building roguelike out there right now and DANG is it good. This game has 5 demon factions (so far) with multiple different mechanics and strategies for each, and you get to take TWO of them with you on your run, giving you tons of different strategies to try. 
Everything outside of battle is streamlined and simplified, showing you exactly what will happen as a result of your decisions, while the battles remain hectic and difficult. I couldn't recommend this game more to any fan of the roguelike genre.

title: Monster Train
review:
While this game clearly draws inspiration from Slay the Spire, it innovates on the genre in a number of ways, adding more depth and a lot of character.

- There are five factions, but you start each run with a combination of two of them, which greatly increases the number of possible starting archetypes.  This is a big plus for players who like to switch between different styles of play frequently.

- Each turn in Monster Train has more mechanical depth than a typical StS turn.  In general, you have a greater range of choices available .  This is balanced by the fact that the total number of turns over the course of the run will be less.

- The game provides a lot more advance information to guide your strategic choices than StS.  There's still a lot of randomness in terms of what you'll have available to build your run, but you can reliably choose to prioritize different types of deck improvements.  One big thing is that it tells you what type of debuff the final boss of the run will apply, which is critical to consider in order to build a successful run.

- The different factions are thematically quite interesting, with very different mechanical gimmicks and lots of opportunities for crazy powerful synergies.

- The game is challenging and has an extensive 'ascension' equivalent mechanic to scale the difficulty as you gain experience in how to play, which I've barely scratched the surface on.

Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys StS, especially if you wished the game gave you just a little bit more control over your strategic progression.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is addictive to play - Each run is relatively short (I'll even say shorter than a full run of Slay The Spire, for comparison) and every single clan is interesting to play and extremely specialized towards their own playstyle. Depending on who you take as the Allied Clan, your playstyle will very much vary with each of the combinations between the 5 different clans - on top of that, your choice of starting upgrade for your Leader Monster and starting Relic will most likely create your playstyle for that specific run, simply because you want to exploit the ability of your Leader Monster and the Relic as much as possible.

This is a total 'yes, buy it' from me. It can only get better with some potential DLC or quality of life improvements like more cutscene events and what not for varied outcomes.

Small note, currently when I write this review, there's been some issues with server-contacting that caused game crashes for a lot of people - this does seem to have been fixed now because I do not have those issues anymore, however as with any newly-released game, there might be some minor bug issues or other such technical problems, although I'd call them all merely negligible issues currently and very much not something you should take too strongly to heart.

title: Monster Train
review:
I just want to say that I absolutely love design of the game mechanics here. Especially upgrading cards. 

There are 2 types of upgrades, one for minions and one for spells, and you can apply any upgrade to any cards of that type. Do you have a spell that deals damage Х times? You can upgrade it with +10 damage, and it will deal Х times 10 damage more. Do you have a unit that deals a lot of damage? Give it multistrike. Want to sacrifice you imps? Give them endless so they are returned to your deck instead of being removed until the end of the battle. 

Simple, but quite brilliant, fells like a really good board game.

title: Monster Train
review:
Easily the best deckbuilder I've played. I was incredibly excited for this to come out after playing the demo and boy, it did not disappoint. What I find most impressive about the game is how the five clans are all completely unique, have vastly different mechanics and yet, each clan can also combine with each other clan to create unique combinations and strategies. The Melting Remnant are my personal favourites and even that single clan can be played in at least three completely different ways depending on which champion ability you pick at the start. 
Add to that the countless decisions you make within the game itself, the replay value from covenant, daily challenges and multiplayer and the unique lore and you have an absolute gem of a game.

100% recommend.

title: Monster Train
review:
It wears its Slay the Spire influence on its sleeve, this is a great evolution of roguelite deckbuilders. If you are fan of StS, you will love this. If you are fan of turn based games in general, you will love this. 

I feel like you are given a lot of agency to build your run the way you want. After every stage you are given lots of strategic choices to make, and it feels like all of them matter. The tactical game is not on rails either, you have to make choices all the time, which is what makes a turn based game. 

The difficulty is pitched well - its not so difficult it becomes frustrating, and when you fail you feel its your own fault rather than being at the whim of the RNG, given the agency you have to mitigate bad luck. 

Pacing is good, with a run weighing in at about an hour - short enough that a failed attempt doesn't feel like a waste of time, but long enough to feel meaty. 

Really the only negative I can think of is the name, which could not be less inspiring if it tried. Thanks to Northernlion for featuring this game on his channel, else I would probably have missed it.

review:
Some have tried, few worth the download and only this one can stand besides slay the spire. Or -dare I say- above it.
Not an alpha, beta, early access, "got potential" game. Nails it right off the bat.

Boss and enemy variety is fine, but I believe this is a field the devs can improve.
Clan quality, quantity, balance, synergies are very well thought.

title: Monster Train
review:
Great game. I prefer it a lot over Slay the Spire. Extremely well polished. It's at the level of dead cells for me where I was blown away by how well made, and cleverly crafted, the game is. It's gotten rid of most of the monotony and time-wasting that comes with the genre. You're straight into the action and kept there until you finish the ride.

Synergies are well thought out and directly rewarding for your forethought and investment in them. Most importantly synergies no longer rely completely chance and can be planned accordingly. While synergies in Slay the Spire were fun, even if you planned for one you often had to rely on RNG for whether your acquire it. This game does them much better.

It's incredibly fun to start with the champion or an item and think 'oh cool I could do this'. My last run I had a starting artifact that majorly buffed my initial (extremely) weak creatures and my immediate thought was 'how can I capitalise the shit out of this and make them OP' and I was able to do just that because I could plan for the forge (spend money to buff a creature) and duplicate which copies a card. I nearly won with my silly build but lost at the end stretch of the last boss.

The devs should feel proud, and maybe a bit smug, for what they've made.  Much rarer these days then it should be, Monster Train is a game about having fun and I'll certainly be continuing to take it up on that offer.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review: I feel like we are a few weeks away from Monster Train being a household name among rougelike enthusiasts. Time will tell if this game will continue to hold people's interest through hundreds of hours (as STS does) but as of release this game is absolutely worth the price of admission. There is so much design space still available with it's amazing framework that I can definitely see new and exciting clans coming out over time.

The different decks play well and support each other in unique ways.

A really polished and fun deckbuilder / roguelite game.

title: Monster Train
review:
As a fan of deck building games, I personally find this one to be one of the better ones available. Unlike many of the games of this genre which I've played (mostly on ios), a run in this is a lot shorter which means over time the deck feels more and more tailored/controlled as opposed to the RNG-ness of others. I'd like to call out the length in this game specifically because it's very well paced. A lot of these type of games last too long and allow you to go overboard with the deck/items which isn't a bad thing, but in my opinion makes the genre less strategic and more random, so this is one thing this game excels at.

Aside from gameplay, the art direction and music is also very good. Overall I'd say this is a very polished game that will keep you entertained for a while especially in bite sized runs/playthroughs. I haven't tried multiplayer yet but it seems like they're just competitive modes... I'd like to see a co-op mode in the future if that's a possibility, but other than that I'd give this game a 10/10.

title: Monster Train
review: First of all, comparing to STS there are obviously many similarities but the game has some elements STS doesn't have and I love it. Even if STS is obviously more polished right now I think Monster Train plays in the same league and offers more variation. I even think that the game is a little bit more immersive than STS due to its artstyle, at least for me. For example, you battle in 3 lanes and have to act more strategically. On the other hand, it's a mix between spells and minions and one particular hero per "class". The class system looks promising because you can build mixed classes and play around with different combinations. Furthermore, the classes itself provide strong diversification based on how you evolve your hero. In the end I'm very curious about further updates / content and I'm happy that I bought a game with just a few reviews back then. If you liked or are interested in STS I highly recommend Monster Train, because it is for me STS with new possibilities.

review:
If you're looking for a game that's like Slay the Spire, this is your go to. 

The game invokes a lot of the same you've become accustomed to over the years with deck builders, but the way the present the formula is a lot better in my opinion. With the "double decks" that you pull from two different clans, you have a lot of ways you can build and adapt to a situation. 

The roguelike element is pretty much the same. You go until you die and you unlock cards for the decks. Each clan has it's own level and each has it's own unlocks and artifacts. So between the main runs and the custom modes you can build and share out, you should have a lot of game to play.

title: Monster Train
review:
I'm going to be honest with you, I don't play a ton of deck builders, but I've played a lot of Slay the Spire, and so I'm going to compare this game to that quite a bit for this review.  You've been warned.

Really digging this game right now.  Plays a lot like Slay the Spire, but slimmed down and streamlined in the rogue-like department, and with a much more robust and fleshed out battle system.  Instead of choosing your path one encounter at a time, you just select one of two tracks, each of which will offer you 2-4 beneficial encounters (shops, healing, etc.) before meeting at the middle with a battle.  Then there's train car mechanic, which allows for multiple battles to happen simultaneously across multiple train cars.  You can finish a run in about an hour and a half--probably less if you've been playing a while.

Buy this if you like Slay the Spire.

66/6, would get destroyed by my own grand designs again. Definitely check this game out if you love Slay the Spire but feel the need for a fresh start and new twists.

title: Monster Train
review:
If you like slay the spire, or other deckbuilding rogue-lites you will love this game. This is the absolute best game of this genre I have played since Slay the Spire (and I have played a lot). I would personally say it's equally as good as StS. There is a ton of content here, there are 5 factions to play as. When you choose your main faction you will also combine it with another faction, that faction being your secondary faction. This gives a ton of options in how to play the game.

On top of that there are plenty of modes, it has the standard mode you would expect where you go through a series of battles and when you beat it, you get a harder version of it (like ascension in slay the spire). But it also has multiplayer, a daily challenge mode, and lets you create your own challenge runs and post them up for others to play.

Overall, it's really just a fantastic game, I can't recommend it enough.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is very fun. Probably the best thing I can say about it is just how absurdly powerful you become in such a short time; it makes each run feel very satisfying. There's a lot of content, and the multiplayer is surprisingly good. You can see other players attempting the same challenge you are and there's a real incentive to play well and try and achieve a high score.

I recommend this game to anyone who loves strategy games, but especially to people who love Slay the Spire or deckbuilding games in general, as this is a shining example of the genre.

I think a game never surprised me so much in such a positive way. At first glance you might think this looks like a cheap mobile-game, but after you play for a few minutes you can so clearly see how much heart has been put into this. It looks great, it sounds amazing and the gameplay is just awesome with so much diversity and different possibilities.

The difficulty is perfect, i feel like the win is always dangling in front of my nose, just to be snatched away by some weird boss with a ridiculous amount of Health. But it never feels unfair, because you also get ridiculous tools to work with, for example literally one-shotting that same boss with a special combo later on. Its so fun and satisfying!

I hope this game and the devs will have a bright future, its deserved for sure!

title: Monster Train
review:
The game is above average and worth playing, but it won't knock your socks off if you're used to the depth of something like Slay the Spire. While the choices at first seem to be very diverse, in the end they don't mean very much as the game is quite easy, quite short, and quite shallow.

That being said, for 20 bucks, I still think it's worth picking up and enjoying - it's a good game, but it doesn't live up to other games of its Genre.

A couple of things that could really bump this game up in my opinion:

1) Controller Support. I would love to hook this up to my TV and play on my couch!
2) More levels, slower scaling. There's only 9 levels per run, and that honestly feels too short for any of your choices to be meaningful in the long run. It feels too much like luck (of which you don't need much...) and not enough like planning and forethought.

title: Monster Train
review:
OK. I have perhaps 20 reviews of Steam games. More than half are good reviews, and a sprinkling of games that didn't meet up to my expectations.

I won't review a game until I have played it enough to learn it. It doesn't do YOU any good if I am making half-assed comments about the game, and I don't understand the mechanics.

OK...let's start with the graphics and polish. Similar to Hearthstone, with bright colors and sharp detail. Sounds are excellent, and the presentation is very good.

But...I don't care about graphics. I still play Master of Magic, and the original X-Com. I am all about the gameplay.

I keep discovering new things about the game. As I blasted past the two hour refund point, I never hesitated. I knew that this game had legs, and was a keeper, and will be a favorite of mine for a very long time.

I don't have anything to fault here. If you win, it is very, VERY satisfying. I have had 25 "runs", and have one just once. It's a roguelike, and the stars have to align for this to happen.

I think that what I enjoy most is the sense of progression. Even if you lose, you gain experience in your main army, and the secondary army you choose. Play enough games, and you unlock levels, and unlocking levels unlocks more cards, better cards, and a better chance to progress deeper in your next game.

There are five armies in the game, with two unlocked at the start. After 15 hours of gameplay, I just unlocked the fifth one..so everything is unlocked.

After my one and only victory, the challenge level increased. I didn't realize it, but I was getting smoked pretty good. In complete honesty, I am not great at strategy games....but I am doing OK here, trying to figure out the synergies and relationships between the cards.

There are MANY variables on each run through. I haven't begun to believe that I have remotely seen the content. Under 10% at this point. This game can be played for hundreds of hours, and still have unique combinations and synergies uncovered.

Each run starts with a base set of cards, and some standard, non-army specific cards using generic units. There are units and spells, and each has their own purchase price. You can increase the cost or their efficacy, or make them stronger at the risk of consuming them - one shot. If you don't use all the cards in your hand, they go into your discard pile, to be recycled. 

This really is a terrific gaming system. My grandson was looking over my shoulder as I played earlier today..he's ten, but smart, really smart, like his mom. I think the Bank of Grandpa is going to kick in here....

Bottom line, buy this game.

title: Monster Train
review:
I don't write these kinds of things often, but I'm very impressed by this game so far.  This is a deck builder roguelike with some extreme polish on every side.  Graphics are gorgeous, music is kicking, difficulty curve is just in that perfect sweet spot of challenging but not frustrating, cards are well balanced with artifacts in mind, and so far the progression system seems to add tools to certain types of builds rather than just adding dumb filler like a lot of these types of games.  I've been trying to gold as many cards as I can, and almost every one has felt viable and useful in some capacity.

I haven't tried the MP yet, but the very fact that you can race with other people is a really fun idea and I'm glad it's there, as well as the standard dailies.  I would love to see the addition of an endless/score attack mode as well.  I think this would be the perfect type of game for it.  Also glad that they included a Run Report that saves to your account!  Why haven't other deckbuilders jumped in on this???  It's a small thing but it makes a world of difference and it's fun to be able to look back at past runs, whether to see where you went wrong or to laugh at how broken you ended up making your deck!

monstertrain://runresult/a70b36a0-1ca1-420c-97d8-6494247e66b0

That's my most broken so far, would love to see some of yours!

If you're a fan of the genre, definitely try this one out!  You won't be disappointed :)

title: Monster Train
review: This is not only a well made, fun game, but it seems to have solved (or at least vastly improved) the "lane" mechanic attempted by other games such as Artifact, Elder Scrolls: Legends, and Gwent.  The aforementioned games approached lanes in their various ways, but the approach in Monster Train feels not only the most intuitive, but genuinely adds to the game's strategy and fun, while feeling streamlined instead of cumbersome.  Even without the lane mechanic, Monster Train would be an interesting and enjoyable card fighter, brandishing a personality that sets it apart from the saturated genre.  It's smooth, fast, interesting, fun, has professional quality and depth, and just downright feels good to play.  Definitely compels the "just one more run!" user experience that signals the hallmarks of a good game.  Highly recommended!

title: Monster Train
review:
[h1]Amazing deckbuilding roguelike, with a dash of tower-defense mechanisms. You will love this game[/h1]
Pesky angels and holy knights? Not on my Hell train!!!

Can't talk about deckbuilding without naming Slay the Spire. Monster train takes on the formula and brings tower-defense elements to make it all the more intense.
- Instead of a hero fighting a couple of enemies for its life, you now have waves of monsters relentlessly walking toward the end of the path to kill you.
- Balance your deck well: Summons will invoke a champion (like a tower) to guard a part of the path. Enchant to make them stronger. Use spells for instant profit. Remove or upgrade cards at the shop to improve your deck ... all the good parts of a deckbuilder are here.
- The world in-between fights has been simplified: 2 choices every time, no long term consequences. No need to plan 10 turns in advance where you want to go, you have more urgent problems to deal with.
- "Want +400 gold? Sure, but in the next fight, the enemies will fully heal every turn." featuring plenty of terrible choices for greedy players like you and me
- You want more pressure? There's intense minibosses battles at the end of every waves. You won't have time to rest.
 
Oh yeah baby, welcome aboard the Hell train, the MONSTER TRAIN

title: Monster Train
review:
You can choose upgrades for spells at a spell vendor, units at a merc vendor and buy artifacts at an artifact vendor....
The ONLY random factors are what those upgrades are, what cards you get and an occasional event node. Aswell as a node for regaining hp, duplicating a card, a moneydrop, choose from 3 units of a faction, choose between 2 artifacts and for purging 2 cards from the deck. A maximum of 3 per side+one available for both paths.

That makes runs very variable in what will happen especially because the fights themselves have different patterns and you can add an extra challenge that ofcourse means you get moar gold.....Anyhoo I somehow feel like this is less chaotic than StS even though it seems like theres alot more that changes from run to run.

You also get a Champion, which is unique to each playable clan, and for which you can choose between upgradepaths 3 times during the run, you could synergize this unit with your others or just build the most badass champion you can which adds even more options onto the plate....

It also is alot less combat instances than in StS overall but on the flipside each combat has mulitple rounds and can get quite long depending on your deck. The three different combat rooms also makes for very interesting mechanics.

As alot of other reviews have already stated, there are so many viable combinations, ways to build yourself a deck and unit-placements on the train that it will take a very long time until you get bored with this game.

title: Monster Train
review: This game is dope.

title: Monster Train
review:
I've checked out the few bad reviews, and I'd like to counter some of those points since they don't allow comments. If you're on the fence this is for you. One person says the game is too hard, after spending only a couple hours trying it, well it will take you a few runs to get good, it's that simple. The game is not too hard, it's less RNG dependant than STS just from the fact that you can see the specific final boss you will need to prepare for as soon as the run begins, no more making it to act 3 with a 0-cost deck only to see Time Snail as the 3rd act boss who will 100% counter you. There are 25 levels bumping up the difficulty and you can win on lower levels even with no knowledge and bad strategies, just don't expect to win every run unless you get better. 

Someone else complains the final boss that gives your units "Sap 3" and that makes them unable to attack, which just isn't true. Sap lowers stats a tiny bit temporarily, and you can tell if the final boss will know Sap as soon as the run begins, so you can simply use bigger guys who can be useful despite being sapped.

Another bad review claims there's "No strategy", claiming enemies spawn on you with no warning what type they'll be or what they will do. Well that's wrong, before every single fight you get a screen where you can see and mouse over the enemy types that will spawn, and learn EXACTLY what stats they have and how they will behave (and learn their lore as to why they do that). It also claims RNG decides if your starting cards are useful or useless, which again is not true, as the game has a 100% guarantee your first card is your Champion (usually one of your best cards) and also a guarantee of a 2nd Unit. In fact, the game has a pool of "worthless" starting cards that will NEVER be in your starting hand, which completely counters the argument that RNG solely decides if your starting hand is good or bad.

This specific review also trolls by pretending there are no build strategies, in the same breath as saying they haven't unlocked most cards yet. Base STS has maybe 25 build styles total, like The Defect can win through a couple of Orb deck types, a turtle build, or Powers build, or 0-cost card build, or maybe if you're insane and lucky Claw, and then you get more build types with the other 3 characters of course. Well, I'll explain more below, but suffice to say that base Monster Train has very clear builds, supported by using cards and artifacts that lead to a strategy and build. Like, you can get 2 different artifacts for the Hellhorn clan that give armor to units, and then many units can generate their own armor, and spells grant armor, and there's the win condition spell just like Slay The Spire that converts armor directly into a huge amount of damage for you. The 2-clan system improves build variety immensely, for example Armor-build can sub-class Stygian because there are units in that clan that gain armor, even 1 that gives armor to all your units every time you cast a spell, and that class can even buff your spell's final damage output, letting you one-shot a boss with proper prep work, just like STS's armor build. It can also work well with Melting Remnant, as that clan has an Artifact that gives armor to units as well, or with Awoken, as you can protect that units gaining armor behind big bulkly tanks that can be healed cheap, or with Umbra, which lets you give units damage shields to take damage while the armor keeps building up, and offers plentiful buffs and ways to manipulate energy and how much space you can use to fill with units. Let's just say the build variety not only exists, but it also overshadows base STS by a massive degree in just how many ways you can build.

This is an amazing game, personally, it passes Slay The Spire, and that's coming from someone with over 300 hours of Slay The Spire on Steam. Deceptively simple at first, you get to mix 2 of 5 clans for your run, and the 2 unlocked at the start are very simple, which each unlocked clan being more complex than the last. After spending 20 hours in the demo I knew I needed the game, but after 18 hours in the main game I'm now sure I'll be playing this for hundreds of hours.

Not only can you curve your difficulty through 25 Covenants (think Ascensions from STS), but you can curve your complexity by picking a combo that is simpler/harder. STS lets you play as Ironclad for a straightforward game where you heal a bit after rounds so small mistakes are forgiven, and then later classes are more complex, this is true. However, in Monster Train there's 20 different starting combos with a wide variety of complexities in this game, you can go Hellhorn+Awoken for a very simple game where you probably win (if you're at the Covenant difficulty for your skill level) just by putting DPS behind tanks, and then using simple buffs and heals and damage spells to keep your guys alive and kill the other guys. You can rank the complexity up just a little, but example Hellhorn+Stygian makes magic a huge priority, in fact winning with only 2 or 3 units in the deck with the rest being spells is not unthinkable, this is a bit more complex than the last example but the simplicity of the Hellhorns make using the Stygian gimmicks easier, and the two classes share some natural synergy through shared use of the Armor mechanic and lots of damage spells synergy in Stygian supporting the Hellhorn's powerful fire spells. If you want complexity, you can jump straight to the final classes and go for something like Melting Remnants+Umbra, making a build where timing things is key, proper placement of your units is essential, using cards in the right order is relevant, and building a deck that minimizes RNG is vital. This is a perfect game for tailoring it to what you want, you can be very skilled and still have the choice between 20 very hard run combos, just with different complexity levels and combos for each one. Each of the 5 clans has at least 3 solid paths to win with, for example, Hellhorn can win by stacking armor up and using spells that damage based on armor, or they can win by using many high damage units hitting over and over in the most basic style possible, or you can build up your Champion to do insane damage while other units take the hits to protect him, and once you unlock enough of the extra cards and Artifacts for this clan, you can build an Imp deck, using token units and synergies to do hilarious strong things at a level more complex than the class allows at first. The most important thing to note, though, is that you get 2 clans, which means with the right build, each of the 20 combos can strive for an absolute minimum of 6 winning builds, given each class has at least 3. Playing Hellhorn doesn't lock you to winning only through basic strategies or imps, if you sub-class as the Stygian, you can find their cards and Artifacts, allowing you to win through strategies like extremely high damage spells, or status effect damage ticking over and over, or buffing units through abilities that trigger on spell use while your units do the killing, or discarding and drawing cards to not only get you to the cards you want that turn while in the process activate certain card's abilities through discarding them. There is a LOT of valid potential for every clan, and with 20 combos to choose from you can play for 100+ hours without running out of new win conditions to try. Especially with the scaling of Covenants, you can win with wacky strategies that are weaker simply by scaling back the difficulty in order to give you a fair chance, or you can pump the difficulty up because you want to use the OP strats that would obliterate enemies at lower difficulties while still being fun.
 

Buy this game, it is worth it. Comment with concerns or questions.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is incredible. It hits all the marks for a roguelite for me.
-Relatively quick runs that don't feel like a chore to complete.
-Mid-run savepoints if you need to abandon your computer and close the game.
-Lots of variety with faction combinations
-Items (in this case, artifacts) that can greatly change your run and impact how you play
-Nice challenge balancing, where you don't feel overwhelmed by difficulty but it's not braindead either
-Great soundtrack, one of the only games that I don't turn off the music and listen to something else.
-Entertaining to play, and entertaining to watch.
-Highrolls that let you just ball out of control and destroy a run
-Special encounters that ask for a risk vs reward type of play (HP for an artifact, etc. etc.)
-Special rewards for upping the difficulty
-Not disgustingly punishing

I would list negatives, but I don't really have any, honestly. Maybe the risks vs rewards could be higher, things that ask for more HP and such and reward you for keeping your Pyre healthy in battle, but I feel it's there in the extra challenge during battle. Overall, fantastic game. Nothing to complain about. Buy it at full price, please.

title: Monster Train
review:
This game is incredible. It took a bunch of pages out of Slay the Spire's book, and it holds that fact proudly. As it should, because this game remains very unique and dynamic. 

It's hard to put into words everything I like about this game without forming a 5-page thesis. I'll just list off my favorite things.

Game has StS-like Ascensions: 25 of them. 
I've only seen Ascension 1 thus far "Gain 5 random cards at the start of the game" and its already awesome. Bad on paper, but forcing you to take some of those cards, good or bad, and use them synergistically and remove the rest from your deck is such a cool idea.

5 Classes, and you can choose 1 sub-class alongside your main class so you get cards from both classes. It does take a bit too long imo to unlock all the classes, but the sub-class mechanic is awesome. 10 total unique combinations is almost as good as 10 classes.

The upgrade system is cool too, definitely dig it. You buy various upgrades from a shop and tack them onto a minion or spell, up to 2 upgrades normally.

I think the most satisfying part of the game is that things can really spiral and become very overpowered. Even when you could topple the biggest bosses, there's other enemies that have a particular gimmick that counters typical play and you have to anticipate or play around them, which is the enemy design I really enjoyed from StS.

Monster Train, aka Protect the Pyre, aka reverse Slay the Spire.

One thing that really stands out about Monster Train's game design is the choices presented to player. Every upgrade, card you take, and purchase you make is interesting. The game is basically a series of interesting decisions-- one after another. Also, there are plenty of unlocks-- currently five factions (equivalent to characters in StS)-- and unlocks for each faction.

review:
Thanks NL, this is already a serious GOTY contender!

The mechanics are crazy cool, the game achieves this super weird (and probably really hard to pull off) split that almost every upgrade you get seems super powerful when it's actually well balanced. Your cards get out of control at the same pace that the difficulty ramps up, super quick, and as a result the next upgrade-and-battle-phase feels like a rush. Real "just one more turn" vibe from this!
the great art goes hand-in-hand with the over-the-top mechanics, and details such as the train you're playing on actually being animated to move at what feels like breakneck speed add a sweet sense of urgency to the gameplay, which is then exacerbated by the very pushy, absolutely *banging* soundtrack!
Loving this!

title: Monster Train
review: Good

title: Monster Train
review:
(This is written based mostly on having played public beta for several weeks, prior to release) 

If you played Slay the Spire, this is very familiar, only that you're the spire and are in a train, rolling your way through all the rings hell, right to where the heart of hell itself used to reside. Your mission is to bring a fragment of the heart, the "Pyre", to rekindle the flames of a barren and frozen hell, while the stubborn (evil?) Winged try to stop your train and constantly attack you. 
Yup, THAT's the setting. 

Mechanically the game is very similar to slay the spire as I said, but there's a big difference in the fact that you summon units that auto-battle for you, through 3 different levels stacked vertically. The Winged (enemies) troops try to ascend all the levels past your units, to get to the top where your Pyre is, then they attack it (if it's completely destroyed, GAME OVER). Inbetween battles you gather new cards, power up those already in the deck, or get artifacts (akin to relics in Slay the Spire). 
The powerups are very interesting too, btw. You have 2 slots to put improvements to cards like +attack or +HP to units, extra damage on spells, reduced "ember" costs (mana), etc. There are some more interesting, like being able to recast an ability each turn, and those become really fun if you learn to use them (and manage to find them, too).


The game has great attention to detail, solid mechanics inspired in Slay the Spire with very nice and fun-ctional additions that make it really unique! Also some interesting lore that has picked my interest, nice and fun interactions and combos, etc. 

Overall a very great game, with many more aspects I'd love to talk about , but I'll keep it in a short summary here
-Theres 5 factions, you play one as "main" and other as an "ally", which gives you the champion of the main faction and then you can get extra support cards from both factions. Overall 20 combinations (for any of the 5 factions, you can ally with any of the resting 4, 5x4=20 possible combinations with different synergies and strategies).
-Besides usual standard play, with an increasing difficulty with the "covenant" system (similar to ascension), there's daily runs with different mutators, custom runs, and even some semi-multiplayer where you are playing the same run at the same time as other players. Real time, same seeded run with the same options, competing for the biggest score. 
-There was a period of open Beta with similar content to the current demo, available for a couple months prior to release. All free, and pretty polished even then! I bet the demo is still available now, so feel free to try the game (only 2 of the 5 clans, and only 1 covenant is possible, but it's pretty fun just by itself!)
-Devs used to do a weekly stream in the "Good Shepherd" channels (youtube and twitch), showing new content and being in contact with the community. Also on Discord! Hopefully this tradition will continue in some form, giving us updates of the coming features post-release! They have been very active and responsive of feedback on the past, I'm sure it'll still be that way and we'll get updates :D

PS: I love the setting of playing as devils and other spawns from hell, but also being the "good guys" under attack instead of playing on the side of "big evil". Seems like a very original setting!

title: Monster Train
review:
I'm a fan of tower defense games and deck builders, so this game was right up my alley. There are some interactions that the game does a poor job of telling you about, (example: spell weakness causes a unit to take the damage of a spell X more times, where X is stacks of spell weakness, but a card does 1 damage 5 times, does spell weakness proc on the first instance of damage, or the whole spell? The answer is the whole spell, but I had to just play it out and see). There are a few examples outside of card interactions that just playing is the only way to learn, like learning that you can enter a shop, leave it, then come back later as long as you haven't moved on to the next fight.

Some nitpicks I have are things like the champion not changing appearance with different upgrades, lots of units look almost entirely the same, things like that. I would have enjoyed the polish of seeing your champion evolve in its art or more diverse looking units, but these are small things.

Up to this point I have talked about things I don't like, and I hope no one reads those criticisms and sees a bad game. I love the balance of the game and the way the difficulty evolves with the covenant system! The game can be as easy as "pay attention and you'll win" if you want with covenant off, and when I just want a relaxing play I do covenant 1, which is another thing I love: Early access to huge variability in how you start. I find that the most fun part of the game is just starting out on a double random run, examining my deck and figuring out where I want to go with it.
The compartmentalized upgrade system with units and spells makes you feel like an absolute genius, and in a break away from other deck builder games there is no shortage of opportunities to really streamline your deck and prune it to your liking (early drop 2/dupe 1 abound), which really puts the onus on the player. RNG happens, it is part of the game and a fun element, but (mostly due to consistency of options) whether or not you have a well built deck is much more up to you than chance as compared to other games.

title: Monster Train

title: Monster Train
review:
TL;DR: All-in-all a decent game - certaintly not bad, but also not outstanding... (don't expect a second "Slay the Spire")

Monster Train iterates on the Rogue-like deckbuilding formula, and does a decent job at that. However some special "spice" seems to be missing to make it the smash-hit its (obvious) rolemodel "Slay the Spire" was: And after a few games I'm can begin to narrow it down a bit:

* The "map" hurts the game quite a bit - after each fight you get to choose between two goody-filled paths, followed by the next fight. Where in "Slay the Spire" deciding what path to go down was a game element on its own (play it safe with a campfire, gamble with "?",  or go high-risk to the miniboss even though you are low on HP). In Monster Train you could replace the map with a popup "Which goodies do you want before the next fight? A or B?"

* The fights themselves are entertaining but the enemies rather lack variety. It mostly boils down to "this one has extra armor, this one has extra health, you can't hit this one for a bit" - there are few deep strategic elements involved.

* Balancing is rather out-of-whack. You can upgrade your spells and units (which is neat), but there the problems begin to show: one the most common upgrades for your spells simply adds 10 damage - and since your base spell does 2 damage by default this results in a 5-fold increase... which you need since enemies scale to match. After a few fights doing 2 damage is next to meaningless. On the other hand some upgrades are simply overpowered: after the 2nd fight I had a 1-cost, 3 "size" unit that delivered 28 damage per attack... and attack 3 times per turn. An encounter allowed to clone that card 5 times - and no enemy unit in the game posed any kind of challenge anymore.

So Monster Train has its flaws - it is not outstanding, but it is an decent game, so if you see it for ~10-15€ grab it and you'll get your money's worth out of it

review: Picked it up and joyfully wasted my entire day playing this. It has the craziest concept (seriously, who comes up with battling monsters on a train?) but it seems well balanced, interesting, and highly addictive. Many reviews likened the game to Slay the Spire (i've never heard of it). For me, it feels extremely similar to a dungeon run from Hearthstone. You fight a boss, pick out which treasure you want, pick a few cards to add, and fight the next boss. There's a ton of customizability without having to actually build your own deck from scratch.

title: Monster Train
review:
It is actually the best deckbuilder I have ever played. I liked slay the spire, but I just couldn't get into it like a lot of people have, but this game just hits a similar scratch but adds a lot more to it. It hits a bit of that addictive part of plants vs zombies did several years ago, but it is way closer to slay the spire if that makes any sense. Leveling up heroes with different powers, making a basic card you had at the start into a custom made monster of a card, using spells in one run that can be used in a completely different way from another (like using a heal to create a beefy tank in one run, while in another using the heals as a nuke for the enemies) 

It is fantastic, and easily worth the buying price esp on sale. If you ever liked the hearthstone, plants vs zombies, or slay the spire, you owe it yourself to give it a chance.

title: Monster Train
review:
It's the sort of game that I just can't stop playing. 

Your train is going to hell, and the good guys want to stop it. Each encounter follows more or less the same formula. Your train has three levels, enemies enter at the bottom and advance upwards unless you kill them. You draw cards from your managed hand to summon mobs and cast spells. Between encounters you get the chance to buy upgrades, artifacts, go on random events etc. Make it past 10 encounters and you win, and you start over from zero. Massive replayability as you start over with different clans (card setups) that you choose 2 out of 5, and unlock new cards and artifacts for the clans that you go far with. If you win, you unlock higher difficulties.

It's all about making a snowball of the stats your cards get. Spike builds, multistrike builds, heavy hitter builds, spell builds... sometimes the RNG is against you, and sometimes it is with you.

title: Monster Train
review:
If slay the spire laid the foundation, Monster train built the house.


Roguelites have been my favorite kind of game for years now. The opportunity to get on an insane run then die then start over is somehow so appealing. When the binding of isaac came out and I started playing that felt like the best rush ever. Get sooped up, die, repeat. Win every now and then, fun, fun, fun! It was an insane. Then my love of card games which never really existed came into fold. I used to play Pokemon but that's the extent of any card game I played. Isaac got boring after a million hours so lets try something new. Enter Slay the Spire. A completely unique game no one has ever really experienced before. It scratches all the itches we were looking or and then some. Then, a year or two later, card and roguelike games get stale. Who plays those anymore? StS had a great roguelike deckbuilding kinda game but every game after that was kinda cheap and a moneygrab. 

Uh Oh turns out monster train is up to bat in 2020, and they hit this shit out of the fucking park. Slay the spire started the genre and really killed it. Monster train basically went from Goldeneye to Halo 2. A great game to set the stage (StS) to basic perfection of the genre (MT). That's it, just buy this game if you're even remotely interested in roguelites or deckbuilders. You won't  be disappointed.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is fantastic.  I'd say if you enjoyed Slay the Spire you'll love this.  I tried a few other card attack like games after Slay but none felt great, until now.  I don't know about the longevity (at this point), but much to my surprise I'd say I like this even more than I did Slay the Spire at this point and I thought it was great.
There are different cards per class like in Slay, here though you get to cast a champion of your primary class (each is different) which along with the class cards (primary and secondary class) really mixes things up further and adds to the enjoyment.  Then before each level's boss fight you get a decent upgrade and you get a choice of which upgrade you want.  You get opportunities to upgrade cards and your hero as you go really allowing you to try different tactics.  
I've got plenty to try yet, but so far each system/approach seems to be quite viable assuming you make good decisions.  It seems far more likely of a positive outcome than bad luck that could hit you in Slay, some bosses in Slay could deal out mega damage.  In this game some bosses have mega health, but you can work towards a combination to eat into that.  
As you go along you unlock new cards, artifacts, classes for future runs, much like in Slay.  The game keeps a nice compendium of what all you've done/unlocked.  I can't recommend this game enough, give it a try.

title: Monster Train
review:
Slay the Spire with slightly more complex combat? Yes pls.

Oh did... did you need more than "a good variant of Slay the Spire?"
Uh... well... alright... there are quite a few other solid strengths:

Each of the Clans feel not only unique, but actually have strengths that match along with them. I won't go into too much detail here, as I feel discovering them is part of the fun, but each covenant unlock has been a surprising new addition.

The combat is satisfying, doesn't feel painfully repetitive, and actually involves some decision making. It's important to note, this *will not be evident in your first few plays*, because...

The game gets progressively harder the more you win, rather than easier the more you lose. You are expected to complete the delivery and "win" the first few times. You might even, if you're an experienced card game enthusiast, find yourself winning easily your first three or four times. However, the game has a brilliant "it gets harder" mechanic in the form of Covenant level, which makes the game progressively more difficult each time you win. The important thing here is that each Covenant rank does not simply say "enemies are more powerful". They will add some new mechanics, some bits to mess up your deck design, more enemies, etc. It is not strictly "and then +10% to all enemy stats". The result is something surprisingly exciting to see what new roadblock will be added, and it makes winning not only possible, but good and rewarding.

Ultimately, is this game of the year? No, probably not. Will you have fun for it's reasonable price tag? If you like Slay the Spire, Roguelikes, or card games in general, then yes, most likely. Give the demo a try if you're in doubt!

As a note - I've yet to encounter a bug. I feel like having an actually solid release and not years of Early Access helps a lot in that regard.

title: Monster Train
review:
Description: (Non-Early-Access) Roguelike-Card-Battler with a lot of depth, a ton of things to unlock and multiple strategies & deck archetypes. If you like Slay-The-Spire you will love this.


Positive (+)

+ Easy to grasp the fundamental game mechanics & Smooth introduction of additional features

+ Huge complexity & depth once you unlock more cards & deck types

+ Multiplayer custom challenges, daily challenges, leaderboards

+ The amount of unlockables is really high and feels motiviating

+ Different characters & allied clans bring a lot of variety options to choose from when beginning a new run


Neutral (>) 

> The soundtrack is fitting & accompanies the different levels & bosses individually


Negative (-)

- No steam-workshop support (yet)

- An art-style which you need to get used to. I do not like it (hugely subjective though)


Overall: If you like slay the spire or card-battlers in general this game is a no brainer. HUGE replay value and a lot of fun. Even though I do not like the art style this should not stop you from buying and enjoying this game. If you are unsure, try the game. A full run takes you about ~1hours15minutes. So can still get a refund. I doubt you would want this after playing the game though. The game is a 10/10 in the card-battle genre!

Edit* There is a demo!

title: Monster Train
review:
Gameplay - 5/5 if you like slay the spire this is different enough to feel fresh while being just as fun, decks can stack crazily or fall flat depending on your choices along the way
UI - 4/5 a little too cluttered with space not being used. When you have a ton of units/cards, they get pretty hard to interact with.
Graphics - 5/5 21:9 support, smooth animations, looks is subjective
Sound - 2/5 it gets pretty irritating when you have a unit battle it out with the boss for multiple turns making the exact same sound effects, especially on ultra speed.
Content - 4/5 25 clan combos with 25 covenent (ascension) levels. Enemies feel repetitive. Item and card choices allow for different synergies, but it feels like some balancing could be done (or I am just bad at certain combos)

If you are watching northernlion play and ripping your hair out, buy the game.

title: Monster Train
review:
This is the first deckbuilder roguelike that compares favorable to Slay the Spire. And I did play a lot of imitators form Deck Of Ashes to literal abandon ware like Destiny Or Fate. None came even close to the elegance of Slay the spire. 

Until now (insert dramatic music). Seriously though Monster Train is great. Each run takes around 45 min and eventhough I clear runs in slay the spire within 30 it felt like barely any time had past and I am always surprised that I reached the endboss already. Visually it is way better which isn't that surprising as slay the spire was made by 2 guys. Although I am not keen on the sound design as bosses attack multiple times each turn and so you have to hear their attack grunt 5-10 times in quick succession. 

Balance from what I can tell right now seems to be ok, but then I only played for 4 hours so I don't know for sure. Red demons seem to be really weak compared to green or purple but then I haven't probably found the correct play style yet. 

A must buy for every slay the spire fan. If you haven't played slay the spire yet... the f*** have you been doing the past 2 years?

title: Monster Train
review:
The presentation is great, and the mechanics are a good blend of solid foundations and fresh ideas.

One thing I love is that you start each run by picking 2 of 5 factions whose cards will form your deck. This gives 20 possible combinations (the 1st faction determines which champion unit you start with, so order matters), which gives both a lot of variety, while keeping it manageable. However, this could be very difficult to balance well, unlike Slay the Spire where each faction has a very well tuned deck. Ultimately time will tell how it works as they continue to balance the game in its early stages.

If you love this genre, you'll at least find this game interesting, and if you have not given it a shot before, it is a good enough introduction.

title: Monster Train
review:
Short Version - Slay The Spire + a bit of tower defense. It's fantastic. 10/10.

Longer Version - It has the challenge for those looking for it, much like ascension mode from STS. The different faction combos are a lot of fun and change up the game quite a bit from run to run. You may have a spell heavy run with 1-combo, a minion heavy combo with another, or vice versa. The mechanics are familiar (besides the 'Morsel' mechanic, which is one I haven't seen before, but is a lot of fun) and the game's ability to summarize the outcome of a turn (sometimes a turn that lasts upwards of 100 attacks) at a single glance mean that all the strategy is still there, but people new to this sort of game and veterans alike will be able to determine the outcome of a played card to a much more effective degree. It's tough to explain in a Steam review, but it's honestly amazing from a design standpoint given the amount of information that is being calculated from various abilities across a ton of different units. The designers and programmers deserve a serious high five for this.

I was drawn to this by Northernlion's series on it. It's a ton of fun to watch and it's a blast to play. I'm 6 hours into it, but from my experience with it and my love of the genre, this may just be an early GOTY contender for me.

Highly recommended, 10/10.

title: Monster Train
review:
The devs owe Northernlion a cut. I would have never known this existed without him, and this game fucking rocks.

If you’re into deck-building rogue-lites, this is going to scratch all your itches. 

Monster Train, a game with a really terrible name, but some of the best gameplay mechanics in the deck-building genre. A unique gameplay loop that feels immediately like a combination of Slay the Spire and Darkest Dungeon, coupled with so much polish I can see my face in it makes for pretty good time. The most unique thing Monster Train brings to the table is certainly its floor-to-floor card synergies. Messing with the way units play together to create angle-ass-blasting combos is the most fun I’ve had with a deck-builder in a while. Unique upgrades and artifact interactions allow for a lot more varied loop than something like Slay the Spire, which can start to feel stale due to the lack of variance in effective-deck building. Monster Train seems like it has a LOT to give in the replayability department, three hours in and I have barely scratched the surface of card unlocks and have only played with 3 of the clans. 

All in all, I think Monster Train is very good and has a ton of depth and flavor to it. Heavily inspired by the genre-king Slay the Spire, but with a few key mechanics that make it addictive and unique. I seriously hope this game gets the same amount of love Spire got, because it’s got a lot of gas in the tank.

title: Monster Train
review:
Awesome game and soon to be staple in the deck builder rougelite titles. What this game does that others haven't is put an emphasis on community. There are so many multiplayer options, whether it's just racing, leader-boarders, playing with friends on custom mods, there's plenty to do. On top of the single player experience which will have you playing for hours to unlock new cards, better strategy, etc etc. You know how this stuff works. The gameplay loop is fun, strategic, challenging, and there's plenty to progress through. Even though I have a list of cons, I absolutely recommend this game if you enjoyed STS.

Cons (So far):
-Art style isn't for everyone and there's no visible progression of making a card stronger
-You're on a train. Not really sure what the lore is there but not really a griping or immersive setting.
-The background is also very bland, the colors aren't the best.
-Animations also aren't very exciting, all very simple attack animations NOTHING exciting about how the characters move or attack.
-Lack of varying enemy type. The enemy's all look the same to me, I only pay attention to their stats.
-Not many bosses. I've done 4-5 completed runs and have seen every boss.

You know a game is good if people actually take the time to point out things that could be better while excited to play another round.

title: Monster Train
review: Amazing game

title: Monster Train
review:
There are very few good attempts to mash Slay the Spire style roguelike/deck-building with other genres.  This is one that succeeds and brings a few interesting additions along with it.  Mixing deck-building with multi-tiered tower defense doesn't actually sound like that good of an idea but it's executed well enough in it's own lane that you can't help having fun and keeping your eyes glued to your screen as "just one more run" stretches into your entire day.  Is it as deep and satisfying as StS?  Maybe not in the same way but there's enough nuance here to spend the time learning the different deck combinations and practicing different card combos.

Personally, I find the idea of multiplayer intriguing and it's execution is actually really well done... I hope people tend to keep at it and the developers implement leaderboards/ranking to make it feel more weighty.  Also, as an aside to newer players, the starting classes (most notably Hell Horned) are a bit on the dull side.  While it does take some time to unlock all the classes, stick with it as the first few hours got a bit boring before I pushed through and found the more exciting parts of the game.
