title: Monster Train
review: An excellent deck building card game that takes elements from many different sources to combine into one amazingly varied experience. If you love Slay The Spire, you'll love this. If you love(d) Hearthstone, you'll love this. If you love Artifact, you'll love this. This game is truly amazing in terms of just how much content you can get out of what really doesn't appear to be that much. There doesnt appear to be any ludicrous number of cards for each group, but since every run you pick one main and one ally there are so many combinations that it doesn't get old at all. That isn't even to mention all the different mechanics that each group uses. One is an extremely defensive healer, one is a balls to the wall warrior, one is a strange sort of shaman, one literally eats tiny units to gain new powers, its crazy how varied this game is. As much as Slay The Spire is truly one of my favorite games of all time and is polished to an incredible shine, this game blows it out of the water in terms of content (and thus variety).

title: Monster Train
review: I don't know what happened, I watched an egg do witty commentary with humorous anecdotes and now I'm here.

title: Monster Train
review:
Played the open beta, demo, and now the full release, and I'm really enjoying it.  I've got 500+ hours in Slay the Spire, and I've played a ton of the other rogue-like, deck-builders on Stream and this is the first one that's scratched the same itch that Slay the Spire has, while also doing something new.

The art is lovely, the music is exceptional, the online features are complete and interesting, the friend integration is brilliant(seriously, this should be the gold standard for what online integration on a single player game looks like), and the price is great.  Unlike most US$20 games on Steam, I don't feel like any corner has been cut, this is as polished a release game as I've ever seen.

TLDR: I would consider it a favor if you give Shiny Shoe your money.  This increase the chances we get more clans, more relics, mods, whatever, and I want all that.

title: Monster Train
review: Monster Train is like Magic: The Gathering and Slay The Spire, but also better in some ways. The devs are really friendly, and the Discord chat is super active. Definitely worth buying if you liked Slay The Spire, especially as they give a 10% discount if you already own STS. Extremely worth the 20 dollars I paid on launch week, still worth the 25 you might have to pay.

title: Monster Train
review:
It's as least as good as slay the spire, better if you like a bit more forward planning with the multiple floor setup and combinations from two different clans worth of cards.  If you like deckbuilding strategy games then you should try this.  

Each combination of clans (there are 5, you pick 2 to start) plays quite differently from each other, some synergize well, some don't but you can usually eke out some unusual strategy if you try hard enough.  On top of that there's a goodly collection of artifacts, clanless cards and other bits and pieces to give a massive amount of combinatorial variety.  Everything is pretty well balanced, with space to find things that seem (but aren't) completely brokenly powerful, which is always fun.  Then, often, you run into the one thing that counters that, which has never been a problem before but now is what's stopping you from just rolling over the whole game, and you see if you can adjust your strategy to cope with it.  Overall it's a game full of small but meaningful decisions adding up to an overall effect on how successful you are, and everything looks nice, sounds fine, and plays smoothly.  You can also stop and save at almost any time (I believe you only lose anything already done on the turn you exit), which is nice.

title: Monster Train
review: Okay - so I almost didn't download the demo because of the name; "Monster Train"?  Sounds kind of lame.  Well, I couldn't have been more wrong!  This game rocks.  Within about 15 minutes of playing the demo I knew this would be a day-one purchase for me.  I love it so much I called my brother and told him to download the demo.  He too wasn't sure about a game called "Monster Train" but decided to give it a chance.  He ALSO was a day one buy!  This game scratches all of the right itches for me.  It's a deck builder (which I love) but also feels sort of like a tower defense game?  It's very unique.  When I played the demo, there were only 2 races you could play as; now there are more that you can unlock.  Given how many different cards you can unlock for each race, this game seems to have endless replayability.  I can't stop playing it!  If you like it even half as much as I do then you'll be in good shape!

title: Monster Train
review:
Its Artifact
If Artifact was Slay the Spire
and if Artifact was a good game. 

You have 3 train carts stacking upwards, that you must fill with your own minions to defeat the onslaught of enemies. there are 5?(not sure if any hidden) classes, you always play as 2, one as your main which chooses your champion, and one as support which lets you get cards and power ups from that class, as well as the choice of minions from the support too. 

Initially the game feels great, but not super hard, but i feel the real normal game is the first "ascension" or as they call it covenant (similar to slay the spires ascension mode, but goes up to 25 instead of 20).  It makes enemies much more difficult and allows for less greedy builds at the start but still allows you to get great combos. 

Ive played 4 of the 5 classes. 3 of them seem really great, they synergize with each other. The odd one out feels pretty far out. the class im talking about is the 3rd unlock/magic water class (forgot the name). it may be similar to slay where its hard to make a good deck until you learn all the cards and what fits where but its a struggle to get through the early game with them as support or main, since they really only seem to synergize with themselves. 

Overall so far the game is really great, a bit more relaxing then slay the spire i feel. 9/10 for anyone that enjoys roguelite card games, for sure one of the best ones to come out in recent memory.

title: Monster Train
review:
Its Slay the Spire meets tower defence type game, absolutely loving it so far. Combat is good, you can break the game which is fun, but you can also think you've broken the game only to get absolutely pummeled at the end.

There are interesting systems that sets it apart from other deck builders, the use of 2 decks at once is interesting and leads to some crazy synergies. Think if you could get Silent cards as the Ironclad and just laugh at your 999 defence only to face an enemy that deals direct health damage instead of shield damage.

If you need some better insight on the game, I'd suggest watching Northerlions YouTube, the egg is hilariously bad which makes you want to get the game just to do better. But in his defence, he is showing youtube every single mistake he makes, whereas we can just forget it and move on.

review: Monster Train is the concentrated essence of what makes deckbuilders fun. title: Monster Train
review:
The game has high production values the art style and music is really good. In the surface its similar to Slay the Spire so If you played it a lot you will love it, but its quite deeper.

- Each run you build a deck chosing between 2 different kind of card families (there are several decks unlockables ingame)
- You have a Hero unit in each battle that you can level up choosing from a pool of skills
- Before each level you get a nice introduction about the enemies you will face
- Each level is a battle against a boss and has 3 fights at the same time
- After a level you can choose between two paths each one with several merchants an upgrades to apply after the level
- Units and Spells can be level up with modifiers from merchants

title: Monster Train
review:
Really well-done roguelite with heavy Slay the Spire influences. The tactical component of 3 'lanes' is a very flavorful twist to the formula and adds many new interesting mechanics with it. A lot of run variety and starting classes, with better visuals and smooth interface make this game an easy candidate for strategy deckbuilder of the year just 4 hours in. I can't wait to see the harder modes and explore all the different combinations and builds that I can make. 

A really good pick for people looking for a refreshing new experience to the deckbuilder genre, and a must-play for fans of Slay the Spire.

The mixture of units and spells, the customizability, the differences between the clans, and the over all great polish the game has all come together in a truly excellent package. This is the first game I have bought day one in a long time and I have not been dissapointed. The runs are long enough to feel good without feeling grindy. title: Monster Train
review:
This sure as [i]hell[/i] came out of nowhere. I learnt about this game only a week before its release, so it was all the more pleasant to discover just how outstanding it came to be. Everything about Monster Train oozes quality - the captivating music (that made me rewatch the Credits section several times just to hear the theme song again), the neat graphics (stylized and complete with tidy animations), but most of all, the content. Boy, have I not expected this unspeakably massive amount of content. For those of you who enjoy unlocking things, between the new minion clans, rare cards, artifacts, golden variants of the same, and 25 extra difficulty levels, Monster Train will keep you busy for a good while.

Now, it's impossible to talk about this game and avoid comparisons with Slay the Spire, but here, again, Monster Train holds its own splendidly. The game lets you scale and customize your deck fast - and when I say fast, I mean it. The increase in power levels comes at an uncanny pace, so that you can choose the direction of deck development and stick with it right from the get-go. The combat itself provides a commendable amount of strategic value by letting you tinker with both horizontal and vertical unit placement and choosing from a delightfully diverse pool of ingenious effects attached to all but the most basic cards.

Monster Train is a fully complete, polished, and feature-rich deckbuilder that lives up to the highest expectations. A firm recommendation from me, and one of the best games I've had the pleasure of playing this year.

title: Monster Train
review:
I have over 500 hours in Slay the Spire, and I was very intrigued with how this game looked, as it was reminiscent of that, but after being a Roguelike deck-builder the similarities from Slay the Spire end in a good way. Because StS is probably the most popular rogue-like deck-builder, I'll compare my experience so far with that of StS.

The multi-floor combat system and defense of the pyre gives this game another layer to the battle system that makes the combat deeper than StS and requiring more strategy and less 'broken-card combo that sweeps everything'. Being able to fight with multiple different units that can be upgraded and spells that can also be upgraded is vastly different than StS's 'each card has one singular upgrade' gameplay. 

Everything in this game revolves around combinations. From your clan, unit upgrades, spell upgrades, etc., the game lets you mix and match different upgrades or unit combinations that allow for vastly different gameplay options every playthrough. This is something missing from StS (aside from buying Prismatic Shard from the shop, but even that is ).

Overall, this game looks similar to Slay the Spire, but plays vastly different. I played for nearly 4 hours in my first sitting and beat the game with 2 different combinations of clans and I enjoyed every bit of it. You can tell this game took inspiration from it, but went a different route than StS did with the combat system and expanded on the areas that Monster Train would see to capitalize most. I have nothing but high praise for this game thus far and can highly recommend it.

title: Monster Train
review:
Simply phenomenal!

A hybrid of the gameplay you know from games like Darkest Dungeon combined with card mechanics á la Slay the Spire. 
Gameplay evolves around finding the right combos with your hero-card and 2 of 6 factions, each with a unique playstyle.
While the first trip with your train will definetly end before you reach the goal, you will get into the mechanics and find your own unique playstyle to get around bosses.

Pros:
+ Hybrid of a Trading Card Game (inspired by Slay the Spire) and Dungeon Rougelike (inspired by Darkest Dungeon)
+ Huge replayability -> a ton of new cards, artifacts and playstyles to unlock while playing 
+ Very nice Artwork
+ Seems very balanced as difficulty increases.

Neutral:
> Speed in game can be increased to skip animations if they get too much (and they definetly will :D)

Negative:
- No possibility to save while in a fight. Your game will save automatically before a fight. As fights can take up to 15 mins, it seems bad not to have a "Quicksave" option.


Summary:

All in all, this is a game, that feels very polished and complete. The mix of two genre types seems very smooth. You will forget time, as this game gives you this permanent "just one more game"-feeling. I found myself directly playing it for 3 hours in a row :D Thanks Shiny Shoe for this masterpiece!
